original: “Tattha katame soḷasa hārā desanā”tyādinā hārasarūpaṃ vuttaṃ, kimatthaṃ “tassānugīti”tyādi
analyzed: tattha katame soḷasa hārāḥ desanā tyādinā hāra sarūpam vuttam kimattham
translated: “Herein, what are the sixteen kinds of phrasing of teaching? ” and so on is said in the form of the phrasing of teaching. Why is it said again beginning with “Its singing” ?

original: vuttanti? Anugītigāthāya sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ puna “tassānugīti desanā vicayo yutti”tyādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha tassāti hāruddesassa. Anugītīti anu pacchā gāyanagāthā. Pañcadasoti
analyzed: vuttam ti anugīti gāthāya sukha ggahaṇa attham puna desanā vicayaḥ yutti tyādi  vuttam tattha tassa ati hāra uddesassa anugīti iti anu pacchā gāyana gāthā pañcadasā iti
translated: It is said again beginning with “Its singing” and so on for the purpose of easy grasping of the verse of singing.

original: pañcadasamo. Soḷasoti soḷasamo. Atthato asaṃkiṇṇāti desanādipadatthato lakkhaṇatthato
analyzed: pañcadasamaḥ soḷasoti soḷasamaḥ atthataḥ asaṃkiṇṇā ati desanā ādi pada tthataḥ lakkhaṇa tthato
translated: Herein, its means of the phrasing of teaching. Singing is a verse that is sung afterwards. Fifteenth means the fifteenth. Sixteenth means the sixteenth. In meaning it is unmixed means that in the meaning of the terms teaching and so on and in the meaning of the characteristics it is devoid of confusion.

original: saṅkarato rahitā. Tena vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “so ca nesaṃ asaṅkaro lakkhaṇaniddese🔽supākaṭo hotī”ti. Sesaṃ saṃvaṇṇanānusārena ñātabbanti. “Keci hārā kehici hārehi saṃkiṇṇā
analyzed: saṅkarataḥ rahitā tena vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam so ca na isam asaṅkaraḥ lakkhaṇa niddese  su pākaṭaḥ hoti iti sesam saṃvaṇṇanā anusārena ñātabbanti keci hārā kehici hārehi saṃkiṇṇā
translated: Hence it is said in the commentary, “And their unmixedness is quite clear in the description of the characteristics” . The rest can be known by the method of exposition.

original: viya dissanti, kasmā asaṃkiṇṇāti ñātabba”nti vattabbattā vuttaṃ “etesañcevā”tiādi.
analyzed: viya dissanti kasmā a saṃkiṇṇā iti ñātabbam nti vattabbattā vuttam etesam ca eva atiādi
translated: Some phrasing of teaching seems to be mixed up with some phrasing of teaching. Why should it be known as unmixed? Because of the words “Some phrasing of teaching seems to be mixed up with some phrasing of teaching. Why should it be known as unmixed? ” it is said “And these too” and so on.

original: Tattha etesañceva bhavatīti etesaṃ soḷasannaṃ hārānaṃ yathā yenākārena asaṅkaro hoti,
analyzed: tattha etesam ca iva bhavati iti etesam yathā yena ākārena asaṅkaraḥ
translated: Herein, and these too is the unmixedness of these sixteen kinds of phrasing of teaching in the way in which it occurs.

original: tathā asaṅkarākārena bhavati. Ayati pavattati nayavibhattīti ayā, vitthārena ayāti
analyzed: tathā asaṅkara ākārena bhavati vitthārena
translated: It is a “mode of expression” because it is expressed in the way beginning “It occurs” .🔽“In detail” means in detail.🔽The letter ta is included in order to remove the fault of confusion.

original: vitthāratayā, ta-kāro missakadosāpagamatthāya āgato, nayavibhattivisesavacanaṃ. Nayena
analyzed: vitthāra tayā takāraḥ missaka dosa apagama atthāya āgataḥ naya vibhatti visesa vacanam nayena
translated: The “mode of expression” is a mode of expression by way of the method.

original: ñāyena vibhatti nayavibhatti, na pañcanayavibhattāhārānaṃ vitthārena pavattā ñāyavibhatti
analyzed: ñāyena vibhatti naya vibhatti na vitthārena pavattā ñāya vibhatti
translated: It is not a mode of expression by way of the method of the five modes of expression, which is expressed in detail.

original: tathā asaṅkarākārena bhavati tasmiṃ asaṃkiṇṇāti ñātabbāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tathā asaṅkara ākārena bhavati tasmin asaṃkiṇṇā ati ñātabbā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: It is in the unmixed way in that, and that should be known thus, is the purport.🔽The sixteen modes of expression have been stated in their individual forms and have been understood by us.

original: 2. Soḷasa hārā sarūpato vuttā, amhehi ca viññātā, “katame pañca nayā”ti vattabbabhāvato
analyzed: soḷasa hārā sarūpataḥ vuttā amhehi ca viññātā katame pañca nayā ti vattabba bhāvato
translated: Now, since it is necessary to state “What are the five methods? “ ,

original: tathā pucchitvā sarūpato uddisituṃ “tattha katame pañca nayā”tyādi vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: tathā pucchitvā sarūpataḥ uddisitum tattha katame pañca naya atyādi vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: having asked thus, in order to point out in their individual forms, “Herein, what are the five methods? “ and so on is said.🔽But in the commentary

original: pana “evaṃ hāre uddisitvā idāni naye uddisituṃ ‘tattha katame’tiādi vutta”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana evam hāre uddisitvā idāni naye uddisitum tattha katama itiādi vuttanti vuttam
translated: it is said: “Having thus pointed out the modes of expression, now in order to point out the methods, ‘Herein, what are the five methods? ‘ and so on is said.”🔽“Herein, they lead , and they cause to be known in the mixed and unmixed way, thus they are methods .

original: “Tattha nayanti saṃkilese, vodāne ca vibhāgato ñāpentīti nayā, nīyanti vā tāni ettha,
analyzed: tattha nayanti saṃkilese vodāne ca vibhāgataḥ ñāpenti iti nayāḥ nīyanti vā tāni ettha
translated: Or, they are led here,

original: etehi vāti nayā”tiādinā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vitthārena vacanattho vutto. Nī-dhātuyā nandiyāvaṭṭādinayānusārena
analyzed: etehi vā ti naya ati ādinā aṭṭhakathā ayam vitthārena vacana atthaḥ vuttaḥ nī dhātuyā nandiyāvaṭṭa ādi naya anusārena
translated: The meaning of the words is given in detail in the Commentary beginning with the words, “By these methods.”

original: saṃkilese, vodāne ca ālambitvā pavatto ñāṇasampayuttacittuppādo mukhyattho, nandiyāvaṭṭādinayānaṃ🔽upanissayapaccayasatti phalūpacārato gahitā, iti-saddo taṃ phalūpacārato gahitasattiṃ
analyzed: saṃkilese vodāne ca ālambitvā pavattaḥ ñāṇa sampayutta cittuppādaḥ mukhya tthaḥ  upanissaya paccaya satti phala upacārataḥ gahitā iti saddaḥ tam phala upacārataḥ gahita sattim
translated: The primary meaning is the arising of consciousness associated with knowledge, which occurs in dependence on defilement and on purification, in accordance with the method of the “round of craving” and so on.🔽The secondary meaning is the power of the condition, which is included in the method of the “round of craving” and so on, by way of the proximity of the fruit.

original: parāmasi, taṃsattisahitā nandiyāvaṭṭādinayā a-paccayatthā.🔽Taṇhāavijjāhi saṃkilesapakkhassa suttassa, samathavipassanāhi vodānapakkhassa suttassa
analyzed: taṃsatti sahitāḥ a paccaya tthāḥ  taṇhā avijjāhi saṃkilesa pakkhassa suttassa samatha vipassanāhi vodāna pakkhassa suttassa
translated: The word “iti” (thus) refers to the power of the condition, which is included by way of the proximity of the fruit.🔽The method of the “round of craving” and so on, together with the power of the condition, is not the meaning of the condition.

original: catusaccayojanamukhena nayanalakkhaṇo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso nandiyāvaṭṭo nayo. Tattha🔽catusaccanti taṇhā ca avijjā ca bhavamūlattā samudayasaccaṃ, avasesā tebhūmakā dhammā
analyzed: catur acca yojana mukhena nayana lakkhaṇaḥ saṃvaṇṇanā viseso nandiyāvaṭṭaḥ nayo tattha  taṇhā ca avijjā ca bhava mūla ttā samudaya saccam avasesā tebhūmakāḥ dhammā
translated: The method of the “round of craving” is the special kind of commentary, which has the characteristic of a method, by way of the four truths, of the sutta of the side of defilement, with craving and ignorance, and of the sutta of the side of purification, with serenity and insight.🔽Herein, the four truths are as follows: Craving and ignorance are the truth of the origin because they are the root of existence. The remaining states of the three planes are the truth of suffering.

original: dukkhasaccaṃ, samathavipassanā maggasaccaṃ, tena pattabbā asaṅkhatadhātu nirodhasaccanti.
analyzed: dukkha saccam samatha vipassanā magga saccam tena pattabbā asaṅkhata dhātu nirodha saccanti
translated: Serenity and insight are the truth of the path. The unformed element, which is to be attained by means of that, is the truth of cessation.

original: Tīhi avayavehi lobhādīhi saṃkilesapakkhe, tīhi avayavehi alobhādīhi ca vodānapakkhe
analyzed: tīhi avayavehi lobha ādīhi saṃkilesa pakkhe tīhi avayavehi alobha ādīhi ca vodāna pakkhe
translated: The three terms “defilement” , “purity” , and “both” are respectively the three terms “greed” , etc., on the side of defilement, and the three terms “non-greed” , etc., on the side of purity.

original: pukkhalo sobhanoti tipukkhalo, akusalamūlehi saṃkilesapakkhassa, kusalamūlehi vodānapakkhassa
analyzed: pukkhalo sobhano ti ti pukkhalo akusala mūlehi saṃkilesa pakkhassa kusala mūlehi vodāna pakkhassa
translated: The three terms “defilement” , “purity” , and “both” are respectively the three terms “root of unprofit” , “root of profit” , and “both” .

original: suttatthassa catusaccayojanamukhena nayanalakkhaṇo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso tipukkhalo.🔽Sīhassa bhagavato vikkīḷitaṃ ettha nayeti sīhavikkīḷito, subhasaññādīhi vipallāsehi
analyzed: sīhassa bhagavataḥ vikkīḷitam ettha naya iti sīha vikkīḷitaḥ subha saññā ādīhi vipallāsehi
translated: The Tipukkhalanaya is a special method of exposition characterized by the method of expounding the meaning of the texts by means of the four noble truths.🔽The Sivivikkiḷitanaya is a special method of exposition characterized by the method of expounding the meaning of the texts by means of the four noble truths.

original: sakalasaṃkilesapakkhassa, saddhindriyādīhi vodānapakkhassa suttatthassa catusaccayojanamukhena🔽nayanalakkhaṇo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso sīhavikkīḷitanayo.🔽Atthanayattayadisābhāvena kusalādidhammānaṃ ālocanaṃ disālocanaṃ. Tassa tassa atthanayassa
analyzed: sakala saṃkilesa pakkhassa saddhi indriya ādīhi vodāna pakkhassa suttatthassa catu accayojana mukhena  nayana lakkhaṇaḥ saṃvaṇṇanā viseso sīha vikkīḷi tanayo  attha naya ttaya disa abhāvena kusala ādi dhammānam ālocanam disa ālocanam tassa tassa attha nayassa
translated: The Disalocananaya is the discerning of profitable and unprofitable states by way of the three methods of exposition and the four directions.🔽The Disalocananaya is the discerning of profitable and unprofitable states by way of the three methods of exposition and the four directions.

original: yojanatthaṃ katesu suttassa atthavissajjanesu ye vodānādayo, saṃkilesikā ca tassa
analyzed: yojana attham katesu suttassa attha vissajjanesu ye vodāna ādayaḥ saṃkilesikā ca tassa
translated: The Disalocananaya is the discerning of profitable and unprofitable states by way of the three methods of exposition and the four directions.

original: tassa nayassa disābhūtā dhammā suttato niddhāretvā kathitā, tesaṃ yathāvuttadhammānaṃ🔽citteneva “ayaṃ paṭhamā disā, ayaṃ dutiyā disā”tiādinā ālocanaṃ disālocanaṃ.
analyzed: tassa nayassa disābhūtāḥ dhammāḥ suttataḥ niddhāretvā kathitā tesam yathāvutta dhammānam  cittena iva ayam paṭhamā disā ayam dutiyā disā ati ādinā ālocanam disa ālocanam
translated: The Threads are the things that are the directions for that method. They are extracted from the Suttas and are stated.🔽The “direction-seeing” is the seeing of those things stated as “This is the first direction, this is the second direction” and so on,

original: Tathā ālocitānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthanayattayayojane samānayanato aṅkuso viyāti aṅkuso, tassa tassa nayassa disābhūtānaṃ kusalādidhammānaṃ samānayanaṃ aṅkuso nayo.🔽Lañjetīti lañjako. Yo nayo suttatthaṃ lañjeti pakāseti, iti lañjanato pakāsanato
analyzed: tathā ālocitānam dhammānam attha naya ttaya yojane samānayanataḥ aṅkusaḥ viyāti aṅkusaḥ tassa tassa nayassa disā bhūtānam kusala ādi dhammānam samānayanam aṅkusaḥ nayaḥ  lañjeti iti lañjakaḥ yaḥ nayo sutta ttham lañjeti pakāseti iti lañjanato pakāsanato
translated: with the mind only. The “goad” is so called because it “goes” to the “ad” or three methods of construing the things stated as the directions.🔽“It marks” , thus it is a “mark” . The method that “marks” , that is, reveals, the meaning of the Thread,

original: so nayo lañjako nāma, nayo ca so lañjako cāti nayalañjako. Nayalañjako paṭhamo nandiyāvaṭṭo
analyzed: saḥ nayaḥ lañjakaḥ nāma nayo ca saḥ lañjako ca ati naya lañjakaḥ naya lañjakaḥ paṭhamaḥ nandiyāvaṭṭaḥ
translated: is called a “mark” because it marks, because it reveals. And that method is a mark, thus it is a “mark of method” .🔽The first “mark of method” is called the “first turn of the wheel” ,🔽the second “mark of method” is called the “three ponders” ,

original: nāma, nayalañjako dutiyo tipukkhalo nāma, nayalañjako tatiyo sīhavikkīḷito nāmāti yojetabbo.
analyzed: nāma naya lañjakaḥ dutiyaḥ tipukkhalaḥ nāma naya lañjakaḥ tatiyaḥ sīhavikkīḷitaḥ nāma ati yojetabbo
translated: the third “mark of method” is called the “lion’s play” .

original: Uggatānaṃ visesena uggatoti uttamo, taṃ uttamaṃ. Gatāti ñātā, matāti attho. “Matā”ti vā pāṭho. Sesamettha vuttanayānusārenapi saṃvaṇṇanānusārenapi jānitabbanti.
analyzed: uggatānam visesena uggataḥ iti uttamaḥ tam uttamam gatā ati ñātā matā ati atthaḥ matā ati vā pāṭhaḥ sesam ettha vutta naya anusārena api saṃvaṇṇanā anusārena api jānitabbanti
translated: and it is the best, the most excellent, because it is the most excellent of all that is disclosed, that is to say, of all the truths that are disclosed. It is known, understood, is the meaning. Or the reading is “mata” . The rest here should be understood by the method stated and by the method of commentarial exposition.

original: Yathāvuttanayavisesasaṃvaṇṇanāya ṭīkāyaṃ –
analyzed: yathā vutta naya visesa saṃvaṇṇanāya ṭīkāyam
translated: In the commentary, the exposition of the distinction in the method stated is as follows:

original: “Samūhādiṃ upādāya lokasaṅketasiddhā vohāramattatā sammutisabhāvo, pathavīphassādīnaṃ
analyzed: samūha ādim upādāya loka saṅketa siddhā vohāra matta tā sammuti sabhāvaḥ pathavī phassa ādīnam
translated: “The state of being a mere expression established by social convention, taking as its basis a collection, etc., is the conventional nature. The characteristic of hardness, etc., of earth-contact, etc.,

original: kakkhaḷaphusanādilakkhaṇaṃ paramatthasabhāvo. Ayañhettha saṅkhepo – yasmiṃ bhinne,
analyzed: kakkhaḷa phusana ādi lakkhaṇam paramattha sabhāvaḥ ayam ha ittha saṅkhepaḥ yasmin bhinne
translated: is the ultimate nature. The brief meaning here is this: When something is divided,

original: itarāpohe vā cittena kate na tathā buddhi, idaṃ sammutisaccaṃ yathā ghaṭe, sasambhārajale
analyzed: itara apohe vā cittena kate na tathā idam sammuti saccam yathā ghaṭe sa sambhāra jale
translated: or when it is mentally made other than what it is by the exclusion of what is other, and there is no such perception, that is conventional truth, like a pot, water with ripples,

original: ca, tabbipariyāyena paramatthasacca”nti –
analyzed: ca tad bipariyāyena paramattha saccanti
translated: etc. The opposite of that is ultimate truth” .

original: Vacane ghaṭakathalaāpajalakaddamādisaṅkhātaṃ samūhādiṃ upādāya lokassa pubbe ghaṭakathalaāpajalakaddamādisaṅketasiddhā
analyzed: vacane ghaṭaka thala āpa jala kaddama ādi saṅkhātam samūha ādim upādāya lokassa pubbe ghaṭaka thala āpa jala kaddama ādi saṅketa siddhā
translated: In the statement, taking as its basis a collection, etc., called “pot,” “slab,” “water,” “mud,” etc., the state of being a mere expression established by the prior social convention of the world as “pot,” “slab,” “water,” “mud,” etc.,

original: ghaṭakathalaāpajalakaddamādivohāramattatā sammutisabhāvo saṅketavasena avitathattā.
analyzed: ghaṭa ka thala āpa jala kaddama ādi vohāra matta tā sammuti sabhāvaḥ saṅketa vasena a vitatha ttā
translated: The state of conventional nature is the mere usage of such terms as “pot,” “slab,” “water,” “mud,” etc., which is not deceptive by way of convention.

original: Pathavīādīnaṃ kakkhaḷādilakkhaṇaṃ, phassādīnaṃ phusanādilakkhaṇaṃ paramatthasabhāvo.
analyzed: pathavī ādīnam kakkhaḷa ādi lakkhaṇam phassa ādīnam phusana ādi lakkhaṇam paramattha sabhāvaḥ
translated: The state of ultimate nature is the characteristic of hardness, etc., of earth, etc., and the characteristic of touching, etc., of contact, etc.

original: “Yadi evaṃ ghaṭādike abhinne vā āpādike vā anurūpena ūnabhāvena appavattamāne vā
analyzed: yadi evam ghaṭa ādike abhinne vā āpa ādike vā anurūpena ūna bhāvena appavattamāne vā
translated: “If that is so, then let the state of conventional nature be in a pot, etc., which are undifferentiated, or in water, etc., which are not occurring with a corresponding deficiency,

original: sati sammutibhāvo hotu, bhinne vā ūne vā kathaṃ sammutibhāvo bhaveyya, pathavīphassādīnampi🔽bhijjamānattā, kakkhaḷaphusanādīnañca pathavīphassādīhi anaññattā kathaṃ paramatthasabhāvo
analyzed: sati sammuti bhāvaḥ hotu bhinne vā ūne vā katham sammuti bhāvaḥ bhaveyya pathavī phassa ādīnam pi  bhijjamāna ttā kakkhaḷa phusana ādīnam ca pathavī phassa ādīhi anañña ttā katham paramattha sabhāvaḥ
translated: but how can the state of conventional nature be in what is differentiated or deficient? And how can the state of ultimate nature be in earth, contact, etc.,

original: bhaveyya, katamena saṅkhepena atthena sammutisabhāvo, paramatthasabhāvo ca amhehi🔽jānitabbo”ti vattabbabhāvato “ayañhettha saṅkhepo”tiādimāha. Tattha etthāti etesu
analyzed: bhaveyya katamena saṅkhepena atthena sammuti sabhāvaḥ paramattha sabhāvaḥ ca amhehi  jānitabbaḥ iti vattabba bhāvataḥ ayan ha ittha saṅkhepaḥ iti ādim āha tattha ettha ati etesu
translated: because they are breakable, and because hardness, touching, etc., are not different from earth, contact, etc.? In what way, then, should the state of conventional nature and the state of ultimate nature be understood by us🔽because it is proper to say this?” Therefore he said, “Herein, this is the brief explanation,” etc. Herein, ettha = etesu means in these states of conventional nature and ultimate nature.

original: sammutisabhāvaparamatthasabhāvesu ayaṃ nayo vuccamāno saṅkhepo attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: sammuti sabhāva paramattha sabhāvesu ayam nayaḥ vuccamānaḥ saṅkhepaḥ atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: This is the brief explanation that should be seen as the meaning.

original: Yasmiṃ ghaṭādike bhinne sati tato ghaṭādito itaro kathalādibhāvo cittena pubbe katena🔽yathā yena kathalādivohārena bhavati, yasmiṃ āpādike sambhārajalādike ūnabhāvena
analyzed: yasmin ghaṭa ādike bhinne sati tatas ghaṭa āditaḥ itaraḥ kathala ādi bhāvaḥ cittena pubbe katena  yathā yena bhavati yasmin āpa ādike sambhāra jala ādike ūna bhāvena
translated: When a pot, etc., is broken, the other state of the pieces, etc., is the same as that of the pot, etc., as previously cognized by the mind.

original: pavattamāne sati vā tato āpādito itaro kaddamādibhāvo cittena pubbe katena yathā🔽yena kaddamādivohārena bhavati, tathā tena vohārena buddhi kathalādisabhāvajānanaṃ🔽kaddamādisabhāvajānanaṃ bhavati, idaṃ abhinne ghaṭādikaṃ vā bhinne kathalādikaṃ vā
analyzed: pavattamāne sati vā tatas āpāditaḥ itaraḥ kaddama ādi bhāvaḥ cittena pubbe katena yathā  yena kaddama ādi vohārena bhavati tathā tena vohārena buddhi kathala ādi sabhāva jānanam  kaddama ādi sabhāva jānanam bhavati idam abhinne ghaṭa ādikam vā bhinne kathala ādikam vā
translated: When the water in a reservoir, etc., is insufficient, the other state of the mud, etc., is the same as that of the water, etc., as previously cognized by the mind.🔽Thus the cognition of the state of the pieces, etc., as that of the pot, etc., and the cognition of the state of the mud, etc., as that of the water, etc., are due to the conventional terms “pieces, etc.,” and “mud, etc.”

original: anūne āpādikaṃ vā ūne kaddamādikaṃ vā sabbaṃ sammutisaccaṃ hotveva. “Kaddamasmiṃ🔽bhinne, kaddamasmiṃ ūne vā sati itaro sammutisabhāvo”ti pucchitabbabhāvato “ghaṭe,
analyzed: anūne āpa ādikam vā ūne kaddama ādikam vā sabbam sammuti saccam hotvā iva kaddamasmiṃ  bhinne kaddamasmin ūne vā sati itaro sammuti sabhāvaḥ ti pucchitabba bhāvataḥ ghaṭe
translated: All this, whether the pot, etc., is unbroken or the pieces, etc., are broken, or whether the water in the reservoir, etc., is insufficient or the mud, etc., is insufficient, is conventional truth.

original: sambhārajale cā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sambhāra jale ca ati vuttam
translated: When the mud is broken or insufficient, the other conventional state is to be asked about, and so “pot” and “water in the reservoir” are mentioned.

original: Sammutisaccasabhāvo tumhehi vutto, amhehi ca ñāto, “katamo paramatthasaccasabhāvo”ti
analyzed: sammuti sacca sabhāvaḥ tumhehi vuttaḥ amhehi ca ñāto katamo paramattha sacca sabhāvaḥ ti
translated: The conventional truth state has been stated by you and is known by us. “What is the ultimate truth state?”

original: vattabbabhāvato “tabbipariyāyena paramatthasacca”nti vuttaṃ. Pathavīādīnaṃ kakkhaḷādilakkhaṇato
analyzed: vattabba bhāvataḥ tad vipariyāyena paramattha saccan ti vuttam pathavī ādīnam kakkhaḷa ādi lakkhaṇato
translated: Because the characteristic of hardness, etc., of earth, etc.,🔽is impossible in the other, which has the characteristic of being molested, etc.,

original: itarassa phusanādilakkhaṇassa asambhavato, phassādīnañca phusanādilakkhaṇato itarassa
analyzed: itarassa phusana ādi lakkhaṇassa asambhavataḥ phassa ādīnam ca phusana ādi lakkhaṇataḥ itarassa
translated: and because the characteristic of being molested, etc., of contact, etc., is impossible in the other, which has the characteristic of hardness, etc.,

original: kakkhaḷādilakkhaṇassa asambhavato pathavīphassādīnaṃ lakkhaḷaphusanādilakkhaṇaṃ paramatthasaccaṃ
analyzed: kakkhaḷa ādi lakkhaṇassa asambhavataḥ pathavī phassa ādīnam lakkhaḷa phusana ādi lakkhaṇam paramattha saccam
translated: the characteristic of hardness and the characteristic of being molested are ultimate realities in the case of earth-contact, etc.

original: hotvevāti imasmiṃ saṅkhepatthe gahite koci virodho natthīti adhippāyoti.🔽3. Pañca nayā sarūpato ācariyena uddiṭṭhā, amhehi ca viññātā, “yāni padāni aṭṭhārasa🔽mūlapadāni uddiṭṭhāni, katamāni tānī”ti pucchitabbattā tāni sarūpato dassetuṃ “tattha🔽katamāni aṭṭhārasa mūlapadāni”tyādimāha. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “evaṃ nayepi uddisitvā
analyzed: hotvā iva ati imasmin saṅkhepa atthe gahite koci virodhaḥ natthi iti adhippāyaḥ ti  pañca nayā sarūpataḥ ācariyena uddiṭṭhā amhehi ca viññātā yāni padāni aṭṭhārasa  mūlapadāni uddiṭṭhāni katamāni tāni iti pucchitabba ttā tāni sarūpataḥ dassetum tattha  katamāni aṭṭhārasa mūlapadāni ityādim āha aṭṭhakathā ayam pana evam naye pi uddisitvā
translated: When this brief meaning is grasped, there is no contradiction at all. This is the purport.🔽The five methods have been stated by the teacher in the original text and have been understood by us. Now, since it is necessary to ask, “What are the eighteen root-terms that have been stated?” in order to show them in the original text, he says, “Herein, what are the eighteen root-terms?”

original: idāni mūlapadāni uddisituṃ ‘tattha katamānī’tiādi āraddha”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha kusalāni
analyzed: idāni mūlapadāni uddisitum tattha katamāni itiādi āraddhanti vuttam tattha kusalāni
translated: But in the commentary it is said: “Having thus stated the method, he now begins the statement of the root-terms with the words ‘Herein, what are the eighteen root-terms?’”🔽Herein, the profitable,

original: nava padāni, akusalāni nava padāni aṭṭhārasa mūlapadānīti daṭṭhabbānīti yojanā. Mūlanti🔽patiṭṭhahanti etehi nayā, patiṭṭhānavibhāgā cāti mūlāni, padanti patiṭṭhahanti ettha
analyzed: nava padāni akusalāni nava padāni aṭṭhārasa mūlapadāni iti daṭṭhabbāni iti yojanā mūlam ti  patiṭṭhahanti etehi nayā patiṭṭhāna vibhāgā ca ati mūlāni padanti patiṭṭhahanti ettha
translated: The construction is this: the nine unprofitable terms and the nine unprofitable roots should be regarded as the eighteen terms and roots. Roots:🔽because the ways of entry find support in them, and because they are the analysis of the support, they are roots. Terms:

original: nayā, paṭṭhānavibhāgā, adhigamā cāti padāni, vuttappakāraṭṭhena mūlāni ca tāni padāni
analyzed: nayāḥ paṭṭhāna vibhāgāḥ adhigamāḥ ca ati padāni vutta pakāra ṭṭhena mūlāni ca tāni padāni
translated: because the ways of entry find support in them, and because they are the analysis of the support, and because they are the attainments, they are terms. They are roots in the sense already stated and they are terms, thus they are terms and roots. They are profitable because they burn up evil qualities in the heart’s core;🔽or they are profitable because they cut off lust, etc., as a ploughshare cuts up the soil;

original: cāti mūlapadāni. Kucchite pāpadhamme salayantīti kusalāni, kuse rāgādayo lunantīti
analyzed: mūla padāni kucchite pāpa dhamme kuse rāga ādayaḥ lunanti iti
translated: or they are profitable because they cut up as a plough cuts up the soil;

original: kusalāni, kusā viya lunantīti kusalāni, kusena ñāṇena lātabbāni pavattetabbānīti🔽kusalāni. Kusalānaṃ paṭipakkhānīti akusalāni a-saddo cettha paṭipakkhatthoti.
analyzed: kusalāni kusāḥ viya lunanti iti kusalāni kusena ñāṇena lātabbāni pavattetabbāni iti  kusalāni kusalānam paṭipakkhāni iti akusalāni a saddaḥ ca ittha paṭipakkha atthaḥ ti
translated: or they are profitable because they should be brought to presence by being ploughed with the plough of knowledge. They are unprofitable because they are the opposites of the profitable;🔽and here the prefix a- has the sense of opposite.

original: Nava padāni kusalāni, nava padāni akusalānīti gaṇanaparicchedato, jātibhedato ca
analyzed: nava padāni kusalāni nava padāni akusalāni iti gaṇana paricchedataḥ jāti bhedataḥ ca
translated: The nine profitable terms and the nine unprofitable terms are stated by way of enumeration and by way of class,

original: uddiṭṭhāni, “katamāni tānī”ti pucchitabbattā nava padāni akusalāni paccāsattinyāyena
analyzed: uddiṭṭhāni katamāni tāni iti pucchitabba ttā nava padāni akusalāni pacca āsatti nyāyena
translated: and they are stated by way of question and answer in the way beginning, “What are the nine unprofitable terms?”

original: sarūpato dassetuṃ “katamāni nava padāni akusalānī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana –
analyzed: sarūpataḥ dassetum katamāni nava padāni akusalāni itiādi vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam pana
translated: The words “What are the nine unprofitable terms?” are said in order to show them in their individual essences. But in the commentary it is said:

original: “Evaṃ gaṇanaparicchedato, jātibhedato ca mūlapadāni dassetvā idāni sarūpato dassento saṃkilesapakkhaṃyeva paṭhamaṃ uddisati ‘taṇhā’tiādinā”ti –
analyzed: evam gaṇana paricchedataḥ jāti bhedato ca mūlapadāni dassetvā idāni sarūpataḥ dassento saṃkilesa pakkham yā iva paṭhamam uddisati taṇhā ati ādinā iti
translated: “Having thus shown the root-terms by way of enumeration and by way of class, he now shows them by way of their individual essences. He does this by first announcing the terms of the defilement class with the words ‘Craving’ and so on” .

original: Vuttaṃ. Tattha rūpādike khandhe tasati paritasatīti taṇhā. Avindiyaṃ kāyaduccaritādiṃ🔽vindatīti avijjā, vindiyaṃ kāyasucaritādiṃ na vindatīti avijjā, vijjāya paṭipakkhāti
analyzed: vuttam tattha rūpa ādike khandhe tasati paritasati iti taṇhā avindiyam kāya duccarita ādim  vindati iti avijjā kāya su carita ādim na vindati iti avijjā vijjāya paṭipakkhāti
translated: Herein, it is craving because it craves, it is eager for, form and the other aggregates. It is ignorance because it does not find, it does not see, bodily good conduct, etc.,

original: vā avijjā. Lubbhanti tenāti lobho, lubbhatīti vā lobho, lubbhanaṃ vā lobho. Dosamohesupi🔽eseva nayo. Asubhe rūpakkhandhādike “subha”nti pavattā saññā subhasaññā. Dukkhadukkhādike
analyzed: vā avijjāḥ lubbhanti tena ati lobhaḥ lubbhati iti vā lobhaḥ lubbhanam vā lobhaḥ dosa mohesu pi  esa iva nayaḥ asubhe rūpa kkhandha ādike subhanti pavattā saññā subha saññā dukkha dukkha ādike
translated: or because it is the opposite of knowledge . It is greed because of greediness, or it is greed because it greeds, or it is greed because of the act of greediness. The same method applies in the case of hate and delusion.

original: “sukha”nti pavattā saññā sukhasaññā. Anicce saṅkhāradhamme “nicca”nti pavattā saññā
analyzed: sukhanti pavattā saññā sukha saññā anicce saṅkhāra dhamme niccanti pavattā saññā
translated: The perception that occurs regarding the form aggregate, etc., as beautiful is the perception of beauty. The perception that occurs regarding the painful, painful-to-experience states, etc., as pleasant is the perception of pleasure. The perception that occurs regarding impermanent formations as permanent is the perception of permanence.

original: niccasaññā. Anattasabhāvesu cakkhādīsu khandhesu “attā”ti pavattā saññā attasaññā.
analyzed: nicca saññā anatta sabhāvesu cakkha ādīsu khandhesu attā ati pavattā saññā attasaññā
translated: Perception of permanence. Perception of self occurs in regard to the eye, etc., which are by nature not self, perceiving them as self.

original: Yatthāti yesu padesu sabbo akusalapakkho saṅgahaṃ samosaraṇaṃ gacchati, tāni padāni
analyzed: yattha ati yesu padesu sabbaḥ akusala pakkhaḥ saṅgaham samosaraṇam gacchati tāni padāni
translated: In regard to which: in regard to which places the whole unprofitable side is included, gathered together, collected.

original: akusalānīti yojanā. Saṅgahaṃ gaṇanaṃ. Samosaraṇaṃ samāropanaṃ.🔽Paccanīkadhamme uddhaccādike nīvaraṇe sameti vūpasameti tadaṅgavikkhambhanavasenāti
analyzed: akusalāni iti yojanā saṅgaham gaṇanam samosaraṇam samāropanam  paccanīka dhamme uddhacca ādike nīvaraṇe sameti vūpasameti tad aṅga vikkhambhana vasena ati
translated: The unprofitable: the unprofitable is to be construed as the places. Included: gathered, collected.🔽It is calm: it is the same, it is quieted, by suppression of the hindrances such as agitation, etc., which are opposed to it.

original: samatho. Saṅkhāre aniccādīhi vividhehi ākārehi passatīti vipassanā. Lobhassa paṭipakkho
analyzed: samatho saṅkhāre anicca ādīhi vividhehi ākārehi passati iti vipassanā lobhassa paṭipakkho
translated: Tranquillity: insight is the seeing of formations in various ways as impermanent, etc.

original: alobho. Dosassa paṭipakkho adoso. Mohassa paṭipakkho amoho. Etthāpi a-saddo paṭipakkhattho,
analyzed: a lobhaḥ dosassa paṭipakkhaḥ a dosaḥ mohassa paṭipakkhaḥ a mohaḥ ettha api a saddaḥ paṭipakkha attho
translated: Non-greed: non-greed is the opposite of greed. Non-hate is the opposite of hate. Non-delusion is the opposite of delusion. The meaning of opposite is the meaning of a- in each case.

original: na abhāvatthādikoti adhippāyo. Asubhe rūpakkhandhādike, cakkhādimhi vā “asubha”nti
analyzed: na abhāva ttha ādiko ti adhippāyaḥ asubhe rūpa kkhandha ādike cakkha ādimhi vā asubham ti
translated: The intention is that it does not mean non-existence, etc. Perception of foulness: perception occurring in regard to the visible-form aggregate, etc., or in regard to the eye, etc., as “foul”

original: pavattā saññāpadhānacittuppādā asubhasaññā, visesato kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: pavattā saññā apadhāna cittuppādā asubha saññā visesataḥ kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam
translated: is perception of foulness, which is the meditation subject of mindfulness occupied with the body, especially.

original: Dukkhadukkhatādīsu “dukkha”nti pavattā saññāpadhānacittuppādā dukkhasaññā, visesato🔽vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ. Anicce khandhādike vipariṇāmadhamme “anicca”nti pavattā🔽saññāpadhānacittuppādā aniccasaññā, visesato cittānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ. Anattasabhāve
analyzed: dukkha dukkha tā ādīsu dukkhanti pavattā saññā apadhāna cittuppādā dukkha saññā visesato  vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam anicce khandha ādike vipariṇāma dhamme aniccanti pavattā  saññā apadhāna cittuppādāḥ anicca saññā visesataḥ citta anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam anatta sabhāve
translated: The perception and the consciousness with perception predominating that occur as “painful” in regard to the kinds of suffering beginning with pain as suffering are the perception of pain. Especially🔽the foundation of mindfulness consisting in the contemplation of feeling. The perception and the consciousness with perception predominating that occur as “impermanent” in regard to the aggregates, etc., which are subject to change are the perception of impermanence. Especially

original: khandhe, cakkhādimhi vā “anattā”ti pavattā saññāpadhānacittuppādā anattasaññā, visesato
analyzed: khandhe cakkha ādimhi vā anattā ati pavattā saññā padhāna cittuppādā anatta saññā visesato
translated: the foundation of mindfulness consisting in the contemplation of mind. The perception and the consciousness with perception predominating that occur as “not self” in regard to the aggregates, which are by nature not self, or in regard to the eye, etc., are the perception of not-self. Especially

original: dhammānupassanāsatipadhānaṃ. Paññāsatisīsena hi pavattā ayaṃ desanā. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā sati padhānam paññā sati sīsena hi pavattā ayam desanā tena vuttam
translated: the foundation of mindfulness consisting in the contemplation of mental objects. For this teaching occurs under the heading of the mindfulness of the four foundations of mindfulness. Hence it is said:

original: bhagavatā “kathañca, bhikkhave, satibalaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ? Catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu, ettha
analyzed: bhagavatā katham ca bhikkhave sati balam daṭṭhabbam catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu ettha
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, should the strength of mindfulness be seen? In the four foundations of mindfulness,🔽herein the strength of mindfulness should be seen” .

original: satibalaṃ daṭṭhabba”nti. Yatthāti yesu padesu sabbo kusalapakkho saṅgahaṃ samosaraṇaṃ
analyzed: sati balam daṭṭhabbanti yattha ati yesu padesu sabbaḥ kusala pakkhaḥ saṅgaham samosaraṇam
translated: Wherein: in which passages the whole of the profitable side is included, gathered together,

original: gacchati, tāni padāni kusalānīti yojanā.
analyzed: gacchati tāni padāni kusalāni iti yojanā
translated: these passages are profitable. The construction is this.

original: Uddānanti uddhaṃ dānaṃ rakkhaṇaṃ uddānaṃ, saṅgahavacananti attho. Uddāne avutte sati
analyzed: uddānam ti uddham dānam rakkhaṇam uddānam saṅgaha vacanan ti atthaḥ uddāne a vutte sati
translated: The summary is the giving, the guarding, the summary, the collection, the expression, the meaning. When the summary is not stated,

original: heṭṭhā vuttassa atthassa vippakiṇṇabhāvo dinno viya bhaveyya, tasmā vippakiṇṇabhāvassa
analyzed: heṭṭhā vuttassa atthassa vippakiṇṇa bhāvaḥ dinnaḥ viya bhaveyya tasmā vippakiṇṇa bhāvassa
translated: the meaning stated below is as if given in a scattered way. Therefore the intention is that the summary is for the purpose of preventing a scattered way.

original: nivāraṇatthaṃ uddānanti adhippāyo. Caturo ca vipallāsāti subhasukhaniccaattasaññā.
analyzed: nivāraṇa attham uddānanti adhippāyo caturo ca subha sukha nicca atta saññā
translated: And the four perversions are the perception of the beautiful, happiness, permanence, and self.

original: Kilesā bhavanti ettha navapadesūti bhūmī, kilesānaṃ bhūmīti kilesabhūmī, kilesapavattanaṭṭhānāni
analyzed: kilesāḥ bhavanti ettha nava padesu iti bhūmī kilesānam bhūmī iti kilesa bhūmī kilesa pavattana ṭṭhānāni
translated: The nine terms are the grounds for defilements. The grounds for defilements are the places of occurrence of defilements,

original: nava padānīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: nava padāni iti vuttam hoti
translated: the nine terms are what is meant.

original: Caturo satipaṭṭhānāti asubhadukkhaaniccaanattasaññā. Indriyabhūmīti saddhādīnaṃ vimuttiparipācanindriyānaṃ bhūmī pavattanaṭṭhānāni samosaraṇaṭṭhānāni.
analyzed: caturo sati paṭṭhānā ti asubha dukkha anicca anatta saññā indriya bhūmī iti saddhā ādīnam vimutti paripācanindriyānam bhūmī pavattana ṭṭhānāni samosaraṇa ṭṭhānāni
translated: The four foundations of mindfulness are the perceptions of foulness, pain, impermanence, and not-self. The grounds for the faculties are the grounds for the faculties that ripen in liberation, the places of occurrence, the meeting-places, of the faculties beginning with faith.

original: Navahi kusalapadehi kusalapakkhā yujjanti yojīyanti, navahi akusalapadehi akusalapakkhā
analyzed: navahi kusala padehi kusala pakkhāḥ yujjanti yojīyanti navahi akusala padehi akusala pakkhāḥ
translated: The side of profit is joined to, yoked with, the nine profitable terms. The side of loss is joined to, yoked with, the nine unprofitable terms.

original: yujjanti yojīyanti. Navahi kusalapadehi saha kusalapakkhā yujjanti yujjantā bhavanti,🔽navahi akusalapadehi saha akusalapakkhā yujjanti yujjantā bhavantīti uddesavāre vuttāvaseso
analyzed: yujjanti yojīyanti navahi kusala padehi saha kusala pakkhāḥ yujjanti yujjantāḥ bhavanti  navahi akusala padehi saha akusala pakkhāḥ yujjanti yujjantāḥ bhavanti iti uddesa vāre vutta avaseso
translated: They are yoked, they are joined, with the nine profitable terms the profitable section is yoked, is joined,

original: saṃvaṇṇanānusārena vijānitabbo.
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā anusārena vijānitabbaḥ
translated: with the nine unprofitable terms the unprofitable section is yoked, is joined. The remainder of the Thread’s Meaning is to be known by the method of the commentary.

original: Iti sattibalānurūpā racitā
analyzed: iti satti bala anurūpā racitā
translated: So this is composed in accordance with the strength of the needle.

original: Uddesavārassa atthavibhāvanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uddesa vārassa attha vibhāvanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Thread’s Meaning in the Description Section is ended.

original: 3. Niddesavāraatthavibhāvanā
translated: Exposition of the Thread’s Meaning in the Description Section

original: Soḷasahāraniddesavibhāvanā🔽4. Hārādīsu samudāyassa nettippakaraṇassa uddeso uddiṭṭho, amhehi ca ñāto, “katamo🔽niddeso”ti pucchitabbattā uddiṭṭhe hārādayo niddisituṃ “tattha saṅkhepato nettī”tiādi🔽āraddhaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “evaṃ uddiṭṭhe hārādayo niddisituṃ ‘tattha saṅkhepato’tiādi
analyzed: hāra ādīsu samudāyassa netti pakaraṇassa uddesaḥ uddiṭṭhaḥ amhehi ca ñātaḥ katamaḥ  niddeso ti pucchitabbattā uddiṭṭhe hāra ādayaḥ niddisitum tattha saṅkhepataḥ netti itiādi  āraddham aṭṭhakathā ayam pana evam uddiṭṭhe hāra ādayaḥ niddisitum tattha saṅkhepato tiādi
translated: Exposition of the Description of the Sixteen Modes🔽In the case of the Modes, etc., the Description of the Guide-Line has been stated in the Description Section, and we have understood it. Since it is a question of “What is the Description? “ , the Modes, etc., stated in the Description Section are described by the words “ Herein, in brief, the Guide-Line” , etc.

original: āraddha”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tasmiṃ “tattha katame soḷasa hārā? Desanā vicayo”tiādiuddesapāṭhe.
analyzed: āraddham ti vuttam tattha tattha ati tasmin tattha katame soḷasa hārāḥ desanā vicaya uti ādi uddesa pāṭhe
translated: But in the Commentary it is said “ When the Modes, etc., stated thus are described, the words ‘ Herein, in brief, the Guide-Line’ , etc., are begun “. Herein, there is the “ here “ in the Description Section’s wording “ Herein, what are the sixteen Modes? Teaching, Investigation” , etc.

original: Saṅkhepatoti samāsato. Nettīti nettippakaraṇaṃ. Kittitāti kathitā, idāni niddesato
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ ti samāsatas netti iti netti pakaraṇam kittitā ati kathitā idāni niddesato
translated: In brief: in brief. Netti: the Netti-pakaraṇa. Kitti: is called.

original: kathessāmīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: kathessāmi iti vuttam hoti
translated: In brief: in brief, in summary. The Guide: the Guide-book. Has been extolled: has been expounded. Now I shall expound it by analysis: this is what is meant.🔽“The pleasure, the danger, and the escape,

original: “Assādādīnavatā, nissaraṇampi ca phalaṃ upāyo ca.
analyzed: assāda ādīnava tā nissaraṇam pi ca phalam upāyaḥ ca
translated: The fruit, the means, and the Lord’s word,

original: Āṇattī ca bhagavato, yogīnaṃ desanāhāro”ti. –
analyzed: āṇattī ca bhagavataḥ
translated: Are the nutriment for the yogis’ teaching.”

original: Gāthāyaṃ yena saṃvaṇṇanāvisesena sutte āgatā assādopi ādīnavatā ādīnavopi nissaraṇampi
analyzed: gāthā ayam yena saṃvaṇṇanā visesena sutte āgatā assādaḥ api ādīnava tā ādīnavaḥ api nissaraṇam pi
translated: In this stanza the pleasure, the danger, the escape,

original: phalampi upāyopi yogīnaṃ atthāya bhagavato āṇattipi ime dhammā dassitā saṃvaṇṇitā
analyzed: phalam pi upāyaḥ api yogīnam atthāya bhagavataḥ āṇatti pi ime dhammā dassitā saṃvaṇṇitā
translated: the fruit, the means, and the Lord’s word, by which these things are shown, expounded,

original: saṃvaṇṇanāvasena ñāpitā, so saṃvaṇṇanāviseso desanāhāro nāmāti atthayojanā.
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā vasena ñāpitā saḥ saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ desanā āhāraḥ nāma ati attha yojanā
translated: and made known by the exposition, are called “the nutriment for the yogis’ teaching.”

original: Vacanatthādayo aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vitthārato vuttāva, tasmā kiñcimattameva kathessāmi.
analyzed: vacana ttha ādayaḥ aṭṭhakathā ayam vitthārataḥ tasmai kiñcimattam eva kathessāmi
translated: The meaning of the words, etc., are given in detail in the commentary, so I shall expound only a little of it.

original: Assādīyateti assādo, ko so? Sukhaṃ, somanassaṃ, iṭṭhārammaṇabhūtā pañcupādānakkhandhā
analyzed: assādīyateti assādo ko so sukham somanassam iṭṭha ārammaṇa bhūtā pañca upādāna khandhā
translated: It is savoured , thus it is pleasure . What is it? Happiness, joy, the five aggregates as objects of clinging that are a desirable object,

original: ca. Assādeti etāyāti vā assādo, ko so? Taṇhā, vipallāsā ca. Vipallāsavasena hi ekacce
analyzed: ca assāda iti vā assādaḥ vipallāsā ca vipallāsa vasena hi ekacce
translated: Or alternatively, it is relished by means of this, thus it is relishing . What is it? It is craving and the perversions. For some beings relish an unlovable object by means of the perversions,

original: sattā aniṭṭhampi ārammaṇaṃ iṭṭhākārena assādenti.
analyzed: sattāḥ aniṭṭham pi ārammaṇam iṭṭha ākārena assādenti
translated: as if it were lovable.

original: Ābhusaṃ kammena dīnaṃ dukkhādi hutvā vāti pavattatīti ādīnavo, dukkhādi. Atha vā
analyzed: ābhusam kammena dīnam dukkha ādi hutvā vāti pavattati iti ādīnavaḥ dukkha ādi atha vā
translated: It is danger because it occurs having become very mean and wretched, having become suffering, etc., thus it is danger . Or alternatively,

original: ativiya ādīnaṃ kapaṇaṃ hutvā vāti pavattatīti ādīnavo, kapaṇamanusso, tathābhāvā🔽ca tebhūmakā dhammā aniccatādiyogato.
analyzed: ativiya ādīnam kapaṇam hutvā vāti pavattati iti ādīnavaḥ kapaṇa manussaḥ tathābhāvā  ca tebhūmakāḥ dhammāḥ anicca tā ādi yogato
translated: it occurs having become very mean and wretched, thus it is danger , as in the case of a wretched man. And those states of the three planes are danger in the sense of impermanence, etc.,

original: Nissarati etenāti nissaraṇaṃ, ariyamaggo. Nissaratīti vā nissaraṇaṃ, nibbānaṃ. Pi-saddo sampiṇḍanattho. Nissaraṇabhedo aṭṭhakathāyaṃ bahudhā vuttova.
analyzed: nissarati etena ati nissaraṇam ariya maggaḥ nissarati iti vā nissaraṇam nibbānam pi saddaḥ sampiṇḍana atthaḥ nissaraṇa bhedaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam bahudhā vuttaḥ iva
translated: because they are so. It is escape because one escapes by means of this, thus it is escape . It is the noble path. Or alternatively, it is escape because it escapes, thus it is escape . It is Nibbāna. The word “or” has the meaning of an alternative. The kinds of escape have been given in the commentaries in many places.

original: Phalati pavattatīti phalaṃ, desanāya phalaṃ. Yadipi desanā phalanipphādikā na hoti,
analyzed: phalati pavattati iti phalam desanāya phalam yadi api desanā phala nipphādikā na hoti
translated: It bears fruit, thus it is fruit . It is the fruit of the teaching. Although the teaching is not the producer of the fruit,

original: tathāpi bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ sutvā puññasambhārā sambhavanti, puññasambhārahetuto
analyzed: tathā api bhagavataḥ dhamma desanam sutvā puñña sambhārā sambhavanti puñña sambhāra hetutaḥ
translated: nevertheless, when people have listened to the Blessed One’s teaching of the Dhamma, they accumulate the requisites of merit, and as a result of the requisites of merit

original: phalaṃ pavattaṃ, tasmā desanāya phalaṃ nāmāti. Katamaṃ taṃ? Devamanussesu āyuvaṇṇasukhabalayasaparivāraadhipateyyaupadhisampatticakkavattisiridevarajja-🔽siricatusampatticakkasīlasamādhisampadā vijjābhiññā paṭisambhidā sāvakabodhipaccekabodhisammāsambodhiyo.🔽Paccayasāmaggiṃ upagantvā ayati pavattati phalaṃ etenāti upāyo, ko so? Ariyamaggassa🔽pubbabhāgapaṭipadā. Purimā paṭipadā hi pacchimāya paṭipadāya adhigamūpāyo, paramparāya
analyzed: phalam pavattam tasmā desanāya phalam nāma ati katamam tam deva manussesu āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala yasa parivāra adhipateyya aupadhi sampatti cakkavatti siri deva rajja  siri catu sampatti cakka sīla samādhi sampadā vijjā abhiññā paṭisambhidā sāvaka bodhi pacceka bodhi sammāsambodhiyo  paccaya sāmaggim upagantvā ayati pavattati phalam etena ati upāyaḥ kaḥ saḥ ariya maggassa  pubba bhāga paṭipadā purimā paṭipadā hi pacchimāya paṭipadāya adhigama upāyaḥ paramparāya
translated: and it is the fruit of the teaching, thus it is called the fruit of the teaching. What is it? It is the excellence of life-span, physical beauty, happiness, strength, voice, retinue, lordship, and material goods among gods and men, the glory of a universal monarch, the glory of a divine king, the four kinds of excellence, the excellence of the wheel, virtue, concentration, knowledge, the direct knowledges, the analytical knowledges, the enlightenment of disciples, the enlightenment of paccekabuddhas, and the supreme enlightenment.🔽It is the means by which the fruit occurs when it is brought into conformity with the conditions, thus it is a means. What is it? It is the preliminary part of the noble path.🔽For the earlier practice is the means to the later practice, and the later practice is the means to the earlier practice, by way of mutual support.

original: magganibbānādhigamassa ca upāyo. Keci “maggopi upāyo”ti vadanti, tesaṃ matena nibbānameva🔽nissaraṇanti vuttaṃ siyā. “Te pahāya tare oghanti idaṃ nissaraṇa”nti pana ariyamaggassa🔽nissaraṇabhāvaṃ vakkhati, tasmā kesañci vādo na gahetabbo.
analyzed: magga nibbāna adhigamassa ca upāyaḥ keci maggaḥ api upāyaḥ ti vadanti tesam matena nibbānam eva 🔽nissaraṇanti vuttam siyā te pahāya tare oghan ti idam nissaraṇanti pana ariya maggassa 🔽nissaraṇa bhāvam vakkhati tasmā kesañci vādaḥ na gahetabbo
translated: It is the fruit of the teaching, thus it is called the fruit of the teaching. What is it? It is the excellence of life-span, physical beauty, happiness, strength, wisdom, retinue, rulership, and material possessions among gods and men; the glory of a universal monarch, the glory of the
