analyzed: tattha ye hāra ādayo uddesa niddesesu niddiṭṭhā tattha hāra ādīsu katamaḥ desanā hāro ti  ce yā assa ādīnava tā ati ādi gāthā vuttā sā ayam gāthā niddesa vasena desanā āhāraḥ nāma
translated: Herein, the Modes of Conveying beginning with the Mode of Conveying a Thread that have been demonstrated in the demonstration of the demonstration of the Thread, here in the case of those Modes of Conveying beginning with the Mode of Conveying a Thread, what is the Mode of Conveying Description?🔽If it be asked, the verse stated thus ‘ With profit and with loss ‘ is the Mode of Conveying Description,

original: tassa “assādādīnavatā”tiādi niddesassa idāni mayā vuccamāno “ayaṃ desanāhāro kiṃ🔽desayatī”tiādiko vitthārasaṃvaṇṇanāviseso desanāhāravibhaṅgo nāmāti yojanā. “Ayaṃ
analyzed: tassa niddesassa idāni mayā vuccamānaḥ ayam desanā āhāro kim  desayati iti ādikaḥ vitthāra saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ desanāhāravibhaṅgaḥ nāma ati yojanā ayaṃ
translated: the Mode of Conveying Description is the name for the special kind of commentary that I am now giving on that demonstration beginning with ‘ With profit and with loss ‘,🔽which is called the Mode of Conveying Description. The question ‘ What does this Mode of Conveying Description teach? ‘

original: desanāhāro kiṃ desayatī”ti pucchitabbattā pucchaṃ ṭhapetvā “imaṃ desayatī”ti niyametvā
analyzed: desanā āhāraḥ kim desayati iti pucchitabba ttā puccham ṭhapetvā imam desayati iti niyametvā
translated: is set aside by the statement ‘ This Mode of Conveying Description teaches this ‘, which is made in order to show by specifying what it is that it teaches.

original: dassetuṃ “ayaṃ desanāhāro kiṃ desayati? Assādaṃ ādīnava”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ayaṃ
analyzed: dassetum ayam desanā āhāraḥ kim desayati ādīnava nti ādi vuttam tattha ayam
translated: ‘ What does this Mode of Conveying Description teach? It teaches profit and loss ‘, and so on is said. Herein,

original: desanāhāro kiṃ desayatīti ce? Assādaṃ desayati saṃvaṇṇeti vitthāreti, ādīnavaṃ desayati…pe…
analyzed: desanā āhāraḥ kim desayati iti ce assādam desayati saṃvaṇṇā iti vitthārā iti ādīnavam desayati pe
translated: It teaches danger: it teaches, it demonstrates, it lays open, it makes clear, it reveals, it explains, it illuminates.🔽It teaches escape: it teaches, it demonstrates, it lays open, it makes clear, it reveals, it explains, it illuminates.

original: vitthāreti, nissaraṇaṃ desayati…pe… vitthāreti, phalaṃ desayati…pe… vitthāreti, upāyaṃ
analyzed: vitthārā iti nissaraṇam desayati pe vitthārā iti phalam desayati pe vitthārā iti upāyam
translated: It teaches fruit: it teaches, it demonstrates, it lays open, it makes clear, it reveals, it explains, it illuminates.🔽It teaches means: it teaches, it demonstrates, it lays open, it makes clear, it reveals, it explains, it illuminates.

original: desayati…pe… vitthāreti, āṇattiṃ desayati saṃvaṇṇeti vitthāretīti yojano.
analyzed: desayati pe vitthāreti āṇattim desayati saṃvaṇṇā iti vitthāreti iti yojanaḥ
translated: It teaches command: it teaches, it demonstrates, it lays open, it makes clear, it reveals, it explains, it illuminates.

original: Ettha ca “ayaṃ desanāhāro”ti saddo pubbāparāpekkhoti daṭṭhabbo. “‘Assādādīnavatā’tiādigāthāyaṃ🔽dassitā ime assādādayo kattha saṃvaṇṇetabbe pāḷidhamme āgatā”ti pucchitabbattā “dhammaṃ🔽vo, bhikkhave, desessāmī”tiādi vuttaṃ. “‘Assādādīnavatā’tiādigāthāyaṃ dassitā ime
analyzed: ettha ca ayam desanā āhāro ti saddo pubba apara apekkho ti daṭṭhabbaḥ assāda ādīnava tā ati ādi gāthāyam  dassitāḥ ime assāda ādayaḥ kattha saṃvaṇṇetabbe pāḷi dhamme āgatā ati pucchitabba ttā dhammaṃ  vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi itiādi vuttam assāda ādīnavatā ati ādi gāthāyam dassitāḥ ime
translated: And here the word nutriment of consciousness should be regarded as looking to what precedes and what follows.🔽Since it is necessary to ask, “Where in the texts are these gratifications, etc., stated that are shown in the verse ‘With gratification, danger, escape’ ,”🔽the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you a Dhamma with a nutriment” is stated.

original: assādādayo kattha saṃvaṇṇetabbe pāḷidhamme āgatā”ti pucchitabbattā “dhammaṃ vo, bhikkhave,
analyzed: assāda ādayaḥ kattha saṃvaṇṇetabbe pāḷi dhamme āgatā ati pucchitabba ttā dhammam vaḥ bhikkhave
translated: Since it is necessary to ask, “Where in the texts are these gratifications, etc., stated that are shown in the verse ‘With gratification, danger, escape’ ,” the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you a Dhamma with a nutriment” is stated.

original: desessāmi ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: desessāmi ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam
translated: I will teach the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing,

original: parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsessāmī”ti paṭiññātabbe pāḷidhamme saṃvaṇṇetabbe ye
analyzed: parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāsessāmi iti paṭiññātabbe pāḷi dhamme saṃvaṇṇetabbe ye
translated: and I will reveal a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.”

original: assādādayo āgatā, te ayaṃ desanāhāro desayatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: assāda ādayaḥ āgatā te ayam desanā āhāraḥ desayati iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning of the words in the passage to be recited in assent is to be commended.🔽The intention is that this teaching shows the benefits, etc., that are included in the passage.

original: Tattha dhammasaddo pariyattisaccasamādhipaññāpakatipuññāpattiñeyyādīsu bahūsu atthesu
analyzed: tattha dhamma saddaḥ bahūsu atthesu
translated: Herein, the word “Dhamma” occurs in many meanings, such as the scriptures, the four noble truths, concentration, wisdom, nature, merit, attainment, what should be known, and so on.

original: pavatto, tathāpi idha pariyattidhammeyeva pavattoti daṭṭhabbo. Atthuddeso pana aṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽vutto, tasmā idha mayā na vutto. Vo-kāropi upayogakaraṇapadapūraṇasampadānatthesu
analyzed: pavatto tathā api idha pariyatti dhammeya iva pavatto ti daṭṭhabbaḥ attha uddeso pana aṭṭhakathāyam  vuttaḥ tasmai idha mayā na vuttaḥ vokāraḥ api upayoga karaṇa pada pūraṇa sampadāna atthesu
translated: Nevertheless, it should be regarded as occurring here in the meaning of the scriptures. The word-commentary on the meaning of the passage is given in the commentary,🔽and therefore it is not given here. The word “bhikkhu” is seen to occur in the meanings of “using,” “making use of,” “filling a grammatical case,” and “endowing.”

original: dissati ca, tathāpi idha sampadānatthevāti daṭṭhabbo. Bhikkhanti yācanti sīlakkhandhādayo,
analyzed: dissati ca tathā api idha sampadāna atthā iva ati daṭṭhabbaḥ bhikkhanti yācanti sīlakkhandha ādayaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, it should be regarded as occurring here in the meaning of “endowing.” Those who are endowed with the aggregates of virtue, etc.,

original: paccaye vā kāyaviññattiyāti bhikkhū, saṃsāre bhayaṃ ikkhanti paccavekkhantīti vā
analyzed: paccaye vā kāya viññattiyā ati bhikkhū saṃsāre bhayam ikkhanti paccavekkhanti iti vā
translated: or with the bodily expression of the attainment of the noble paths, are called “bhikkhus.” Or they are called “bhikkhus” because they see fear in saṃsāra and review it.

original: bhikkhū. Bhikkhaveti te bhikkhū ālapati, kimatthāyāti attano mukhābhimukhaṃ katvā🔽dhammassavane atiussāhane niyojetuṃ ālapatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: bhikkhū bhikkhave ti te bhikkhū ālapati kimatthāya ati attanaḥ mukha abhimukham katvā  dhammassavane atiussāhane niyojetum ālapati iti veditabbaḥ
translated: ‘Bhikkhus’: he addresses those bhikkhus. ‘What for?’: he addresses them in order to urge them to listen to the Dhamma by turning their faces towards him.

original: Dhammaṃ desessāmīti nāhaṃ issaratāya tumhe aññaṃ kiñci kāreyyāmi, dhammaṃyeva desessāmi,
analyzed: dhammam desessāmi iti na aham issara tāya tumhe aññam kiñci kāreyyāmi dhammaṃ yeva desessāmi
translated: ‘I shall teach the Dhamma’: I shall not make you do anything else out of my own will, I shall only teach the Dhamma.

original: desento ca na aññesaṃ dhammaṃ sutvā sutamayañāṇānusārena desessāmi, anāvaraṇañāṇena
analyzed: desento ca na aññesam dhammam sutvā suta maya ñāṇa anusārena desessāmi anāvaraṇa ñāṇena
translated: And when I teach it, I shall not teach it by way of what has been heard and known by inference, but

original: sabbañeyyadhammesu paccakkhakāritāya idāni mayāyeva pavattiyamānaṃ dhammaṃ ahaṃ desessāmīti
analyzed: sabba ñeyya dhammesu paccakkha kāritāya idāni mayāya iva pavattiyamānam dhammam aham desessāmi iti
translated: I shall teach the Dhamma that is being taught by me now by means of knowledge that is unobstructed with regard to all knowable dhammas because of my being a witness to them myself.

original: paṭijānāti. Ādimhi kalyāṇaṃ ādikalyāṇaṃ, ādi kalyāṇametassāti vā ādikalyāṇaṃ. Sesesupi
analyzed: paṭijānāti ādimhi kalyāṇam ādi kalyāṇam ādi kalyāṇam etassa ati vā ādi kalyāṇam sesesu pi
translated: ‘Good in the beginning’: ‘good’ is ‘goodness’ . ‘Good in the beginning’ is that which has goodness at the beginning, or it is good at the beginning. The same method of explanation applies in the case of ‘good in the middle’ and ‘good in the end.’

original: eseva nayo. Ādikalyāṇādayo cettha atthakalyāṇādivasena vuttāti daṭṭhabbā. Tenāha
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ādi kalyāṇa ādayaḥ ca ittha attha kalyāṇa ādi vasena vuttā ati daṭṭhabbā tena āha
translated: But these should be regarded as ‘good in the beginning, etc.,’ according to the method of explanation given in the Niddesa, which is as follows: ‘Good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own intrinsic meaning, with its own intrinsic nature, with its own intrinsic characteristics, with the special qualities of the Ariyanness, this is the Dhamma’s goodness.

original: – “sīlena ādikalyāṇaṃ, samādhinā majjhekalyāṇaṃ, paññāya pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ. Buddhasubuddhatāya
analyzed: sīlena ādi kalyāṇam samādhinā majjhe kalyāṇam paññāya pariyosāna kalyāṇam buddha subuddha tāya
translated: ‘Good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own intrinsic meaning, with its own intrinsic nature, with its own intrinsic characteristics, with the special qualities of the Ariyanness, this is the Dhamma’s goodness’ .

original: vā ādikalyāṇaṃ, dhammasudhammatāya majjhekalyāṇaṃ, saṅghasuppaṭipattiyā pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ.
analyzed: vā ādi kalyāṇam dhamma su dhamma tāya majjhe kalyāṇam saṅgha su paṭipattiyā pariyosāna kalyāṇam
translated: It is good in the beginning as the True Idea, in the middle as the True Object, and in the end as the True Realization.

original: Atha vā ugghaṭitaññuvinayanena ādikalyāṇaṃ, vipañcitaññuvinayanena majjhekalyāṇaṃ,
analyzed: atha vā ugghaṭita ññu vinayanena ādi kalyāṇam vipañcita ññu vinayanena majjhe kalyāṇam
translated: Or alternatively, it is good in the beginning as the Discipline for those who learn by a bare statement, in the middle as the Discipline for those who learn by analysis,

original: neyyapuggalavinayanena pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ. Ayamevattho idhādhippeto”ti.
analyzed: neyya puggala vinayanena pariyosāna kalyāṇam ayam eva atthaḥ idha adhippeto ti
translated: and in the end as the Discipline for those who learn by what is to be directly known. This is the meaning intended here.

original: Arīyati ñāyatīti attho, ara-dhātuyā nippariyāyato ñāṇappadhāno ārammaṇikacittuppādo
analyzed: arīyati ñāyati iti atthaḥ ara dhātuyā nippariyāyataḥ ñāṇa ppadhānaḥ ārammaṇika cittuppādo
translated: The meaning is that it is penetrated and known. The meaning is the occurrence of consciousness that is the footing for knowledge in the sense of the root aramh, which is the opposite of aram, ‘to be unpenetrated and unknown.’

original: attho, ṭhānūpacārato atthassa ñātabbassa ārammaṇapaccayasatti attho, iti-saddena🔽sāyeva satti parāmasīyati, ārammaṇapaccayasattisahito ārammaṇapaccayasaṅkhāto ñātabbo🔽attho ta-paccayassa atthoti dhātupaccayānaṃ atthaviseso daṭṭhabbo. Asati bhavatīti
analyzed: atthaḥ ṭhāna upacārataḥ atthassa ñātabbassa ārammaṇa paccaya satti atthaḥ iti saddena  sāya iva satti parāmasīyati ārammaṇa paccaya satti sahitaḥ ārammaṇa paccaya saṅkhātaḥ ñātabbaḥ  atthaḥ ta paccayassa atthaḥ ti dhātu paccayānam attha viseso daṭṭhabbo asati bhavati iti
translated: The meaning is the presence of the object condition for the known object, in the sense of the place and the approach. The word iti is used🔽to refer to that presence. The meaning is the known object, called the object condition, which is accompanied by the presence of the object condition.🔽The meaning of the condition is the meaning of the condition for that. This is how the difference in the meanings of the roots should be seen.

original: vā attho, saha atthena yo dhammo vattatīti so dhammo sāttho, atthena samannāgato
analyzed: vā atthaḥ saha atthena yaḥ dhammaḥ vattati iti so dhammo sa atthaḥ atthena samannāgato
translated: The meaning is that it is not when there is not. The state of a thing that occurs together with the meaning is the meaning of the state of being possessed of the meaning,

original: vā dhammo sāttho, saṅkāsanādichaatthapadasamāyogato vā sāttho. Ayamevattho idhādhippeto
analyzed: vā dhammo sa atthaḥ saṅkāsana ādi cha attha pada samāyogataḥ vā sa atthaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ idha adhippeto
translated: and this is what is intended here.

original: nettivisayattā. Sampannaṃ byañjanaṃ yassa dhammassāti sabyañjano. Sithiladhanitadīgharassagarulahusambandhavavatthitavimuttaniggahitasampannattā,
analyzed: netti visaya ttā sampannam byañjanam yassa dhammassa ati sa byañjanaḥ sithila dhanita dīgha rassa garu lahu sambandha vavatthita vimutta niggahita sampanna ttā
translated: It is “well-worded” because of the perfection of its component parts. The component parts are perfect because of the perfection of the loose syllables, the compact syllables, the long syllables, the short syllables, the guttural syllables, the labial syllables, the sibilants, the cerebrals, the dentals, the linguals, the vowels, the consonants, the connected letters, the free letters, the restrained letters, and the unrestrained letters,

original: akārantādiitthiliṅgādiekavacanādisampannattā, pamādalekhādirahitattā ca avayavo sampanno
analyzed: akāra anta ādi itthi liṅga ādi ekavacana ādi sampanna ttā pamāda lekhā ādi rahita ttā ca avayavaḥ sampannaḥ
translated: and because of the perfection of the feminine gender, etc., the singular number, etc., and the absence of such faults as omissions, additions, and the like.

original: taṃsamūhattā dhammo sampannabyañjano nāma, akkharādichabyañjanapadasamāyogā vā sabyañjano.
analyzed: dhammaḥ sampanna byañjanaḥ nāma akkhara ādi cha byañjana pada samāyogā vā sa byañjanaḥ
translated: The Dhamma is called “well-worded” because it is a collection of these component parts. Or it is “well-worded” because of its connection with the eight component parts beginning with the letters.🔽And this is what is intended here.

original: Ayamevattho idhādhippeto. Imasmiṃ ayaṃ ūno, so netabbo pakkhipitabboti upanetabbābhāvato
analyzed: ayam eva atthaḥ idha adhippetaḥ imasmin ayam ūnaḥ saḥ netabbo pakkhipitabbaḥ iti upanetabba abhāvato
translated: It is “complete” because it is not to be supplemented, because it is not to be added to.

original: kevalaparipuṇṇo, sīlakkhandhasamādhikkhandhapaññākkhandha- vimuttikkhandhavimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhapāripūriyā
analyzed: kevala paripuṇṇaḥ sīla kkhandha samādhi kkhandha paññā kkhandha vimutti kkhandha vimutti ñāṇa dassana kkhandha pāripūriyā
translated: It is complete in the perfection of the aggregate of virtue, the aggregate of concentration, the aggregate of wisdom, the aggregate of emancipation, and the aggregate of the knowledge and vision of emancipation.

original: vā kevalaparipuṇṇo. Idhāyaṃ atireko, so apanetabboti vatvā apanetabbābhāvato parisuddho,
analyzed: vā kevala paripuṇṇaḥ idha ayam atirekaḥ so apanetabbaḥ iti vatvā apanetabba abhāvataḥ parisuddho
translated: or it is complete in every way. Herein, this excess should be removed. Since it is not to be removed, it is purified.

original: caturoghanittharaṇatthāya, lokāmisanirapekkhatāya pavattiyamānattā vā parisuddho.
analyzed: catur ogha nittharaṇa tthāya loka āmisa nirapekkha tāya vā parisuddhaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, it is purified since it is carried out without regard for worldly things in order to cross over the four floods.

original: Seṭṭhattā brahmacariyaṃ, brahmānaṃ vā seṭṭhānaṃ ariyānaṃ cariyaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, pabbajjabrahmacariyamaggabrahmacariyasāsanabrahmacariyādīsu
analyzed: seṭṭha ttā brahmacariyam brahmānam vā seṭṭhānam ariyānam cariyam brahmacariyam pabbajja brahmacariya magga brahmacariya sāsana brahmacariya ādīsu
translated: The life of the holy ones: the life of the holy ones is the life of the highest, or the life of the noble ones who are holy. The life of the holy ones is the life of the one gone forth, the life of the path, the life of the Dispensation, and so on.

original: sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ pakāsayissāmi, paridīpayissāmīti attho.
analyzed: sāsana brahmacariyam pakāsayissāmi paridīpayissāmi iti attho
translated: Herein, I shall make known, I shall reveal the life of the Dispensation.

original: “Dhammaṃ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi…pe… pakāsessāmī”ti paṭiññātabbe pāḷidhamme āgate
analyzed: dhammam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi pe pakāsessāmi iti paṭiññātabbe pāḷi dhamme āgate
translated: When it is said, “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the Dhamma” … “I shall reveal the Dhamma” , the profitable and unprofitable, etc., which are stated in the text

original: assādādayo desanāhāro desayati saṃvaṇṇeti vitthāretīti ācariyena sāmaññavaseneva
analyzed: assāda ādayaḥ desanā āhāraḥ desayati saṃvaṇṇeti vitthāreti iti ācariyena sāmañña vasena iva
translated: are taught, expounded, and broadcast by the teacher as the nutriment of instruction.🔽Therefore the nutriment of instruction here teaches this taste stated in the text.

original: vuttaṃ, tasmā desanāhāro idha pāḷiyaṃ āgataṃ imaṃ assādaṃ desayati, idha pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tasmā desanā āhāraḥ idha pāḷiyam āgatam imam assādam desayati idha pāḷiyam
translated: Herein, the nutriment of instruction teaches this taste stated in the text.

original: āgataṃ imaṃ ādīnavaṃ desayatītiādi viseso na viññātabbo, “kathaṃ viññātabbo”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: āgatam imam ādīnavam desayati itiādi visesaḥ na viññātabbaḥ katham viññātabbaḥ ti pucchitabba ttā
translated: The difference between the two should be understood thus: “The Blessed One teaches the profit in the way beginning, ‘When a man is lusting after sensual desires,’ and the danger in the way beginning, ‘When a man is lusting after sensual desires,’ and so on. How should it be understood?”

original: “idha pāḷiyaṃ āgato ayaṃ assādo, idha pāḷiyaṃ āgato ayaṃ ādīnavo”ti visesaṃ niyametvā
analyzed: idha pāḷiyam āgataḥ ayam assādaḥ idha pāḷiyam āgataḥ ayam ādīnavaḥ ti visesam niyametvā
translated: “Herein, this is the profit stated in the text, and this is the danger.”

original: upalakkhaṇanayena dassetuṃ “tattha katamo assādo? Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassā”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: upalakkhaṇa nayena dassetum tattha katamaḥ assādaḥ kāmam kāmayamānassa ati ādi āraddham
translated: In order to show the difference by defining it in this way, he began the explanation with the words, “Herein, what is the profit? When a man is lusting after sensual desires” .

original: Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ niddiṭṭhesu visayavisayibhedesu
analyzed: tattha tattha ati niddiṭṭhesu visaya visayi bhedesu
translated: Herein, herein in the verse quoted above, which is stated in terms of profit and danger, in the various instances of object and possessor of the object,

original: assādesu katamo assādo tattha tesu pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷiyaṃ āgatoti pucchitvā –
analyzed: assādesu katamaḥ assādo tattha tesu pāḷi dhammesu kattha pāḷiyam āgataḥ ti pucchitvā
translated: what is the profit? Wherein is the profit stated in the text?

original: “Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassa, tassa cetaṃ samijjhati;
analyzed: kāmam kāmayamānassa tassa cetam samijjhati
translated: “When a man is lusting after sensual desires, If his lust is gratified,

original: Addhā pītimano hoti, laddhā macco yadicchatī”ti. –
analyzed: addhā pītimanaḥ hoti laddhā maccaḥ yat icchati iti
translated: He is sure to be elated, Having got what he wanted” .

original: Idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ yo visayabhūto assādo āgato, so ayaṃ assādetabbo assādo desanāhārassa visayoti. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana –
analyzed: idha pāḷigāthā ayam yaḥ visaya bhūto assādaḥ āgato saḥ ayam assādetabbaḥ assādaḥ desanā āhārassa visayo ti aṭṭhakathā ayam pana
translated: Herein, the profit that is stated in the text in the verse is the profit to be enjoyed. It is the object of the teacher’s instruction. But in the commentary

original: “Evaṃ bhagavatā desito, pakāsito ca sāsanadhammo yesaṃ assādādīnaṃ dassanavasena
analyzed: evam bhagavatā desitaḥ pakāsitaḥ ca sāsana dhammaḥ yesam assāda ādīnam dassana vasena
translated: “The Blessed One has taught and shown the Dhamma of the Dispensation in such a way that the benefits, etc.,

original: pavatto, te assādādayo desanāhārassa visayabhūtā yattha yattha pāṭhe savisesaṃ vuttā,
analyzed: te assāda ādayaḥ desanā āhārassa visaya bhūtāḥ yattha yattha pāṭhe sa visesam vuttā
translated: which occur by seeing the benefits, etc., are the province of the exposition. They are stated in particular places in the texts.

original: tato tato niddhāretvā udāharaṇavasena idhānetvā dassetuṃ ‘tattha katamo assādo’tiādi āraddha”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha assādīyateti assādo, assādetabbo vatthukāmo. Kāmīyateti kāmo, vatthukāmo ca.🔽Taṃ kāmayatīti kāmayamāno, satto. Tassa pītiyā yuttaṃ mano etassāti pītimano. Manati
analyzed: tatas tatas niddhāretvā udāharaṇa vasena idha anetvā dassetum tattha katamaḥ assādaḥ tiādi āraddhanti vuttam  tattha assādīyateti assādaḥ assādetabbaḥ vatthu kāmo kāmīyateti kāmaḥ vatthu kāmo ca  tam kāmayati iti kāmayamānaḥ satto tassa pītiyā yuttam manaḥ etassa ati pīti manaḥ manati
translated: Having extracted them from here and there, they are brought together here by way of examples and shown by the words ‘What is the benefit? ‘ and so on.”🔽Herein, it is savoured , thus it is a benefit ; sensual pleasure as object is to be savoured . It is desired , thus it is sensual pleasure ; sensual pleasure as object is desired .

original: jānātītiādivacanatthena macco. Kāmaṃ kāmitabbaṃ vatthu kāmayamānassa tassa sattassa
analyzed: jānāti iti ādi vacana tthena macco kāmam kāmitabbam vatthu kāmayamānassa tassa sattassa
translated: One who desires that is a being who desires . The mind of one who is associated with joy is a joyful mind . The mind is applied , thus it is a mortal being , in the sense of the words “He knows , he sees” .

original: etaṃ kāmitabbaṃ vatthu sace samijjhati, evaṃ sati so satto addhā pītimano hoti. Yo
analyzed: etam kāmitabbam vatthu sace samijjhati evam sati saḥ sattaḥ addhā pīti manaḥ hoti yaḥ
translated: The object of desire is a desirable object . If that desirable object succeeds for that being who desires it, then certainly his mind is joyful.

original: macco yaṃ vatthuṃ icchati, taṃ vatthuṃ so macco laddhā addhā pītimano hotīti gāthāyattho daṭṭhabbo.🔽“Kāmaṃ …pe… pītimano hotī”ti ettakameva avatvā “laddhā macco yadicchatī”ti vuttattā
analyzed: maccaḥ yam vatthum icchati tam vatthum saḥ maccaḥ laddhā addhā pīti manaḥ hoti iti gāthāya atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  kāmam pe pīti manaḥ hoti iti ettakam eva avatvā laddhā maccaḥ yat icchati iti vutta ttā
translated: The meaning of the verse should be understood as follows: “When a man gets the thing he wants, he is pleased indeed.”🔽But instead of saying this much, the text says, “When a man gets what he wants, he is pleased indeed.”🔽So it should be understood that he is pleased not only when he gets a desirable object but also when he gets what he wants and what he can enjoy and what he can worship.

original: lobhanīyaṃ vatthuṃyeva laddhā pītimano na hoti, atha kho patthetabbaṃ pūjetabbanti🔽sabbaṃ laddhā macco pītimano ca hotīti atirekattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: lobhanīyam vatthuṃyeva laddhā pīti manaḥ na hoti atha kho patthetabbam pūjetabbanti  sabbam laddhā macco pīti manaḥ ca hoti iti atireka atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ
translated: And it should be understood that the meaning of the words “When a man gets what he wants, he is pleased indeed” is this: “When a man gets all that, he is pleased indeed.”

original: Visayabhūto assādetabbo assādo idha pāḷiyaṃ gāthāyaṃ āgatoti ācariyena vibhatto,
analyzed: visaya bhūtaḥ assādetabbaḥ assādaḥ idha pāḷiyam gāthāyam āgataḥ ti ācariyena vibhatto
translated: The teacher has analyzed the verse in the text, which contains the word “enjoyment” , as follows: “The enjoyment is to be relished as the object of relishing.”

original: amhehi ca ñāto, “dukkhadomanassādibhedesu ādīnavesu katamo ādīnavo kattha pāḷidhamme
analyzed: amhehi ca ñātaḥ dukkha domanassa ādi bhedesu ādīnavesu katamaḥ ādīnavaḥ kattha pāḷi dhamme
translated: We have understood that. But since it has to be asked, “Among the dangers classed as pain and grief, etc., which danger is referred to in the text? In which state of consciousness is it?

original: āgato”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha katamo ādīnavo? Tassa ce kāmayānassā”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: āgataḥ ti pucchitabbattā tattha katamaḥ ādīnavaḥ tassa ce kāmayānassa atiādi āraddham
translated: How is it stated in the texts?” the answer is given in the way beginning, “Herein, which is the danger? If he delights in what he feels” .

original: Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ niddiṭṭhesu dukkhadomanassādīsu
analyzed: tattha tattha ati tassam niddiṭṭhesu dukkha domanassa ādīsu
translated: Herein, herein = in the pain and grief, etc.,

original: ādīnavesu katamo ādīnavo tattha tesu pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷiyaṃ āgatoti pucchitvā –
analyzed: ādīnavesu katamaḥ ādīnavaḥ tattha tesu pāḷi dhammesu kattha pāḷiyam āgataḥ ti pucchitvā
translated: What is the danger there in the case of those states of ideas stated in the text? Where is it stated in the text?

original: “Tassa ce kāmayānassa, chandajātassa jantuno;
analyzed: tassa ce kāmayānassa chanda jātassa jantunaḥ
translated: “If he is one who longs for sensual desires,

original: Te kāmā parihāyanti, sallaviddhova ruppatī”ti. –
analyzed: te kāmā parihāyanti salla viddhaḥ uva ruppati iti
translated: His sensual desires desert him, as an arrow shot the archer” .

original: Idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ yo domanassasaṅkhāto ādīnavo āgato, so ayaṃ domanassasaṅkhāto ādīnavo desanāhārassa visayoti.
analyzed: idha pāḷigāthā ayam yaḥ domanassa saṅkhātaḥ ādīnavaḥ āgataḥ saḥ ayam domanassa saṅkhātaḥ ādīnavaḥ desanā āhārassa visayo ti
translated: Herein, the danger consisting in sorrow stated in this text line is the province of the teacher’s instruction.

original: Gāthāyaṃ pana kāmayati icchatīti kāmayāno. Atha vā yāyati gacchatīti yāno, kāmena
analyzed: pana kāmayati icchati iti kāmayānaḥ atha vā yāyati gacchati iti kāmena
translated: In the text line, however, the word kāmayāno is derived from the verb kāmayati , which means “he longs for, he desires” . Or alternatively, yāyati means “he goes” , and kāmena yāyati means “he goes by desire” .

original: yāno kāmayāno, tassa. Chando jāto yassa so chandajāto, tassa. Vijjhīyateti viddho,
analyzed: yānaḥ kāmayānaḥ tassa chandaḥ jātaḥ yassa saḥ chanda jātaḥ tassa vijjhīyate iti viddhaḥ
translated: He is kāmayāno . He is chandajāto , he is vijjhīyati ,

original: sallati pavisatīti sallo, sallena viddho sallaviddho. Kāmaṃ kāmayānassa chandajātassa
analyzed: sallati pavisati iti sallaḥ sallena viddhaḥ salla viddhaḥ kāmam kāmayānassa chanda jātassa
translated: he is sallo , he is sallaviddho .

original: jantuno ye kāmā labhitabbā, te kāmā kenaci antarāyena yadā parihāyanti, tadā so jantu
analyzed: jantunaḥ ye kāmā labhitabbā te kāmā kenaci antarāyena yadā parihāyanti tadā saḥ jantu
translated: When the sensual desires that the man who longs for sensual desires and is born of desire is to obtain are deserted by some obstruction, then that man

original: ruppati. Kīdisova ruppati? Ayomayasallaviddho migo ruppati iva, parihīnakāmo jantu
analyzed: ruppati kīdisā uva ruppati ayaḥ maya salla viddhaḥ migaḥ ruppati iva parihīna kāmaḥ jantu
translated: How does he suffer? He suffers like a deer pierced by an iron dart. A being who has lost his desire

original: ruppatīti daṭṭhabbo. Ettha ca “ruppatī”tivacanena domanassuppatti dassitāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Domanassabhūto ādīnavo idha pāḷiyaṃ āgatoti ācariyena vibhatto, amhehi ca ñāto, “magganibbānavasena
analyzed: ruppati iti daṭṭhabbaḥ ettha ca ruppati iti vacanena domanassa uppatti dassitā iti daṭṭhabbā  domanassa bhūtaḥ ādīnavaḥ idha pāḷiyam āgataḥ ti ācariyena vibhattaḥ amhehi ca ñātaḥ magga nibbāna vasena
translated: should be seen as suffering. And here the word “suffers” should be seen as showing the arising of grief.

original: duvidhesu nissaraṇesu katamaṃ nissaraṇaṃ kattha pāḷiyaṃ āgata”nti pucchitabbattā🔽“tattha katamaṃ nissaraṇaṃ? Yo kāme parivajjetī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ🔽“assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ niddiṭṭhesu magganibbānavasena duvidhesu nissaraṇesu
analyzed: duvidhesu nissaraṇesu katamam nissaraṇam kattha pāḷiyam āgatan ti pucchitabbattā  tattha katamam nissaraṇam yaḥ kāme parivajjeti itiādi āraddham tattha tattha ati  assāda ādīnava tā ati ādi gāthāyam niddiṭṭhesu magga nibbāna vasena duvidhesu nissaraṇesu
translated: The danger that is the state of grief is shown in the text. It has been analyzed by the teacher and is known to us. But since it has to be asked: “In the two kinds of escape, namely, the path and Nibbāna, which escape is shown in the text and where?”

original: katamaṃ nissaraṇaṃ tattha tesu pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷidhamme āgatanti pucchitvā –
analyzed: katamam nissaraṇam tattha tesu pāḷi dhammesu kattha pāḷi dhamme āgatanti pucchitvā
translated: “Herein, what is escape? He who avoids sense desires” , etc., is stated. Herein, there is the question: “In the two kinds of escape shown in the text, namely, the path and Nibbāna, which escape is shown in the text and where?”

original: “Yo kāme parivajjeti, sappasseva padā siro;
analyzed: yaḥ kāme parivajjeti sappassa iva padā siraḥ
translated: “Herein, what is escape? He who avoids sense desires, like a snake’s slough,

original: Somaṃ visattikaṃ loke, sato samativattatī”ti. –
analyzed: somam visattikam loke sataḥ samativattati iti
translated: The wise man, mindful, overcomes the world’s attraction and repulsion.”

original: Idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ yaṃ samativattanakaraṇaṃ maggasaṅkhātaṃ nissaraṇaṃ āgataṃ, taṃ idaṃ maggasaṅkhātaṃ samativattanakaraṇaṃ nissaraṇaṃ desanāhārassa visayanti.🔽Gāthāyaṃ yoti jhānalābhī vā ariyo vā. Kāmeti vuttappakāro vatthukāmo. Tesu pavattachandarāgassa🔽vikkhambhanena vā samucchindanena vā parivajjeti. Kiṃ parivajjeti iva vajjeti? Sappassa
analyzed: idha pāḷigāthāyam yam samativattana karaṇam magga saṅkhātam nissaraṇam āgatam tam idam magga saṅkhātam samativattana karaṇam nissaraṇam desanā āhārassa  gāthā ayam yaḥ ti jhāna lābhī vā ariyaḥ vā kāmeti vutta ppakāraḥ vatthu kāmaḥ tesu pavatta chanda rāgassa  vikkhambhanena vā samucchindanena vā parivajjeti kim parivajjeti iva vajjeti sappassa
translated: The escape consisting in the way that has been stated in the verse as the means of surmounting is the province of the teaching of the Thread.

original: siro siraṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā padā pādena parivajjeti iva, evaṃ parivajjeti. Sato
analyzed: siraḥ siram cakkhumā purisaḥ disvā padā pādena parivajjeti iva evam parivajjeti sataḥ
translated: The “one” in the verse is either a Noble Person who has attained jhana or a worldling. “Pleasure” is the kind of sensual desire stated. He avoids it either by suppressing the desire and greed that occur in him for the objects of sensual desire or by abandoning them. How does he avoid it as if avoiding a snake’s head or a blazing charcoal? Just as a man with eyes might avoid a snake’s head or a piece of burning charcoal by stepping back, so he avoids sensual desire.

original: satisampanno so puggalo loke rūpādīsu visattikaṃ imaṃ taṇhaṃ yena maggena samativattati
analyzed: sati sampannaḥ saḥ puggalaḥ loke rūpa ādīsu visattikam imam taṇham yena maggena samativattati
translated: The “one” is a person possessed of mindfulness, who, by the way of the path, surmounts this craving that is scattered in the world in the form of sensual desire, etc.,

original: saṃ suṭṭhu atikkamitvā vattati, idaṃ maggasaṅkhātaṃ samativattanakaraṇaṃ ekadesaṃ
analyzed: sam suṭṭhu atikkamitvā vattati idam magga saṅkhātam samativattana karaṇam eka desam
translated: and goes well beyond it. This escape consisting in the way that has been stated as the means of surmounting is one part of the province of the teaching of the Thread.

original: nissaraṇaṃ nāmāti yojetabbaṃ. “Pādā”ti vattabbe ākārassa rassaṃ katvā “padā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nissaraṇam nāma ati yojetabbam pādā ti vattabbe ākārassa rassam katvā pādā ti vuttam
translated: “Padā” is said with the vowel length of the syllable “padā” instead of “pādā” .

original: Pādāti ca pādena yathā “amohabhāvā amohabhāvenā”ti. Tena vuttaṃ “attano pādenā”ti.
analyzed: ca pādena yathā amoha bhāvā amoha bhāvena ati tena vuttam attanaḥ pādena ati
translated: And “foot” is like “non-delusion” in the passage “through non-delusion as a footing for faith” . That is why “with his own foot” is said.

original: Ekadeso visayasaṅkhāto assādo idha pāḷiyaṃ āgatoti ācariyena vibhatto, amhehi ca
analyzed: eka desaḥ visaya saṅkhāto assādaḥ idha pāḷiyam āgato ti ācariyena vibhattaḥ amhehi ca
translated: The teacher has analysed the “enjoyment” in the passage “enjoyment is a single aspect of the objective field” , and we have

original: ñāto, “ekadeso visayisaṅkhāto assādo kattha pāḷiyaṃ āgato”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha🔽katamo assādo? Khettaṃ vatthu”ntiādi āraddhaṃ. Atha vā “tattha katamo assādo? Khettaṃ
analyzed: ñātaḥ eka desaḥ visayi saṅkhātaḥ assādaḥ kattha pāḷiyam āgato ti pucchitabba ttā tattha  katamaḥ assādaḥ khettam vatthuṃ ti ādi āraddham atha vā tattha katamaḥ assādaḥ khettam
translated: understood it. But since it has to be asked “Where in the text is the ‘enjoyment’ that is a single aspect of the objective field stated? ” ,🔽the answer is given in the passage beginning, “Herein, what is enjoyment? A field, a site” .

original: vatthu”ntiādi kasmā evaṃ āraddhaṃ, nanu “tattha katamo assādo? Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassā”tiādinā🔽assādo vibhatto? Saccaṃ, assādo pana duvidho visayavisayivasena, tasmiṃ visayasaṅkhāto
analyzed: vatthum tiādi kasmai evam āraddham nanu tattha katamaḥ assādaḥ kāmam kāmayamānassa atiādinā  assādaḥ vibhatto saccam assādaḥ pana duvidhaḥ visaya visayi vasena tasmim visaya saṅkhāto
translated: Or alternatively, why is it that the answer is given in the passage beginning, “Herein, what is enjoyment? A field, a site” , since “enjoyment” has already been analysed in the passage beginning, “Herein, what is enjoyment? When one who is desirous desires” ?

original: assādo pubbe vibhatto, idāni visayisaṅkhātaṃ assādaṃ vibhajituṃ “tattha katamo assādo?🔽Khettaṃ vatthu”ntiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ
analyzed: assādaḥ pubbe vibhattaḥ idāni visayi saṅkhātam assādam vibhajitum tattha katamaḥ assādo 🔽khettam vatthum tiādi āraddham tattha tattha ati tassam
translated: It is true that it has, but “enjoyment” is of two kinds, that is to say, as objective field and as enjoyer. The “enjoyment” as objective field has been analysed previously. Now in order to analyse the “enjoyment” as enjoyer, the answer is given in the passage beginning, “Herein, what is enjoyment? A field, a site” .🔽Herein, herein in that stanza beginning “With enjoyment and with suffering” ,

original: niddiṭṭhesu visayavisayibhedesu assādesu katamo assādo tattha tesu pāḷidhammesu kattha
analyzed: niddiṭṭhesu visaya visayi bhedesu assādesu katamaḥ assādaḥ tattha tesu pāḷi dhammesu kattha
translated: Among the objects and subjects of the three kinds of delight that have been demonstrated, what is the delight? And where is it stated in the texts?

original: pāḷiyaṃ āgatoti pucchitvā –
analyzed: pāḷiyam āgataḥ iti pucchitvā
translated: Having asked thus, he should answer:

original: “Khettaṃ vatthuṃ hiraññaṃ vā, gavāssaṃ dāsaporisaṃ;
analyzed: khettam vatthum hiraññam vā gavāssam dāsa porisam
translated: “A field, a site, gold, a cow, a horse, a slave, a servant,

original: Thiyo bandhū puthū kāme, yo naro anugijjhatī”ti. –
analyzed: thiyaḥ bandhū puthū kāme yaḥ naraḥ anugijjhati iti
translated: Women, relatives, various desires: the man who delights in these” .

original: Idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ yo anugijjhanasaṅkhāto assādo āgato, so ayaṃ anugijjhanasaṅkhāto visayiassādo desanāhārassa visayoti.
analyzed: idha pāḷigāthā ayam yaḥ anugijjhana saṅkhāto assādaḥ āgataḥ saḥ ayam anugijjhana saṅkhātaḥ visayi assādaḥ desanā āhārassa visayo ti
translated: Herein, the delight called “delighting” that is stated in this verse of the texts is the delight as object of the subject of teaching.🔽In the verse “field” is a place where seeds are sown. “Site” is a place where a house is built. “Gold” is the colour of gold. “Cow” is a cow that gives milk. “Horse” is a horse that can be ridden. “Slave” is a slave who does one’s bidding. “Servant” is a servant who does one’s bidding. “Women” are women who are one’s relatives. “Relatives” are relatives who are one’s own. “Various desires” are the five strands of sense pleasure. “The man who delights in these” is the man who delights in these.

original: Gāthāyaṃ khettanti khipīyanti bījāni ettha ṭhāneti khettaṃ. Khipantānaṃ janānaṃ khipanakiriyā🔽khipa-dhātuyā mukhyattho, khipanakiriyājanako cittuppādo phalūpacārattho, tassa cittuppādassa
analyzed: gāthāyam bījāni ettha ṭhāne iti khettam khipantānam janānam khipana kiriyā  khipa dhātuyāḥ mukhya tthaḥ khipana kiriyā janako cittuppādo phala upacāra attho tassa cittuppādassa
translated: Herein, the “field” is the primary meaning of the verb “to sow” . The act of sowing is the meaning of the verb “to sow” .

original: upanissayapaccayabhūtassa kedārassa viruḷhāpanasatti phalūpacārattho, iti-saddena🔽sā viruḷhāpanasattiyeva parāmasīyati, tassā sattiyā patiṭṭhaṃ kedārasaṅkhātaṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: upanissaya paccaya bhūtassa kedārassa phala upacāra atthaḥ iti saddena 🔽sā viruḷhāpana sattiyā iva parāmasīyati tassā sattiyā patiṭṭham kedāra saṅkhātam ṭhānam
translated: The mental volition that causes the act of sowing is the meaning of the verb “to sow” by metonymy of cause by the effect. The bamboo that grows from the bamboo seed that is the condition by conditionality for that mental volition is the meaning of the verb “to sow” by metonymy of the effect by the cause.🔽By the word “so”🔽that bamboo is referred to. The site called “bamboo” that is the support of that bamboo is the meaning of the verb “to sow” by metonymy of the support by the supported.

original: ta-paccayattho. Esa nayo tīsu piṭakesu evarūpesu ca vacanatthesu yathārahaṃ nīharitvā🔽gahetabbo. Vapanti patiṭṭhahanti etthāti vatthu. Aparaṇṇādīnaṃ patiṭṭhahanaṃ vapa-dhātuyā
analyzed: esa nayaḥ tīsu piṭakesu evarūpesu ca vacana tthesu yathāraham nīharitvā  gahetabbaḥ vapanti patiṭṭhahanti ettha ati vatthu aparaṇṇa ādīnam patiṭṭhahanam vapa dhātuyā
translated: is the meaning of ta-paccaya. This is the method in the three Baskets and in such meanings of words as these. Having extracted them as is appropriate,🔽they should be taken. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. The foundation of such things as rice and so on is the primary meaning of the word🔽vap-dhātu. The meaning of the word ṭhāna is the ability to establish a place, the meaning of the word phalūpacāra is the meaning of the word ṭhāna. By the word iti the ability to establish that place

original: mukhyattho, ṭhānassa patiṭṭhāpanasatti phalūpacārattho, iti-saddena sā patiṭṭhāpanasatti🔽parāmasīyati. Tassā sattiyā patiṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ ta-paccayattho. Khettaṃ pana pubbaṇṇavirūhanaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: mukhya atthaḥ ṭhānassa patiṭṭhāpana satti phala upacāra atthaḥ iti saddena sā patiṭṭhāpana satti  tassā sattiyā patiṭṭha ṭṭhānam khettam pana pubbaṇṇa virūhana ṭṭhānam
translated: is referred to. The meaning of the word ta-paccaya is the place that is established by that ability. But a field is the place for the growth of rice,

original: vatthu aparaṇṇavirūhanaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Hinoti pavattati pītisomanassanti hi, kiṃ taṃ? Pītisomanassaṃ, rāti pavatteti jātarūpanti🔽raṃ, kiṃ taṃ? Jātarūpaṃ, hiṃ ranti hiraṃ, dutiyātappurisasamāso. Ñāpeti tosetīti
analyzed: vatthu aparaṇṇa virūhana ṭṭhānaṃ  hinoti pavattati pīti somanassanti hi kim tam pīti somanassam rāti pavatteti jātarūpanti  raṃ kim tam jātarūpam him ranti hiraṃ dutiyā tappurisa samāsaḥ toseti iti
translated: a place is the place for the growth of such things as beans.🔽It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is gold because it is a foundation for this and that.

original: ñaṃ, kiṃ taṃ? Jātarūpaṃ. Hiraṃ hutvā ñaṃ hiraññaṃ, pavattamānaṃ pītisomanassaṃ pavattetvā
analyzed: kim tam jātarūpam hiram hutvā ñam hiraññam pavattamānam pīti somanassam pavattetvā
translated: What is that? It is gold. It is gold because it is a foundation for this and that. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that. What is that? It is joy and happiness. It is a place because it is a foundation for this and that.

original: jane visesena tosetīti attho gahetabbo. Vā-saddo vuttāvuttatthasamuccayattho. Gacchanti
analyzed: jane visesena toseti iti atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ vā saddaḥ vutta avutta ttha samuccaya tthaḥ gacchanti
translated: The meaning should be taken as “he delights in people, especially.” The word vā is a particle of combination, meaning “what has been said and what has not been said.”

original: visesenāti gāvo, rattindivaṃ asanti bhakkhanti visesenāti assā, gāvo ca assā ca gavāssaṃ.🔽Dātabbaṃ paṭhamaṃ dentīti dā, asanti bhakkhantīti asā, datvā asā dāsā, sāmikānaṃ
analyzed: visesena ati gāvaḥ rattindivam asanti bhakkhanti visesena ati assāḥ gāvaḥ ca assā ca gavāssam  dātabbam paṭhamam denti iti dā asanti bhakkhanti iti asā da tvā asā dāsā sāmikānam
translated: They go with a distinction : cows . They are not absent, they eat with a distinction : horses . Cows and horses : cows and horses.

original: dātabbaṃ paṭhamaṃ datvā pacchā asanti bhakkhantīti attho. Sāmikehi vā dinnaṃ asanti
analyzed: dātabbam paṭhamam da tvā pacchā asanti bhakkhanti iti attho sāmikehi vā dinnam asanti
translated: She is to be given, she gives first : a slave . She is not absent, she eats : a slave . The meaning is: “She is to be given, she gives first, and afterwards she is not absent, she eats.” Or alternatively, she is a slave because she is given and she is not absent, she eats what is given by her masters.

original: bhakkhantīti dāsā, dukkhena kasirena asanti pavattantīti vā dāsā,. Mātāpitūnaṃ hadayaṃ🔽purentīti purisā, puraṃ hitaṃ vā isanti gavesantīti purisā. Buddhapaccekabuddhacakkavattibhāvaṃ
analyzed: bhakkhanti iti dāsāḥ dukkhena kasirena asanti pavattanti iti vā dāsāḥ mātā pitūnam hadayam  purenti iti purisāḥ puram hitam vā isanti gavesanti iti purisāḥ buddha paccekabuddha cakkavatti bhāvam
translated: She goes with difficulty, with hardship : a slave . She goes in front of mother and father : a man . The meaning is: “He goes in front, or he seeks, he looks for, what is beneficial.”

original: pureti kammanti puraṃ, kiṃ taṃ? Balavakammaṃ, puraṃ isanti sīlenāti vā purisā. Purisā
analyzed: purā iti puram kim tam balava kammam puram sīlena ati vā purisā purisā
translated: He goes in front by kamma : a man . What is that? Powerful kamma . Or alternatively, a man is so called because he seeks, he looks for, what is in front, i.e., virtue.

original: eva hi sammāsambuddhapaccekabuddhacakkavattibhāvaṃ gacchanti. “Puri uccaṭṭhāne sentīti
analyzed: eva hi sammāsambuddha paccekabuddha cakkavatti bhāvam gacchanti puri ucca ṭṭhāne senti iti
translated: For only men go forth to the states of a Perfectly Enlightened Buddha, a Paccekabuddha, and a Wheel-turning Monarch.🔽He sends in a high place : a man .

original: vā purisā. Purisā hi mātūnaṃ pituṭṭhāne ṭhitā”ti ime vacanatthā vuttappakārā yuttāyeva
analyzed: vā purisā purisāḥ hi mātūnam pitu ṭṭhāne ṭhitā ti ime vacana atthāḥ vutta ppakārāḥ yuttāya eva
translated: The meanings of the words are appropriate in this way because it is possible to take them to have that meaning.🔽“Slave and man” is a dvanda compound. The middle term is extended. And here

original: atthasambhavato. Dāsā ca purisā ca dāsaporisaṃ, majjhe vuddhi. Ettha ca dāsaggahaṇena🔽dāsīpi gahitā. Dāsā dukkaṭajanā, purisā sukhitajanāti viseso daṭṭhabbo. Ṭhanti patiṭṭhahanti🔽ettha mātugāme puttadhītāti thiyo. Narasaddassa viggahattho heṭṭhā vuttova.
analyzed: attha sambhavataḥ dāsā ca purisā ca dāsa porisam majjhe ettha ca dāsa ggahaṇena  dāsī pi gahitāḥ dāsāḥ dukkaṭa janā purisā sukhita janā ti visesaḥ daṭṭhabbo ṭhanti patiṭṭhahanti  ettha mātu gāme putta dhītā ati thiyaḥ nara saddassa viggaha atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ iva
translated: by the word “slave” a female slave is included. Slaves are people who are ill-treated; men are people who are happy. The distinction should be seen thus.

original: Ekadeso domanassasaṅkhāto ādīnavo idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ āgatoti ācariyena vibhatto, amhehi🔽ca ñāto, “dukkhasaṅkhāto ādīnavo kattha pāḷiyaṃ āgato”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha katamo🔽ādīnavo? Abalā naṃ balīyantī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Atha vā “tattha katamo ādīnavo? Abalā🔽naṃ balīyantī”tiādi kasmā evaṃ āraddhaṃ, nanu “tattha katamo ādīnavo? Tassa ce kāmayānassā”tiādinā
analyzed: eka desaḥ domanassa saṅkhātaḥ ādīnavaḥ idha pāḷi gāthāyam āgataḥ ti ācariyena vibhattaḥ amhehi 🔽ca ñātaḥ dukkha saṅkhātaḥ ādīnavaḥ kattha pāḷiyam āgataḥ ti pucchitabba ttā tattha katamo 🔽ādīnavaḥ abalāḥ nam balīyanti itiādi āraddham atha vā tattha katamaḥ ādīnavaḥ abalā 🔽nam balīyanti itiādi kasmai evam āraddham nanu tattha katamaḥ ādīnavaḥ tassa ce kāmayānassa ati ādinā
translated: They stand, they are established, in this, in the woman, in the mother, in the wife, in the daughter, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring, in the female relative, in the female friend, in the female companion, in the female kinsman, in the female blood-relative, in the female offspring, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring, in the female relative, in the female friend, in the female companion, in the female kinsman, in the female blood-relative, in the female offspring, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring, in the female relative, in the female friend, in the female companion, in the female kinsman, in the female blood-relative, in the female offspring, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring, in the female relative, in the female friend, in the female companion, in the female kinsman, in the female blood-relative, in the female offspring, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring, in the female relative, in the female friend, in the female companion, in the female kinsman, in the female blood-relative, in the female offspring, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring, in the female relative, in the female friend, in the female companion, in the female kinsman, in the female blood-relative, in the female offspring, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring, in the female relative, in the female friend, in the female companion, in the female kinsman, in the female blood-relative, in the female offspring, in the female slave, in the female worker, in the female servant, in the female offspring,

original: ādīnavo vibhattoti? Saccaṃ, ādīnavo pana bahuvidho dukkhadomanassādivasena, tasmiṃ
analyzed: ādīnavaḥ vibhatto ti saccam ādīnavaḥ pana bahuvidhaḥ dukkha domanassa ādi vasena tasmin
translated: Has the danger been analysed? —True, but the danger is of many kinds as suffering, grief, and so on.

original: bahuvidhe ādīnave ekadeso domanassasaṅkhāto ādīnavo pubbe vibhatto, idāni dukkhasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: bahuvidhe ādīnave eka desaḥ domanassa saṅkhātaḥ ādīnavaḥ pubbe vibhattaḥ idāni dukkha saṅkhātam
translated: In that many-sided danger, one aspect called grief has been analysed already. Now in order to analyse the danger called suffering,🔽the text is begun with the words, “Herein, what is danger? The weak are overpowered by the strong” .

original: ādīnavaṃ vibhajituṃ “tattha katamo ādīnavo? Abalā naṃ balīyantī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: ādīnavam vibhajitum tattha katamaḥ ādīnavaḥ abalāḥ nam balīyanti itiādi āraddham tattha
translated: Herein,🔽in the verse beginning, “The profitable and the unprofitable, the unprofitable and the profitable too” ,

original: tatthāti tassaṃ “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ niddiṭṭhesu dukkhadomanassādīsu ādīnavesu
analyzed: tattha ati tassam niddiṭṭhesu dukkha domanassa ādīsu ādīnavesu
translated: the danger is of many kinds as suffering, grief, and so on.

original: katamo ādīnavo tattha tesu pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷidhamme āgatoti pucchitvā –
analyzed: katamaḥ ādīnavaḥ tattha tesu pāḷi dhammesu kattha pāḷi dhamme āgato ti pucchitvā
translated: Which is the danger here in those terms of the text? Where in those terms of the text is the danger stated?

original: “Abalā naṃ balīyanti, maddantenaṃ parissayā;
analyzed: abalāḥ nam balīyanti maddantenam parissayā
translated: The weak are overpowered by the strong, And by defilements they are harmed.

original: Tato naṃ dukkhamanveti, nāvaṃ bhinnamivodaka”nti. –
analyzed: tatas nam dukkham anveti nāvam bhinnam iva udakanti
translated: Then suffering follows them, As water follows the descending bird.

original: Idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ yo dukkhasaṅkhāto ekadeso ādīnavo āgato, so ayaṃ dukkhasaṅkhāto ekadeso ādīnavo desanāhārassa visayoti.
analyzed: idha pāḷigāthā ayam yaḥ dukkha saṅkhātaḥ eka desaḥ ādīnavaḥ āgataḥ saḥ ayam dukkha saṅkhātaḥ eka desaḥ ādīnavaḥ desanā āhārassa visayaḥ ti
translated: Herein, the danger called suffering, which is one aspect of the danger stated in the verse of the text, is the province of the teacher’s instruction.

original: Gāthāyaṃ natthi balaṃ etesaṃ kilesānanti abalā. Kasmā kilesā abalā hontīti? Kusalehi
analyzed: natthi balam etesam kilesānanti abalā kasmā kilesāḥ abalāḥ honti iti kusalehi
translated: In the verse there is no strength in them, thus they are weak . Why are defilements weak?🔽Because they are to be abandoned by the wholesome .

original: pahātabbattā. Naranti khettādikāme anugijjhantaṃ naraṃ, saddhābalādivirahato vā abalaṃ
analyzed: pahātabba ttā khetta ādi kāme anugijjhantam naram saddhā bala ādi virahataḥ vā abalam
translated: Or, because of the absence of the strength of faith, etc., they are weak .

original: taṃ naraṃ balīyanti abhibhavanti. Kiñcāpi kilesā kusalehi pahātabbattā abalā honti,
analyzed: tam naram balīyanti abhibhavanti kiñca api kilesā kusalehi abalāḥ honti
translated: They overpower that weak man. Although defilements are weak because they are to be abandoned by the wholesome,

original: tathāpi kāmamanugijjhantaṃ saddhābalādivirahitaṃ abhibhavituṃ samatthā bhavanti.🔽Maddantenaṃ parissayāti kāmagiddhaṃ kāme pariyesantaṃ, kāmaṃ rakkhantañca enaṃ naraṃ
analyzed: tathā api saddhā bala ādi virahitam abhibhavitum samatthāḥ bhavanti  kāma giddham kāme pariyesantam kāmam rakkhantam ca enam naram
translated: nevertheless they are able to overpower him who is greedy for sensual pleasures and who is devoid of the strength of faith, etc.🔽While he is intoxicated, the dangers come upon him. While he is intoxicated with sensual pleasures, while he is seeking sensual pleasures, while he is guarding sensual pleasures,

original: pari samantato paripīḷetvā ayanti pavattantīti parissayā, sīhabyagghādayo ceva kāyaduccaritādayo
analyzed: pari samantataḥ paripīḍetvā ayanti pavattanti iti parissayā sīha byaggha ādayaḥ ca iva kāya duccarita ādayaḥ
translated: the dangers come upon him. Having afflicted him all around, they proceed. The dangers are lions, tigers, etc., and bodily misconduct, etc.

original: ca maddanti. Tato tehi parissayehi abhibhūtaṃ naṃ naraṃ jātiādidukkhaṃ anveti anugacchati.
analyzed: ca maddanti tatas tehi parissayehi abhibhūtam nam naram jāti ādi dukkham anveti anugacchati
translated: They intoxicate him. Then, being overcome by those dangers, birth, etc., follow him.

original: Kimiva anveti? Udakaṃ bhinnanāvaṃ anveti iva, evaṃ anvetīti attho.
analyzed: kim iva anveti udakam bhinna nāvam anveti iva evam anveti iti attho
translated: What do they follow? They follow him as the water follows the broken boat. This is the meaning.

original: Ekadesaṃ maggasaṅkhātaṃ nissaraṇaṃ idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ āgatanti ācariyena vibhattaṃ,
analyzed: eka desam magga saṅkhātam nissaraṇam idha pāḷigāthāyam āgatanti ācariyena vibhattam
translated: The teacher has analyzed the verse in the text as follows: “The escape called the path is found in the text.”

original: amheti ca viññātaṃ, “nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ ekadesaṃ nissaraṇaṃ kattha pāḷidhamme āgata”nti
analyzed: amhe ti ca viññātam nibbāna saṅkhātam eka desam nissaraṇam kattha pāḷi dhamme āgatam ti
translated: And he has indicated the escape called Nibbāna as follows: “Where is the escape called Nibbāna found in the text?”

original: pucchitabbattā “tattha katamaṃ nissaraṇaṃ? Tasmā jantu sadā sato”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: pucchitabba ttā tattha katamam nissaraṇam tasmā jantu sadā satā iti ādi āraddham
translated: The answer is given in the verse, “Therefore a man should ever be mindful.”

original: Atha vā “tattha katamaṃ nissaraṇaṃ? Tasmā jantu sadā sato”tiādi kasmā evaṃ āraddhaṃ,
analyzed: atha vā katamam nissaraṇam tasmai kasmai evam āraddham
translated: Or alternatively, why is the verse, “Therefore a man should ever be mindful,” etc., given?

original: nanu “tattha katamaṃ nissaraṇaṃ? Yo kāme parivajjetī”tiādinā nissaraṇaṃ vibhattanti?🔽Saccaṃ, nissaraṇaṃ pana duvidhaṃ magganibbānavasena, tattha duvidhe nissaraṇe maggasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: nanu tattha katamam nissaraṇam yaḥ kāme parivajjeti itiādinā nissaraṇam  saccam nissaraṇam pana duvidham magga nibbāna vasena tattha duvidhe nissaraṇe magga saṅkhātam
translated: Has not the escape been analyzed already in the verse, “Where one leaves contact with sense desires”?

original: nissaraṇaṃ pubbe vibhattaṃ, idāni nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ nissaraṇaṃ vibhajituṃ “tattha
analyzed: nissaraṇam pubbe vibhattam idāni nibbāna saṅkhātam nissaraṇam vibhajitum tattha
translated: It is true that it has, but the escape is twofold as path and Nibbāna. Of these, the escape called the path has been analyzed already. Now in order to analyze the escape called Nibbāna, the verse, “Therefore a man should ever be mindful,” etc., is given. Herein, there is the escape called the path in the verse, “Where one leaves contact with sense desires,” etc.;

original: katamaṃ nissaraṇaṃ? Tasmā jantu sadā sato”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ
analyzed: katamam nissaraṇam tasmā jantu sadā satā utiādi āraddham tattha tattha ati
translated: and there is the escape called Nibbāna in the verse, “Therefore a man should ever be mindful,” etc.

original: “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ niddiṭṭhesu magganibbānesu nissaraṇesu ekadesaṃ nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: assāda ādīnava tā ati ādi gāthāyam niddiṭṭhesu magga nibbānesu nissaraṇesu eka desam nibbāna saṅkhātam
translated: In the verse beginning “The pleasant and the painful” , the escape called Nibbāna is a part of the path and Nibbāna stated there.🔽When the question is asked, “Where in the texts is that escape stated?”

original: nissaraṇaṃ tattha tesu pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷidhamme āgatanti pucchitvā –
analyzed: nissaraṇam tattha tesu pāḷi dhammesu kattha pāḷi dhamme āgatanti pucchitvā
translated: the answer is:

original: “Tasmā jantu sadā sato, kāmāni parivajjaye;
analyzed: tasmai jantu sadā sataḥ kāmāni parivajjaye
translated: Therefore, ever mindful, let him shun Sensual desires;

original: Te pahāya tare oghaṃ, nāvaṃ sitvāva pāragū”ti. –
analyzed: te pahāya tare ogham nāvam sitvā ava pāragū iti
translated: Having shunned them, let him cross the flood, Like one who plucks a ripe fruit from the tree.

original: Idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ yaṃ nibbānasaṅkhātaṃ nissaraṇaṃ āgataṃ, idaṃ nissaraṇaṃ desanāhārassa visayanti.
analyzed: idha pāḷigāthāyam yam nibbāna saṅkhātam nissaraṇam āgatam idam nissaraṇam desanā āhārassa
translated: Here, the escape called Nibbāna stated in the verse is the province of the teacher’s instruction.

original: Gāthāyaṃ tasmāti yasmā kāmagiddhaṃ naraṃ dukkhaṃ anveti, tasmā jantu sadā sabbakāle🔽pubbarattāpararatte jāgariyānuyogena sato satisampanno hutvā kāmāni kilesakāme vikkhambhanavasena
analyzed: tasmā ati yasmā kāma giddham naram dukkham anveti tasmā jantu sadā sabba kāle  pubbaratta apararatte jāgariya anuyogena sataḥ sati sampannaḥ hutvā kāmāni kilesa kāme vikkhambhana vasena
translated: In the verse, “Therefore” means: since suffering follows a man who is infatuated with sensual desires, therefore, ever mindful, let him shun sensual desires.

original: vā samucchedavasena vā parivajjaye parijaheyya. Te kāme ariyamaggena pahāya catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: vā samuccheda vasena vā parijaheyya te kāme ariya maggena pahāya catubbidham
translated: Let him shun sensual desires, let him abandon them, by suppressing the defilements of sensual desires or by eradicating them. Having shunned them, having abandoned them, by means of the noble path, let him cross the flood, like one who plucks a ripe fruit from the tree.

original: oghaṃ tareyya tarituṃ sakkuṇeyya. Ko tarati iva tareyya? Nāvāsāmiko nāvaṃ yaṃ pavisantaṃ
analyzed: ogham tareyya taritum sakkuṇeyya kaḥ tarati iva tareyya nāvāsāmikaḥ nāvam yam pavisantam
translated: he would be able to cross the flood. Who crosses as if he were crossing? The owner of a boat who, when he enters the boat,

original: udakaṃ sitvā bahi siñcitvā lahukāya nāvāya appakasirena taritvā pāragū pāraṃ gacchati
analyzed: udakam sitvā bahi siñcitvā lahukāya nāvāya appaka sirena taritvā pāragū pāram gacchati
translated: having sprinkled the water outside, having made the boat light, crosses with little difficulty, and having gone to the other side,

original: iva, evaṃ attani pavattaṃ kilesūdakaṃ siñcitvā ariyamaggena nīharitvā lahukena attabhāvena
analyzed: iva evam attani pavattam kilesu udakam siñcitvā ariya maggena nīharitvā lahukena atta bhāvena
translated: goes to the further shore. In the same way, having sprinkled the water of defilements that arise in himself, having removed them by the noble path, with a light self,

original: anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā nibbānena pāraṃ nibbānaṃ santiṃ gaccheyyāti attho. Idaṃ
analyzed: anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyāḥ nibbānena pāram nibbānam santim gaccheyya attho idam
translated: he would go to the further shore, the peace of Nibbāna, by the extinction in the Nibbāna-element without residue left. This is the meaning.

original: nibbānaṃ kasmā nissaraṇaṃ hoti? Sabbasaṅkhatanissaraṇato nissaraṇaṃ nāma.
analyzed: nibbānam kasmā nissaraṇam hoti sabba saṅkhata nissaraṇataḥ nissaraṇam nāma
translated: Why is this Nibbāna an escape? It is an escape because it is an escape from all formations.

original: Idaṃ nissaraṇaṃ idha pāḷidhamme āgatanti ācariyena vibhattaṃ, amhehi ca viññātaṃ,
analyzed: idam nissaraṇam idha pāḷi dhamme āgatanti ācariyena vibhattam amhehi ca viññātam
translated: This escape is found in the text of the Dhamma here. It is explained by the teacher and known by us,

original: “katamaṃ phalaṃ kattha pāḷidhamme āgata”nti pucchitabbattā “tattha katamaṃ phalaṃ?
analyzed: katamam phalam kattha pāḷi dhamme āgatanti pucchitabba ttā tattha katamam phalam
translated: “What is the fruit? Where is it found in the text of the Dhamma?” because it must be asked. Therefore, “What is the fruit?

original: Dhammo have rakkhati dhammacāri”ntiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ
analyzed: dhammaḥ have rakkhati dhamma cārin ti ādi āraddham tattha tattha ati tassam
translated: The Dhamma protects the one who lives by the Dhamma” is begun. There, there means in that verse beginning “The pleasant and the unpleasant” .

original: niddiṭṭhesu rakkhananipphādanamaccutaraṇādīsu phalesu katamaṃ phalaṃ tattha tesu
analyzed: niddiṭṭhesu rakkhana nipphādana maccu taraṇa ādīsu phalesu katamam phalam tattha tesu
translated: What fruit is there among the fruits stated, namely, protection, production, crossing over the flood, and so on?

original: pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷidhamme āgatanti pucchitvā –
analyzed: pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷidhamme āgatanti pucchitvā
translated: And among the terms of the texts, where is the text that states it?

original: “Dhammo have rakkhati dhammacāriṃ, chattaṃ mahantaṃ yatha vassakāle;
analyzed: dhammaḥ have rakkhati dhamma cārim chattam mahantam vassa kāle
translated: “The Dhamma protects the one who lives by Dhamma Like a good umbrella in the rainy season.

original: Esānisaṃso dhamme suciṇṇe, na duggatiṃ gacchati dhammacārī”ti. –
analyzed: esa anisaṃsaḥ dhamme su ciṇṇe na duggatim gacchati dhamma cārī iti
translated: This is the advantage in the Dhamma well developed: The one who lives by Dhamma does not go to a bad destination” .

original: Idha pāḷigāthāyaṃ yaṃ anatthehi dhammassa rakkhanaphalaṃ āgataṃ, rakkhāvahanassa
analyzed: idha pāḷigāthāyam yam anatthehi dhammassa rakkhana phalam āgatam rakkhā vahanassa
translated: Herein, the fruit of protection that is stated by the text of the verse as protection from what is unprofitable,

original: abbhudayassa yañca nipphādanaṃ phalaṃ āgataṃ, idaṃ rakkhananipphādanaṃ phalaṃ desanāhārassa visayanti.🔽Gāthāyaṃ dhammoti yena puggalena yo dānādippabhedo puññadhammo nibbattito, so dhammo.
analyzed: abbhudayassa yat ca nipphādanam phalam āgatam idam rakkhana nipphādanam phalam desanā āhārassa  gāthā ayam dhammo ti yena puggalena yaḥ dāna ādi ppabhedaḥ puñña dhammo nibbattitaḥ so dhammo
translated: and the fruit of production that is stated as production of what is profitable, is the fruit of protection and production.🔽The text of the verse is the province of the teaching.🔽In the verse the word “Dhamma” is the profitable Dhamma consisting in giving, etc., produced by a person.

original: Dhammacāriṃ dhammanibbattakaṃ taṃ puggalaṃ anatthehi rakkhati. Kimiva? Vassakāle
analyzed: dhamma cārim dhamma nibbattakam tam puggalam anatthehi rakkhati kim iva vassa kāle
translated: That Dhamma protects the person who lives by Dhamma, that is, the person who produces the Dhamma, from what is unprofitable. Like what?🔽Like a good umbrella in the rainy season.

original: deve vassante sati mahantaṃ kusalena dhāretabbaṃ chattaṃ dhārentaṃ kusalaṃ taṃ janaṃ
analyzed: deve vassante sati mahantam kusalena dhāretabbam chattam dhārentam kusalam tam janam
translated: When it rains, it is good to hold up a well-made umbrella. It is good to protect a person who holds up a well-made umbrella from the rain.

original: vassatemanato rakkhati yathā, evaṃ rakkhitabbo dhammopi attasammāpaṇidhānena appamatto
analyzed: vassa temanataḥ rakkhati yathā evam rakkhitabbaḥ dhammaḥ api atta sammāpaṇidhānena appamattaḥ
translated: Just as it protects him from the rain, so too the Dhamma protects him who is heedful by right aspiration.

original: hutvā suṭṭhu dhammaṃ rakkhantaṃyeva rakkhati, tādiso dhammacārīyeva duggatiṃ na gacchati.
analyzed: hutvā suṭṭhu dhammam rakkhantaṃyeva rakkhati tādisaḥ dhamma cārīyā iva duggatim na gacchati
translated: It is only one who protects the Dhamma well by keeping it in being that is protected by the Dhamma, and such a one does not go to a state of suffering.

original: Eso ānisaṃso suciṇṇe suciṇṇassa dhamme dhammassa ānisaṃsoti attho.🔽Ekadesaṃ phalaṃ idha pāḷidhamme āgatanti ācariyena vibhattaṃ, amhehi ca ñātaṃ, “katamo🔽upāyo kattha pāḷiyaṃ āgato”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha katamo upāyo? Sabbe saṅkhārā🔽aniccā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ niddiṭṭhesu
analyzed: esaḥ ānisaṃsaḥ su ciṇṇe su ciṇṇassa dhamme dhammassa ānisaṃsaḥ ti attho  eka desam phalam idha pāḷi dhamme āgatanti ācariyena vibhattam amhehi ca ñātam katamaḥ  upāyaḥ kattha pāḷiyam āgataḥ ti pucchitabba ttā tattha katamaḥ upāyaḥ sabbe saṅkhārā  anicca atiādi āraddham tattha tattha ati niddiṭṭhesu
translated: This is the benefit in the Dhamma that is well kept in being. The meaning is: the benefit of the Dhamma that is well kept in being.

original: vipassanāpubbaṅgamanibbidādīsu upāyesu katamo upāyo tattha tesu pāḷidhammesu kattha
analyzed: vipassanā pubbaṅgama nibbida ādīsu upāyesu katamaḥ upāyaḥ tattha tesu pāḷi dhammesu kattha
translated: The teacher has analysed the fruit in part here in the text, and we have understood it. “What is the method? Where in the text is it found?”—because it has to be asked, “What is the method there? All formations are impermanent” is stated. Herein, in the case of the method in the various kinds of insight that begin with dispassion, which are demonstrated in the verse beginning, “The gratification, the danger, and the escape in the case of …” , what is the method there? Where in the text is it found?

original: pāḷidhamme āgatoti pucchitvā –🔽“Sabbe saṅkhārā ‘aniccā’ti…pe…;
analyzed: pāḷidhamme āgato ti pucchitvā  sabbe saṅkhārāḥ anicca atipe
translated: He has come to the text of the True Idea.

original: Sabbe dhammā ‘anattā’ti, yadā paññāya passatī”ti. –
analyzed: sabbe dhammā anattā ati yadā paññāya passati iti
translated: “All formations are impermanent, all formations are painful, all ideas are not self.” When he sees this with understanding,

original: Idha pāḷigāthāsu yo vipassanāpubbaṅgamanibbidāñāṇasaṅkhāto visuddhiyā adhigamahetubhāvato maggo āgato, ayaṃ upāyo desanāhārassa visayoti.
analyzed: idha pāḷi gāthāsu yaḥ vipassanā pubbaṅgama nibbidā ñāṇa saṅkhātaḥ visuddhiyāḥ adhigama hetu bhāvataḥ maggaḥ āgataḥ ayam upāyaḥ desanā āhārassa visayaḥ ti
translated: Herein, the path, which is the cause for the attainment of purification consisting in the knowledge of dispassion that has insight as its forerunner, has come in the text of the verse. This is the means for the subject of teaching, namely, the text of the verse.

original: Gāthāsu sabbe niravasesā kammacittotuāhārehi saṅkharitā saṅkhatasaṅkhārā hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena🔽aniccā iti yadā paññāya passati, atha anicce dukkhasabhāve nibbindati, eso vipassanāpubbaṅgamo
analyzed: gāthāsu sabbe niravasesā saṅkharitā saṅkhata saṅkhārā hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena  aniccā iti yadā paññāya passati atha anicce dukkha sabhāve nibbindati esaḥ vipassanā pubbaṅgamo
translated: All formations, which are formed by the formation of action and the formation of expression, are impermanent in the sense of non-existence.🔽When he sees this with understanding, then he becomes dispassionate towards what is impermanent and has the nature of suffering. This is the idea consisting in the knowledge of dispassion that has insight as its forerunner and is the path to purification.

original: nibbindanañāṇasaṅkhāto dhammo visuddhiyā maggoti. “Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā”tiādīsu
analyzed: nibbindana ñāṇa saṅkhātaḥ dhammaḥ visuddhiyā maggo ti sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā ti ādīsu
translated: In the passage beginning “All formations are impermanent”

original: saṅkhārānaṃ saṅkhatadhammabhāvo paccayākāravibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttova, taṃ vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhārānam saṅkhata dhamma bhāvo paccaya ākāra vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāyam vuttaḥ iva tam vibhaṅga ṭṭhakatham
translated: the formedness of formations is stated in the Vibhaṅga Commentary, which is quoted in the Paṭṭhāna Commentary.

original: anoloketvā ekacce ācariyā “vipassanāñāṇārammaṇattā tebhūmakadhammāyevā”ti vadanti,
analyzed: ekacce ācariyāḥ vipassanā ñāṇa ārammaṇa ttā tebhūmaka dhammāya iva ati vadanti
translated: Without looking at the Vibhaṅga Commentary, some teachers say that only ideas of the three planes are the object of insight knowledge.

original: evaṃ sati maggaphaladhammānaṃ niccādibhāvo bhaveyya, tasmā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathānurūpova
analyzed: evam sati magga phala dhammānam nicca ādi bhāvaḥ tasmā
translated: so the meaning should be understood in accordance with the Vibhaṅga commentary.

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Dukkhāti dukkhadukkhavipariṇāmadukkhasaṅkhāradukkhabhāvena dukkhā.
analyzed: atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ dukkhā ti dukkha dukkha vipariṇāma dukkha saṅkhāra dukkha bhāvena dukkhā
translated: Painful: painful in the sense of the pain of pain, the pain of change, and the pain of suffering adjoined to the aggregates.

original: Anattāti niccasārasukhasāraattasārarahitattā asārakaṭṭhena anattā, avasavattanaṭṭhena vā anattā.🔽Ekadeso upāyo idha pāḷidhamme āgatoti ācariyena vibhatto, amhehi ca ñāto, “katamā
analyzed: anattā ati nicca sāra sukha sāra atta sāra rahita ttā asāraka ṭṭhena anattā avasavattana ṭṭhena vā anattā  eka desaḥ upāyaḥ idha pāḷi dhamme āgato ti ācariyena vibhattaḥ amhehi ca ñāto katamā
translated: Not self: devoid of a self that is permanent, a self that is blissful, a self that is beautiful, and a self that exercises control, it is not self in the sense of being devoid of an inner essence, or it is not self in the sense of not being able to be made into what one wants.

original: āṇatti kattha pāḷidhamme āgatā”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha katamā āṇatti? Cakkhumā
analyzed: āṇatti kattha pāḷi dhamme āgatā ti pucchitabbattā tattha katamā āṇatti cakkhumā
translated: The method is partly given in the text of the sutta, and partly it has been pointed out by the teacher and is known to us. But since it is necessary to ask, “What is the incitement? Where is it given in the text? ” the passage beginning with the words, “Herein, what is the incitement? ‘With eye as with a mirror’ ” is stated.🔽Herein, here means in the verse quoted above, “The wise one should unhinge the door of Death by seeing the peril in the world of births” .

original: visamānīvā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tassaṃ “assādādīnavatā”tiādigāthāyaṃ niddiṭṭhāsu🔽pāpaduccaritaparivajjanāṇattikalyāṇasucaritacaraṇāṇattiādīsu katamāṇatti tattha tesu
analyzed: āraddham tattha tattha ati tassam niddiṭṭhāsu  pāpa duccarita parivajjana āṇatti kalyāṇa su carita caraṇa āṇatti ādīsu tattha tesu
translated: In the passage, “The wise one should unhinge the door of Death by seeing the peril in the world of births,” the incitement is given in the words, “The wise one should unhinge the door of Death by seeing the peril in the world of births.”🔽The method is given in the words, “By seeing the peril in the world of births.”

original: pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷidhamme āgatāti pucchitvā –
analyzed: pāḷidhammesu kattha pāḷidhamme āgatā ati pucchitvā
translated: Having asked, “What is the incitement? Where is it given in the text? ” the question, “Where is the method given in the text? ” must be asked.🔽“With eye as with a mirror,

original: “Cakkhumā visamānīva, vijjamāne parakkame;
analyzed: cakkhumā visamāni iva vijjamāne parakkame
translated: when there is opportunity,

original: Paṇḍito jīvalokasmiṃ, pāpāni parivajjaye”ti. –
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ jīva lokasmin pāpāni parivajjaya iti
translated: The wise man in the world of life Should shun all evil deeds.

original: Idha pāḷidhamme yā pāpaduccaritaparivajjanāṇatti āgatā, ayaṃ pāpaduccaritaparivajjanāṇatti desanāhārassa visayāti.
analyzed: idha pāḷi dhamme yā āgatā ayam desanā āhārassa
translated: Herein, the exhortation to shun evil conduct is stated in the text of the verse. This is the province of the teacher’s instruction.

original: Gāthāyaṃ cakkhumā puriso vijjamāne parakkame āvahitaṃ sarīraṃ āvahantova hutvā visamāni🔽bhūmippadesāni vā visame hatthiādayo vā parivajjeti iva, evaṃ jīvalokasmiṃ paṇḍito
analyzed: cakkhumā puriso vijjamāne parakkame āvahitam sarīram āvahantaḥ iva hutvā visamāni  bhūmi ppadesāni vā visame hatthi ādayaḥ vā parivajjeti iva evam jīva lokasmim paṇḍito
translated: In the verse, the man with eyes, when he has strength, should, as one who is carrying a load, avoid uneven

original: pāpāni lāmakāni duccaritāni parivajjeti. Āṇatti nāma āṇārahassa dhammarājassa bhagavato
analyzed: pāpāni lāmakāni duccaritāni parivajjeti āṇatti nāma āṇārahassa dhammarājassa bhagavato
translated: places in the ground or uneven elephants, etc. In the same way, the wise man in the world of life should avoid evil, bad, wrong conduct. An exhortation is the exhortation of the Blessed One, the King of the Dhamma, who is worthy of an exhortation.

original: āṇā, sā bahuvidhā, tasmā “kareyya kalyāṇa”ntiādigāthāyaṃ sucaritacaraṇā āṇatti.
analyzed: sā bahuvidhā su carita caraṇā
translated: It is of many kinds. Therefore, in the verse “He should do what is good” , the exhortation is to the practice of good conduct.

original: “Upetha saraṇaṃ buddhaṃ, dhammaṃ saṅghañca tādinaṃ;
analyzed: upetha saraṇam buddham dhammam saṅghañca tādinam
translated: “Go for refuge to the Buddha, To the Dhamma and the Saṅgha, too;

original: Samādiyatha sīlāni, taṃ vo atthāya hehitī”ti. –
analyzed: samādiyatha sīlāni tam vaḥ atthāya hehiti iti
translated: Take up the precepts, and that will be For your welfare and help.”

original: Ādīsu gāthāsu saraṇagamanāṇattisīlasamādānāṇattiādi āgatāti.
analyzed: ādīsu gāthāsu saraṇa gamana āṇatti sīla samādāna āṇatti ādi āgatā ati
translated: In the verses beginning with these words, the exhortation to go for refuge, the exhortation to undertake the precepts, and so on, are stated.

original: “Suññato lokaṃ avekkhassū”tiādi kasmā evaṃ āraddhaṃ, nanu “tattha katamaṃ phalaṃ?
analyzed: suññatas lokam avekkhassu iti ādi kasmai evam āraddham nanu tattha katamam phalam
translated: respectively, shown in the following? “Herein, what is the fruit?

original: Dhammo have”tiādinā, “tattha katamo upāyo? Sabbe saṅkhārā”tiādinā, “tattha katamā🔽āṇatti? Cakkhumā”tiādinā ca phalūpāyāṇattiyo vibhattāti? Saccaṃ, visuṃ visuṃ pana
analyzed: dhammaḥ have itiādinā tattha katamaḥ upāyaḥ sabbe saṅkhārā ati ādinā tattha katamā  āṇatti cakkhumā ti ādinā ca phala upāya āṇattiyaḥ vibhattā ati saccam visum visum pana
translated: Dhamma indeed” , etc.; “Herein, what is the means? All determinations” , etc.; “Herein, what is the urging? He who has eyes” , etc.?

original: suttesu āgatā phalūpāyāṇattiyo vibhattā, idāni ekato āgatā phalūpāyāṇattiyo vibhajituṃ🔽“suññato lokaṃ avekkhassū”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: suttesu āgatā phalu upāyāṇattiyaḥ vibhattā idāni ekatas āgatā phalu upāyāṇattiyaḥ vibhajitum  suññatas lokam avekkhassu iti ādi āraddham
translated: They are indeed shown in the various Threads, but they are shown here in order to show that the fruit, the means, and the urging,🔽which are given together in the Thread, are shown in the three terms “void”, “signless”, and “wishless”.

original: Tattha suññato lokaṃ avekkhassūti sabbampi saṅkhāralokaṃ attato suññoti avasavattitāsallakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: tattha suññataḥ lokam avekkhassu iti sabbam pi saṅkhāra lokam attataḥ suññaḥ ti avasa vatti tā sat lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: Herein, he should review the world as void : he should see that the whole world of determinations is void of self and what belongs to self, either by seeing the individual essence of voidness, which is the characteristic of unsubstantiality ,

original: vā tucchabhāvasamanupassanavasena vā passāti idaṃ bhagavato vacanaṃ vidhānabhāvato
analyzed: vā tuccha bhāva samanupassana vasena vā passāti idam bhagavataḥ vacanam vidhāna bhāvataḥ
translated: or by seeing the state of voidness, which is the mere presence of what is not there. This is the Blessed One’s speech as an urging in the sense of an injunction.

original: āṇatti nāma. Niccasārasukhasāraattasārādirahitattā “mogharājā”ti ālapati, saddhāsīlasutacāgādirahitattā vā mogho.
analyzed: nāma nicca sāra sukha sāra atta sāra ādi rahita ttā ālapati saddhā sīla suta cāga ādi rahita ttā vā
translated: He addresses him as “Mogha” because he is devoid of permanence, lastingness, health, and self, or because he is devoid of faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

original: “Sadā sato”ti puggalavasena vuttāya satiyā suññatādassanassa sampajānahetubhāvato satiyeva upāyo, na satimāti ettha satīti adhippāyo.🔽Attānudiṭṭhiṃ ūhaccāti ettha attānudiṭṭhi nāma “rūpaṃ attā, rūpavā attā, rūpasmiṃ
analyzed: sadā satoti puggala vasena vuttāya satiyā suñña tā dassanassa sampajāna hetu bhāvato satiyā iva upāyaḥ na satimā ati ettha satī iti adhippāyaḥ  attā anudiṭṭhim ettha attā anudiṭṭhi nāma rūpam attā rūpavā attā rūpasmin
translated: “The means is mindfulness” : the intention is that mindfulness is the means, not the sati itself, since mindfulness, stated as “mindfulness” in the sense of the person, is the cause for the clear comprehension of the seeing of voidness.

original: attā, attani rūpa”ntiādippakārā vīsativatthukā diṭṭhi. Maggena ūhacca samucchinditvā🔽evaṃ vuttavidhinā maccutaro maccuno visayātikkanto siyā bhaveyya. Ettha yaṃ maccuvisayaṃ🔽taraṇaṃ atikkamanaṃ, tassa atikkamanassa yañca pubbabhāgapaṭipadāsampajjanaṃ, idaṃ
analyzed: vīsati vatthukā  evam vutta vidhinā maccutaraḥ maccunaḥ visaya atikkanto siyā bhaveyya ettha yam maccu visayam  taraṇam atikkamanam tassa atikkamanassa yat ca pubbabhāga paṭipadā sampajjanam idam
translated: “Having shaken off the view of self” : the view of self is the twenty-fold view of self in the modes of “form is self,” “self possesses form,” “in form is self,” “self is in form,” etc. Having shaken off, having cut off, by the path,

original: bhagavato desanāya phalaṃ desanāhārassa visayanti adhippāyo. Pubbe visuṃ visuṃ phalūpāyāṇattiyo vibhattāpi –
analyzed: bhagavataḥ desanāya phalam desanā āhārassa adhippāyo pubbe visum visum phala upāya āṇattiyaḥ
translated: in the manner stated, one would be one who has crossed over death, who has gone beyond the range of Death. Herein, the intention is that the crossing over, the going beyond, the range of Death, and the attainment of the preliminary path, are the fruit of the Blessed One’s teaching, the range of the teaching’s nutriment. Although the means to the fruit were previously stated separately,

original: “Suññato lokaṃ avekkhassu, mogharāja sadā sato;
analyzed: suññatas lokam avekkhassu mogha rāja sadā sataḥ
translated: “Contemplate the world as void, Mogharaja, always mindful;

original: Attānudiṭṭhiṃ ūhacca, evaṃ maccutaro siyā”ti. –
analyzed: attā anudiṭṭhim ūhat ca evam maccutaraḥ siyāti
translated: Having shaken off the view of self, thus you will cross over death.”

original: Ekagāthāyaṃ puna ekato vibhajanato phalādīsu ekato dassitesu sabbattha suttesu vā
analyzed: eka gāthāyam puna ekatas vibhajanataḥ phala ādīsu ekatas dassitesu sabbattha suttesu vā
translated: And in the case of the verse, when the fruits, etc., are shown together, they should be shown in all the suttas shown together,
