original: avatvā sote anāmasitvā saṃvarapidhānānaṃ vasena “savanti sabbadhi sotā”tiādimhi “dve🔽pañhā”ti vuttā. Tadanusārena “kenassu nivuto loko”tiādimhipi lokaṃ anāmasitvā nīvaraṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: avatvā sote an āmasitvā saṃvara pidhānānam vasena savanti sabbadhi sota ati ādimhi dve  pañhā ti vuttā tad anusārena lokaḥ ti ādimhi pi lokam an āmasitvā nīvaraṇa ādīnam
translated: without mentioning the streams, he said: “Two questions” in the passage beginning, “The streams flow everywhere,” by way of the restraint and the covering.🔽In the same way, in the passage beginning, “By what is the world covered? “ he showed the method of exposition by saying: “Four questions” by way of the four hindrances, etc., without mentioning the world.

original: catunnaṃ vasena “cattāro pañhā”tipi vattabbāti ayaṃ nayo dassitoti nayadassanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Desanākāle vuttadhammassa anusandhimaggahetvā attanā racitaniyāmeneva pucchitapañhassa
analyzed: catunnam vasena cattāro pañhā atipi vattabbā ti ayam nayaḥ dassito ti naya dassanam daṭṭhabbam  desanā kāle vutta dhammassa anusandhi magga hetvā attanā racita niyāmena iva pucchita pañhassa
translated: The method of exposition should be understood as the showing of the method in this way.🔽The teacher has analyzed the exposition of the question asked by way of the method of composition of the teacher himself, without taking up the question and without giving an answer, at the time of the teaching.

original: ceva pañhaṃ aṭṭhapetvā, paṭiññañca akatvā vissajjanassa ca vicayahāro ācariyena vibhatto,🔽amhehi ca ñāto, “desanākāle vuttadhammassa anusandhiṃ gahetvā pucchitapañhassa ceva
analyzed: ca iva pañham aṭṭhapetvā paṭiññam ca a katvā vissajjanassa ca vicaya hāraḥ ācariyena vibhattaḥ  amhehi ca ñātaḥ desanā kāle vutta dhammassa anusandhim gahetvā pucchita pañhassa ca iva
translated: And it has been understood by us. The exposition of the answer,🔽after taking up the question asked by way of the continuity of the teaching given at the time of the teaching,

original: taṃ pañhaṃ ṭhapetvā, paṭiññañca katvā vissajjanassa ca yo vicayo hāro vibhatto, so
analyzed: tam pañham ṭhapetvā paṭiññam ca katvā vissajjanassa ca yaḥ vicayaḥ hāraḥ vibhattaḥ saḥ
translated: after taking up the question and giving an answer,🔽has been analyzed by the teacher.

original: vicayahāro kathaṃ amhehi viññāyati, amhākaṃ viññāpanatthāya tasmiṃ vicayaṃ vibhajethā”ti
analyzed: vicaya hāro katham amhehi viññāyati amhākam viññāpana tthāya tasmin vicayam vibhajetha ati
translated: How is the mode of Conveying an Investigation to be known by us? Please analyse that mode of Conveying an Investigation for the purpose of our knowing it.”

original: vattabbabhāvato tesu vicetabbākāraṃ dassento “yāni sotānī”tiādigāthāya vicayākāradassanānantaraṃ
analyzed: vattabba bhāvataḥ tesu vicetabba ākāram dassento yāni sotāni iti ādi gāthāya vicaya ākāra dassana anantaram
translated: As to the question “How is the mode of Conveying an Investigation to be known by us? Please analyse that mode of Conveying an Investigation for the purpose of our knowing it”, the Blessed One, after showing the mode of Conveying an Investigation in the verse beginning with the words “The ear is the cause” ,

original: “paññā ceva sati cā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: paññā ca iva sati ca ati ādim āha
translated: said the verse beginning with the words “Wisdom and mindfulness” .

original: Tattha gāthāttho tāva viññātabbo – yāya paññāya anusayappahānena sotanirujjhanaṃ
analyzed: tattha gāthā attho tāva viññātabbo yāya paññāya anusaya ppahānena sota nirujjhanam
translated: Herein, the meaning of the verse should be known in the first place as follows: By what wisdom the cessation of the ear is stated with the abandoning of inherent tendency,

original: vuttaṃ, yāya satiyā ca pariyuṭṭhānappahānena sotanirujjhanaṃ vuttaṃ, sāyaṃ paññā
analyzed: vuttam yāya satiyā ca pariyuṭṭhāna ppahānena sota nirujjhanam vuttam sāyam paññā
translated: and by what mindfulness the cessation of the ear is stated with the abandoning of obsession, that is wisdom

original: ceva sāyaṃ sati ca tāhi paññāsatīhi asesaṃ sahuppannaṃ nāmañceva rūpañca, etaṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: ca iva sāyam sati ca tāhi paññā satīhi asesam sahuppannam nāman ca iva rūpan ca etam sabbam
translated: and that is mindfulness. By those wisdom and mindfulness all that is present, namely, the name and the form,

original: kattha nirujjhamāne asesaṃ uparujjhatīti mārisa me mayā puṭṭho tvaṃ bhagavā mayhaṃ
analyzed: kattha nirujjhamāne asesam uparujjhati iti mārisa me mayā puṭṭhaḥ tvam bhagavā mayham
translated: cease without remainder. Where do they cease without remainder? O Lord, I ask you this.

original: etaṃ nirujjhanaṃ pabrūhi, iti āyasmā ajito bhagavantaṃ pucchati.
analyzed: etam nirujjhanam pabrūhi iti āyasmai ajitaḥ bhagavantam pucchati
translated: Please tell me that cessation.” Thus the venerable Ajita asks the Blessed One.

original: Ajita tvaṃ yametaṃ pañhaṃ pucchitaṃ nirujjhanaṃ maṃ apucchi, ahaṃ te tava taṃ nirujjhanaṃ
analyzed: ajita tvam yam etam pañham pucchitam nirujjhanam mam apucchi aham te tava tam nirujjhanam
translated: “Ajita, the question you have asked me, asking ‘Where does cessation come about?’, I tell you that

original: vadāmi. Yattha viññāṇanirodhe paññāsatisahitaṃ nāmañca rūpañca viññāṇassa nirodhena
analyzed: vadāmi yattha viññāṇa nirodhe paññā sati sahitam nāmañca rūpañca viññāṇassa nirodhena
translated: where there is cessation of consciousness, name-and-form together with the fifty mental concomitants cease together with the cessation of consciousness,

original: saha ekato asesaṃ uparujjhati, ettha viññāṇanirodhe etaṃ sabbaṃ viññāṇanirodhena🔽ekato ekakkhaṇe apubbaṃ acarimaṃ uparujjhati, etaṃ viññāṇanirodhaṃ tassa nāmarūpassa
analyzed: saha ekatas asesam uparujjhati ettha viññāṇa nirodhe etam sabbam viññāṇa nirodhena  ekatas eka khaṇe apubbam acarimam uparujjhati etam viññāṇa nirodham tassa nāma rūpassa
translated: all this ceases together with the cessation of consciousness.🔽This cessation of consciousness does not go beyond the cessation of that name-and-form,

original: nirodho nātivattati, taṃ taṃ nāmarūpanirodhaṃ so so viññāṇanirodho nātivattatīti.
analyzed: nirodhaḥ na ativattati tam tam nāma rūpa nirodham saḥ saḥ viññāṇa nirodhaḥ na ativattati iti
translated: and the cessation of that name-and-form does not go beyond the cessation of consciousness.”

original: “Tasmiṃ pañhe ayaṃ ajito kiṃ pucchati? Uparujjhanameva pucchati, udāhu aññaṃ pucchatī”ti
analyzed: tasmin pañhe ayam ajitaḥ kim pucchati uparujjhanam eva pucchati udāhu aññam pucchati iti
translated: “What does this Ajita ask in this question? Does he ask about cessation, or does he ask about something else?”

original: vattabbato “ayaṃ pañhe anusandhiṃ pucchatī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ayanti yo āyasmā
analyzed: vattabbataḥ ayam pañhe anusandhim pucchati itiādi vuttam tattha ayanti yaḥ
translated: Because it is necessary to say this, it is said: “This is a question about the connection in the question.” Here, the venerable

original: ajito pañhaṃ apucchīti ayaṃ ajito. Pañheti “paññā ceva sati cā”tiādipañhe. Yadi anusandhiṃ
analyzed: ajitaḥ pañham apucchi iti ayam ajitaḥ pañhā iti paññā ca iva sati ca ati ādi pañhe yadi anusandhim
translated: Ajita is the one who asked the question. The question is the question beginning, “What is wisdom? What is mindfulness?” If the connection🔽is asked about,

original: pucchati, evaṃ sati “katthetaṃ uparujjhatī”ti pucchanaṃ ayuttaṃ bhaveyyāti? Na, anusandhīyati🔽etena upanirujjhanenāti anusandhīti atthasambhavato. Tena vuttaṃ “anusandhiṃ pucchanto
analyzed: pucchati evam sati katthā itam uparujjhati iti pucchanam ayuttam bhaveyyāti na anusandhīyati  etena upanirujjhanena ati anusandhi iti attha sambhavataḥ tena vuttam anusandhim pucchantaḥ
translated: It is not inappropriate, because the questioner is concerned with the cessation of the process.🔽The questioner is concerned with the cessation of the process, because he is concerned with the cessation of the process that is referred to in the question.

original: kiṃ…pe… nibbānadhātu”nti. Anusandhipucchanena anupādisesanibbānadhātuyāpi pucchanato🔽“katthetaṃ uparujjhatī”ti pucchanaṃ yuttameva.
analyzed: nibbānadhātunti anusandhi pucchanena anupādisesa nibbānadhātuyā api pucchanato  katthā itam uparujjhati iti pucchanam yuttam eva
translated: Therefore the question, “Where does it finally cease?” is appropriate.🔽Since the questioner is concerned with the attainment of the state of Nibbana without residue left,

original: “Yā anupādisesanibbānadhātu pucchitā, taṃ katamāya paṭipadāya adhigacchatī”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: yā anupādisesa nibbāna dhātu pucchitā tam katamāya paṭipadāya adhigacchati iti pucchitabba ttā
translated: he asks, “By what way does one reach the Nibbana element without residue left?”

original: catusaccakammaṭṭhānabhāvanāsaṅkhātaṃ paṭipadaṃ visayena saha dassetuṃ “tīṇī saccānī”tiādi
analyzed: catu sacca kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanā saṅkhātam paṭipadam visayena saha dassetum tīṇi saccāni itiādi
translated: In order to show the way, which is the development of the meditation subject consisting of the Four Noble Truths, together with its object, the Exalted One said, “Three truths and a truth.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha saṅkhatānīti kammādipaccayehi samecca sambhūya dukkhādīni karīyantīti
analyzed: vuttam tattha saṅkhatāni iti kamma ādi paccayehi sametca sambhūya dukkha ādīni karīyanti iti
translated: Herein, the truths are called “conditioned” because they are made by the conditions of kamma, etc., and because they are made by being brought together and made to arise.

original: saṅkhatāni. Nirodhadhammānīti nirujjhanaṃ nirodho, dhammopi nirodhadhammova, tasmā
analyzed: saṅkhatāni nirodha dhammāni iti nirujjhanam nirodhaḥ dhammaḥ api nirodha dhammaḥ u tasmā
translated: The truth of cessation is called “the truth of cessation” because it is the cessation of suffering.

original: nirodho dhammo sabhāvo yesaṃ dukkhādīnanti nirodhadhammānīti atthova gahetabbo. Tāni
analyzed: nirodhaḥ dhammo sabhāvaḥ yesam dukkha ādīnam ti nirodha dhammāni iti atthaḥ uva gahetabbaḥ tāni
translated: The meaning of the words “cessation-idea” is to be taken as follows: “Those ideas which have cessation as their nature, i.e. suffering, etc.”

original: tīṇi saccāni sarūpato dassetuṃ “dukkhaṃ samudayo maggo”ti vuttaṃ. Tīṇi dukkhasamudayamaggasaccāni🔽saṅkhatānīti vuttāni, “kiṃ nirodhasacca”nti pucchitabbattā “nirodho asaṅkhato”ti
analyzed: tīṇi saccāni sarūpataḥ dassetum dukkham samudayaḥ maggo ti vuttam tīṇi dukkha samudaya magga saccāni  saṅkhatāni iti vuttāni kim nirodha saccanti pucchitabba ttā nirodhaḥ asaṅkhataḥ ti
translated: The three truths are stated in the words “Suffering, origin, path” in order to show them in their individual characteristics. The three truths of suffering, origin, and path🔽are stated in the words “are formed” . The truth of cessation is stated in the words “Cessation is unformed”

original: vuttaṃ. Idha “nirodhadhammo”tipi vattabbaṃ. Kammādipaccayehi asaṅkhatattā asaṅkhato.
analyzed: vuttam idha nirodha dhammaḥ ti pi vattabbam kamma ādi paccayehi asaṅkhata ttā asaṅkhato
translated: in order to answer the question “What is the truth of cessation?” Here it could also be said “cessation-idea” . It is unformed because it is not formed by such conditions as kamma.

original: Uppādanirodhābhāvato anirodhadhammo. “Pahāyakapahātabbesu saccesu katamena pahāyakena🔽katamo pahātabbo, katamāya bhūmiyā pahīno”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha samudayo dvīsu🔽bhūmīsū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha dvīsu bhūmīsūti dassanabhāvanābhūmīsu. Kāmacchandoti
analyzed: uppāda nirodha abhāvataḥ anirodha dhammaḥ pahāyaka pahātabbesu saccesu katamena pahāyakena  katamaḥ pahātabbaḥ katamāya bhūmiyā pahīno ti pucchitabba ttā tattha samudayaḥ dvīsu  bhūmīsu utiādi vuttam tattha dvīsu bhūmīsu iti dassana bhāvanā bhūmīsu kāmacchandaḥ ti
translated: It is not an idea of cessation because it has no arising and cessation.🔽In the case of the truths that are abandoners and the truths that are abandoned, it is necessary to ask: “By which abandoner is which truth abandoned? On what plane is it abandoned?” Therefore it is said: “Herein, origin is on two planes” , and so on. Herein, on two planes: on the plane of seeing and on the plane of development. Lust for sensual desires:

original: kāmabhavarāgo. Rūparāgoti rūpabhavarāgo. Arūparāgoti arūpabhavarāgo. Saṃyojanabhedato
analyzed: kāma bhava rāgaḥ rūpa rāgaḥ iti rūpa bhava rāgaḥ a rūpa rāgaḥ iti a rūpa bhava rāgaḥ saṃyojana bhedataḥ
translated: lust for the sensual desires of the fine-material and immaterial-sphere existences. Fetters:

original: dasa saṃyojanāni pahīyantīti yojanā.
analyzed: dasa saṃyojanāni pahīyanti iti yojanā
translated: The ten fetters are abandoned.

original: 12. Pahātabbasaṃyojanāni dassanabhūmibhāvanābhūmibhedena vibhattāni, amhehipi ñātāni,
analyzed: pahātabba saṃyojanāni dassana bhūmi bhāvanā bhūmi bhedena vibhattāni amhehi pi ñātāni
translated: The fetters to be abandoned have been explained by way of the plane of seeing and the plane of development. They are known to us.

original: “indriyabhedato kathaṃ vibhattānī”ti vattabbabhāvato “tattha tīṇī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Atha
analyzed: indriya bhedataḥ katham vibhattāni iti vattabba bhāvataḥ tattha tīṇi itiādi vuttam atha
translated: “But how are they explained by way of the faculties?”

original: vā “pahātabbasaṃyojanesu katamāni saṃyojanāni katamaṃ indriyaṃ attano pahāyakaṃ katvā
analyzed: vā pahātabba saṃyojanesu katamāni saṃyojanāni katamam indriyam attanaḥ pahāyakam katvā
translated: Or alternatively, among the fetters to be abandoned, which fetters are abandoned by which faculty, making that faculty its own abandoner?🔽Therefore it is said: “Herein, three are abandoned by two.”

original: nirujjhantī”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha tīṇī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Adhiṭṭhāya attano pahāyakaṃ🔽katvā nirujjhanti anuppādavasena. “Anaññātaññassāmītindriyañca aññindriyañca saṃyojanānaṃ
analyzed: nirujjhanti iti pucchitabbattā tattha tīṇi itiādi vuttam adhiṭṭhāya attanaḥ pahāyakam  katvā nirujjhanti an uppāda vasena an aññātaññassāmi iti indriyam ca aññ indriyam ca saṃyojana
translated: They are abandoned by way of non-arising, making that faculty its own abandoner.🔽The faculty of final knowledge and the faculty of the state of having final knowledge are the cause for the cessation of the fetters.

original: nirujjhanahetu hotu, aññātāvindriyaṃ kissa hetū”ti pucchitabbattā “yaṃ panā”tiādi
analyzed: nirujjhana hetu hotu aññātāvindriyam kissa hetu uti pucchitabbattā yam pana atiādi
translated: But what is the cause for the faculty of final knowledge? Therefore it is said: “But that which is the cause for the faculty of final knowledge.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha yaṃ yena aññātāvindriyena arahā “me jāti khīṇā”ti evaṃ jānāti, idaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tattha yam yena aññātāvindriyena arahā me jāti evam jānāti idam
translated: Herein, that which is the faculty of final knowledge by which the arahat knows thus: “My birth is destroyed,”

original: jānanahetu aññātāvindriyaṃ khaye jātikkhaye arahattaphale pavattaṃ ñāṇaṃ. Yaṃ yena
analyzed: jānana hetu aññātau indriyam khaye jāti khaye arahatta phale pavattam ñāṇam yam yena
translated: The knowledge that occurs in the destruction of birth, in the fruition of Arahantship, is the cause for the arising of the final-knowledge faculty.

original: aññātāvindriyena arahā “itthattāya aparaṃ na bhavissāmī”ti pajānāti, idaṃ pajānanahetu
analyzed: aññātāvindriyena arahā itthattāya aparam na bhavissāmi iti pajānāti idam pajānana hetu
translated: The final-knowledge faculty is the cause for the arising of the knowledge by which the Arahant knows: “Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.”

original: aññātāvindriyaṃ. Anuppāde pana anuppajjane arahattaphale pavattaṃ ñāṇaṃ aññātāvindriyaṃ
analyzed: aññātau indriyam anuppāde pana anuppajjane arahatta phale pavattam ñāṇam aññātau indriyam
translated: But the knowledge that occurs in the non-arising of the unarisen fruition of Arahantship is the cause for the arising of the final-knowledge faculty.

original: jānanahetu hotīti vuttaṃ hoti. Indriyañāṇāni pahāyakāni katvā saṃyojanāni nirujjhanti,
analyzed: jānana hetu hoti iti vuttam hoti indriya ñāṇāni pahāyakāni katvā saṃyojanāni nirujjhanti
translated: The knowledge of the faculties causes the fetters to cease by abandoning them.

original: “tāni ñāṇāni kadā nirujjhantī”ti vattabbabhāvato “tattha yañcā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tāni ñāṇāni kadā nirujjhanti iti vattabba bhāvato tattha yat ca itiādi vuttam
translated: Since it is necessary to say “When do these knowledges cease?” the text says, “Herein, that which is in the destruction … .”

original: “Anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ aññindriyaṃ pāpuṇantassa nirujjhatu, aññindriyaṃ arahattaṃ🔽pāpuṇantassa nirujjhatu, aññātāvindriyaṃ kadā nirujjhatī”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha
analyzed: an aññā ataññassa ami itindriyam aññindriyam pāpuṇantassa nirujjhatu aññindriyam arahattam  pāpuṇantassa nirujjhatu aññātāvindriyam kadā nirujjhati iti pucchitabbattā tattha
translated: “May the faculty ‘I am a knower’ cease when one reaches the faculty of final knowledge; may the faculty of final knowledge cease when one reaches Arahantship;

original: yañca khaye”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha dveti kiccabhedena dve, sabhāvato pana ekāva.
analyzed: yat ca khaya itiādi vuttam tattha dve iti kicca bhedena dve sabhāvato pana ekā ava
translated: when does the final-knowledge faculty cease?” Since it is necessary to ask this, the text says, “Herein, that which is in the destruction … .” Herein, two means two by way of function, but in reality it is one only.

original: “Pajānanakiccampi ekameva, kathaṃ dve siyu”nti vattabbattā “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ārammaṇapaññābhedena🔽dve nāmāni labbhantīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sāti yā paññā pubbagāthāyaṃ sotapidhānakiccena
analyzed: pajānana kiccam pi ekam eva katham dve siyun ti vattabbattā api ca ātiādi vuttam ārammaṇa paññā bhedena  dve nāmāni labbhanti iti vuttam hoti sā ati yā paññā pubbagāthāyam sota pidhāna kiccena
translated: “But how can there be two kinds of knowledge when the function is one only?” In order to answer this question, he said, “Besides, the knowledge of the meaning of the text is also twofold.”🔽What is meant is that it is given two names according to the distinction of the knowledge of the text and the knowledge of the meaning. The knowledge of the text is the knowledge of the text of the sutta, etc., which is the means of access to the knowledge of the meaning.🔽

original: vuttā, sā paññā pakārehi jānanasabhāvena paññā nāma. Yathādiṭṭhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ apilāpanaṭṭhena🔽ogāhanaṭṭhena sati nāma.🔽13. “Paññā ceva sati cā”ti padassa attho ācariyena vibhatto, amhehi ca ñāto, “nāmarūpañcā’ti🔽padassa attho kathaṃ amhehi ñātabbo”ti vattabbattā nāmarūpaṃ vibhajanto “tattha ye
analyzed: vuttā sā paññā pakārehi jānana sabhāvena paññā nāma yathādiṭṭham ārammaṇam apilāpana ṭṭhena  ogāhana ṭṭhena sati nāma  paññā ca iva sati ca ati padassa attho ācariyena vibhattaḥ amhehi ca ñātaḥ nāma rūpam ca ati  padassa atthaḥ katham amhehi ñātabbaḥ iti vattabba ttā nāma rūpam vibhajantaḥ tattha ye
translated: “But if the function is one only, how can there be two? ”—in order to answer this question, he said “Moreover” , etc. What is meant is that the two names are obtained by way of the classification of understanding according to its object. The word “she” refers to the understanding stated in the first stanza by the words “the function of the ear-cover” . That understanding is called “understanding” in the sense of the nature of knowing by way of the aspects .🔽It is called “mindfulness” in the sense of the nature of not floating on the surface of the object as it has been seen, and in the sense of the nature of diving into the object.

original: pañcupādānakkhandhā”tiādimāha. Tattha tatthāti kammavipākavaṭṭabhede bhavattaye.
analyzed: pañca upādāna khandhā ti ādim āha tattha tattha iti kamma vipāka vaṭṭa bhede bhavattaye
translated: The meaning of the words “understanding and mindfulness” has been analyzed by the teacher and is known to us. But how is the meaning of the words “mind and bodily form” to be known to us? —in order to answer this question, he said “Herein, the five aggregates as objects of clinging” , etc. Herein, there means in the three kinds of existence, which are classified as the round of kamma and result .

original: Tatthāti pañcupādānakkhandhasaṅkhātanāmarūpasamudāye. Pañcindriyānīti cakkhādipañcindriyāni.
analyzed: tattha ati pañca upādāna kkhandha saṅkhāta nāma rūpa samudāye pañca indriyāni iti cakkha ādi pañca indriyāni
translated: There means in the collection of mind and bodily form, which is called the five aggregates as objects of clinging. The five faculties means the five faculties beginning with the eye.

original: Viññāṇasampayuttanti sampayuttapaccayattaṃ sandhāya na vuttaṃ, pacurajanassa pana🔽avibhajitvā gahaṇīyasabhāvamattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Vibhāgaṃ jānantehi pana “nāmaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇa sampayuttan ti sampayutta paccaya ttam sandhāya na vuttam pacurajanassa pana  a vibhajitvā gahaṇīya sabhāva mattam sandhāya vuttam vibhāgam jānantehi pana nāmam
translated: “ Associated with consciousness” is not said with reference to the association condition, but with reference to the mere fact that it is to be apprehended without distinction by ordinary people.

original: viññāṇasampayuttaṃ, rūpaṃ pana na viññāṇasampayuttaṃ, sahajāta”nti vibhajitvā gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: viññāṇa sampayuttam rūpam pana na viññāṇa sampayuttam sahajātam ti vibhajitvā gahetabbam
translated: But those who know the distinction should apprehend it thus: “The mental factors are associated with consciousness, but the materiality is not associated with consciousness; it is co-nascent.”

original: Tassāti paññāsatisahitassa nāmarūpassa. Nirodhanti anupādisesanibbānadhātuṃ.
analyzed: tassa ti paññā sati sahitassa nāma rūpassa nirodham ti anupādisesa nibbāna dhātum
translated: “Its” stands for the mentality-materiality accompanied by the fifty mental factors. “Cessation” is the Nibbāna element without residue left.🔽When he asks the Blessed One, the venerable Ajita says in the Pārāyana:

original: Bhagavantaṃ pucchanto āyasmā ajito “paññā ceva…pe… katthetaṃ uparujjhatī”ti evaṃ🔽pārāyane āha. “Paññā cevātiādigāthāya yā anupādisesanibbānadhātu pucchitā, sā anupādisesanibbānadhātu
analyzed: bhagavantam pucchantaḥ āyasmai ajito paññā kattha itam uparujjhati iti evam  pārāyane āha paññā ca iva ati ādi gāthāya yā anupādisesa nibbāna dhātu pucchitā sā anupādisesa nibbāna dhātu
translated: “When wisdom and the things that are the field of wisdom,🔽The question is asked: “By what kind of attainment is the Nibbāna element without residue left to be reached, which is asked about in the stanza beginning, ‘When wisdom and the things that are the field of wisdom’?”

original: katamena adhigamena pattabbā”ti pucchitabbattā caturiddhipādamukhena ariyamaggādhigamamukhena
analyzed: katamena adhigamena pattabbā ati pucchitabba ttā catur iddhipāda mukhena ariya magga adhigama mukhena
translated: It is to be reached by the attainment of the noble path, which is headed by the four bases for success.

original: pattabbā, caturiddhipādabhāvanāya ca cattārindriyāni mūlabhūtāni, tasmā mūlabhūtāni
analyzed: pattabbā catur iddhipāda bhāvanāya ca cattāri indriyāni mūla bhūtāni tasmā mūla bhūtāni
translated: And the four roads to power are the roots of the four roads to power. Therefore the four roads to power are the roots of the four bases for success.

original: tāni cattārindriyāni niddhāretvā dassento “tattha sati ca paññā cā”tiādimāha. Kusalākusaladhammagatiyo
analyzed: tāni cattāri indriyāni niddhāretvā dassento tattha sati ca paññā ca ati ādim āha kusala akusala dhamma gatiyo
translated: He shows these four faculties by saying “Herein, mindfulness and understanding” .

original: samanvesamānāya satiyā sijjhamānāya ekantena samādhi nipphādetabbo, satiggahaṇena
analyzed: samanvesamānāya satiyā sijjhamānāya ekantena samādhi nipphādetabbaḥ sati ggahaṇena
translated: When mindfulness is successful in investigating the states that are profitable and unprofitable, then concentration must certainly be produced. And by the mention of mindfulness

original: ca pariyuṭṭhānappahānaṃ gāthāyaṃ adhippetaṃ, pariyuṭṭhānappahānena ca samādhikiccaṃ
analyzed: ca pariyuṭṭhāna ppahānam gāthāyam adhippetam pariyuṭṭhāna ppahānena ca samādhi kiccam
translated: what is intended is the abandoning of obsession, and by the abandoning of obsession the function of concentration is evident.

original: pākaṭanti āha “sati dve indriyāni satindriyañca samādhindriyañcā”ti. Paññāya anusayasamugghātaṃ🔽catubbidhasammappadhānasaṅkhātena vīriyena sijjhati, na vinā tenāti vuttaṃ “paññā
analyzed: āha sati dve indriyāni satindriyam ca samādhindriyam ca ati paññāya anusaya samugghātam  catubbidha sammappadhāna saṅkhātena vīriyena sijjhati na vinā tena ati vuttam paññā
translated: So he said: “Mindfulness and understanding are two faculties, the mindfulness faculty and the concentration faculty” .

original: dve indriyāni paññindriyañca vīriyindriyañcā”ti.
analyzed: dve indriyāni paññindriyañca vīriyindriyañca ati
translated: And the complete uprooting of inherent tendency by understanding is successful by means of energy, which is called the four right endeavours, and not without that. So he said: “Understanding and energy are two faculties, the understanding faculty and the energy faculty” .

original: Imesu yathāvuttesu catūsu indriyesu pubbabhāge vā maggakkhaṇe vā sijjhantesu taṃsampayuttā
analyzed: imesu yathā vuttesu catūsu indriyesu pubbabhāge vā magga kkhaṇe vā sijjhantesu tad sampayuttā
translated: When these four faculties mentioned in this way are successful either in the prior stage or at the moment of the path, then the confidence and the resolution associated with them

original: yā saddahanā okappanā siddhā, idaṃ saddahanaokappanasaṅkhātaṃ dhammajātaṃ saddhindriyaṃ
analyzed: yā saddahanā okappanā siddhā idam saddahana okappana saṅkhātam dhamma jātam saddhindriyam
translated: are established. This state called confidence and resolution is the faith faculty.

original: siddhaṃ, “tesu mūlabhūtesu indriyesu siddhesu katamena indriyena katamo dhammo siddho”ti
analyzed: siddham tesu mūla bhūtesu indriyesu siddhesu katamena indriyena katamaḥ dhammo siddho ti
translated: “When the faculties which are the roots of the dhammas have been established, by which faculty is which dhamma established?”

original: pucchitabbattā iminā ayaṃ siddhoti dassento “tattha yā saddhādhipateyyā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: pucchitabba ttā iminā ayam siddhaḥ ti dassentaḥ tattha yā saddhā ādhipateyyā iti ādim āha
translated: In order to show this, he said: “Herein, the desire which is dominated by faith” etc.

original: Tattha tatthāti satyādīsu. Saddhādhipateyyāti paccayabhūtāya saddhāya siddho chando🔽adhipatīti saddhādhipati, saddhādhipatinā pavattetabbā cittekaggatāti saddhādhipateyyā.
analyzed: tattha tattha ati satya ādīsu saddhā ādhipateyyā ati paccaya bhūtāya saddhāya siddhaḥ chando  adhipati iti saddhā adhipati saddhā adhipatinā pavattetabbā citta ekagga tā ati saddhā ādhipateyyā
translated: Herein, “herein” means in the truths etc. “Dominated by faith” means established by faith which is a condition.

original: Chandasamādhīti chandaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā pavattito samādhi vā chandādhipatinā sampayutto
analyzed: chanda samādhi iti chandam jeṭṭhakam katvā pavattitaḥ samādhi vā chanda adhipatinā sampayuttaḥ
translated: “Desire” is the desire to act. “Dominated by faith” means dominated by the faith faculty. “Concentration of desire” means concentration arisen by making desire the chief factor, or concentration associated with the desire faculty,

original: pubbabhāge pavatto samādhi vā chandasamādhi, pahānaṃ pahānahetu hotīti yojanā kātabbā.
analyzed: pubbabhāge pavattaḥ samādhi vā chanda samādhi pahānam pahāna hetu hoti iti yojanā kātabbā
translated: or concentration arisen in the preliminary stage. “The cause of abandoning” should be construed as follows: “Abandoning is the cause of abandoning.”

original: Pahānanti ca pajahati vikkhambhitakilese etena chandasamādhināti pahānanti karaṇasādhanattho
analyzed: pahānanti ca pajahati vikkhambhita kilese etena chanda samādhinā ati pahānanti karaṇa sādhana ttho
translated: “Abandoning” means abandoning, i.e. the abandoning of defilements that have been suppressed. By this “abandoning” is the instrumental case.

original: gahetabbo. Paṭisaṅkhānabalenāti parikammabalena. Bhāvanābalenāti mahaggatabhāvanābalena.
analyzed: gahetabbaḥ paṭisaṅkhāna balena ati parikamma balena bhāvanā balena ati mahaggata bhāvanā balena
translated: “In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.

original: “So chandasamādhi sayaṃ kevalova pahāna”nti vattabbattā “tattha ye assāsapassāsā”tiādi
analyzed: saḥ chanda samādhi sayam kevalaḥ iva pahānan ti vattabba ttā tattha ye assāsa passāsa atiādi
translated: “In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tasmiṃ samāhite citte cittuppāde. “Tasmiṃ samāhite cittuppāde
analyzed: vuttam tattha tattha ati tasmin samāhite citte cittuppāde tasmin samāhite cittuppāde
translated: “In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.

original: assāsā”tiādinā assāsādisīsena assāsādijanakā vīriyasaṅkhārā gahitā, te ca yāva bhāvanāpāripūrī,
analyzed: assāsa ati ādinā assāsa ādi sīsena assāsa ādi janakāḥ vīriya saṅkhārāḥ gahitā te ca bhāvanā pāripūrī
translated: “In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.

original: tāva punappunaṃ saraṇato ca sarā, punappunaṃ saṅkappato ca saṅkappā. Yo pana “sarasaṅkappā,🔽ime saṅkhārā cā”ti evaṃ vuttappakāro purimako chandasamādhi vā kilesavikkhambhanatāya
analyzed: tāva punappunam saraṇataḥ ca sarā punappunam saṅkappataḥ ca saṅkappā  ime saṅkhārā ca ati evam vutta ppakāro purimako chanda samādhi vā kilesa vikkhambhana tāya
translated: “In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.

original: ca tadaṅgappahānatāya ca pahānaṃ pahānahetupadhānaṃ vā, “ime vuttappakārā saṅkhārādayo
analyzed: ca tad aṅga ppahāna tāya ca pahānam pahāna hetu padhānam vā ime vutta ppakārā saṅkhāra ādayaḥ
translated: “In-breaths and out-breaths tranquillizing the bodily formation” are a single meditation subject.🔽“In-breaths and out

original: kiṃ bhāventī”ti pucchitabbattā “ime ca saṅkhārā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ime saṅkhārā
analyzed: kim bhāventi iti pucchitabba ttā ime ca saṅkhārā tiādi vuttam tattha ime saṅkhārā
translated: “What does he develop?” is asked. So it was said beginning with “These formations” . Herein, these formations

original: ca tadubhayañca chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ
analyzed: ca tat ubhayañca chanda samādhi ppadhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam viveka nissitam virāga nissitam
translated: and both of them are “accompanied by desire and accompanied by determination and accompanied by energy and accompanied by investigation” . They are “based upon seclusion” , “based upon dispassion” ,

original: nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāvetīti yojanā.
analyzed: nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmim iddhipādam bhāveti iti yojanā
translated: “based upon cessation” , and “resulting in relinquishment” . This is how the construction should be understood.

original: Chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgatanti chando eva adhipati chandādhipati, chandādhipatisamādhi.
analyzed: chanda eva adhipati chanda adhipati chanda adhipati samādhi
translated: “Accompanied by desire and accompanied by determination and accompanied by energy and accompanied by investigation”: desire itself is predominance, and that is desire-predominance. Concentration is concentration due to desire-predominance.

original: Tena vuttaṃ bhagavatā – “chandaṃ ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu adhipatiṃ karitvā labhati🔽samādhi”nti. Chandahetuko vā samādhi, chandādiko vā samādhi chandasamādhi, chandādhipatissa
analyzed: tena vuttam bhagavatā chandam ce bhikkhave bhikkhu adhipatim karitvā labhati  samādhinti chanda hetukaḥ vā samādhi chanda ādikaḥ vā samādhi chanda samādhi chanda adhipatissa
translated: So it was said by the Blessed One: “Bhikkhus, if a bhikkhu makes desire the forerunner,🔽he achieves the concentration of mind” . Or concentration is due to desire, or concentration is of the nature of desire, thus it is concentration due to desire. What is meant is that concentration is originated by the predominance of desire. Formations that are of the nature of predominance are formations due to predominance.

original: paccayuppanno samādhīti vuttaṃ hoti. Padhānabhūtā saṅkhārā padhānasaṅkhārā, padhānasaddena
analyzed: paccaya uppanno samādhi iti vuttam hoti padhāna bhūtā saṅkhārā padhāna saṅkhārā padhāna saddena
translated: By the word “predominance”

original: saṅkhatasaṅkhārādayo nivattāpitā, chandasamādhi ca padhānasaṅkhārā cāti chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārā,
analyzed: chanda samādhi ca padhāna saṅkhārā ca ati chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhārā
translated: The formations of what is formed, etc., are turned away from, and zeal, and concentration, and the formations of striving: these are the formations of zeal, concentration, and striving.🔽He possesses zeal, etc., and he possesses concentration, and he possesses the formations of striving, and he possesses the path, and he possesses the fruition of the path, and he possesses the cankers, and he possesses the things that are cankerless, and he possesses the formed, and he possesses the unformed, and he possesses the supramundane, and he possesses the mundane, and he possesses the wholesome, and he possesses the unwholesome, and he possesses the indeterminate, and he possesses the past, and he possesses the future, and he possesses the present, and he possesses the unarisen, and he possesses the already arisen, and he possesses the not-yet- ceased, and he possesses the already ceased, and he possesses the abandonable by seeing, and he possesses the abandonable by keeping-in- being, and he possesses the unabandonable, and he possesses the seen, and he possesses the un-seen, and he possesses the seen and un-seen, and he possesses the seen and the un-seen together.

original: tehi samannāgato chanda…pe… samannāgato, taṃ…pe… gataṃ. Ijjhati samijjhati nippajjatīti
analyzed: tehi samannāgataḥ chandape samannāgataḥ taṃpe gatam ijjhati samijjhati nippajjati iti
translated: It succeeds, prospers, comes to fulfilment:🔽it is success.🔽It is a part, a portion:🔽it is a footing for success.

original: iddhi, koṭṭhāso, iddhi eva pādo koṭṭhāsoti iddhipādo, iddhipādacatuttho. Ijjhanti
analyzed: iddhi koṭṭhāso iddhi eva pādo koṭṭhāso ti iddhi pādo iddhi pāda catuttho
translated: It is the fourth of the four bases of success.🔽Or alternatively, beings are successful, grown, gone to excellence, by means of it, thus it is success.🔽It is a foot, thus it is a footing.

original: vā tāya sattā iddhā vuddhā ukkaṃsagatā hontīti iddhi, pajjati etenāti pādo, iddhiyā
analyzed: vā tāya sattāḥ iddhāḥ vuddhāḥ ukkaṃsa gatāḥ honti iti iddhi pajjati etena ati pādaḥ iddhiyā
translated: It is a footing for success, thus it is a footing for success.

original: pādoti iddhipādo. Iddhipādoti sāmaññatthavasena vuttopi “chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgata”nti
analyzed: pādo ti iddhipādo iddhipādo ti sāmaññattha vasena vuttaḥ api chanda samādhi ppadhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatanti
translated: Although the expression “a footing for success” is used in the sense of a general term, still it should be taken as “a footing for success consisting in zeal” because it is said to be “endowed with zeal, concentration, and the formations of striving.”

original: vuttattā chandiddhipādova gahetabbo, taṃ iddhipādaṃ taṃ chandiddhipādaṃ bhāveti vaḍḍhetīti attho.
analyzed: vutta ttā chanda iddhipādaḥ uva gahetabbaḥ tam iddhipādam tam chanda iddhipādam bhāveti vaḍḍheti iti attho
translated: The meaning is that he develops, he increases, that footing for success.

original: Vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitanti vipassanākkhaṇe kiccato tadaṅgavivekanissitaṃ, ajjhāsayato
analyzed: viveka nissitam virāga nissitanti vipassanā kkhaṇe kiccataḥ tad aṅga viveka nissitam ajjhāsayato
translated: It is secluded, and it is dispassionate, thus it is secluded and dispassionate. At the moment of insight it is secluded and dispassionate as a factor of that, and in the sense of the underlying tendency to it.

original: nissaraṇavivekanissitaṃ, maggakkhaṇe pana kiccato samucchedavivekanissitaṃ, ārammaṇato
analyzed: nissaraṇa viveka nissitam magga kkhaṇe pana kiccataḥ samuccheda viveka nissitam ārammaṇato
translated: and at the moment of the path it is dissociated from the renunciation of abandoning by function, but it is dissociated from the renunciation of escape by object.🔽Dissociated from fading away: at the moment of insight it is dissociated from the fading away of its counterpart by function,

original: nissaraṇavivekanissitaṃ. Virāganissitanti vipassanākkhaṇe kiccato tadaṅgavirāganissitaṃ,🔽ajjhāsayato nissaraṇavivekanissitaṃ, maggakkhaṇe pana kiccato samucchedavirāganissitaṃ,
analyzed: nissaraṇa viveka nissitam virāga nissitam ti vipassanā kkhaṇe kiccato tad aṅga virāga nissitam  ajjhāsayataḥ nissaraṇa viveka nissitam magga kkhaṇe pana kiccataḥ samuccheda virāga nissitam
translated: but it is dissociated from the fading away of renunciation by underlying tendency. At the moment of the path it is dissociated from the fading away of abandoning by function,🔽but it is dissociated from the fading away of escape by object.

original: ārammaṇato nissaraṇavirāganissitaṃ. Nirodhanissitanti vipassanākkhaṇe kiccato tadaṅganirodhanissitaṃ,
analyzed: ārammaṇataḥ nissaraṇa virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam ti vipassanā kkhaṇe kiccato tad aṅga nirodha nissitam
translated: Dissociated from cessation: at the moment of insight it is dissociated from the cessation of its counterpart by function,

original: ajjhāsayato nissaraṇanirodhanissitaṃ, maggakkhaṇe kiccato samucchedanirodhanissitaṃ,🔽ārammaṇato nissaraṇanirodhanissitaṃ. Vossaggapariṇāminti ettha pariccāgavossaggapakkhandanavossaggavasena
analyzed: ajjhāsayataḥ nissaraṇa nirodha nissitam magga kkhaṇe kiccataḥ samuccheda nirodha nissitam  ārammaṇataḥ nissaraṇa nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmin ti ettha pariccāga vossagga pakkhandana vossagga vasena
translated: but it is dissociated from the cessation of renunciation by underlying tendency. At the moment of the path it is dissociated from the cessation of abandoning by function,🔽but it is dissociated from the cessation of escape by object.🔽Relinquishment-transformation: relinquishment is twofold, as relinquishment by giving up and relinquishment by suppression.🔽Herein, at the moment of insight it is relinquishment by giving up by function,

original: vossaggo duvidho. Tatthapi vipassanākkhaṇe tadaṅgavasena pariccāgavossaggo, nibbānaninnabhāvena
analyzed: vossaggaḥ duvidhaḥ tattha api vipassanā kkhaṇe tad aṅga vasena pariccāga vossaggo nibbāna ninna bhāvena
translated: but it is relinquishment by suppression by underlying tendency. At the moment of the path it is relinquishment by giving up by function,

original: pakkhandanavossaggo, maggakkhaṇe samucchedavasena pariccāgavossaggo, ārammaṇakaraṇena
analyzed: pakkhandana vossaggaḥ magga kkhaṇe samuccheda vasena pariccāga vossaggaḥ ārammaṇa karaṇena
translated: The “surrender” is the “surrender by penetration” at the moment of the path, the “surrender by giving up” by way of cutting off, and the “surrender by penetration to Nibbāna” by making Nibbāna the object.

original: nibbānapakkhandanavossaggoti vibhajitvā gahetabbo. Yathāvuttavossaggatthaṃ pariṇamati,
analyzed: nibbāna pakkhandana vossaggaḥ ti vibhajitvā gahetabbaḥ yathā vutta vossagga attham pariṇamati
translated: It “turns to” the meaning of the surrender described in the way stated,

original: pariṇataṃ vā paripacati paripacanaṃ karotīti vossaggapariṇāmī, taṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.🔽Chandiddhipādabhāvanākāro ācariyena vutto, amhehi ca ñāto, “kathaṃ vīriyiddhipādabhāvanākāro
analyzed: pariṇatam vā paripacati paripacanam karoti iti vossagga pariṇāmī tam vossagga pariṇāmim  chanda iddhipāda bhāvanā ākāraḥ ācariyena vuttaḥ amhehi ca ñātaḥ katham vīriya iddhipāda bhāvanā ākāraḥ
translated: or it “cooks” what has been turned to, it makes it “cooked,” thus it is “that which has surrender and turning” , which is why the text says “vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.

original: amhehi vijānitabbo”ti vattabbabhāvato “tattha yā vīriyādhipateyyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tassattho
analyzed: amhehi vijānitabbaḥ iti vattabba bhāvato tattha yā vīriya ādhipateyyā ātiādi vuttam tassa atthaḥ
translated: ” The method of developing the road to power consisting in desire has been stated by the teacher and is known to us. “How is the method of developing the road to power consisting in energy to be known to us?”—because it is necessary to say this, “Herein, the unification of mind due to the influence of energy” is said. The meaning of that is

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayānusāreneva viññeyyo. Saṃkhittavasena pana ṭhapitaṃ pāṭhaṃ vitthārato
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta naya anusārena iva viññeyyaḥ saṃkhitta vasena pana ṭhapitam pāṭham vitthārato
translated: to be understood by the method stated below . But the text that has been given in brief

original: ṭhapessāmi. Kathaṃ? –
analyzed: ṭhapessāmi katham
translated: I shall give in detail. How?

original: “Tattha yā vīriyādhipateyyā cittekaggatā, ayaṃ vīriyasamādhi. Samāhite citte kilesānaṃ
analyzed: tattha yā vīriya ādhipateyyā citta ekagga tā ayam vīriya samādhi samāhite citte kilesānaṃ
translated: “Herein, the unification of mind due to the influence of energy is concentration due to energy. When the mind is concentrated,

original: vikkhambhanatāya paṭisaṅkhānabalena vā bhāvanābalena vā, idaṃ pahānaṃ. Tattha ye
analyzed: vikkhambhana tāya paṭisaṅkhāna balena vā bhāvanā balena vā idam pahānam tattha ye
translated: by suppression through the power of reviewing or through the power of development, this is abandoning. Herein,

original: assāsapassāsā vitakkavicārā saññāvedayitā sarasaṅkappā, ime saṅkhārā. Iti purimako
analyzed: assāsa passāsāḥ vitakka vicārā saññā vedayitā sara saṅkappāḥ ime saṅkhārāḥ iti purimako
translated: the in-breaths and out-breaths, applied thought, sustained thought, perception, feeling, and intention, are determinations. So this

original: ca vīriyasamādhi, kilesavikkhambhanatāya ca pahānaṃ ime ca saṅkhārā, tadubhayaṃ vīriyasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: ca vīriya samādhi kilesa vikkhambhana tāya ca pahānam ime ca saṅkhārā tat ubhayam vīriya samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam
translated: energy concentration and this abandoning and these determinations are the concentration by energy, the abandoning by energy, and the determinations consisting in the arousing of energy,

original: iddhipādaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
analyzed: iddhipādam bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmiṃ
translated: which he develops, depending on seclusion, on dispassion, on cessation, ending in self-surrender.

original: “Tattha yā cittādhipateyyā cittekaggatā, ayaṃ cittasamādhi. Samāhite citte kilesānaṃ
analyzed: tattha yā citta ādhipateyyā citta ekagga tā ayam citta samādhi samāhite citte kilesānaṃ
translated: “Herein, the unification of cognizance and the balance of cognizance in one who has mastery in concentration are concentration by cognizance. When cognizance is concentrated,

original: vikkhambhanatāya paṭisaṅkhānabalena vā bhāvanābalena vā, idaṃ pahānaṃ. Tattha ye
analyzed: vikkhambhana tāya paṭisaṅkhāna balena vā bhāvanā balena vā idam pahānam tattha ye
translated: by suppression through the power of reviewing or through the power of development, this is abandoning. Herein,

original: assāsapassāsā vitakkavicārā saññāvedayitā sarasaṅkappā, ime saṅkhārā. Iti purimako
analyzed: assāsa passāsāḥ vitakka vicārā saññā vedayitā sara saṅkappāḥ ime saṅkhārāḥ iti purimako
translated: the in-breaths and out-breaths, applied thought, sustained thought, perception, feeling, and intention, are determinations. So this

original: ca cittasamādhi, kilesavikkhambhanatāya ca pahānaṃ ime ca saṅkhārā, tadubhayaṃ cittasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: ca citta samādhi kilesa vikkhambhana tāya ca pahānam ime ca saṅkhārā tat ubhayam citta samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam
translated: and unification of cognizance is the equanimity, and the abandoning is the suppression of defilements. And these are the formations. Both these and the unification of cognizance are the concentration- and-equanimity factor of Complete Awakening, which he develops by making it his vehicle, by making it his foundation, by making it his resort, by making it his basis.🔽“Herein, the unification of cognizance that is dominated by inquiry is the concentration due to inquiry. When his cognizance is concentrated,

original: iddhipādaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
analyzed: iddhipādam bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmiṃ
translated: by the power of reviewing or by the power of development, he abandons the defilements. Herein,🔽the in-breaths and out-breaths, the applied thought, the sustained thought, the perception, the feeling, the intention, and the conception, these are the formations. So both the concentration due to inquiry and the abandoning of defilements and these formations are the concentration- and-equanimity factor of Complete Awakening, which he develops by making it his vehicle, by making it his foundation, by making it his resort, by making it his basis.

original: “Tattha yā vīmaṃsādhipateyyā cittekaggatā, ayaṃ vīmaṃsāsamādhi, samāhite citte kilesānaṃ
analyzed: tattha yā vīmaṃsā ādhipateyyā citta ekagga tā ayam vīmaṃsā samādhi samāhite citte kilesānaṃ
translated: “Herein, the unification of cognizance that is dominated by energy is the concentration due to energy. When his cognizance is concentrated,

original: vikkhambhanatāya paṭisaṅkhānabalena vā bhāvanābalena vā, idaṃ pahānaṃ. Tattha ye
analyzed: vikkhambhana tāya paṭisaṅkhāna balena vā bhāvanā balena vā idam pahānam tattha ye
translated: by the power of reviewing or by the power of development, he abandons the defilements. Herein,🔽the in-breaths and out-breaths, the applied thought, the sustained thought, the perception, the feeling, the intention, and the conception, these are the formations. So both the concentration due to energy and the abandoning of defilements and these formations are the concentration- and-equanimity factor of Complete Awakening, which he develops by making it his vehicle, by making it his foundation, by making it his resort, by making it his basis.

original: assāsapassāsā vitakkavicārā saññāvedayitā sarasaṅkappā, ime saṅkhārā. Iti purimako🔽ca vīmaṃsāsamādhi kilesavikkhambhanatāya ca pahānaṃ ime ca saṅkhārā, tadubhayaṃ vīmaṃsāsamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: assāsa passāsāḥ vitakka vicārā saññā vedayitā sara saṅkappāḥ ime saṅkhārāḥ iti purimako  ca vīmaṃsā asamādhi kilesa vikkhambhana tāya ca pahānam ime ca saṅkhārā tat ubhayam vīmaṃsā asamādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam
translated: “Herein, the unification of cognizance that is dominated by natural purity is the concentration due to purity. When his cognizance is concentrated,🔽by the power of reviewing or by the power of development, he abandons the defilements. Herein,

original: iddhipādaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmi”nti.
analyzed: iddhipādam bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vossagga pariṇāmin ti
translated: the in-breaths and out-breaths, the applied thought, the sustained thought, the perception, the feeling, the intention, and the conception, these are the formations. So both the concentration due to purity and the abandoning of defilements and these formations are the concentration- and-equanimity factor of Complete Awakening, which he develops by making it his vehicle, by making it his foundation, by making it his resort, by making it his basis

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – vīriyasamādhīti vīriyaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā pavattito samādhi vā vīriyādhipatinā🔽sampayutto pubbabhāge pavatto samādhi vā vīriyasamādhi. Cittasamādhīti cittaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ🔽katvā pavattito samādhi vā cittādhipatinā sampayutto pubbabhāge pavatto samādhi vā🔽cittasamādhi. Vīmaṃsāsamādhīti vīmaṃsaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā pavattito samādhi vā vīmaṃsādhipatinā
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ vīriya samādhi iti vīriyam jeṭṭhakam katvā pavattitaḥ samādhi vā vīriya adhipatinā  sampayutto pubbabhāge pavatto samādhi vā vīriya samādhi citta samādhi iti cittam jeṭṭhakam  katvā pavattitaḥ samādhi vā citta adhipatinā sampayuttaḥ pubbabhāge pavatto samādhi vā  citta samādhi vīmaṃsa asamādhi iti vīmaṃsam jeṭṭhakam katvā pavattitaḥ samādhi vā vīmaṃsa adhipatinā
translated: But there is this difference. Concentration due to energy is concentration occurring with energy as its forerunner, or concentration associated with the energy faculty. Concentration due to consciousness is concentration occurring with consciousness as its forerunner, or concentration associated with the consciousness faculty. Concentration due to inquiry is concentration occurring with inquiry as its forerunner, or concentration associated with the faculty of understanding.

original: sampayutto pubbabhāge pavatto samādhi vā vīmaṃsāsamādhīti.
analyzed: sampayuttaḥ pubbabhāge pavattaḥ samādhi vā vīmaṃsā samādhi iti
translated: But there is this difference. Concentration due to energy is either concentration that occurs making energy the forerunner, or concentration that is associated with the predominance of energy in the earlier stages. Concentration due to mind is either concentration that occurs making mind the forerunner, or concentration that is associated with the predominance of mind in the earlier stages. Concentration due to investigation is either concentration that occurs making investigation the forerunner, or concentration that is associated with the predominance of investigation in the earlier stages.

original: Sattibalānurūpenettha saṅkhepavaṇṇanā katā, gambhīrañāṇehi pana aṭṭhakathāṭīkānurūpena vitthārato vā gambhīrato vā vibhajitvā gahetabbā.
analyzed: satti bala anurūpena ittha saṅkhepa vaṇṇanā katā gambhīra ñāṇehi pana aṭṭhakathā ṭīkā anurūpena vitthārataḥ vā gambhīrataḥ vā vibhajitvā gahetabbā
translated: The brief treatment here is in accordance with the strength of the sword; but it should be taken in detail and in the deep way in accordance with the commentaries and subcommentaries.

original: 14. “Chandasamādhi vīriyasamādhi cittasamādhi vīmaṃsāsamādhī”ti vutto, “evaṃ sati
analyzed: chanda samādhi vīriya samādhi citta samādhi vīmaṃsā samādhi iti vuttaḥ evam sati
translated: “Concentration due to zeal, concentration due to energy, concentration due to mind, and concentration due to investigation” are mentioned. When that is so,

original: vīmaṃsāsamādhiyeva ñāṇamūlako ñāṇapubbaṅgamo ñāṇānuparivatti bhaveyya, aññe tayo
analyzed: vīmaṃsā samādhiyā iva ñāṇa mūlakaḥ ñāṇa pubbaṅgamaḥ ñāṇa anuparivatti bhaveyya aññe tayo
translated: and that only the concentration of inquiry would have knowledge as its root, would have knowledge as its forerunner, would have knowledge as its guide, while the other three

original: samādhayo aññāṇamūlakā aññāṇapubbaṅgamā aññāṇapavattiyo bhaveyyu”nti vattabbattā
analyzed: samādhayaḥ aññāṇa mūlakāḥ aññāṇa pubbaṅgamāḥ aññāṇa pavattiyaḥ bhaveyyuṃ ti vattabbattā
translated: concentrations would have non-knowledge as their root, would have non-knowledge as their forerunner, would have non-knowledge as their guide.

original: sabbe samādhayo ñāṇamūlakādayoyevāti dassetuṃ “sabbo samādhi ñāṇamūlako”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sabbe samādhayaḥ ñāṇa mūlaka ādayo yeva ati dassetum sabbaḥ samādhi ñāṇa mūlakaḥ tiādi vuttam
translated: So in order to show that all the concentrations have knowledge as their root, etc., it is said: “All concentration has knowledge as its root, etc.”

original: Tattha sabbo samādhīti chandasamādhi, vīriyasamādhi, cittasamādhi, vīmaṃsāsamādhīti
analyzed: tattha sabbo samādhi iti chanda samādhi vīriya samādhi citta samādhi vīmaṃsā samādhi iti
translated: Herein, all concentration is the fourfold concentration consisting of the concentration of will, of energy, of consciousness, and of inquiry.

original: catubbidho samādhi. Ñāṇamūlakoti ekāvajjanavīthinānāvajjanavīthīsu pavattaṃ upacārañāṇamūlako.
analyzed: catubbidhaḥ samādhi ñāṇa mūlako ti ekāvajjana vīthi nānā āvajjana vīthīsu pavattam upacāra ñāṇa mūlako
translated: It has knowledge as its root: it has the knowledge of access occurring in the course of the single cognitive series and the multiple cognitive series as its root.

original: Ñāṇapubbaṅgamoti adhigamañāṇaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ assāti ñāṇapubbaṅgamo. Ñāṇānuparivattīti🔽paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ anuparivatti assāti ñāṇānuparivatti. Atha vā nānāvajjanūpacārañāṇaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa pubbaṅgamaḥ ti adhigama ñāṇam pubbaṅgamam assa ati ñāṇa pubbaṅgamaḥ ñāṇa anuparivattī iti  paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam anuparivatti assa ati ñāṇa anuparivatti atha vā nānā vajjanūpacāra ñāṇam
translated: It has knowledge as its forerunner: it has the knowledge of obtaining as its forerunner, thus it has knowledge as its forerunner. It has knowledge as its guide:

original: vā paṭisandhiñāṇaṃ vā mūlaṃ assāti ñāṇamūlako, upacārañāṇaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ assāti ñāṇapubbaṅgamo,
analyzed: vā paṭisandhi ñāṇam vā mūlam assa ati ñāṇa mūlakaḥ upacāra ñāṇam pubbaṅgamam assa ati ñāṇa pubbaṅgamaḥ
translated: it has the knowledge of reviewing as its guide, thus it has knowledge as its guide. Or alternatively, it has the knowledge of access or the knowledge of rebirth-linking as its root, thus it has knowledge as its root. It has the knowledge of access as its forerunner, thus it has knowledge as its forerunner.

original: appanāñāṇaṃ anuparivatti assāti ñāṇānuparivatti. Sabbaṃ vā upacārañāṇaṃ mūlaṃ assāti🔽ñāṇamūlako. Appanāñāṇaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ assāti ñāṇapubbaṅgamo. Abhiññāñāṇaṃ anuparivatti🔽assāti ñāṇānuparivatti, anuparivattanaṃ vā anuparivatti, ñāṇassa anuparivatti ñāṇānuparivatti,
analyzed: appanā ñāṇam anuparivatti assa ati ñāṇa anuparivatti sabbam vā upacāra ñāṇam mūlam assa ati  ñāṇa mūlakaḥ appanā ñāṇam pubbaṅgamam assa ati ñāṇa pubbaṅgamaḥ abhiññā ñāṇam anuparivatti  assa ati ñāṇa anuparivatti anuparivattanam vā anuparivatti ñāṇassa anuparivatti ñāṇa anuparivatti
translated: Knowledge of absorption is its attendant, thus it is knowledge-attended. Or all access concentration is its root, thus

original: ñāṇānuparivatti assāti ñāṇānuparivatti. Ñāṇaṃ pana pubbe vuttappakārameva.🔽Yathā pure tathā pacchāti yathā chandasamādhiādicatubbidhasamādhissa pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇānuparivattibhāvena
analyzed: ñāṇa anuparivatti assa ati ñāṇa anuparivatti ñāṇam pana pubbe vutta ppakāram eva  yathā pure tathā pacchā ati yathā chanda samādhi ādi catubbidha samādhissa pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena
translated: it is knowledge-rooted. Knowledge of absorption is its forerunner, thus it is knowledge-foregone. Knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power is its attendant, thus it is knowledge-attended. Or the act of attending is attending, and the attending of knowledge is knowledge-attended, thus it is knowledge-attended. But knowledge is of the kind already stated.

original: pure atītāsu jātīsu asaṅkhyeyyesupi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭesu attano khandhapaṭibaddhassa,
analyzed: pure atītāsu jātīsu asaṅkhyeyyesu pi saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭesu attanaḥ khandha paṭibaddhassa
translated: As before, so after: as in the case of the knowledge of recollection of past lives, which is attended by concentration consisting of will, concentration consisting of energy, and so on, in the past, in the countless past aeons of the process of becoming, it penetrates well, not unpenetratingly, the aggregates that were his own in the past,🔽and the aggregates that were others’. As it was then, so now,

original: paresaṃ khandhapaṭibaddhassa ca suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhanaṃ tathā
analyzed: paresam khandha paṭibaddhassa ca suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanam tathā
translated: thus it is as before, so after.

original: tathāvuttasamādhissa anāgataṃsañāṇānuparivattibhāvena pacchā anāgatāsu jātīsu asaṅkhyeyyesupi
analyzed: tathā vutta samādhissa anāgataṃsañāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena pacchā anāgatāsu jātīsu asaṅkhyeyyesu pi
translated: and the knowledge of the future is the subsequent knowledge of the concentration described in this way, in the future in the future existences, even in countless existences,

original: saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭesu attano khandhapaṭibaddhassa, paresaṃ khandhapaṭibaddhassa ca suṭṭhu🔽paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhananti attho daṭṭhabbo. Yathā pacchā tathā pureti
analyzed: saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭesu attanaḥ khandha paṭibaddhassa paresam khandha paṭibaddhassa ca suṭṭhu  paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhananti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo yathā pacchā tathā purā iti
translated: And the meaning should be regarded as follows: “Just as, in the future, in future births, even in countless world-cycles, he will penetrate well, not with difficulty, the aggregates that are his own and the aggregates of others, by the occurrence of knowledge of the future in one who has attained that jhana described in the way beginning, ‘When his concentrated mind’ ,

original: yathā yathāvuttasamādhissa cetopariyañāṇānuparivattibhāvena anāgatesu sattasuyeva🔽divasesu parasattānaṃyeva cittassa suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhanaṃ,🔽tathā tathāvuttasamādhissa pure atītesu sattasuyeva divasesu parasattānaṃyeva cittassa
analyzed: yathā yathā vutta samādhissa cetaḥ pariya ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena anāgatesu  divasesu para sattānam yeva cittassa suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanam  tathā tathā vutta samādhissa pure atītesu sattasu yeva divasesu para sattānam yeva cittassa
translated: so too in the past, in the past seven days, he will penetrate well, not with difficulty, the minds of other beings, by the occurrence of knowledge of penetration of minds in one who has attained that jhana described in the way beginning, ‘When his concentrated mind’ .🔽And the meaning should be regarded as follows: ‘Just as, in the future, in future births, even in countless world-cycles, he will penetrate well, not with difficulty, the aggregates that are his own and the aggregates of others, by the occurrence of knowledge of the future in one who has attained that jhana described in the way beginning, “When his concentrated mind” ,

original: suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhananti attho.
analyzed: suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanan ti attho
translated: so too in the past, in the past seven days, he will penetrate well, not with difficulty, the minds of other beings, by the occurrence of knowledge of penetration of minds in one who has attained that jhana described in the way beginning, “When his concentrated mind” .

original: Yathā divā tathā rattinti yathā cakkhumantānaṃ sattānaṃ divasabhāge sūriyālokena
analyzed: yathā divā tathā yathā cakkhumantānam sattānam divasa bhāge sūriya ālokena
translated: And the meaning should be regarded as follows: ‘Just as, in the daytime, for beings who have eyes, by the light of the sun and the moon, by the light of stars, by the light of gems, by the light of torches,

original: andhakārassa viddhaṃsitattā āpāthagataṃ cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpaṃ manoviññāṇenapi suviññeyyaṃ,
analyzed: andhakārassa viddhaṃsita ttā āpātha gatam cakkhu viññeyyam rūpam manaḥ viññāṇena api su viññeyyam
translated: Because the darkness has been dispelled, visible forms cognizable by the eye that come into the visual focus are quite cognizable by the mind-element too.

original: tathā rattibhāge caturaṅgasamannāgatepi andhakāre vattamāne yathāvuttasamādhissa
analyzed: tathā ratti bhāge catur aṅga samannāgate pi andhakāre vattamāne yathā vutta samādhissa
translated: Likewise, even when darkness is present in the night with the four constituents, by the influence of the divine eye knowledge on the concentration described above,

original: dibbacakkhuñāṇānuparivattibhāvena rūpāyatanassa suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhanaṃ.
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena rūpa āyatanassa suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanam
translated: the visible form base is quite penetrated, not difficult to penetrate.

original: Yathā rattiṃ tathā divāti yathā rattibhāge caturaṅgasamannāgatepi andhakāre yathāvuttasamādhissa
analyzed: yathā rattim tathā divā ati yathā ratti bhāge catur aṅga samannāgate pi andhakāre yathā vutta samādhissa
translated: As in the night, so in the day: even when darkness with the four constituents is present in the night, by the influence of the divine eye knowledge on the concentration described above,

original: dibbacakkhuñāṇānuparivattibhāvena rūpāyatanassa suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhanaṃ,
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena rūpa āyatanassa suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanam
translated: the visible form base is quite penetrated, not difficult to penetrate.

original: tathā divasabhāge sukhumassa rūpāyatanassa vā kenaci pākārādinā tirohitassa rūpāyatanassa
analyzed: tathā divasa bhāge sukhumassa rūpa āyatanassa vā kenaci pākāra ādinā tirohitassa rūpa āyatanassa
translated: Likewise, even when a subtle visible form base is present in the day, or a visible form base that is obstructed by a wall, etc.,

original: vā atidūraṭṭhāne pavattassa rūpāyatanassa vā yathāvuttasamādhissa dibbacakkhuñāṇānuparivattibhāvena
analyzed: vā ati dūra ṭṭhāne pavattassa rūpa āyatanassa vā yathā vutta samādhissa dibba cakkhu ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena
translated: or a visible form base that occurs in a place too far away, by the influence of the divine eye knowledge on the concentration described above,

original: suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhananti attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanam ti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning should be regarded as follows: “It is only the penetrating of sound, not the non-penetrating.”

original: Yathā yathāvuttasamādhissa divasabhāge dibbasotañāṇānuparivattibhāvena sukhumassa
analyzed: yathā yathā vutta samādhissa divasa bhāge dibba sota ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena sukhumassa
translated: Just as by day there is only the penetrating of the subtle sound base, not the non-penetrating, by reason of the conformity of the knowledge of the divine ear to the concentration described,

original: saddāyatanassa vā kenaci pākārādinā tirohitassa saddāyatanassa vā atidūraṭṭhāne pavattassa🔽saddāyatanassa vā suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhanaṃ, tathā rattibhāgepi
analyzed: sadda āyatanassa vā kenacid pākāra ādinā tirohitassa sadda āyatanassa vā atidūra ṭṭhāne pavattassa  sadda āyatanassa vā suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanam tathā ratti bhāge pi
translated: whether it be a sound base that is obstructed by a wall, etc., or a sound base occurring in a place that is very far,

original: yathāvuttasamādhissa dibbasotañāṇānuparivattibhāvena sukhumassa saddāyatanassa vā🔽kenaci pākārādinā tirohitassa saddāyatanassa vā atidūraṭṭhāne pavattassa saddāyatanassa
analyzed: yathā vutta samādhissa dibba sota ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena sukhumassa sadda āyatanassa vā  kenaci pākāra ādinā tirohitassa sadda āyatanassa vā atidūra ṭṭhāne pavattassa sadda āyatanassa
translated: so too by night there is only the penetrating of the subtle sound base, not the non-penetrating, by reason of the conformity of the knowledge of the divine ear to the concentration described,

original: vā suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanameva, na duppaṭivijjhananti ayaṃ nayopi netabbo. Tena vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ –
analyzed: vā suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanam eva na duppaṭivijjhanan ti ayam nayaḥ api netabbaḥ tena vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: whether it be a sound base that is obstructed by a wall, etc., or a sound base occurring in a place that is very far. This is the method of explanation. Hence it is said in the commentary:

original: “Yathā pureti yathā samādhissa pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇānuparivattibhāvenā”tiādiṃ vatvā
analyzed: yathā purā iti yathā samādhissa pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāvena atiādim vatvā
translated: “As before” means by reason of the conformity of the knowledge of recollection of past lives to the concentration described.

original: “yathā ca rūpāyatane vuttaṃ, tathā samādhissa dibbasotañāṇānuparivattitāya saddāyatane ca netabba”nti.
analyzed: yathā ca rūpāyatane vuttam tathā samādhissa dibba sota ñāṇa anuparivatti tāya sadda āyatane ca netabbanti
translated: “And as it is stated in the case of the base of visible form, so it should be understood in the case of the base of sounds by substituting the divine ear for the supernormal power.”

original: “Ñāṇamūlakādisamādhinā pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇānuparivattibhāvādisahitena kiṃ bhāvetī”ti
analyzed: ñāṇa mūlaka ādi samādhinā pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa anuparivatti bhāva ādi sahitena kim bhāveti iti
translated: “What does he develop? ”

original: pucchitabbattā “iti vivaṭenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha itīti evaṃ vuttappakārena. Apariyonaddhenāti
analyzed: pucchitabbattā iti vivaṭena atiādi vuttam tattha iti iti evam vutta ppakārena a pariyonaddhena ati
translated: The answer is given in the words “Thus with an open and unencumbered mind” . Herein, thus means in the way already stated.🔽Unencumbered means free from the hindrances, etc.

original: nīvaraṇādivigamanena. Sappabhāsaṃ cittanti iddhipādasampayuttaṃ maggacittaṃ bhāveti.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ādi vigamanena sa pabhāsam cittanti iddhipāda sampayuttam magga cittam bhāveti
translated: He develops the luminous mind, which is the path mind associated with the bases of success.

original: Iddhipādasampayutte maggacitte uppajjamāne hi maggacittasahabhūni kusalāni saddhindriyavīriyindriyasatindriyasamādhindriyapaññindriyabhūtāni
analyzed: iddhipāda sampayutte magga citte uppajjamāne hi magga citta sahabhūni kusalāni saddhindriya vīriyindriya satindriya samādhindriya paññindriya bhūtāni
translated: For when the path mind associated with the bases of success arises, the wholesome states that are conascent with the path mind, which are the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding,

original: pañcindriyāni uppajjanti. Maggacitte nirujjhamāne anuppajjanabhāvena nirujjhanti
analyzed: pañca indriyāni uppajjanti magga citte nirujjhamāne anuppajjana bhāvena nirujjhanti
translated: arise as the five faculties. When the path mind ceases, they cease by not arising again,

original: ekacittakkhaṇikattā. Evaṃ maggaviññāṇassa nirodhā paññā ca sati ca nirujjhatīti yojanā.
analyzed: eka citta khaṇika ttā evam magga viññāṇassa nirodhā paññā ca sati ca nirujjhati iti yojanā
translated: because they last only for a single mind-moment. Thus it should be construed: “With the cessation of the path consciousness, understanding and mindfulness cease.”

original: “Kassa viññāṇassa nirodhā nāmarūpaṃ nirujjhatī”ti vattabbattā “nāmarūpañcā”tiādi
analyzed: kassa viññāṇassa nirodhā nāma rūpam nirujjhati iti vattabbattā nāma rūpam ca atiādi
translated: “With the cessation of what consciousness does mentality-materiality cease?”

original: vuttaṃ, paṭisandhiviññāṇassa nirodhā nāmarūpañca nirujjhatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā
analyzed: vuttam paṭisandhi viññāṇassa nirodhā nāma rūpam ca nirujjhati iti vuttam hoti atha vā
translated: “With the cessation of mentality-materiality” is said. With the cessation of rebirth-linking consciousness mentality-materiality ceases. Or alternatively,

original: “viññāṇassa nirodhā paññā ca sati cāti vuttāni pañcindriyāni evaṃ nirujjhantī”ti🔽vattabbattā nāmarūpañca nirujjhati, nirujjhamānaṃ pana nāmarūpaṃ paṭisandhiviññāṇassa🔽nirodhā nirujjhatīti dassetuṃ “nāmarūpañcā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha nāmarūpañcāti maggena
analyzed: viññāṇassa nirodhā paññā ca sati ca ati vuttāni pañca indriyāni evam nirujjhanti iti  vattabba ttā nāma rūpam ca nirujjhati nirujjhamānam pana nāma rūpam paṭisandhi viññāṇassa  nirodhā nirujjhati iti dassetum nāma rūpam ca iti ādi vuttam tattha nāma rūpam ca iti maggena
translated: “With the cessation of consciousness the five faculties stated thus, ‘With the cessation of consciousness, bhikkhus, do the five aggregates of cankers cease’ cease”

original: taṇhāavijjādike anupacchinne uppajjanārahaṃ vedanādikkhandhattayaṃ, bhūtupādārūpañca.🔽Viññāṇahetukanti uppajjanārahaṃ paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ hetu assa nāmarūpassāti viññāṇahetukaṃ.
analyzed: taṇhā avijjā ādike anupacchinne uppajjana araham vedanā ādi khandha ttayam  viññāṇa hetukanti uppajjana araham paṭisandhi viññāṇam hetu assa nāma rūpassa ati viññāṇa hetukam
translated: is to be said. But when mentality-materiality ceases, it does so with the cessation of rebirth-linking consciousness. In order to show this, “With the cessation of mentality-materiality” is said. Herein, “mentality-materiality” is the three aggregates beginning with feeling, which are due to arise when craving and ignorance, etc., are not yet cut off by the path, and the four primary elements and the materiality derived from the primary elements.🔽“With consciousness as its condition” : rebirth-linking consciousness, which is due to arise, is its condition, thus it has consciousness as its condition.

original: Viññāṇapaccayā nibbattanti viññāṇena paccayena nibbattaṃ. Tassāti uppajjanārahassa
analyzed: viññāṇa paccayāḥ nibbattanti viññāṇena paccayena nibbattam tassa āti uppajjanā rahassa
translated: “Produced by consciousness as a condition” : it is produced by consciousness as a condition. “That” refers to the rebirth-linking consciousness that is due to arise.

original: paṭisandhiviññāṇassa. Hetūti taṇhāavijjādiko kileso. Viññāṇanti uppajjanārahaṃ paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisandhi viññāṇassa hetu uti taṇhā avijjā ādikaḥ kilesaḥ viññāṇanti uppajjana araham paṭisandhi viññāṇam
translated: and of rebirth-linking consciousness. ‘With no cause’ means with no defilement such as craving and ignorance. ‘Consciousness’ means rebirth-linking consciousness ready to arise.

original: Anāhāranti appaccayaṃ. Anabhinanditanti kāmataṇhādīhi anabhinanditabbaṃ. Appaṭisandhikanti🔽punabbhavābhisandahanarahitaṃ. Nti tādisaṃ viññāṇaṃ. Ahetūti natthi hetusaṅkhātaṃ🔽paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ imassa nāmarūpassāti ahetu. Appaccayanti sahāyavirahena natthi
analyzed: anāhāram ti appaccayam an abhinanditam ti kāma taṇhā ādīhi an abhinanditabbam appaṭisandhikam ti  punabbhava abhisandahana rahitam tādisam viññāṇam ahetu uti natthi hetu saṅkhātam  paṭisandhi viññāṇam imassa nāma rūpassa ati ahetu appaccaya nti sahāya virahena natthi
translated: ‘With no nutriment’ means with no condition. ‘Not delighting’ means not delighting in sensual desire, etc. ‘With no rebirth-linking’ means🔽without the function of linking to renewed existence. ‘Such consciousness’ means such as that. ‘With no cause’ means that there is no rebirth-linking consciousness that could be called the cause of this mentality-materiality. ‘With no condition’ means that there are no formations as a condition for it by reason of the absence of a companion.

original: paccayā saṅkhārā imassāti appaccayaṃ. Evaṃ paṭisandhiviññāṇassa nirodhā nāmarūpañca nirujjhatīti.
analyzed: paccayā saṅkhārā imassa ati appaccayam evam paṭisandhi viññāṇassa nirodhā nāma rūpam ca nirujjhati iti
translated: Thus with the cessation of rebirth-linking consciousness, mentality-materiality ceases.’

original: “Paññāsatīnañceva nāmarūpassa ca vuttappakārena nirujjhanabhāvo kathaṃ amhehi saddahitabbo”ti
analyzed: paññā satīnam ca iva nāma rūpassa ca vutta ppakārena nirujjhana bhāvaḥ katham amhehi saddahitabbo ti
translated: ‘How can we believe in the cessation of mentality-materiality and of the sixfold base in the way described?’

original: vattabbattā “tenāha bhagavā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Vattabbākārena paññāsatīnañceva nāmarūpassa
analyzed: vattabba ttā tena āha bhagavā itiādi vuttam vattabba ākārena paññā satīnam ca iva nāma rūpassa
translated: Because this question is to be asked, the text is stated thus: ‘Hence the Exalted One said …’ . The meaning of what is to be stated is this: ‘Mentality-materiality and the sixfold base

original: ca nirujjhanabhāvajānanako bhagavā yathānirujjhanabhāvadīpakaṃ “yametaṃ…pe… etthetaṃ
analyzed: ca nirujjhana bhāva jānanakaḥ bhagavā yathā nirujjhana bhāva dīpakam etthā itam
translated: … it is this that ceases” , which illuminates the state of cessation.

original: uparujjhatī”ti gāthāvacanaṃ āha. Tena gāthāvacanena tumhehi mayā vutto nirujjhanabhāvo
analyzed: uparujjhati iti gāthā vacanam āha tena gāthā vacanena tumhehi mayā vuttaḥ nirujjhana bhāvaḥ
translated: By means of that verse you should have confidence in the state of cessation that I have stated.

original: saddahitabboyevāti. Etthāpi paññāsatināmarūpānaṃ nirujjhanaṃ ajānantena tattha vā🔽saṃsayantena ajitena pucchitabbattā “adiṭṭhajotanā pucchāti vā diṭṭhasaṃsandanā pucchāti🔽vā paññādīnaṃ anekatthattā dhammato vā anekādhiṭṭhānā pucchāti vā dhammādhiṭṭhānā🔽pucchā”ti vā iccevamādipucchāvicayo niddhāretabbo. “Sarūpadassanavissajjananti vā🔽anekādhiṭṭhānavissajjananti vā dhammādhiṭṭhānavissajjana”nti vā iccevamādivissajjanavicayo niddhāretabbo.
analyzed: ettha api paññāsati nāma rūpānam a jānantena tattha vā  saṃsayantena ajitena pucchitabba ttā a diṭṭha jotanā pucchāti vā diṭṭha saṃsandanā pucchāti  vā paññā ādīnam aneka attha ttā dhammataḥ vā aneka adhiṭṭhānā pucchā ati vā dhamma adhiṭṭhānā  pucchā ati vā icca evamādi pucchā vicayaḥ niddhāretabbo sarūpa dassana vissajjana nti vā  aneka adhiṭṭhāna vissajjananti vā dhamma adhiṭṭhāna vissajjananti vā icca evamādi vissajjana vicayaḥ niddhāretabbaḥ
translated: Herein, since it is one who does not know or who is doubtful about the cessation of mentality-materiality that should ask, the question is one that should be asked by Ajita.

original: Evaṃ sattādhiṭṭhānādipucchāvissajjanāni ceva dhammādhiṭṭhānādipucchāvissajjanāni
analyzed: evam satta adhiṭṭhāna ādi pucchā vissajjanāni ca iva dhamma adhiṭṭhāna ādi pucchā vissajjanāni
translated: So the analysis of the question should be made in this way: “Is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that has not been answered? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that has been answered? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be put away? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be given up? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be passed over? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be further questioned? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered in a way that accords with what is well known? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered in a way that does not accord with what is well known? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by countering it with a counter-question? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by analysis? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by teaching? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by cross-questioning? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by a counter-question that is in turn to be answered by cross-questioning? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by a counter-question that is in turn to be answered by analysis? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by a counter-question that is in turn to be answered by teaching? Or is it a question that should be asked because it is a question that should be answered by a counter-question

original: ca visuṃ visuṃ dassetvā pucchāvicayo ceva vissajjanavicayo ca ācariyena vibhatto,
analyzed: ca visum visum dassetvā pucchā vicayaḥ ca iva vissajjana vicayaḥ ca ācariyena vibhatto
translated: and the teacher has analysed the question and the answer separately,

original: amhehi ca ñāto, “sattādhiṭṭhānadhammādhiṭṭhānesu ekato dassitesu pucchāvissajjanesu
analyzed: amhehi ca ñāto satta adhiṭṭhāna dhamma adhiṭṭhānesu ekatas dassitesu pucchā vissajjanesu
translated: and we know them, but when the questions and answers are shown together in the case of the ideas based on the living being and those based on the ideas,

original: kathaṃ pucchāvicayo ceva vissajjanavicayo ca amhehi viññātabbo”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: katham pucchā vicayaḥ ca iva vissajjana vicayaḥ ca amhehi viññātabbaḥ ti pucchitabba ttā
translated: how are we to know the analysis of the question and the analysis of the answer? ”

original: sattādhiṭṭhānadhammādhiṭṭhānaṃ pucchaṃ nīharitvā tattha vicayaṃ vibhajanto “ye ca
analyzed: satta adhiṭṭhāna dhamma adhiṭṭhānam puccham nīharitvā tattha vicayam vibhajantaḥ ye ca
translated: so he took out the question about the ideas based on the living being and those based on ideas and he analysed the analysis there, saying “Those who are ideas that are formed” .

original: saṅkhatadhammāse”tiādimāha. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana –
analyzed: āha aṭṭhakathā ayam pana
translated: But in the Commentary it is said:

original: “Evaṃ anusandhipucchampi dassetvā heṭṭhā sattādhiṭṭhānā, dhammādhiṭṭhānā ca pucchā visuṃ visuṃ dassitāti idāni tā saha dassetuṃ “ye ca saṅkhatadhammāse’tiādi āraddha”nti –
analyzed: evam anusandhi puccham pi dassetvā heṭṭhā satta adhiṭṭhānā dhamma adhiṭṭhānā ca pucchā visum visum dassitā ati idāni tā saha dassetum ye ca saṅkhata dhammā asa iti ādi āraddhanti
translated: “Having thus shown the question with its sequel, he now shows together the questions about the ideas based on the living being and those based on ideas that were shown separately below, and so he began ‘Those who are ideas that are formed’ and so on” .

original: Vuttaṃ. Tassāyaṃ attho – idha sāsane ye arahanto saṅkhatadhammā honti, puthū bahūyeva
analyzed: vuttam tassa ayam atthaḥ idha sāsane ye arahantaḥ saṅkhata dhammāḥ honti puthū
translated: This is the meaning of that: here in the Dispensation there are many who are Arahants and who are ideas that are formed,
