original: pucchitabbattā “tattha katamo yuttihāro”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tesu niddiṭṭhesu
analyzed: pucchitabba ttā tattha katamaḥ yutti hāraḥ tiādi vuttam tattha tattha ati tesu niddiṭṭhesu
translated: “What is the Mode of Conveying a Fourfold Array?” is said because it is to be asked. Herein, “therein” is in the aforesaid.🔽

original: soḷasasu hāresu katamo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso yuttihāro yuttihāravibhaṅgoti pucchi. “Sabbesaṃ
analyzed: soḷasasu hāresu katamo saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ yutti hāraḥ yutti hāra vibhaṅgo ti pucchi sabbesam
translated: “What is the Mode of Conveying a Conveying? ” is said because it has to be asked about. Herein, in regard to the sixteen kinds of Conveying stated thus, “What is the Mode of Conveying a Conveying? ” he asks about the Mode of Conveying a Conveying, which is a particular kind of exposition.

original: hārāna”ntiādiniddesassa idāni vuccamāno “ayaṃ yuttihāro”tiādiko vitthārasaṃvaṇṇanāviseso🔽yuttihāravibhaṅgo nāmāti viññeyyo. Tena vuttaṃ “tattha katamo yuttihārotiādi yuttihāravibhaṅgo”ti.
analyzed: yutti hāra vibhaṅgaḥ nāma ati viññeyyaḥ tena vuttam tattha katamaḥ yutti hāra itiādi yutti hāra vibhaṅgo ti
translated: The Mode of Conveying a Conveying is the particular kind of exposition that is now being stated thus, “The Mode of Conveying a Conveying is this” , etc., of the demonstration “Of all the Conveying” , etc.🔽That is why it was said above “What is the Mode of Conveying a Conveying? ” is the Mode of Conveying a Conveying.

original: Ayaṃ yuttihāro kiṃ nāma suttatthaṃ yuttāyuttivasena yojayatīti yuñjitabbaṃ suttatthaṃ
analyzed: ayam yuttihāro kim nāma sutta attham yutta ayutti vasena yojayati iti yuñjitabbam sutta attham
translated: This Mode of Conveying a Conveying is called “conveying” because it conveys by way of what is suitable and what is unsuitable in the Thread’s meaning. He asks what the Thread’s meaning is that is to be conveyed.

original: pucchati. Suttattho pana duvidho atathākārena gayhamāno, tathākārena gayhamāno atthoti.
analyzed: pucchati sutta ttho pana duvidhaḥ a tathākārena gayhamāno tathākārena gayhamāno attho ti
translated: But the Thread’s meaning is twofold, namely, that which is conveyed by what is not the way it is and that which is conveyed by what is the way it is.

original: Tattha atathākārena gayhamānova attho yāthāvato yuttiniddhāraṇena yojetabbo, itaro
analyzed: tattha a tathākārena gayhamānaḥ iva atthaḥ yāthāvataḥ yutti niddhāraṇena yojetabbaḥ itaraḥ
translated: Herein, the meaning that is conveyed by what is not the way it is should be conveyed by determining what is suitable in the way it is, while the other

original: pana bhūtakathanamattena yojetabbo. Yasmā panāyaṃ yuttigavesanā nāma saṃvaṇṇanā mahāpadesehi
analyzed: pana bhūta kathana mattena yojetabbaḥ yasmā pana ayam yutti gavesanā nāma saṃvaṇṇanā mahā apadesehi
translated: Now, this kind of investigation of the consistency of a text is called “the search for the great authorities” .

original: vinā na sambhavati, tasmā yuttihāraṃ vibhajanto tassa yuttihārassa lakkhaṇaṃ paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: vinā na sambhavati tasmai yutti hāram vibhajanto tassa yutti hārassa lakkhaṇam paṭhamam
translated: Since this search is not possible without the great authorities,🔽the Expositor, in expounding the search for the great authorities, first teaches the characteristic of the search for the great authorities by saying “The four great authorities.”

original: upadisituṃ “cattāro mahāpadesā”tiādimāha. Tattha mahāpadesāti mahante buddhādayo
analyzed: upadisitum cattāraḥ mahāpadesa iti ādim āha tattha mahāpadesa iti mahante buddha ādayaḥ
translated: Herein, the great authorities are the great Buddhas, etc.,🔽the reasons stated without being stated in the great authorities, or the great supports of the Dhamma, its foundations.🔽The great authorities are the great authorities for this reason,

original: apadisitvā vuttāni kāraṇāni, mahantāni vā dhammassa apadesāni patiṭṭhānāni. Apadisīyateti🔽apadeso, buddho apadeso etassa kāraṇassāti buddhāpadeso. Sesesupi eseva nayo netabbo.
analyzed: apadisitvā vuttāni kāraṇāni mahantāni vā dhammassa apadesāni patiṭṭhānāni apadisīyateti  apadesaḥ buddhaḥ apadeso etassa kāraṇassa ati buddha apadesaḥ sesesu pi esā iva nayaḥ netabbo
translated: The intention is that the search for the great authorities is the reason for the decision that a text is genuine or spurious,

original: “Buddhassa sammukhā etaṃ suttaṃ mayā suta”nti vatvā ābhatassa ganthassa suttavinayehi🔽saṃsandanaṃ dhammo, asaṃsandanaṃ adhammoti vinicchayakāraṇaṃ mahāpadesoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: buddhassa sammukhā etam suttam mayā sutanti vatvā ābhatassa ganthassa sutta vinayehi  saṃsandanam dhammaḥ a saṃsandanam adhammaḥ ti vinicchaya kāraṇam mahā padesaḥ ti adhippāyo
translated: after it has been brought and said: “This sutta was heard by me in the presence of the Buddha,” and the text is then compared with the sutta and the Vinaya.

original: “Buddhassa sammukhā mayā ābhataṃ, saṅghassa sammukhā mayā ābhataṃ, sambahulattherānaṃ
analyzed: buddhassa sammukhā mayā ābhatam saṅghassa sammukhā mayā ābhatam
translated: “It was brought by me in the presence of the Buddha,” “It was brought by me in the presence of the Sangha,” “It was brought by me in the presence of several elders,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a single elder,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a wise person,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the Dhamma,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the Vinaya,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the Abhidhamma,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the sutta,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the gāthās,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the Abhisamaya,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the mātikā,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the ṭīkā,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the tīkā on the tīkā,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the bhāṇavāra,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the bhāṇavāra on the bhāṇavāra,” “It was brought by me in the presence of a reciter of the suttantika,” “It

original: sammukhā mayā ābhataṃ, ekattherassa sammukhā mayā ābhata”nti vatvā ābhatassa ganthassa
analyzed: sammukhā mayā ābhatam eka ttherassa sammukhā mayā ābhatanti vatvā ābhatassa ganthassa
translated: “I have received it face to face. I have received it face to face from a certain elder,”🔽the words and letters of the received text

original: yāni byañjanapadaatthapadāni santi, tāni padabyañjanāni bhagavatā desite sutte otarayitabbāni
analyzed: yāni byañjana pada attha padāni santi tāni pada byañjanāni bhagavatā desite sutte otarayitabbāni
translated: should be inserted into the discourse taught by the Buddha.

original: anuppavesitāni, vinaye rāgādivinaye sandassayitabbāni saṃsandetabbāni. Dhammatāyaṃ🔽upanikkhipitabbāni pakkhipitabbāni. Yadi suttatthena, vinayatthena, dhammatāya ca
analyzed: an uppavesitāni vinaye rāga ādi vinaye sandassayitabbāni saṃsandetabbāni dhamma tāyaṃ  upanikkhipitabbāni pakkhipitabbāni yadi sutta tthena vinaya tthena dhamma tāya ca
translated: They should be applied to the training rule, the rule of the Monastic Law, and the Monastic Law.🔽They should be included in the Monastic Law.🔽If they are not in conflict with the meaning of the discourses, the meaning of the training rules, or the Monastic Law,

original: aviruddhāni honti, evaṃ sati tava ābhatapadabyañjanāni yuttānīti vinicchayantehi🔽vatvā gahetabbānīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: a viruddhāni honti evam sati tava ābhata pada byañjanāni yuttāni iti  vatvā gahetabbāni iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: then the words and letters that you have received are suitable.”

original: Suttavinayadhammatāsu otarayitabbāni sandassayitabbāni upanikkhipitabbānīti ācariyena
analyzed: sutta vinaya dhammatāsu otarayitabbāni sandassayitabbāni upanikkhipitabbāni iti ācariyena
translated: The teacher says, “They should be inserted into the discourses, applied to the training rules, and included in the Monastic Law.”

original: vuttāni, “kattha sutte, kattha vinaye, kattha dhammatāya”nti vattabbattā “katamasmiṃ
analyzed: vuttāni kattha sutte kattha vinaye kattha dhammatāyanti vattabbattā katamasmin
translated: “In which discourses? In which training rules? In which Monastic Law?”

original: sutte”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha catūsu ariyasaccesūti catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ dassanakesu
analyzed: sutta itiādi vuttam tattha catūsu ariya saccesu iti catunnam ariya saccānam dassanakesu
translated: “In the Suttas” and so on. Herein, in the four noble truths is in the Suttas that show the four noble truths.

original: suttesu. Rāgo vinassati vūpasamati etena asubhādināti rāgavinayaṃ, kiṃ taṃ? Asubhādinimittaṃ,
analyzed: suttesu rāgaḥ vinassati vūpasamati etena asubha ādinā ati rāga vinayam kim tam asubha ādi nimittam
translated: Lust is destroyed and ceases by this, the sign of foulness, and so on, is the removal of lust. What is that? The sign of foulness, and so on.

original: taṃ assa atthīti rāgavinayo, ko so? Asubhādinimittadassanako suttantaviseso. Esa🔽nayo dosavinayotiādīsupi. Paṭiccasamuppādo nāma sassatadiṭṭhiucchedadiṭṭhiṃ vivajjetvā
analyzed: tam assa atthi iti rāga vinayaḥ ko so asubha ādi nimitta dassanako suttanta visesaḥ esa  nayaḥ dosa vinaya uti ādīsu pi paṭiccasamuppādaḥ nāma sassata diṭṭhi uccheda diṭṭhim vivajjetvā
translated: That is in it is the removal of lust. Who is that? A particular Sutta that shows the sign of foulness, and so on.🔽The same method applies in the case of the removal of hate, and so on.

original: ekattanayādīnaṃ dīpanena avijjādisaṅkhārādisabhāvadhammānaṃ paccayapaccayuppannabhāvadīpakoti
analyzed: eka ttanaya ādīnam dīpanena avijja ādi saṅkhāra ādi sabhāva dhammānam paccaya paccaya uppanna bhāva dīpakaḥ ti
translated: Dependent origination is said to be the illumination of the mode of the singlefold and so on, which illuminates the states classed as ignorance, formations, and so on, as conditions and as conditionally arisen, by avoiding the view of eternalism and the view of annihilationism.

original: vuttaṃ “katamissaṃ dhammatāyaṃ upanikkhipitabbāni? Paṭiccasamuppāde”ti.
analyzed: vuttam katamissam dhamma tāyam upanikkhipitabbāni paṭiccasamuppāde ti
translated: “In which state should these be deposited? In dependent origination.”

original: “Suttādīsu avatarante sandissante avilomente kiṃ na janetī”ti vattabbato “catūsū”tiādi
analyzed: sutta ādīsu kim na janeti iti vattabbato catūsu utiādi
translated: “When they enter into, incline to, and converge upon the four noble truths, why does he not generate them?” Thus “in the four noble truths” is said.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha “buddhādīnaṃ sammukhā mayā ābhata”nti vatvā ābhatagantho catūsu ariyasaccesu
analyzed: vuttam tattha buddha ādīnam sammukhāḥ mayā ābhata nti vatvā ābhata gantho catūsu ariya saccesu
translated: Herein, having said, “I have received this text face to face from the Enlightened One, and so on,” the four noble truths are

original: yadi avatarati, evaṃ sati ābhatagantho āsave na janeti. Rāgādikilesavinaye yadi sandissati,🔽evaṃ sati ābhatagantho āsave na janeti. Dhammatañca yadi na vilometi, evaṃ sati ābhatagantho
analyzed: yadi avatarati evam sati āsave na janeti rāga ādi kilesa vinaye yadi  evam sati ābhataganthaḥ āsave na janeti dhammataṃ ca yadi na evam sati ābhataganthaḥ
translated: If it does so, then the text learnt does not generate the cankers.🔽If it is seen to be a means of subduing the defilements of lust, etc.,

original: āsave na janetīti attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: āsave na janeti iti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: then the text learnt does not generate the cankers. The meaning should be understood thus: “If it does not contradict the nature of things, then the text learnt does not generate the cankers.”

original: “Kimatthaṃ yuttihāravibhaṅge cattāro mahāpadesā ābhatā”ti vattabbattā “catūhi mahāpadesehī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kimattham yutti hāra vibhaṅge cattāraḥ mahā padesāḥ ābhata ati vattabba ttā catūhi mahā padesehi itiādim āha
translated: In order to answer the question, “Why are the four great authorities stated in the analysis of the method of learning?” he says, “By means of the four great authorities.”

original: Tattha ābhataganthe yaṃ yaṃ atthajātaṃ, yaṃ yaṃ dhammajātaṃ vā catūhi mahāpadesehi
analyzed: tattha ābhataganthe yam yam attha jātam yam yam dhamma jātam vā catūhi mahā padesehi
translated: Herein, any subject matter or any doctrine in the text learnt that is in agreement with the four great authorities

original: yujjati, taṃ taṃ atthajātaṃ vā taṃ taṃ dhammajātaṃ vā saṃvaṇṇetabbasutte gahetabbaṃ.🔽Yena yena kāraṇena ca catūhi mahāpadesehi yujjati, taṃ taṃ kāraṇaṃ saṃvaṇṇanāvasena
analyzed: yujjati tam tam attha jātam vā tam tam dhamma jātam vā saṃvaṇṇetabba sutte gahetabbam  yena yena kāraṇena ca catūhi mahā padesehi yujjati tam tam kāraṇam saṃvaṇṇanā vasena
translated: should be accepted as a sutta to be commended.🔽And any reason by which it is in agreement with the four great authorities should be accepted as a sutta to be commended by way of the commendation.

original: saṃvaṇṇetabbasutte gahetabbaṃ. Yathā yathā pakārena catūhi mahāpadesehi yujjati,
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇetabba sutte gahetabbam yathā yathā pakārena catūhi mahā padesehi yujjati
translated: Any mode by which it is in agreement with the four great authorities

original: so so pakāro saṃvaṇṇanāvasena saṃvaṇṇetabbasutte gahetabbo. Evaṃ gāhaṇatthaṃ cattāro
analyzed: saḥ saḥ pakāraḥ saṃvaṇṇanā vasena saṃvaṇṇetabba sutte gahetabbaḥ evam gāhaṇa attham cattāro
translated: and the various kinds of phrasing should be taken as the sutta to be expounded by way of the exposition. And in order to take them in this way, there are four kinds of meaning.

original: mahāpadesā ābhatāti attho.🔽19. Catūhi mahāpadesehi yuttaṃ aviruddhaṃ taṃ taṃ atthajātaṃ gahetabbanti ācariyena
analyzed: mahāpadesā ābhatā ati attho  catūhi mahāpadesehi yuttam a viruddham tam tam attha jātam gahetabbanti ācariyena
translated: and the four great authorities are to be taken as the Thread to be commended by way of commendation. The meaning is that the four great authorities are taken for the purpose of taking in this way.

original: vuttaṃ, “kattha kena yuttiniddhāraṇaṃ kātabba”nti vattabbattā “pañhaṃ pucchitenā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Pañhe pañhaṃ pucchitena puggalena yuttiniddhāraṇaṃ kātabbanti. Tattha pañhanti
analyzed: vuttam kattha kena yutti niddhāraṇam kātabbanti vattabbattā pañham pucchitena atiādi  vuttam pañhe pañham pucchitena puggalena yutti niddhāraṇam kātabbanti tattha pañham ti
translated: The teacher has said that the various kinds of meaning are to be taken as not in conflict with the four great authorities. Since it is to be asked “ Where and by what is the determination of the appropriateness to be made? “ ,🔽“ By one who has asked a question “ is said. The meaning is that the determination of the appropriateness is to be made by a person who has asked a question about a question. Herein, a question is

original: pañhitabbaṃ sabhāvadhammaṃ. Pucchitenāti vissajjetuṃ samatthena paṇḍitapuggalena.
analyzed: pañhitabbam sabhāva dhammam pucchitena ati vissajjetum samatthena paṇḍita puggalena
translated: a state of being that can be questioned about. By one who has asked : by a wise person who is able to answer.

original: Pañheti pucchāvasena pavattapāṭhe. Padāni kati kittakāni hontīti padaso paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: pañhā iti pucchā vasena pavatta pāṭhe padāni kati kittakāni honti iti padasaḥ paṭhamam
translated: A question is a reading that occurs by way of a question. How many words are there? How many are there? First of all

original: pariyogāhitabbaṃ yuttihārena vicetabbaṃ vīmaṃsitabbaṃ. “Kathaṃ vicetabba”nti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: pariyogāhitabbam yutti hārena vicetabbam vīmaṃsitabbam katham vicetabbam ti pucchitabba ttā
translated: the words are to be taken in by heart and then they are to be investigated by means of the appropriateness and are to be examined. Since it is to be asked “ How are they to be investigated? “ ,

original: “yadi sabbānī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sabbāni padānīti pucchitapāṭhe niravasesāni padāni
analyzed: yadi sabbāni itiādi vuttam tattha sabbāni padāni iti pucchita pāṭhe niravasesāni padāni
translated: “If all the terms” and so on is said. Therein, all the terms in the question are all the terms without exception.

original: ekaṃ samānaṃ atthaṃ yadi abhivadanti, evaṃ sati atthavasena eko pañho. Esa nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: ekam samānam attham yadi abhivadanti evam sati attha vasena ekaḥ pañhaḥ esa nayo sesesu pi
translated: If they express a single meaning, then in that case the question is one in meaning. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “tadatthassekassa ñātuṃ icchitattā”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam tad atthassa ikassa ñātum icchita ttā ati
translated: Therefore it is said: “because of the desire to know the single meaning of that.”

original: Ekanti atthavasena ekavidhaṃ pañhaṃ. Upaparikkhamānena puggalena aññātabbaṃ daḷhaṃ
analyzed: ekam ti attha vasena ekavidham pañham upaparikkhamānena puggalena aññātabbam daḷham
translated: One: a question of one kind in meaning. By a person who is investigating, it should be known firmly

original: jānitabbaṃ. “Ko ājānanākāro”ti pucchitabbattā ājānanākāraṃ dassento “kiṃ ime dhammā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: jānitabbam kaḥ ājānana ākāraḥ iti pucchitabba ttā ājānana ākāram dassentaḥ kim ime dhammā ti ādim āha
translated: and understood. “What is the mode of understanding?” because it should be asked, showing the mode of understanding, he said “What are these ideas?” and so on.

original: Tattha “ye hi pariyattidhammā saṃvaṇṇetabbā, ime pariyattidhammā nānatthā honti kiṃ,
analyzed: tattha ye hi pariyatti dhammā saṃvaṇṇetabbāḥ ime pariyatti dhammāḥ nānatthāḥ honti kiṃ
translated: Therein, “those ideas that are ideas of the scriptures that should be praised, are these ideas of the scriptures different in meaning or not?

original: nānābyañjanā honti kiṃ, udāhu imesaṃ pariyattidhammānaṃ eko attho hoti, byañjanameva
analyzed: nānā byañjanāḥ honti kim udāhu imesam pariyatti dhammānam ekaḥ atthaḥ hoti byañjanam eva
translated: Are they different in phrasing or not? Or else, is the meaning of these ideas of the scriptures one, and is the phrasing only

original: nānaṃ hoti ki”nti yuttito vicetvā aññātabbanti yojanā. “Yathāvutto pañho kiṃ bhave”ti
analyzed: nānam hoti kinti yuttitaḥ vicetvā aññātabbanti yojanā yathā vuttaḥ pañhaḥ kim bhaveti
translated: different?” Having investigated by reasoning, it should be known. The construction is this. “What is the question as stated?”

original: pucchitabbattā yathāvuttaṃ pañhaṃ ekadesaṃ dassetuṃ “yathā kiṃ bhave”ti pucchitvā
analyzed: pucchitabba ttā yathāvuttam pañham eka desam dassetum yathā kim bhaveti pucchitvā
translated: In order to show a part of the question as stated, he asks, “What is it like?”

original: “yathā sā”tiādimāha.🔽Tassaṃ pucchāgāthāyaṃ – coraghātakena manussena coro abbhāhato viya kena dhammena
analyzed: yathā sāti ādim āha  cora ghātakena manussena coraḥ abbhāhataḥ viya kena dhammena
translated: and then says, “It is like that.”

original: sattaloko sadā abbhāhato, māluvalatāya attano nissitarukkho parivārito ajjhotthaṭo🔽viya kena dhammena sattaloko sadā parivārito ajjhotthaṭo, visappītakhurappena sallena
analyzed: satta lokaḥ sadā abbhāhataḥ māluva latāya attanaḥ nissita rukkho parivāritaḥ ajjhotthaṭo  viya kena dhammena satta lokaḥ sadā parivāritaḥ ajjhotthaṭaḥ visappīta khurappena sallena
translated: In the question verse, the construction is as follows: By what state is the world of beings constantly struck down, as a man is struck down by a murderer?🔽By what state is the world of beings constantly surrounded and beset, as a tree surrounded and beset by creepers?

original: otiṇṇo anupaviṭṭho viya kena sallena sattaloko sadā otiṇṇo anupaviṭṭho, kissa kena
analyzed: otiṇṇaḥ anupaviṭṭhaḥ viya kena sallena satta loko sadā otiṇṇaḥ anupaviṭṭho kissa kena
translated: By what dart is the world of beings constantly pierced and stuck, as a man is pierced and stuck by a poisoned dart?

original: kāraṇena sattaloko sadā dhūpāyito santāpitoti yojanā.
analyzed: kāraṇena satta lokaḥ sadā dhūpāyitaḥ santāpitaḥ iti yojanā
translated: For what reason is the world of beings constantly burning and heated?

original: “Imāya pucchāgāthāya kittakāni padānī”ti pucchitabbattā “imānī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: imāya pucchā gāthāya kittakāni padāni iti pucchitabba ttā imāni itiādi vuttam tattha
translated: In order to show how many words there are in the question verse, he says, “These,” etc. Herein,🔽the words that are asked about are four.

original: pucchitānīti pucchitatthāni padāni cattāri honti. “Kittakā pañhā”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: pucchitāni iti pucchita tthāni padāni cattāri honti kittakā pañhā ati pucchitabba ttā
translated: In order to show how many questions there are,

original: “te tayo pañhā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: te tayo pañhā iti vuttam
translated: he says, “These are the three questions.”

original: Bhagavā devatāya hi yasmā vissajjeti, iti tasmā vissajjanato “tayopañhā”ti viññāyati. “Katamā vissajjanagāthā”ti pucchitabbattā –
analyzed: bhagavā devatāya hi yasmai vissajjeti iti tasmai vissajjanato viññāyati katamā vissajjana gāthā ati pucchitabba ttā
translated: The Blessed One answers the deva’s questions, and so it is known that the Thread is “Three Questions” because of the answering.

original: “Maccunābbhāhato loko, jarāya parivārito;
analyzed: lokaḥ jarāya parivāritaḥ
translated: “The world is struck down by death, And by old age is compassed round,

original: Taṇhāsallena otiṇṇo, icchādhūpāyito sadā”ti. –
analyzed: taṇhā sallena otiṇṇaḥ icchā dhūpāyitaḥ
translated: By the dart of craving pierced, And ever fanned by the flame of will” .

original: Vuttaṃ. Tassaṃ vissajjanagāthāyaṃ – coraghātakena manussena coro abbhāhato viya maccunā🔽sattaloko sadā abbhāhato, māluvalatāya attano nissitarukkho parivārito ajjhotthaṭo🔽viya jarāya sattaloko sadā parivārito ajjhotthaṭo, visappītakhurappena sallena otiṇṇo
analyzed: vuttam tassam vissajjana gāthāyam cora ghātakena manussena coraḥ abbhāhataḥ viya maccunā  satta lokaḥ sadā abbhāhataḥ māluva latāya attanaḥ nissita rukkho parivāritaḥ ajjhotthaṭo  viya jarāya satta lokaḥ sadā parivāritaḥ ajjhotthaṭaḥ visappīta khurappena sallena otiṇṇaḥ
translated: This is said. In this answering verse, the world of beings is constantly struck down by death as a man by a murderer,🔽and the world of beings is constantly compassed round, constantly beset, by old age as a tree by a creeper,

original: anupaviṭṭho viya taṇhāsallena sattaloko sadā otiṇṇo anupaviṭṭho, icchāya sattaloko
analyzed: anupaviṭṭhaḥ viya taṇhā sallena satta loko sadā otiṇṇaḥ anupaviṭṭhaḥ icchāya satta loko
translated: and the world of beings is constantly pierced, constantly beset, by the dart of craving as a forest tree by a poisoned arrow,

original: sadā dhūpāyito santāpitoti yojanā.
analyzed: sadā santāpitā iti yojanā
translated: and the world of beings is constantly fanned, constantly heated, by the flame of will.

original: 20. “Katamaṃ maccu, katamā jarā”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha jarā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: katamam maccu katamā jarāti pucchitabbattā tattha jarāti ādi vuttam tattha
translated: “What is death? What is old age?” Since this must be asked, “Herein, old age” is said. Herein,

original: tatthāti tissaṃ vissajjanagāthāyaṃ. Dutiyapade vuttā jarā ca paṭhamapade vuttaṃ maraṇañca
analyzed: tattha ati tissam vissajjana gāthāyam dutiya pade vuttā jarā ca paṭhama pade vuttam maraṇam ca
translated: Herein, in the answer verse, “aging” is stated in the second line and “death” in the first line.

original: imāni dve saṅkhatassa khandhapañcakassa saṅkhatalakkhaṇāni honti, saṅkhataṃ khandhapañcakaṃ🔽muñcitvā visuṃ na upalabbhatīti attho. “Saṅkhatalakkhaṇānaṃ jarāmaraṇānaṃ kathaṃ
analyzed: imāni dve saṅkhatassa khandha pañcakassa saṅkhata lakkhaṇāni honti saṅkhatam khandha pañcakam  muñcitvā visum na upalabbhati iti attho saṅkhata lakkhaṇānam jarā maraṇānam katham
translated: These two are the formedness characteristics of the formed pentad of aggregates.🔽The formed pentad of aggregates is formedness itself; the meaning is that it cannot be found apart from that.

original: bhedo jānitabbo”ti vattabbattā “jarāyaṃ ṭhitassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha jarāyaṃ ṭhitassa🔽aññathattanti ṭhitassa khandhappabandhassa yaṃ aññathattaṃ, ayaṃ pākaṭajarā nāma,
analyzed: bhedaḥ jānitabbaḥ ti vattabbattā jarāyam ṭhitassa atiādi vuttam tattha jarāyam ṭhitassa  aññathattanti ṭhitassa khandha ppabandhassa yam aññathattam ayam pākaṭajarā nāma
translated: Since it must be said how the distinction between aging and death as the formedness characteristics should be known, “When aging is present” is said. Herein, the change of what is present

original: na khaṇaṭṭhitijarā. Maraṇaṃ vayoti sammutimaraṇaṃ cutiyeva hoti, na khaṇikamaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: na khaṇa ṭṭhiti jarā maraṇam sammuti maraṇam cutiyā iva hoti na khaṇika maraṇam
translated: is called manifest aging, not aging as momentary presence. Death is called “passing away” and is merely the conventional death, not momentary death or death as annihilation.

original: na samucchedamaraṇaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “uppādo paññāyati, vayo paññāyati, ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ paññāyatī”ti.
analyzed: na samuccheda maraṇam tena vuttam uppādo paññāyati vayaḥ paññāyati ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Arising is evident, passing away is evident, and the alteration of what is present is evident.”

original: Yadi ṭhitasseva maraṇaṃ siyā, evaṃ sati jarāmaraṇānaṃ nānattaṃ yuttaṃ na siyā, ayutte
analyzed: yadi ṭhitassa iva maraṇam siyā evam sati jarā maraṇānam nānattam yuttam na siyā ayutte
translated: If death were to occur only in one who is already aged, then it would not be proper to distinguish between ageing and death, and

original: sati “te tayo pañhā”ti vacanampi ayuttamevāti vattabbato “tattha jarāya cā”tiādi
analyzed: sati te tayo pañhā ati vacanam pi ayuttam evā ti vattabbato tattha
translated: if that is not proper, then it should be said that the question is improper too, since it is asked in the way beginning, “As to the three questions” . That is why it is said: “Herein, it is proper to distinguish between ageing and the death that is mentioned in the verse that answers the question.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tissaṃ vissajjanagāthāyaṃ vuttāya jarāya ca vuttassa maraṇassa🔽ca atthato nānattaṃ yuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam tattha tattha ati tissam vissajjana gāthāyam vuttāya jarāya ca vuttassa maraṇassa  ca atthataḥ nānattam yuttam
translated: Herein, here in the verse that answers the question, it is proper to distinguish between the ageing that is mentioned and the death that is mentioned.

original: “Kena kāraṇena yuttaṃ, kathaṃ kāraṇena nānattaṃ sampaṭicchitabba”nti vattabbattā
analyzed: kena kāraṇena yuttam katham kāraṇena nānattam sampaṭicchitabbanti vattabbattā
translated: “Why is it proper? How should the distinction be understood?”🔽It is said: “For beings die even in the womb.”

original: “gabbhagatāpi hi mīyantī”ti vuttaṃ. Jaraṃ appattā gabbhagatāpi sattā hi yasmā mīyanti,
analyzed: gabbha gatāḥ api hi mīyanti iti vuttam jaram appattāḥ gabbha gatāḥ api sattāḥ hi yasmai mīyanti
translated: For beings die even in the womb without having reached ageing.🔽That is why the distinction should be understood.

original: tasmā nānattaṃ sampaṭicchitabbaṃ. “Gabbhagatāpi jarappattā bhaveyyu”nti vattabbattā
analyzed: tasmā nānattam sampaṭicchitabbam gabbha gatāḥ api jarappattāḥ bhaveyyun ti vattabba ttā
translated: “But those in the womb would have reached ageing” .🔽It is said: “But they do not become so” .

original: “na ca te jiṇṇā bhavantī”ti vuttaṃ. Jarappattāpi ajiṇṇattā jiṇṇajaraṃ appattāva mīyanti,
analyzed: na ca te jiṇṇāḥ bhavanti iti vuttam jara ppattāḥ api a jiṇṇa ttāḥ jiṇṇa jaram a pattāḥ ava mīyanti
translated: For those who have reached ageing do not become old, and those who have not reached old age die without having become old.

original: evaṃ idhādhippetassa jiṇṇajarāvirahitassa maraṇassa sambhavato aññā jarā, aññaṃ maraṇanti🔽ñātabbanti vuttaṃ hoti. “Na gabbhagatānaṃyeva jiṇṇajaraṃ appattaṃ maraṇaṃ atthi,🔽aññesampi atthī”ti vattabbabhāvato “atthi ca devānaṃ maraṇa”nti vuttaṃ. “Devāpi cirakālasambhavato
analyzed: evam idha adhippetassa jiṇṇa jarā virahitassa maraṇassa sambhavataḥ aññā jarā aññam maraṇanti  ñātabbanti vuttam hoti na gabbha gatānam yeva jiṇṇa jaram appattam maraṇam atthi  aññesam pi atthi iti vattabba bhāvataḥ atthi ca devānam maraṇan ti vuttam devāḥ api cira kāla sambhavato
translated: So it is said: “Thus since there is death without old age and death, it should be understood that there is a difference between old age and death.”🔽It is said: “There is death among the gods” in order to show that death is not only for those who have not reached old age and death while in the womb,

original: jaraṃ pattā bhaveyyu”nti vattabbattā “na ca tesaṃ sarīrāni jīrantī”ti vuttaṃ. “Jarāmaraṇānaṃ🔽nānatte kāraṇaṃ ettakamevā”ti vattabbattā aññampi atthīti dassetuṃ “sakkate vā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha jiṇṇajarāya paṭikammaṃ kātuṃ sakkateva, maraṇassa pana paṭikammassa
analyzed: jaram pattāḥ bhaveyyun ti vattabba ttā na ca tesam sarīrāni jīranti iti vuttam jarā maraṇānam  nānatte kāraṇam ettakam eva ti vattabbattā aññam pi atthi iti dassetum sakkate vā tiādi  vuttam tattha jiṇṇa jarāya paṭikammam kātum sakkatā iva maraṇassa pana paṭikammassa
translated: but also for others. It is said: “Their bodies do not grow old” in order to show that even the gods would reach old age because they exist for a long time.🔽It is said: “There is another reason” in order to show that there is another reason for the difference between old age and death.

original: kātuṃ na sakkateva, imināpi kāraṇena jarāmaraṇānaṃ nānattaṃ sampaṭicchitabbamevāti
analyzed: kātum na sakkatā iva iminā api kāraṇena jarā maraṇānam nānattam sampaṭicchitabbam eva ati
translated: Herein, one can do something about old age and death, but one cannot do anything about death. For this reason too, the difference between old age and death should be accepted.

original: attho. “Na sakkate maraṇassa paṭikammaṃ kātu”nti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu iddhipādabhāvanāya
analyzed: atthaḥ na sakkate maraṇassa paṭikammam kātunti kasmā vuttam nanu iddhipāda bhāvanāya
translated: “He is not able to make an effort to ward off death” — why is this said? Has he not already developed the bases for success?

original: vasībhāve sati sakkā maraṇassāpi paṭikammaṃ kātunti codanaṃ manasi katvā “aññatreva
analyzed: vasībhāve sati sakkā maraṇassa api paṭikammam kātunti codanam manasi katvā aññatra eva
translated: Why is it said that he cannot ward off death? Has he not the power to ward off death if he has the power of the bases of success in action?

original: iddhimantānaṃ iddhivisayā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Jarāmaraṇānaṃ aññamaññaṃ nānābhāvo ācariyena dassito, amhehi ca ñāto, “kathaṃ pana
analyzed: iddhimantānam iddhi visayā ti vuttam  jarā maraṇānaṃ aññamaññam nānābhāvaḥ ācariyena dassitaḥ amhehi ca ñāto katham pana
translated: The answer is: “Except by one who has supernormal power and the range of supernormal power.”🔽The difference between aging and death has been shown by the teacher and is known by us. But how is the difference between craving and aging and death to be understood?

original: taṇhāya jarāmaraṇehi nānābhāvo”ti vattabbato tehi taṇhāya nānattaṃ dassetuṃ “yaṃ
analyzed: taṇhāya jarā maraṇehi nānābhāvaḥ ti vattabbataḥ tehi taṇhāya nānattam dassetum yam
translated: Therefore, in order to show the difference between craving and those two, the following is said: “But when there is no craving, etc.”

original: panāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Taṇhāya avijjamānāyapi jīrantāpi mīyantāpi vītarāgā yasmā dissanti,
analyzed: pana āha atiādi vuttam taṇhāya jīrantā api mīyantā api vīta rāgāḥ yasmā dissanti
translated: Even though there is no craving, those who are free from lust are seen to grow old and die.

original: tasmā taṇhāya jarāmaraṇehi nānābhāvo sampaṭicchitabbo.
analyzed: tasmā taṇhāya jarā maraṇehi nānābhāvaḥ sampaṭicchitabbaḥ
translated: Therefore the difference between craving and aging and death should be admitted.

original: “Taṇhāya jīraṇabhijjanalakkhaṇaṃ atthīti tehi taṇhāya anaññatte ko nāma doso siyā”ti
analyzed: taṇhāya jīraṇa bhijjana lakkhaṇam atthi iti tehi taṇhāya anaññatte kaḥ nāma doso siyāti
translated: “If there is the characteristic of aging and death in craving, what is the fault in not admitting that craving is identical with them?”

original: vattabbato dosaṃ dassetuṃ “yadi cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Jarāmaraṇaṃ yathā yena jīraṇabhijjanalakkhaṇena
analyzed: vattabbataḥ dosam dassetum yadi ca atiādi vuttam jarā maraṇam yathā yena jīraṇa bhijjana lakkhaṇena
translated: In order to show the fault, the following is said: “If aging and death, etc.”

original: pākaṭaṃ, evaṃ jīraṇabhijjanalakkhaṇena taṇhāpi pākaṭā. Yadi ca siyā; evaṃ sante yobbanaṭṭhāpi
analyzed: pākaṭam evam jīraṇa bhijjana lakkhaṇena taṇhā api pākaṭā yadi ca siyā evam sante yobbana ṭṭhā api
translated: Likewise craving is evident in the characteristic of the manifestation of aging-and-death.

original: sabbe māṇavā vigatataṇhā siyuṃ, na ca vigatataṇhā, tasmā nānābhāvo sampaṭicchitabbo.
analyzed: sabbe māṇavā vigata taṇhā siyum na ca vigata taṇhā tasmā nānābhāvaḥ sampaṭicchitabbo
translated: And if it were, then all young men would be free from craving, but they are not free from craving. Therefore the difference must be admitted.

original: Tato aññopi doso āpajjeyyāti dassetuṃ “yathā ca taṇhā dukkhassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽jarāmaraṇānaṃ taṇhāya anaññatte sati taṇhāya bhavataṇhāya dukkhasamudayo hoti, evaṃ🔽jarāmaraṇampi dukkhasamudayo siyā. Yasmā na jarāmaraṇaṃ dukkhasamudayo, tasmā jarāmaraṇehi
analyzed: tatas aññaḥ api doso āpajjeyya iti dassetum yathā ca taṇhā dukkhassa ātiādi vuttam tattha  jarā maraṇānam taṇhāya anaññatte sati taṇhāya bhava taṇhāya dukkha samudayaḥ hoti evam  jarā maraṇam pi dukkha samudayo siyā yasmā na jarā maraṇam dukkha samudayo tasmā jarā maraṇehi
translated: “And if it were otherwise, other faults would follow” . To show this, the following is said:🔽If aging-and-death were not different from craving, then just as craving is the origin of suffering, so aging-and-death would also be the origin of suffering.

original: taṇhāya nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: taṇhāya nānattam veditabbam
translated: But since aging-and-death is not the origin of suffering, therefore craving must be understood as different from aging-and-death.

original: Tehi tāya anaññatte sati evampi doso āpajjeyyāti dassetuṃ “yathā ca taṇhā maggavajjhā”tiādi
analyzed: tehi tāya an aññatte sati evam pi dosaḥ āpajjeyya iti dassetum yathā ca taṇhā magga vajjhā iti ādi
translated: “And if it were otherwise, other faults would follow” . To show this, the following is said:

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha tehi tāya anaññatte sati yathā taṇhā maggavajjhā hoti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇampi
analyzed: vuttam tattha tehi tāya an aññatte sati yathā taṇhā magga vajjhā hoti evam jarā maraṇam pi
translated: If it were otherwise, then just as craving is to be abandoned by the path, so aging-and-death would also be to be abandoned by the path.

original: maggavajjhaṃ siyā. Yathā jarāmaraṇaṃ maggavajjhaṃ na hoti, evaṃ taṇhāpi maggavajjhā
analyzed: magga vajjham siyā yathā jarā maraṇam magga vajjham na hoti evam taṇhā api magga vajjhā
translated: and it may be a state that is not a track of the path. As aging-and-death is not a state that is a track of the path, so too craving may not be a state that is a track of the path.

original: na siyā, tathā ca na hoti pahātabbāpahātabbabhāvato, tasmāpi jarāmaraṇehi taṇhāya
analyzed: na siyā tathā ca na hoti pahātabba a pahātabba bhāvato tasmā api jarā maraṇehi taṇhāya
translated: And it is not so, since it is to be abandoned and not to be abandoned. Therefore the difference between craving and aging-and-death

original: nānattaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nānattam veditabbam
translated: should be understood.

original: “Yadi cātiādinā vuttāya yuttiyā upapattiyā eva jarāmaraṇehi taṇhāya aññattaṃ gavesitabba”nti
analyzed: yadi ca ati ādinā vuttāya yuttiyā upapattiyā eva jarā maraṇehi taṇhāya aññattam gavesitabbanti
translated: “If it should be sought by reason of the argument stated thus ‘If it were the same as aging-and-death, etc.,’ then it should be sought by other reasons as well”

original: vattabbattā aññehipi kāraṇehi gavesitabbanti dassetuṃ “imāya yuttiyā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vattabba ttā aññehi pi kāraṇehi gavesitabbanti dassetum imāya yuttiyā itiādi vuttam
translated: is the meaning of the words “By this argument, etc.”

original: Tattha imāya yuttiyāti yā yutti “yadi cā”tiādinā vuttāya imāya yuttiyā upapattiyā.
analyzed: tattha imāya yuttiyā ati yā yutti yadi ca ati ādinā vuttāya imāya yuttiyā upapattiyā
translated: Herein, by this argument means by this argument stated thus “If it were the same as aging-and-death, etc.”

original: Aññamaññehi kāraṇehi aññehi aññehi kāraṇabhūtehi upapattīhi jarāmaraṇehi taṇhāya
analyzed: aññamaññehi kāraṇehi aññehi aññehi kāraṇa bhūtehi upapattīhi jarā maraṇehi taṇhāya
translated: The meaning is: the difference between craving and aging-and-death should be sought by other reasons, by other arguments.

original: aññattaṃ gavesitabbanti attho. “Aññamaññehi kāraṇehi gavesitabba”nti kasmā vuttaṃ,
analyzed: aññattam gavesitabbanti atthaḥ aññamaññehi kāraṇehi gavesitabbanti kasmā vuttam
translated: Why is it said “It should be sought by other reasons”?

original: nanu yuttiyā, atthato ca aññattaṃ sandissatīti codanaṃ manasi katvā “yadi ca sandissatī”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha yuttisamāruḷhaṃ atthato ca maraṇehi taṇhāya ca aññattaṃ yadi ca sandissati,
analyzed: nanu yuttiyāḥ atthato ca aññattam sandissati iti codanam manasi katvā yadi ca sandissati iti ādim āha  tattha yutti samāruḷham atthataḥ ca maraṇehi taṇhāya ca aññattam yadi ca sandissati
translated: “But does it not appear to be different in meaning and in phrasing?”

original: byañjanatopi aññattaṃ gavesitabbamevāti attho.
analyzed: byañjanataḥ pi aññattam gavesitabbam eva iti attho
translated: If it appears to be different in meaning and in phrasing, then it should be sought out as to whether it is different in phrasing too.🔽“How should it be sought out as to whether it is different in phrasing?”

original: “Kathaṃ byañjanato aññattaṃ gavesitabba”nti vattabbattā “salloti vā”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha “sallo”ti vā “dhūpāyana”nti vā dvīhi byañjanehi vuccamānānaṃ imesaṃ icchātaṇhāsaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: katham byañjanataḥ aññattam gavesitabbanti vattabbattā sallo ti vā ātiādi vuttam  tattha sallaḥ ti vā dhūpāyananti vā dvīhi byañjanehi vuccamānānam imesam icchā taṇhā saṅkhātānam
translated: “As ‘sallo’ or ‘dhūpāyana’ ” is said.

original: dhammānaṃ atthato ekattaṃ samānattaṃ yujjati, na aññattaṃ. “Sallo”ti vā “dhūpāyana”nti
analyzed: dhammānam atthataḥ ekattam samānattam yujjati na aññattam vā
translated: Herein, it is proper that the meaning of these ideas consisting of craving called “desire” should be the same, should be common, when they are called “sallo” and “dhūpāyana” by two different phrases, and that they should not be different.

original: vā dvīhi byañjanehi avuccamānānaṃ jarāmaraṇānaṃ taṇhāya ekattaṃ na yujjati. Tamevatthaṃ
analyzed: vā dvīhi byañjanehi a vuccamānānam jarā maraṇānam taṇhāyaḥ ekattam na yujjati tamevattham
translated: It is not proper that the meaning of ageing-and-death should be the same as that of craving when they are not called by the two phrases “sallo” and “dhūpāyana.”

original: vivarituṃ “na hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha icchāya ca taṇhāya ca atthato aññattaṃ na yujjati,
analyzed: vivaritum na hi itiādi vuttam tattha icchāya ca taṇhāya ca atthataḥ aññattam na yujjati
translated: In order to make that meaning clear, “No, friend” is said. Herein, it is not proper that the meaning of desire and of craving should be different,

original: ekattameva yujjatīti yojanā. Icchāya ca taṇhāya ca jīraṇabhijjanasambhavato jarāmaraṇehi
analyzed: ekattam eva yujjati iti yojanā icchāya ca taṇhāya ca jīraṇa bhid jana sambhavataḥ jarā maraṇehi
translated: it is proper to construe craving as one with aging and death.🔽Since it can be asked: “Why is it proper to construe them as different?”

original: taṇhāya ekattaṃ siyā, “kasmā aññattaṃ yutta”nti vattabbato “taṇhāya adhippāye”tiādi
analyzed: taṇhāya ekattam siyā kasmai aññattam yuttan ti vattabbataḥ taṇhāya adhippāya itiādi
translated: it is said: “When craving is not fulfilled, etc.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha taṇhāya adhippāye aparipūramāne navasu āghātavatthūsu kodho ca uppajjati,
analyzed: vuttam tattha taṇhāya adhippāye aparipūramāne navasu āghāta vatthūsu kodhaḥ ca uppajjati
translated: Herein, when craving is not fulfilled, anger and enmity arise in the nine grounds for anger.

original: upanāho ca uppajjati. Jarāmaraṇesu aparipūramānesu navasu āghātavatthūsu kodho ca🔽na uppajjati, upanāho ca na uppajjati. Iti imāya yuttiyā jarāya ca maraṇassa ca taṇhāya
analyzed: upanāhaḥ ca uppajjati jarā maraṇesu a paripūramānesu navasu āghāta vatthūsu kodho ca  na uppajjati upanāhaḥ ca na uppajjati iti imāya yuttiyā jarāya ca maraṇassa ca taṇhāya
translated: When aging and death are not fulfilled, anger and enmity do not arise in the nine grounds for anger.

original: ca atthato aññattaṃ yujjatiyevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Yadi icchā taṇhāya atthato ekattaṃ yuttaṃ, evaṃ sati kasmā bhagavatā “maccunābbhāhato
analyzed: ca atthataḥ aññattam daṭṭhabbam  yadi icchā taṇhāya atthataḥ ekattam yuttam evam sati kasmai bhagavatā
translated: Thus, by this method, it should be seen that it is proper to construe aging and death as different in meaning from craving.🔽If it is proper to construe desire as one in meaning with craving, then why is it stated in two ways in the verse: “The world is afflicted by the dart of death,🔽afflicted by the dart of craving,🔽enveloped by the dart of craving,

original: loko”tiādigāthāyaṃ “taṇhāsallena otiṇṇo, icchādhūpāyito sadā”ti dvidhā vuttāti codanaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā sallena otiṇṇaḥ icchā dhūpāyito sadā iti dvidhā vuttā ati codanam
translated: always burning with the fire of desire” ?

original: pariharanto “yaṃ panidaṃ bhagavatā”tiādimāha. Tattha “icchā”tipi “taṇhā”tipi dvīhi
analyzed: pariharantaḥ yam pan idam bhagavatā ati ādim āha tattha icchā atipi taṇhā atipi dvīhi
translated: In order to avoid this, he says, “But this craving, which is spoken of by the Exalted One in two ways,” etc. Herein, “craving” and “thirst” are two terms

original: nāmehi yaṃ panidaṃ abhilapitaṃ yaṃ panidaṃ abhilapanaṃ kataṃ, idaṃ abhilapanaṃ bhagavatā
analyzed: nāma ihi yam panidam abhilapitam yam panidam abhilapanam katam idam abhilapanam bhagavatā
translated: that are used by the Exalted One to refer to the same thing. This is the meaning: “This craving, which is spoken of by the Exalted One in two ways,

original: bāhirānaṃ icchitabbatasitabbānaṃ vatthūnaṃ rūpādiārammaṇānaṃ bhedānaṃ vasena “icchā”tipi🔽“taṇhā”tipi dvīhi nāmehi abhilapitaṃ abhilapanavasena katanti ekattaṃ yuttameva,
analyzed: bāhirānam icchitabba tasitabbānam vatthūnam rūpa ādi ārammaṇānam bhedānam vasena  dvīhi nāmehi abhilapitam abhilapana vasena ekattam yuttam eva
translated: ‘craving’ and ‘thirst,’ in terms of the various external objects of desire, such as visible forms, etc., is rightly regarded as one,

original: na nānattanti attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: na nānattanti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: not as different.”

original: “Nāmavasena dvidhā vuttānaṃ icchātaṇhādīnaṃ kena ekattaṃ yuttanti saddahitabba”nti
analyzed: nāma vasena dvidhā vuttānam icchā taṇhā ādīnam kena ekattam yuttan ti saddahitabbanti
translated: “But why is it rightly regarded as one, in spite of the fact that it is spoken of in two ways in terms of different names?”

original: vattabbattā “sabbāhī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha nānānāmavasena pabhedā sabbā icchādikā
analyzed: vattabba ttā sabbāhi itiādi vuttam tattha nānā nāma vasena pabhedā sabbā icchā ādikā
translated: In order to answer this question, he says, “All craving, etc., is rightly regarded as one,” etc. Herein, all craving, etc., which is divided into different kinds by way of different names,

original: taṇhā ajjhosānalakkhaṇena ekalakkhaṇā hi yasmā yuttā, tasmā nāmavasena bhinnānampi
analyzed: taṇhā ajjhosāna lakkhaṇena eka lakkhaṇā hi yasmā yuttā tasmā nāma vasena
translated: is rightly regarded as one, because it is characterized by a single characteristic, that of clinging.

original: ekalakkhaṇena ekattaṃ yuttanti saddahitabbanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Kimiva yutta”nti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: eka lakkhaṇena ekattam yuttanti saddahitabbanti daṭṭhabbam kim iva yuttanti pucchitabba ttā
translated: “How is it unified?”

original: “yathā sabbo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha kaṭṭhaggiādivasena aneko sabbo aggi uṇhattalakkhaṇena
analyzed: yathā sabba uti ādi vuttam tattha kaṭṭhaggi ādi vasena anekaḥ sabbaḥ aggi uṇhatta lakkhaṇena
translated: The answer is: “As all is by heat.” Herein, all fire, which is manifold by way of logs, etc., is unified by the single characteristic of heat.

original: ekalakkhaṇo yathā, evaṃ ajjhosānalakkhaṇena ekalakkhaṇāti yojanā. Sabbassa aggino
analyzed: eka lakkhaṇaḥ yathā evam ajjhosāna lakkhaṇena eka lakkhaṇā ati yojanā sabbassa aggino
translated: Just as all fire is unified by the single characteristic of heat, so craving is unified by the single characteristic of cleaving.🔽“But,” it may be asked, “why does the Exalted One not say simply ‘craving’ but rather ‘fire’?”🔽The answer is: “To show the many names for fire by way of its objective supports.”

original: upādānavasena anekāni nāmāni sarūpato dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tassattho pākaṭo.🔽Ārammaṇavasena taṇhā aññehi aññehi nāmehi bhagavatā abhilapitā, upādānavasena aggi🔽aññehi aññehi nāmehi abhilapitoti yojanā kātabbā.
analyzed: upādāna vasena anekāni nāmāni sarūpataḥ dassetum api ca atiādi vuttam tassa atthaḥ pākaṭaḥ  ārammaṇa vasena taṇhā aññehi aññehi nāmehi bhagavatā abhilapitā upādāna vasena aggi  aññehi aññehi nāmehi abhilapito ti yojanā kātabbā
translated: The meaning is plain.🔽The Exalted One has spoken of craving by different names according to its different objective supports. He has spoken of fire by different names according to its different kinds of clinging.

original: “Vissajjanagāthāyaṃ āgatanāmehi eva taṇhā abhilapitā”ti pucchitabbattā anekehi nāmehi
analyzed: vissajjana gāthāyam āgata nāmehi eva taṇhā abhilapitā ati pucchitabba ttā anekehi nāmehi
translated: “But,” it may be asked, “why does the Exalted One not speak of craving by the names given in the answer to the question but rather by the names given in the question?”🔽The answer is: “To show that craving is spoken of by many names.”

original: abhilapitāti dassetuṃ “icchāitipī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha icchitabbāni atthāni rūpādīni
analyzed: abhilapitā iti dassetum icchā itipi itiādi vuttam tattha icchitabbāni atthāni rūpa ādīni
translated: The meaning is plain.

original: ārammaṇāni sattā icchanti etāyāti icchā. Tasanti etāyāti taṇhā. Sallati pavisati🔽visappītaṃ sallaṃ viyāti sallā, santāpaṃ lāti ādadātīti vā sallā, santāpaṃ lāti pavattetīti🔽vā sallā. Dhūpāyati santāpeti paridahatīti dhūpāyanā. Sarati ākaḍḍhati avaharati🔽sīghasotā saritā viyāti saritā, sarati sallatīti vā saritā. Visaratīti visattikā.
analyzed: ārammaṇāni sattāḥ icchanti etāya ati icchā tasanti etāya ati taṇhā sallati pavisati  visappītam sallam viyāti sallā santāpam lāti ādadāti iti vā sallā santāpam lāti pavatteti iti  vā sallā dhūpāyati santāpeti paridahati iti dhūpāyanā sarati ākaḍḍhati avaharati  sīgha sotā saritā viyāti saritā sarati sallati iti vā saritā visarati iti visattikā
translated: Craving is so called because it is desired by beings as objects, or because it is craved by them. It is thirst because it thirsts, or because it is itself thirsted for.🔽It is a dart because it is a dart that has entered, or because it darts, or because it is darted.🔽It is burning because it burns, or because it is itself burned, or because it carries off.🔽It is a stream because it flows, or because it is itself flowed along, or because it flows out.🔽

original: Pītivasena sinehatīti sineho. Tāsu tāsu gatīsu kilamathaṃ uppādetīti kilamatho. Sattā🔽rūpādiārammaṇāni maññanti etāyāti maññanā. Bhavaṃ bandhatīti bandho. Āsīyate patthīyateti🔽āsā. Āsiyati patthetīti vā āsā. Pipāsīyateti pipāsā, ārammaṇarasaṃ pipāsatīti vā🔽pipāsā. Abhinandīyateti abhinandanā, abhinandatīti vā abhinandanā. Vitthārato aṭṭhakathāvasena veditabbo.
analyzed: pīti vasena sinehati iti sinehaḥ tāsu tāsu gatīsu kilamatham uppādeti iti kilamathaḥ sattā 🔽rūpa ādi ārammaṇāni maññanti etāya ati maññanā bhavam bandhati iti bandho āsīyate patthīyate iti 🔽āsā āsiyati pattheti iti vā āsā pipāsīyate iti pipāsā ārammaṇa rasam pipāsati iti vā 🔽pipāsā abhinandīyateti abhinandanā abhinandati iti vā abhinandanā vitthārataḥ aṭṭhakathā vasena veditabbo

original: “Taṇhāya icchādippakāravasena ālapitabhāvo kena saddahitabbo”ti vattabbattā “yathā
analyzed: taṇhāyaḥ icchā ādi ppakāra vasena ālapita bhāvaḥ kena saddahitabbaḥ iti vattabba ttā yathā
translated: “By whom is it to be believed that craving is spoken of in the way of desire, etc.?” Since this must be said, it is said: “As

original: ca vevacane”tiādi vuttaṃ. Vevacanahāravibhaṅge “āsā ca pīhā…pe… vevacana”nti yā taṇhā
analyzed: ca vevacana iti ādi vuttam vevacana hāra vibhaṅge āsā ca yā taṇhā
translated: “By whom is it to be believed that craving is spoken of in the way of desire, etc., in the way in which it is stated? ”—in order to answer this, “And as in the synonyms” , etc., is said. In the Synonyms of the Discourse on the Aggregates of Grasping , “Hope, longing, … and synonyms” , is craving.

original: yathā yena pakārena vuttā, tathā tena pakārena vuttāya taṇhāya icchādippakāravasena🔽ālapitabhāvo saddahitabbo. “Vevacanavibhaṅge ācariyena vuttopi bhagavatā avutte kena
analyzed: yathā yena pakārena vuttā tathā tena pakārena vuttāya taṇhāya icchā ādi pakāra vasena  ālapita bhāvaḥ saddahitabbaḥ vevacana vibhaṅge ācariyena vuttaḥ api bhagavatā a vutte kena
translated: In the way in which it is stated, in that way, by that way of statement, it is to be believed that craving is spoken of in the way of desire, etc.,

original: saddahitabbo”ti vattabbattā “yathāha bhagavā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yathā yena pakārena bhagavā
analyzed: saddahitabbaḥ iti vattabbattā yathā āha bhagavā itiādi vuttam yathā yena pakārena bhagavā
translated: “In the Synonyms of the Discourse on the Aggregates of Grasping, it is stated by the teacher, but by whom is it to be believed that it is stated by the Blessed One? ”—in order to answer this, “As the Blessed One said” , etc., is said. In the way in which the Blessed One

original: “rūpe tissā”tiādikaṃ yaṃ vacanamāha, tathā tena pakārena vuttena tena vacanena saddahitabbo
analyzed: rūpe tissa ati ādikam yam vacanam āha tathā tena pakārena vuttena tena vacanena saddahitabbaḥ
translated: said the statement beginning with “In the case of form, there is this craving” , in that way, by that way of statement, it is to be believed that it is stated by that statement.

original: vāti. Evaṃ yujjatīti evaṃ vuttanayena icchātaṇhānaṃ atthato ekattā, jarāya ca maraṇassa
analyzed: vāti evam yujjati iti evam vutta nayena icchā taṇhānam atthataḥ ekattā jarāya ca maraṇassa
translated: “In this way it is fitting” : in this way stated, it is fitting that desire and craving are the same in meaning, and that old age and death are the same in meaning.

original: ca taṇhāya ca atthato aññattā ca “tayo pañhā”ti yaṃ vacanaṃ vuttaṃ, taṃ vacanaṃ yujjatīti attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: ca taṇhāya ca atthataḥ aññattā ca tayo pañhā ati yam vacanam vuttam tam vacanam yujjati iti atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ
translated: The meaning to be understood is that the statement “three questions” is appropriate as a statement of the three questions in the sense of their being different in meaning from craving.

original: 21. “Kenassubbhāhato lokotiādigāthāya tayo pañhā vuttā”ti pañhattayabhāve yutti ācariyena
analyzed: lokaḥ iti ādi gāthāya tayo pañhā vuttā ati pañha ttaya bhāve ācariyena
translated: The teacher has analyzed the appropriateness of the three questions in the verse “By what is the world afflicted? ” ,

original: vibhattā, amhehi ca ñātā. “Tato aññehi pakārehi yutti kathaṃ ñātabbā”ti vattabbabhāvato
analyzed: vibhattā amhehi ca ñātā tatas aññehi pakārehi yutti katham ñātabbā ati vattabba bhāvato
translated: and we have understood it. Now, since it has to be said how the appropriateness is to be known by other methods,

original: aññehi pakārehipi yuttigavesanaṃ dassento “sabbo dukkhūpacāro”tiādimāha. Tattha sabbo
analyzed: aññehi pakārehi pi yutti gavesanam dassento sabbaḥ dukkha upacāraḥ ti ādim āha tattha sabbaḥ
translated: showing the search for appropriateness by other methods, he said “All the occurrence of suffering” . Herein,

original: dukkhūpacāro kāmataṇhāsaṅkhāramūlakoti yujjati, sabbo nibbidūpacāro kāmataṇhāparikkhāramūlakoti
analyzed: dukkhu upacāraḥ kāma taṇhā saṅkhāra mūlakaḥ iti yujjati sabbaḥ nibbida upacāraḥ kāma taṇhā parikkhāra mūlakaḥ ti
translated: all the occurrence of suffering is appropriate as having craving for sensual pleasure as its root, but all the occurrence of dispassion is not appropriate as having craving for sensual pleasure as its root.

original: na yujjati. Vacanatthato pana dukkhassa upacāro pavattīti dukkhūpacāro. Kāmataṇhāpaccayā
analyzed: na yujjati vacana atthataḥ pana dukkhassa upacāraḥ pavatti iti dukkha upacāraḥ kāma taṇhā paccayā
translated: But in the sense of the meaning of the words, the occurrence of suffering is the occurrence of suffering,

original: pavatto saṅkhāro mūlaṃ etassāti kāmataṇhāsaṅkhāramūlako. Nibbidāya upacāro pavattīti
analyzed: pavattaḥ saṅkhāraḥ mūlam etassa ati kāma taṇhā saṅkhāra mūlakaḥ nibbidāya upacāraḥ pavatti iti
translated: and the formation that occurs with craving for sensual pleasure as condition is the root of that, thus it has craving for sensual pleasure as its root. The occurrence of dispassion is the occurrence of dispassion,🔽and the formation that occurs with craving for sensual pleasure as condition is the root of that, thus it has craving for sensual pleasure as its root.

original: nibbidūpacāro. Kāmataṇhāya parikkhārabhūto vatthukāmo mūlaṃ etassāti kāmataṇhāparikkhāramūlakoti.
analyzed: nibbida upacāraḥ kāma taṇhāya parikkhāra bhūtaḥ vatthu kāmaḥ mūlam etassa ati kāma taṇhā parikkhāra mūlakaḥ ti
translated: and the state of dispassion is the state of dispassion that is the proximate cause of the state of dispassion that is the root condition for the abandoning of the craving for sense desires.🔽Herein, the dispassion called “disenchantment” is rightly called “the state of dispassion that is the root condition for the abandoning of the craving for sense desires.”

original: Tattha anabhiratisaṅkhātā ukkaṇṭhā nibbidā kāmataṇhāparikkhāramūlikā yujjati, ñāṇanibbidā🔽kāmataṇhāparikkhāramūlikā na yujjati, tasmā sabbo nibbidūpacāro kāmataṇhāparikkhāramūlakoti
analyzed: tattha anabhirati saṅkhātā ukkaṇṭhā nibbidā kāma taṇhā parikkhāra mūlikā yujjati ñāṇa nibbidā  kāma taṇhā parikkhāra mūlikā na yujjati tasmā sabbaḥ nibbida upacāraḥ kāma taṇhā parikkhāra mūlako ti
translated: But the knowledge-state of dispassion is not rightly called “the state of dispassion that is the root condition for the abandoning of the craving for sense desires.”

original: na pana yujjatīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na pana yujjati iti vuttam
translated: So it is said that “the whole state of dispassion is the state of dispassion that is the root condition for the abandoning of the craving for sense desires” is not rightly called “the state of dispassion that is the root condition for the abandoning of the craving for sense desires.”

original: “Pañhattayabhāve ceva dukkhūpacāranibbidūpacāre ca yā yutti ācariyena vibhattā, sāva
analyzed: pañhattaya bhāve ca iva dukkha upacāra nibbida upacāre ca yā yutti ācariyena vibhattā sā ava
translated: “The teacher has analysed the application of the three times and the application of pain in the case of the state of dispassion.🔽That application should be considered.

original: yutti sallakkhetabbā kiṃ, udāhu imāya yuttiyā aññāpi yutti gavesitabbā ki”nti vattabbato
analyzed: yutti sallakkhetabbā kim udāhu imāya yuttiyā aññā api yutti gavesitabbā kim ti vattabbataḥ
translated: Is it that only that application should be sought, or should another application be sought by means of that application?

original: nayaṃ dassetuṃ “imāyā”tiādimāha. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – pañhattayabhāve ceva dukkhūpacāranibbidūpacāre🔽ca yā yutti mayā vibhattā, imāya yuttiyā anusārena aññamaññehi kāraṇehi tesu tesu
analyzed: nayam dassetum imāya iti ādim āha idam vuttam hoti pañhattaya bhāve ca iva dukkha upacāra nibbida upacāre  ca yā yutti mayā vibhattā imāya yuttiyā anusārena aññamaññehi kāraṇehi tesu tesu
translated: ” In order to show the method, he said “by means of that” . This is what is said: “The application that I have analysed in the case of the three times and the application of pain in the case of the state of dispassion,

original: pāḷippadesesu yuttipi gavesitabbāti.
analyzed: pāḷi ppadesesu yuttipi gavesitabbā ti
translated: by means of that application, by means of other reasons, in the various passages of the texts, that application should be sought.”

original: “Idaṃ nayadassanaṃ saṃkhittaṃ, na sakkā vitthārato gavesitu”nti vattabbato taṃ nayadassanaṃ
analyzed: idam naya dassanam saṃkhittam na sakkā vitthārataḥ gavesitun ti vattabbataḥ tam naya dassanam
translated: “This is the way of seeing things in brief; it cannot be sought in detail” should be said.🔽In order to show that way of seeing things in detail, “Just as the Blessed One” and so on is stated.

original: vitthārato vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “yathā hi bhagavā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Asubhassa jigucchanīyabhāvato
analyzed: vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā dassetum yathā hi bhagavā ati ādi āraddham asubhassa jigucchanīya bhāvato
translated: Because foulness is disgusting,

original: rāguppādo na yutto, tasmā rāgacaritassa puggalassa asubhadesanā rāgavinayāya yuttā.
analyzed: rāga uppādaḥ na yuttaḥ tasmā rāga caritassa puggalassa asubha desanā rāga vinayāya yuttā
translated: the arising of lust is not appropriate. Therefore, the teaching on foulness is appropriate for the subduing of lust for a person of lustful temperament.

original: Mettāya dosapaṭipakkhattā dosacaritassa puggalassa mettādesanā dosavinayāya yuttā.
analyzed: mettāya dosa paṭipakkha ttā dosa caritassa puggalassa mettā desanā dosa vinayāya yuttā
translated: Because loving-kindness is the opposite of hatred, the teaching on loving-kindness is appropriate for the subduing of hatred for a person of hating temperament.

original: Paṭiccasamuppādassa paññāvisayattā mohacaritassa puggalassa paṭiccasamuppādadesanā
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādassa paññā visaya ttā moha caritassa puggalassa paṭiccasamuppāda desanā
translated: Because dependent origination is the domain of wisdom, the teaching on dependent origination is appropriate for the subduing of delusion for a person of deluded temperament.

original: mohavinayāya yuttā. “Rāgacaritassāpi mettādidesanā yujjeyya sabbasattasādhāraṇattā”ti
analyzed: moha vinayāya yuttā rāga caritassa api mettā ādi desanā yujjeyya sabba satta sādhāraṇa ttā ati
translated: “The teaching on loving-kindness and so on would be appropriate for one of lustful temperament too, because it is common to all beings” should be said.

original: vattabbattā “yadi hi bhagavā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tibbakilesassa rāgacaritassa adhippetattā
analyzed: vattabba ttā yadi hi bhagavā atiādi vuttam tibba kilesassa rāga caritassa adhippeta ttā
translated: Therefore, “If the Blessed One” and so on is stated. Because one of lustful temperament, who is a person with a small defilement, is intended,

original: tādisassa puggalassa mettaṃ cetovimuttiṃ yadi deseyya, evaṃ sati mettāvasenapi rāguppajjanato🔽desanā na yujjati. Sukhaṃ paṭipadaṃ vā yadi deseyya, evaṃ sati rāgacaritassa dukkhāpaṭipadāyujjanato
analyzed: tādisassa puggalassa mettam cetaḥ vimuttim yadi deseyya evam sati mettā vasena api rāj uppajjanato  desanā na yujjati sukham paṭipadam vā yadi deseyya evam sati rāga caritassa dukkha a paṭipadā yujjanato
translated: If he were to teach the liberation of will by loving-kindness to such a person, then since lust would arise in him by means of the loving-kindness,🔽the teaching would be inappropriate. Or if he were to teach the pleasant way, then since the painful way would be appropriate for one of lustful temperament,

original: desanā na yujjati. Vipassanāpubbaṅgamaṃ pahānaṃ vā yadipi deseyya, evaṃ sati rāgacaritassa🔽asubhānupassanaṃ vajjetvā vipassanāpubbaṅgamassa pahānassa dukkarato desanā na yujjatīti yojanā.
analyzed: desanā na yujjati vipassanā pubbaṅgamam pahānam vā yadi api deseyya evam sati rāga caritassa  asubha anupassanam vajjetvā vipassanā pubbaṅgamassa pahānassa dukkarataḥ desanā na yujjati iti yojanā
translated: the teaching would be inappropriate. Or if he were to teach the surmounting of lust by means of the contemplation of foulness, then since the surmounting of lust by means of the contemplation of foulness is difficult for one of lustful temperament,🔽the teaching would be inappropriate. This is the construction here.

original: “Bhagavā rāgacaritassā”tiādinā niravasesavasena yutti na vibhattā, nayadassanamevāti
analyzed: bhagavā rāga caritassa ati ādinā niravasesa vasena na vibhattā naya dassanam eva ati
translated: The application of the method by way of the entire absence of lust, etc., is not stated in the way beginning, “If the Blessed One were to teach the Dhamma to one of lustful temperament” ,🔽but only the method of demonstration.

original: yo nayo dassito, tena nayena aññāpi gavesitabbāti dassetuṃ “evaṃ yaṃ kiñcī”tiādi
analyzed: yaḥ nayaḥ dassito tena nayena aññā api gavesitabbā ti dassetum evam yam kiñci itiādi
translated: The meaning is that the method demonstrated should be used to seek out other methods as well. In order to show this, it is said: “Thus, whatever” ,

original: vuttaṃ. Rāgassa yaṃ kiñci anulomappahānaṃ, dosassa yaṃ kiñci anulomappahānaṃ, mohassa
analyzed: vuttam rāgassa yat kiñci anuloma ppahānam dosassa yat kiñci anuloma ppahānam mohassa
translated: and so on. Whatever is the conformity-abandoning of lust, whatever is the conformity-abandoning of hate, whatever is the conformity-abandoning of delusion,

original: yaṃ kiñci anulomappahānaṃ desitaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ anulomappahānaṃ yattakā pāḷippadesā
analyzed: yat kiñci anuloma pahānam desitam tat sabbam anuloma ppahānam yattakā pāḷi ppadesā
translated: Whatever abandoning of defilements is taught in the forward order, all that is abandoning in the forward order. As many words as there are

original: ñāṇassa bhūmi, tattakesu vicayena hārena vicinitvā yuttihārena yojetabbanti yojanā.🔽“Rāgādippahānavasena yutti gavesitabbā”ti vattabbabhāvato aññehipi mettādibrahmavihāraphalasamāpattinavānupubbasamāpattivasībhāvehi
analyzed: ñāṇassa bhūmi tattakesu vicayena hārena vicinitvā yutti hārena yojetabbanti yojanā  rāga ādi ppahāna vasena yutti gavesitabbā ati vattabba bhāvataḥ aññehi pi mettā ādi brahmavihāra phala samāpatti nava anupubba samāpatti vasībhāvehi
translated: in the text, the ground for understanding is the text itself. Having investigated it by analysis, it should be construed by construction of the meaning.

original: vibhajitvā yuttigavesanaṃ dassetuṃ “mettāvihārissā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha mettāvihārissa🔽mettāvihāralābhino sato saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa mettāya byāpādapaṭipakkhattā byāpādo
analyzed: vibhajitvā yutti gavesanam dassetum mettāvihārissa ati ādi āraddham tattha mettāvihārissa  mettā vihāra lābhinaḥ sataḥ saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa mettāya byāpāda paṭipakkha ttā byāpādaḥ
translated: “The construction should be sought by way of the abandoning of lust, etc.,” because it is a matter to be stated. In order to show the search for the construction by way of the other fruits of the divine abidings such as loving-kindness, the attainment of the immaterial jhānas, and mastery, the text begins with the words “of one who abides in loving-kindness” . Herein, it is not proper to teach that “lust will invade and persist in the mind of one who abides in loving-kindness, who has attained loving-kindness, who is possessed of loving-kindness”

original: cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti desanā na yujjatīti ca, mettāvihārissa sato byāpādo🔽pahānaṃ abbhatthaṃ gacchatīti desanā yujjati. Karuṇāvihārissa karuṇāvihāralābhino
analyzed: cittam pariyādāya desanā na yujjati iti ca mettāvihārissa sataḥ byāpādaḥ 🔽pahānam abbhattham gacchati iti desanā yujjati karuṇā vihārissa karuṇā vihāra lābhinaḥ
translated: because lust is abandoned in one who abides in loving-kindness. But it is proper to teach that “lust will not invade and persist in the mind of one who abides in loving-kindness” because lust is abandoned in one who abides in loving-kindness. It is not proper to teach that “ill will will invade and persist in the mind of one who abides in compassion, who has attained compassion, who is possessed of compassion”🔽because ill will is abandoned in one who abides in compassion. But it is proper to teach that “ill will will not invade and persist in the mind of one who abides in compassion” because ill will is abandoned in one who abides in compassion.

original: sato saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa karuṇāya vihesāya paṭipakkhattā vihesā cittaṃ pariyādāya
analyzed: sataḥ saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa karuṇāya vihesāya paṭipakkhattā vihesā cittam pariyādāya
translated: because of the opposition of compassion to cruelty, cruelty does not invade the mind of one who is mindful and discerning.

original: ṭhassatīti desanā na yujjati, karuṇāvihārissa sato vihesā pahānaṃ abbhatthaṃ gacchatīti🔽desanā yujjati. Muditāvihārissa muditāvihāralābhino sato saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa🔽muditāya aratiyā paṭipakkhattā arati cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti desanā na yujjati,
analyzed: desanā na yujjati karuṇā vihārissa sataḥ vihesā pahānam abbhattham gacchati iti  desanā yujjati muditāvihārissa muditāvihāra lābhinaḥ sataḥ saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa  muditāya aratiyā arati cittam pariyādāya ṭhassati iti desanā na yujjati
translated: Because of the opposition of compassion to harm, it is not proper to teach that harm will invade the mind of one who possesses compassion and is still found to exist.🔽But it is proper to teach that the abandoning of harm is the outcome for one who possesses compassion.🔽Because of the opposition of gladness to discontent, it is not proper to teach that discontent will invade the mind of one who possesses gladness and is still found to exist.

original: muditāvihārissa sato arati pahānaṃ abbhatthaṃ gacchatīti desanā yujjati. Upekkhāvihārissa🔽upekkhāvihāralābhino sato saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa upekkhāya rāgassa paṭipakkhattā
analyzed: muditā vihārissa sataḥ arati pahānam abbhattham gacchati iti desanā yujjati upekkhā vihārissa  upekkhā vihāra lābhinaḥ sataḥ saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa upekkhāya rāgassa paṭipakkha ttā
translated: But it is proper to teach that the abandoning of discontent is the outcome for one who possesses gladness. Because of the opposition of equanimity to lust,

original: rāgo cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti desanā na yujjati, upekkhāvihārissa sato rāgo pahānaṃ
analyzed: rāgaḥ cittam pariyādāya desanā na yujjati upekkhā vihārissa sataḥ rāgaḥ pahānam
translated: it is not proper to teach that lust will invade the mind of one who possesses equanimity and is still found to exist.

original: abbhatthaṃ gacchatīti desanā yujjati.
analyzed: abbhattham gacchati iti desanā yujjati
translated: But it is proper to teach that the abandoning of lust is the outcome for one who possesses equanimity.

original: Animittavihārissa aniccānupassanāmukhena paṭiladdhaphalasamāpattivihāralābhino sato
analyzed: animitta vihārissa anicca anupassanā mukhena paṭiladdha phala samāpatti vihāra lābhino sato
translated: The teaching that “consciousness occurs with a sign for one who abides in the signless” is not tenable for one who has attained the signless jhāna by insight into impermanence,

original: saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa nimittānusāri tena teneva saṅkhāranimittānusāreneva niccādīsu🔽pahīnena nimittena viññāṇaṃ pavattatīti desanā na yujjati, animittānupassanāya niccādivipallāsapaṭipakkhattā
analyzed: saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa nimitta anusāri tena tena iva saṅkhāra nimitta anusārena iva nicca ādīsu  pahīnena nimittena viññāṇam pavattati iti desanā na yujjati a nimitta anupassanāya nicca ādi vipallāsa paṭipakkha ttā
translated: because the sign of formations, which is the cause of the perversions of perception, etc., is still present for him.

original: animittavihārissa sato nimittaṃ pahānaṃ abbhatthaṃ gacchatīti desanā yujjati. “Asmī”ti🔽maññitaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ attavigataṃ “ayaṃ khandhapañcako ahaṃ asmī”ti na samanupassāmi,
analyzed: animitta vihārissa sataḥ nimittam pahānam abbhattham gacchati iti desanā yujjati asmi iti  maññitam khandha pañcakam atta vigatam ayam khandha pañcakaḥ aham asmi iti na samanupassāmi
translated: The teaching that “the sign is abandoned for one who abides in the signless” is tenable because insight into the signless is the counteraction to the perversions of perception, etc.🔽The teaching that “the doubt and perplexity ‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? ’ will persist in one who does not see” is not tenable,

original: atha ca pana asamanupassane satipi “me kiṃ asmī”ti “kathaṃ asmī”ti vicikicchā kathaṃkathāsallaṃ
analyzed: atha ca pana a samanupassane sati pi me kim asmi iti katham asmi iti vicikicchā kathaṃkathāsallam
translated: because the five aggregates, which are the object of the conceit “I am,” are absent, and he does not see the five aggregates thus: “This is the self, this is the world.”

original: cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti desanā na yujjati, vicikicchāya pahānekaṭṭhabhāvato
analyzed: cittam pariyādāya ṭhassati iti desanā na yujjati vicikicchāya pahāna ekaṭṭha bhāvato
translated: The teaching that “doubt and perplexity will persist in one who does not see” is not tenable because doubt and perplexity are abandoned in one who sees.

original: “ayaṃ khandhapañcako ahaṃ asmī”ti asamanupassantassa vicikicchā kathaṃkathāsallaṃ🔽pahānaṃ abbhatthaṃ gacchatīti desanā yujjati.
analyzed: ayam khandha pañcakaḥ aham asmi iti a samanupassantassa vicikicchā kathaṃkathāsallam  pahānam abbhattham gacchati iti desanā yujjati
translated: This teaching is appropriate.

original: “Phalasamāpattivaseneva yutti gavesitabbā ki”nti vattabbattā jhānasamāpattivasenapi
analyzed: phala samāpatti vasena iva yutti gavesitabbā kinti vattabba ttā jhāna samāpatti vasena api
translated: “But why should the appropriateness be sought only in the case of one who abides in fruition attainment? It should also be sought in the case of one who abides in jhāna attainment.”

original: yutti gavesitabbāti dassetuṃ “yathā vā pana paṭhamaṃ jhāna”ntiādi āraddhaṃ. Atha
analyzed: yutti gavesitabbā ti dassetum yathā vā pana paṭhamam jhāna nti ādi āraddham atha
translated: To show this, the following sutta is cited: “Or just as, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahat, a destroyer of cankers, one who has reached fulfilment, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetter of becoming, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, his taints are destroyed, and he abides mindful and clearly comprehending, having attained the destruction of the taints.🔽“Or just as, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahat, a destroyer of cankers, one who has reached fulfilment, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetter of becoming, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, his taints are destroyed, and he abides mindful and clearly comprehending, having attained the destruction of the taints.

original: vā “phalasamāpattivihārisseva yutti gavesitabbā ki”nti vattabbattā jhānasamāpattivasenapi🔽yutti gavesitabbāti dassetuṃ “yathā vā pana paṭhamaṃ jhāna”ntiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha🔽yathā paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa phalasamāpattivihārissa yutti gavesitabbā, evaṃ
analyzed: vā phala samāpatti vihārissa iva yutti gavesitabbā kinti vattabba ttā jhāna samāpatti vasena api  yutti gavesitabbā ti dassetum yathā vā pana paṭhamam jhāna nti ādi āraddham tattha  yathā paṭhamam jhānam samāpannassa phala samāpatti vihārissa yutti gavesitabbā evam
translated: “Or just as, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahat, a destroyer of cankers, one who has reached fulfilment, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetter of becoming, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, his taints are destroyed, and he abides mindful and clearly comprehending, having attained the destruction of the taints.🔽“Or just as, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahat, a destroyer of cankers, one who has reached fulfilment, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetter of becoming, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, his taints are destroyed, and he abides mindful and clearly comprehending, having attained the destruction of the taints.

original: jhānasamāpattivihārissapi yutti gavesitabbā. Kathaṃ? Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa
analyzed: jhāna samāpatti vihārissa api yutti gavesitabbā katham paṭhamam jhānam samāpannassa
translated: “Or just as, bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahat, a destroyer of cankers, one who has reached fulfilment, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetter of becoming, and is completely liberated through

original: paṭhamajjhānasamaṅgino sato saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa nīvaraṇavikkhambhanato kāmarāgabyāpādā🔽visesāya dutiyajjhānāya saṃvattantīti desanā na yujjati, kāmarāgabyāpādā jhānassa🔽hānāya saṃvattantīti desanā yujjati. Vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā upacāradhammena
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna samaṅginaḥ sataḥ saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa nīvaraṇa vikkhambhanato kāma rāga byāpādāḥ  visesāya dutiya jhānāya saṃvattanti iti desanā na yujjati kāma rāga byāpādāḥ jhānassa  hānāya saṃvattanti iti desanā yujjati vitakka sahagatā saññā manasikārā upacāra dhammena
translated: and the teaching that the abandoning of lust and hate is due to the suppression of the hindrances in one who possesses the first jhāna and is a person in whom lust and hate are present is not tenable, while the teaching that lust and hate are a hindrance to the jhāna is tenable.🔽And the teaching that applied-thought-accompanied perception and attention are a hindrance to the second jhāna is not tenable, while the teaching that applied thought is a hindrance to the second jhāna is tenable.🔽

original: saha dutiyajjhānadhammā jhānassa hānāya saṃvattantīti desanā na yujjati, vitakkasahagatā🔽saññāmanasikārā visesāya uparijhānatthāya saṃvattantīti desanā yujjati.🔽Dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa sato saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa vitakkavicārasahagatā🔽vā saññāmanasikārā upacāradhammena saha paṭhamajjhānadhammā visesāya uparijhānatthāya🔽saṃvattantīti desanā na yujjati, vitakkavicārasahagatā saññāmanasikārā avitakkajhānassa
analyzed: saha dutiya jhāna dhammā jhānassa hānāya saṃvattanti iti desanā na yujjati vitakka sahagatā 🔽saññā manasikārāḥ visesāya upari jhāna atthāya saṃvattanti iti desanā yujjati 🔽dutiyam jhānam samāpannassa sataḥ saṃvijjamānassa puggalassa vitakka vicāra sahagatā 🔽vā saññā manasikārāḥ upacāra dhammena saha paṭhama jhāna dhammāḥ visesāya upari jhāna tthāya 🔽saṃvattanti iti desanā na yujjati vitakka vicāra sahagatā saññā manasikārā avitakka jhānassa
