original: hānāya saṃvattantīti desanā yujjati. Upekkhāsahagatā vā saññāmanasikārā upacāradhammena
analyzed: hānāya saṃvattanti iti desanā yujjati upekkhā sahagatāḥ vā saññā manasikārāḥ upacāra dhammena
translated: and it is proper to teach that they lead to the falling away from it.🔽But it is not proper to teach that the kinds of applied thought associated with equanimity lead to the falling away from the jhāna, since they are of the same plane as the jhāna.

original: saha catutthajjhānadhammā jhānassa hānāya saṃvattantīti desanā na yujjati, upekkhāsahagatā
analyzed: saha catuttha jhāna dhammā jhānassa hānāya saṃvattanti iti desanā na yujjati upekkhā sahagatā
translated: And it is proper to teach that they lead to distinction, to the higher jhāna.

original: saññāmanasikārā visesāya uparijhānatthāya saṃvattantīti desanā yujjati. Sesesupi
analyzed: saññā manasikārāḥ visesāya upari jhāna atthāya saṃvattanti iti desanā yujjati sesesu pi
translated: And the same method of explanation applies to the rest.

original: atthānurūpaṃ yojanā kātabbā. Yathāvuttasamāpattīsu vasībhāvena paricitaṃ kallatāparicitaṃ cittaṃ nāma.
analyzed: attha anurūpam yojanā kātabbā yathāvutta samāpattīsu vasībhāvena paricitam kalla tā paricitam cittam nāma
translated: The “readiness” is the name for the “readiness” consisting in the “readiness to be bent” in the various attainments described above, which is due to the “readiness” due to mastery.

original: Ettakameva yuttigavesanaṃ na kātabbaṃ, navavidhasuttantesu yathāladdhayuttigavesanampi🔽kātabbanti dassetuṃ “evaṃ sabbe”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Sabbesaṃ hārānaṃ yathāvuttabhūmigocarānaṃ
analyzed: ettakam eva yutti gavesanam na kātabbam navavidha suttantesu yathā laddha yutti gavesanam pi  kātabbam ti dassetum evam sabba iti ādi vuttam sabbesam hārānam yathā vutta bhūmi gocarānam
translated: This is the only investigation that need be made. And in the case of the nine kinds of pliability mentioned in the Navavidhasutta, the investigation should be made in the way stated there.🔽In order to show that, it is said: “So too in all” .

original: vicayahārena vicinitvā yuttihārena yojetabbabhāvo kena saddahitabbo”ti vattabbattā
analyzed: vicaya hārena vicinitvā yutti hārena yojetabba bhāvaḥ kena saddahitabbaḥ iti vattabba ttā
translated: The meaning is this: “Having investigated with the investigation of the meaning of all the terms in the way stated, the meaning of the terms in the investigation of the cause should be construed in the way stated.”

original: “tenāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tena yojetabbabhāvena āyasmā mahākaccāno “sabbesa”ntiādikaṃ
analyzed: tena āha atiādi vuttam tattha tena yojetabba bhāvena āyasmā mahākaccāno
translated: “Therefore” : the venerable Maha Kaccana said the words beginning with “all” .

original: yaṃ vacanaṃ āha, tena vacanena saddahitabboti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yam vacanam āha tena vacanena saddahitabbaḥ iti vuttam hoti
translated: What is meant is that one should believe in those words by taking them as a basis for reasoning.

original: Iti yuttihāravibhaṅge sattibalānurūpā racitā
analyzed: iti yutti hāra vibhaṅge satti bala anurūpā racitā
translated: Thus the exposition of the mode of Conveying a Construing is composed in accordance with the measure of the needle.

original: Vibhāvanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vibhāvanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition is finished.

original: Paṇḍitehi pana aṭṭhakathāṭīkānusārena gambhīrattho vitthārato vibhajitvā gahetabboti.
analyzed: paṇḍitehi pana aṭṭhakathā ṭīkā anusārena gambhīra atthaḥ vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā gahetabbaḥ ti
translated: But it should be taken in detail with deep meaning according to the Commentary and Subcommentary by the wise.

original: 4. Padaṭṭhānahāravibhaṅgavibhāvanā
analyzed: pada ṭṭhāna hāra vibhaṅga vibhāvanā
translated: The exposition of the mode of Conveying an Investigation of Terms

original: 22. Yena yena saṃvaṇṇanāvisesabhūtena yuttihāravibhaṅgabhūtena pañhāvissajjanādīnaṃ🔽yuttāyuttabhāvo vibhatto, so saṃvaṇṇanāvisesabhūto yuttihāravibhaṅgo paripuṇṇo, “katamo
analyzed: yena yena saṃvaṇṇanā visesa bhūtena yutti hāra vibhaṅga bhūtena pañhā vissajjana ādīnam  yutta ayutta bhāvaḥ vibhattaḥ saḥ saṃvaṇṇanā visesa bhūto yutti hāra vibhaṅgaḥ paripuṇṇaḥ katamaḥ
translated: . By whatever special kind of commentary, namely, the mode of Conveying a Construing, the suitability or unsuitability of the answers to the questions, etc.,

original: padaṭṭhānahāravibhaṅgo”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha katamo padaṭṭhāno hāro”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: padaṭṭhāna hāra vibhaṅgo ti pucchitabba ttā tattha katamo padaṭṭhānaḥ hāra iti ādi āraddham
translated: is investigated, that special kind of commentary, namely, the mode of Conveying a Construing, is complete. Since it is necessary to ask “What is the mode of Conveying an Investigation of Terms? “ , the passage beginning “Herein, what is the mode of Conveying an Investigation of Terms? “ is undertaken.

original: Tattha tatthāti tesu niddiṭṭhesu soḷasasu desanāhārādīsu hāresu katamo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso
analyzed: tattha tattha ati tesu niddiṭṭhesu soḷasasu desanā hāra ādīsu hāresu katamaḥ saṃvaṇṇanā viseso
translated: Herein, herein, in those sixteen kinds of Conveyings of Threads, etc., mentioned above, what is the special kind of commentary?

original: padaṭṭhāno hāro padaṭṭhānahāravibhaṅgoti pucchati. “Dhammaṃ desesi jino”tiādiniddesassa
analyzed: pada ṭṭhānaḥ hāro pada ṭṭhāna hāra vibhaṅgo ti pucchati dhammam desesi jinoti ādi niddesassa
translated: He asks, “What is the Mode Conveying a Meaning by a Basis?”🔽The detailed exposition of the Mode Conveying a Meaning by a Basis is the special detailed explanation beginning with the words “The Jina taught the True Idea” and

original: idāni mayā vuccamāno “ayaṃ padaṭṭhāno hāro”tiādiko vitthārasaṃvaṇṇanāviseso padaṭṭhānahāravibhaṅgoti
analyzed: idāni mayā vuccamānaḥ ayam padaṭṭhānaḥ hāraḥ ti ādikaḥ vitthāra saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ padaṭṭhāna hāra vibhaṅgaḥ ti
translated: now being given by me, which should be known as “the Mode Conveying a Meaning by a Basis.”

original: viññeyyo. Tena vuttaṃ – “tattha katamo padaṭṭhāno hārotiādi padaṭṭhānahāravibhaṅgo”ti.
analyzed: viññeyyaḥ tena vuttam tattha katamo padaṭṭhānaḥ hāra itiādi padaṭṭhāna hāra vibhaṅgo ti
translated: Hence it was said above, “Herein, what is the Mode Conveying a Meaning by a Basis? ”

original: “Ayaṃ idāni vuccamāno vitthārabhūto padaṭṭhāno hāro piṭakattaye desitesu dhammesu🔽kiṃ nāma dhammaṃ desayati saṃvaṇṇetī”ti pucchaṃ ṭhapetvā “idaṃ āsannakāraṇaṃ imassa
analyzed: ayam idāni vuccamānaḥ vitthāra bhūto padaṭṭhānaḥ hāraḥ piṭaka ttaye desitesu dhammesu  kim nāma dhammam desayati saṃvaṇṇeti iti puccham ṭhapetvā idam āsanna kāraṇam imassa
translated: The Mode Conveying a Meaning by a Basis, which is now being given in detail, is the basis for the True Idea taught in the three Baskets.🔽What is the True Idea that he teaches, that he expounds?

original: āsannaphalassa padaṭṭhāna”nti niyametvā vibhajituṃ “ayaṃ padaṭṭhāno”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: āsanna phalassa padaṭṭhānam ti niyametvā vibhajitum ayam padaṭṭhānaḥ tiādi vuttaṃ
translated: Having set up the question, he then divides it up by determining it thus, “This is the basis for this proximate cause, for this proximate fruit,” and he says “The Mode Conveying a Meaning by a Basis” .

original: Tassattho – sabbesu viññeyyadhammesu yāthāvato asampaṭivedho lakkhaṇaṃ etissā avijjāyāti
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ sabbesu viññeyya dhammesu yāthāvataḥ asampaṭivedhaḥ lakkhaṇam etissāḥ avijjāya ati
translated: The meaning is this. In all ideas that are to be known, the characteristic of non-penetration of the way things are is ignorance.

original: sabbadhammayāthāvaasampaṭivedhalakkhaṇā, avijjā, tassā avijjāya asubhe “subha”ntiādivipallāsā
analyzed: sabba dhamma yāthāva a sampaṭivedha lakkhaṇā avijjā tassā avijjāya asubhe subha anti ādi vipallāsā
translated: Its characteristic is non-penetration of dhammas as they actually are.

original: padaṭṭhānaṃ āsannakāraṇaṃ. Vipallāse sati avijjā vattati uparūpari jāyati na hāyati,
analyzed: padaṭṭhānam āsanna kāraṇam vipallāse sati avijjā vattati upari upari jāyati na hāyati
translated: The proximate cause of ignorance is the four perversions, which are the footing for ignorance. When there are perversions, ignorance occurs and grows and does not diminish.🔽Therefore the perversions are the proximate cause, the footing, for ignorance.

original: tasmā vipallāsā avijjāya padaṭṭhānaṃ āsannakāraṇaṃ bhavanti. Avijjāya vaṭṭamūlakattā
analyzed: tasmai vipallāsāḥ avijjāya padaṭṭhānam āsanna kāraṇam bhavanti avijjāya vaṭṭa mūla kattā
translated: And since ignorance is the root of the round,

original: taṃ ādiṃ katvā padaṭṭhānaṃ vibhattanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tam ādim katvā padaṭṭhānam vibhattam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: its footing should be understood to be stated beginning with that.

original: Taṇhāyapi vaṭṭamūlakattā tadanantaraṃ taṇhāya padaṭṭhānaṃ vibhajituṃ “ajjhosānalakkhaṇā”tiādi
analyzed: taṇhāya api tad anantaram taṇhāya padaṭṭhānam vibhajitum ajjhosāna lakkhaṇa āti ādi
translated: Since craving is also a root of the round, next to ignorance the Exalted One states the footing for craving thus, “Its characteristic is cleaving” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha piyarūpaṃ sātarūpanti piyasabhāvaṃ sātasabhāvaṃ cakkhādidhammajātaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam tattha piya rūpam sāta rūpam ti piya sabhāvam sāta sabhāvam cakkha ādi dhamma jātam
translated: Herein, what is likable and agreeable is the eye, etc., which have the nature of what is likable and agreeable.

original: Piyanīyasātanīye cakkhādike sati taṇhā vattati uparūpari jāyati, tasmā piyarūpaṃ
analyzed: cakkha ādike sati taṇhā vattati upari upari jāyati tasmā piya rūpam
translated: When there is what is likable and agreeable, craving occurs and grows and does not diminish. Therefore what is likable and agreeable

original: sātarūpaṃ taṇhāya padaṭṭhānaṃ āsannakāraṇaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: sātarūpam taṇhāya padaṭṭhānam āsanna kāraṇam bhavati
translated: is the proximate cause, the footing, for craving.

original: Adinnādāne sati lobho vattati, tasmā adinnādānaṃ lobhassa padaṭṭhānaṃ bhavati. Adinnādānañhi ekavāraṃ uppannampi anādīnavadassanato lobhassa āsannakāraṇaṃ bhavatveva.
analyzed: adinnādāne sati lobhaḥ vattati tasmai adinnādānam lobhassa padaṭṭhānam bhavati adinnādānam hi eka vāram uppannam pi anādīnava dassanataḥ lobhassa āsanna kāraṇam bhavatu eva
translated: Greed occurs when there is taking what is not given, thus taking what is not given is a footing for greed. For even though taking what is not given occurs only once, it is a proximate cause for greed because of the non-perception of danger in it.

original: Kesādīsu asubhesu pavattāyapi subhasaññāya nīlādivaṇṇadīghādisaṇṭhānahasanādibyañjanaggahaṇalakkhaṇattā cakkhundriyādīnaṃ asaṃvaro subhasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: kesa ādīsu asubhesu pavattāya api subha saññāya nīla ādi vaṇṇa dīgha ādi saṇṭhāna hasana ādi byañjana ggahaṇa lakkhaṇa ttā cakkhu indriya ādīnam asaṃvaraḥ subha saññāya padaṭṭhānam bhavati
translated: The uncontrolled state of the eye faculty, etc., is a footing for the perception of beauty because it has the characteristic of apprehending the colour such as blue, etc., the configuration such as long, etc., and the secondary characteristics such as smiling, etc., that occur in the unlovely such as head-hairs, etc.

original: Dukkhadukkhādīsu pavattāyapi sukhasaññāya sāsavaphassūpagamanalakkhaṇattā rūpādīsu assādo sukhasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: dukkha dukkha ādīsu sukha saññāya sa āsava phassu upagamana lakkhaṇa ttā rūpa ādīsu assādaḥ sukha saññāya padaṭṭhānam
translated: The gratification in visible forms, etc., is a footing for the perception of pleasure because it has the characteristic of being the approach of contact accompanied by taints.

original: Rūpakkhandhādīsu aniccesu pavattāyapi niccasaññāya saṅkhatalakkhaṇānaṃ dhammānaṃ asamanupassanalakkhaṇattā rūpakkhandhādīsu niccaggahaṇaṃ viññāṇaṃ niccasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa kkhandha ādīsu aniccesu pavattāya api nicca saññāya saṅkhata lakkhaṇānam dhammānam a samanupassana lakkhaṇa ttā rūpa kkhandha ādīsu nicca ggahaṇam viññāṇam nicca saññāya padaṭṭhānam
translated: The apprehension of permanence in the visible-form aggregate, etc., is a footing for the perception of permanence because it has the characteristic of non-observation of the impermanent nature of things that are formed.

original: Aniccadukkhānattasaṅkhātesu khandhādīsu pavattāyapi attasaññāya aniccasaññādukkhasaññānaṃ asamanupassanalakkhaṇattā ahaṃmamādivasena pavatto nāmakāyo attasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: anicca dukkha anatta saṅkhātesu khandha ādīsu pavattāya api atta saññāya anicca saññā dukkha saññānam a samanupassana lakkhaṇa ttā aham mama ādi vasena pavattaḥ nāmakāyaḥ atta saññāya padaṭṭhānam
translated: The body of terms that occurs as “I” and “mine” is the proximate cause for the perception of self, because the perception of impermanence and the perception of pain do not take into account the perception of self that occurs in regard to the aggregates, etc., which are subject to impermanence, pain, and not-self.

original: Evaṃ avijjādīnaṃ akusalapakkhānaṃ dhammānaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ dassetvā idāni tappaṭipakkhānaṃ🔽vijjādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ dassetuṃ “sabbadhammasampaṭivedhalakkhaṇā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Sabbesu ñeyyadhammesu pavattāya vijjāya sabbadhammasampaṭivedhalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: evam avijjā ādīnam akusala pakkhānam dhammānam padaṭṭhānam dassetvā idāni tad paṭipakkhānam  vijjā ādīnam dhammānam padaṭṭhānam dassetum sabba dhamma sampaṭivedha lakkhaṇā tiādi  vuttam sabbesu ñeyya dhammesu pavattāya vijjāya sabba dhamma sampaṭivedha lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: Having thus shown the proximate causes for the states of the unprofitable side beginning with ignorance, he now shows the proximate causes for the states of the opposite side beginning with🔽penetration of all states. The proximate cause for the penetration of all states is all that is to be known,

original: sabbaṃ neyyaṃ vijjāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Samathassa cittavikkhepasaṅkhātauddhaccapaṭisaṃharaṇasaṅkhātavikkhambhanalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: sabbam neyyam vijjāya padaṭṭhānam  samathassa citta vikkhepa saṅkhāta auddhacca paṭisaṃharaṇa saṅkhāta vikkhambhana lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: because the penetration of all states occurs in regard to all knowable states.🔽The proximate cause for serenity is foulness,

original: paṭibhāganimittabhūtā asubhā samathassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Asubhāya hi taṇhāpaṭipakkhattā,
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimitta bhūtā asubhā samathassa padaṭṭhānam asubhāya hi taṇhā paṭipakkha ttā
translated: because serenity has the characteristic of tranquilizing the agitation called “restlessness” and the characteristic of suppressing the agitation called “perception of beauty.” For foulness is the opposite of craving,

original: taṇhāya ca abhāve samatho tiṭṭhatīti.
analyzed: taṇhāya ca abhāve samathaḥ tiṭṭhati iti
translated: and serenity stands when craving is absent.

original: Adinnādānā veramaṇivasena pavattassa alobhassa icchāvacarapaṭisaṃharaṇalakkhaṇattā adinnādānā veramaṇī alobhassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: adinnādānā veramaṇi vasena pavattassa alobhassa icchāvacara paṭisaṃharaṇa lakkhaṇa ttā adinnādānā veramaṇī alobhassa padaṭṭhānam
translated: Non-greed, which occurs as abstinence from taking-what-is-not-given, has the characteristic of warding off the sphere of will. So abstinence from taking-what-is-not-given is the proximate cause of non-greed.

original: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇivasena pavattassa adosassa abyāpajjalakkhaṇattā pāṇātipātā veramaṇī adosassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: pāṇātipātāḥ veramaṇi vasena pavattassa adosassa abyāpajja lakkhaṇa ttā pāṇātipātāḥ veramaṇī adosassa padaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: Non-hate, which occurs as abstinence from killing breathing things, has the characteristic of non-ill-will. So abstinence from killing breathing things is the proximate cause of non-hate.

original: Sammāpaṭipattivasena pavattassa amohassa vatthuavippaṭipattilakkhaṇattā sammāpaṭipatti amohassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Nibbidāvasena pavattāya asubhasaññāya vinīlakavipubbakagahaṇalakkhaṇattā nibbidā
analyzed: sammā paṭipatti vasena pavattassa amohassa vatthu avippaṭipatti lakkhaṇa ttā sammāpaṭipatti amohassa padaṭṭhānaṃ  nibbidā vasena pavattāya asubha saññāya vinīlaka vipubbaka gahaṇa lakkhaṇa ttā nibbidā
translated: Non-delusion, which occurs as right practice, has the characteristic of non-opposition to the object. So right practice is the proximate cause of non-delusion.🔽The perception of foulness, which occurs as dispassion, has the characteristic of apprehending the bloated and the livid. So dispassion

original: asubhasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ. Nibbidāñāṇena hi anabhirati pavattati, anabhiratiyā ca
analyzed: asubha saññāya padaṭṭhānam nibbidā ñāṇena hi anabhirati pavattati anabhiratiyā ca
translated: is the proximate cause of the perception of foulness. For it is through the knowledge of dispassion that non-delight occurs, and it is through non-delight that

original: asubhasaññā ṭhitāti.
analyzed: asubha saññā ṭhitā ati
translated: the perception of foulness is established.

original: Dukkhavedanāvasena pavattāya dukkhasaññāya sāsavaphassaparijānanalakkhaṇattā vedanā dukkhasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: dukkha vedanā vasena pavattāya dukkha saññāya sa āsava phassa parijānana lakkhaṇa ttā vedanā dukkha saññāya padaṭṭhānam
translated: The feeling of pain, which occurs as the perception of pain, has the characteristic of discerning contact accompanied by taints. So feeling is the proximate cause of the perception of pain.

original: Uppādavayavasena pavattāya aniccasaññāya saṅkhatalakkhaṇānaṃ dhammānaṃ samanupassanalakkhaṇattā🔽uppādavayā aniccasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ. Uppādavayañhi samanupassitvā aniccasaññā pavattā.
analyzed: uppāda vaya vasena pavattāya anicca saññāya saṅkhata lakkhaṇānam dhammānam samanupassana lakkhaṇa ttā  uppāda vayā anicca saññāya padaṭṭhānam uppāda vayam hi samanupassitvā anicca saññā pavattā
translated: The sign of arising and dissolution is the basis for the perception of impermanence, because the perception of impermanence occurs by way of the sign of arising and dissolution, since it has the characteristic of observing formations as having the characteristic of being formed.

original: Dhammamattasaññāvasena pavattāya anattasaññāya sabbadhammaabhinivesalakkhaṇattā dhammasaññā anattasaññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Kāmarāgassa rūpādipañcakāmaguṇārammaṇattā pañca kāmaguṇā kāmarāgassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma matta saññā vasena pavattāya anatta saññāya sabba dhamma abhinivesa lakkhaṇa ttā dhamma saññā anatta saññāya padaṭṭhānam  kāmarāgassa rūpa ādi pañca kāmaguṇa ārammaṇa ttā pañca kāmaguṇā kāmarāgassa padaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: The perception of formations is the basis for the perception of non-self, because the perception of non-self occurs by way of the perception of formations, since it has the characteristic of non-adherence to any of the dhammas.🔽The five cords of sense desire are the basis for sense desire, because sense desire has as its object the five cords of sense desire consisting in forms, etc.

original: Rūpasaṅkhāte kāye ārabbha pavattassa rūparāgassa cakkhādipañcindriyānaṃ anusārena pavattanato pañcindriyāni rūpāni rūparāgassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa saṅkhāte kāye ārabbha pavattassa rūparāgassa cakkha ādi pañca indriyānaṃ anusārena pavattanato pañcindriyāni rūpāni rūparāgassa padaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: The five faculties are the basis for lust for form, because lust for form occurs by way of the five faculties of the eye, etc., since it occurs in dependence on the body consisting in form.

original: Bhavanikantivasena pavattassa bhavarāgassa chaḷāyatanaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ. Nibbattabhavānupassitāti
analyzed: bhava nikanti vasena pavattassa bhava rāgassa chaṭṭhāyatanam padaṭṭhānam nibbatta bhava anupassitā ti
translated: The six bases are the basis for lust for existence, because lust for existence occurs by way of the six bases, since it occurs by way of the inclination to delight in the rebirth process.

original: “edisaṃ aniṭṭhaṃ rūpaṃ mā nibbattatu, edisaṃ iṭṭhaṃ rūpaṃ nibbattatu edisī dukkhā
analyzed: edisam aniṭṭham rūpam mā nibbattatu edisam iṭṭham rūpam nibbattatu edisī dukkhā
translated: “May such and such an undesirable visible form not be produced; may such and such a desirable visible form be produced. May such and such an undesirable feeling …

original: vedanā mā nibbattatu, edisī sukhā vedanā nibbattatū”ti evamādinā pakārena pavattā
analyzed: vedanā mā nibbattatu edisī sukhā vedanā nibbattatu uti evamādinā pakārena pavattā
translated: such and such an undesirable perception … such and such undesirable formations … such and such an undesirable consciousness not be produced; may such and such a desirable consciousness be produced” ,

original: rūpābhinandanā, sā pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa abhinandanā sā pañcannam upādānakkhandhānam padaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: and so on. The footing for this is the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: Kammassakataññāṇassa pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇānugatattā pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇadassanaṃ kammassakataññāṇassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Okappanaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ yassā saddhāyāti okappanalakkhaṇā saddhā. Adhimutti paccupaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kammassakata ññāṇassa pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa anugata ttā pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa dassanam kammassakata ññāṇassa padaṭṭhānaṃ  okappanam lakkhaṇam yassā saddhāya ati okappana lakkhaṇā saddhā adhimutti paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: The knowledge of the ownership of kamma is followed by the knowledge of recollecting past lives, thus the knowledge of recollecting past lives is the footing for the knowledge of the ownership of kamma.🔽Faith has the characteristic of resolving upon what is seen. Its manifestation is resolve.

original: yassā saddhāyāti adhimuttipaccupaṭṭhānā ca saddhā. Anāvilaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ yassa pasādassāti
analyzed: yassa saddhāya ati adhimutti paccupaṭṭhānā ca saddhā anāvilam lakkhaṇam yassa pasādassa ati
translated: Faith has the characteristic of resolving upon what is seen. Its manifestation is resolve. Its footing is confidence.

original: anāvilalakkhaṇoti pasādo. Sampasīdanaṃ paccupaṭṭhānaṃ yassa pasādassāti sampasīdanapaccupaṭṭhāno
analyzed: anāvila lakkhaṇo ti pasādaḥ sampasīdanam paccupaṭṭhānam yassa pasādassa ati sampasīdana paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: Confidence has the characteristic of non-disturbance. Its manifestation is non-disturbance.🔽Its footing is faith. Faith has the characteristic of resolving upon what is seen. Its manifestation is resolve. Its footing is confidence.

original: ca pasādo. So pana pasādo saddhāya eva avatthāvisesoti veditabbo. Aveccapasādo abhipatthiyanalakkhaṇāya
analyzed: ca pasādo saḥ pana pasādaḥ saddhāya eva avatthā visesaḥ ti veditabbaḥ avecca pasādaḥ abhipatthiyana lakkhaṇāya
translated: and confidence. But this confidence should be understood as a particular stage of faith.

original: saddhāya padaṭṭhānaṃ, okappanalakkhaṇā saddhā anāvilalakkhaṇassa pasādassa padaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: saddhāya padaṭṭhānam okappana lakkhaṇā saddhā anāvila lakkhaṇassa pasādassa padaṭṭhānam
translated: Confidence in the sense of non-concealment is the proximate cause for faith characterized by inclination. Faith characterized by the characteristic of non-turbidity is the proximate cause for confidence characterized by the characteristic of non-turbidity.

original: catubbidhaṃ sammappadhānaṃ vīriyaṃ ārambhalakkhaṇassa vīriyassa padaṭṭhānaṃ, kāyādisatipaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: catubbidham sammappadhānam vīriyam ārambha lakkhaṇassa vīriyassa padaṭṭhānam kāya ādi sati paṭṭhānam
translated: The four right efforts are the proximate cause for energy characterized by the characteristic of exertion.🔽The four foundations of mindfulness are the proximate cause for mindfulness characterized by the characteristic of non-distraction.

original: apilāpanalakkhaṇāya satiyā padaṭṭhānaṃ, jhānasahitassa samādhissa ekaggalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: apilāpana lakkhaṇāya satiyā padaṭṭhānam jhāna sahitassa samādhissa ekagga lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: Since concentration accompanied by jhāna has the characteristic of one-pointedness,

original: vitakkādijhānāni samādhissa padaṭṭhānaṃ, paññāya kiccapajānanaārammaṇapajānanalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: vitakka ādi jhānāni samādhissa padaṭṭhānam paññāya kicca pajānana ārammaṇa pajānana lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: the jhānas beginning with applied thought are the proximate cause for concentration. Since understanding has the characteristic of knowing the function and knowing the object,

original: saccāni paññāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽“Yesaṃ avijjādīnaṃ padaṭṭhānāni ācariyena vibhattāni, te avijjādayo katamesaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: saccāni paññāya padaṭṭhānam  yesam avijjā ādīnam padaṭṭhānāni ācariyena vibhattāni te avijjā ādayaḥ katamesam dhammānam
translated: the four truths are the proximate cause for understanding.🔽“The teacher has explained the proximate causes of ignorance, etc. But which states are the proximate causes of these states beginning with ignorance?🔽” Since this question should be asked, in order to show that these states beginning with ignorance are the proximate causes of these states,

original: padaṭṭhānānī”ti pucchitabbattā te avijjādayopi imesaṃ dhammānaṃ padaṭṭhānāti dassetuṃ
analyzed: padaṭṭhānāni iti pucchitabba ttā te avijjā ādayaḥ api imesam dhammānam padaṭṭhānā ti dassetuṃ
translated: he said:

original: “aparo nayo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Avijjā assādamanasikāralakkhaṇassa ayonisomanasikārassa🔽padaṭṭhānaṃ. Avijjāya hi ādīnavacchādanato ayonisomanasikāro jātoti. Saccasammohanalakkhaṇā🔽avijjā puññāpuññāneñjābhisaṅkhārānaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ, punabbhavavirohanalakkhaṇā tebhūmakacetanā🔽saṅkhārā vipākaviññāṇassa padaṭṭhānaṃ, opapaccayikasaṅkhātena upapattibhavabhāvena🔽nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ nāmarūpassa padaṭṭhānaṃ, nāmakāyarūpakāyasaṅghātalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ naya iti ādi vuttam avijjā assāda manasikāra lakkhaṇassa ayoniso manasikārassa  pada ṭṭhānam avijjāya hi ādīnava chādanataḥ a yoniso manasikāraḥ jātaḥ ti sacca sammohana lakkhaṇā  avijjā puñña apuñña aneñja abhisaṅkhārānam padaṭṭhānam punabbhava virohana lakkhaṇā tebhūmaka cetanā  saṅkhārāḥ vipāka viññāṇassa padaṭṭhānam opapaccayika saṅkhātena upapatti bhava bhāvena  nibbatti lakkhaṇam paṭisandhi viññāṇam nāma rūpassa padaṭṭhānam nāma kāya rūpa kāya saṅghāta lakkhaṇam
translated: “Another method” is said. Ignorance is the footing for wrong mental attention, which is characterized by the sign of gratification.🔽For wrong mental attention arises because ignorance conceals the danger. Ignorance, which is characterized by delusion about the truths,🔽is the footing for the formations of merit, etc., which are characterized by the arousing of renewed existence. The volitions of the three planes, which are characterized by the arousing of renewed existence,🔽are the footing for the resultant consciousness, which is characterized by rebirth. Rebirth-linking consciousness, which is characterized by rebirth,🔽is the footing for mentality-materiality, which is characterized by the mass of mentality and materiality.

original: nāmarūpaṃ chaḷāyatanassa padaṭṭhānaṃ sahajātādipaccayabhāvato, cakkhādīnaṃ channaṃ🔽indriyānaṃ pavattānaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ chaḷāyatanaṃ chabbidhassa phassassa yathākkamaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nāma rūpam chaṭṭhāyatanassa padaṭṭhānam sahajāta ādi paccaya bhāvato cakkha ādīnam channam 🔽indriyānam pavattānam lakkhaṇam chaḷāyatanam chabbidhassa phassassa yathākkamam padaṭṭhānam
translated: “Another method” is said. Ignorance is the footing for wrong mental-fashioning, which is characterized by the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the sign of the

original: nissayādipaccayabhāvato, cakkhupasādarūpārammaṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādisannipātalakkhaṇo🔽chabbidho phasso, taṃ vedanāya tena chabbidhena phassena sahajātāya chabbidhāya vedanāya
analyzed: nissaya ādi paccaya bhāvataḥ cakkhu pasāda rūpa ārammaṇam cakkhu viññāṇa ādi sannipāta lakkhaṇo  chabbidhaḥ phassaḥ tam vedanāya tena chabbidhena phassena sahajātāya chabbidhāya vedanāya
translated: Because of the condition of support, etc., the eye-sensitivity-visible-form-sense-base is the condition for eye-consciousness, etc., and the meeting of these is the characteristic of the sixfold contact.🔽That is the proximate cause for the sixfold feeling that is associated with the sixfold contact.

original: yathākkamaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ sahajātādipaccayabhāvato, iṭṭhānubhavanaaniṭṭhānubhavanaiṭṭhāniṭṭhānubhavanalakkhaṇā🔽tividhā vedanā, taṃ taṇhāya tāya tividhāya vedanāya vasena pavattāya taṇhāya padaṭṭhānaṃ🔽upanissayādipaccayabhāvato, saparasantānesu ajjhosānalakkhaṇā taṇhā, taṃ upādānassa
analyzed: yathākkamam padaṭṭhānam sahajāta ādi paccaya bhāvato iṭṭha anubhavana aniṭṭha anubhavana eṭṭha aniṭṭha anubhavana lakkhaṇā  tividhā vedanā tam taṇhāya tāya tividhāya vedanāya vasena pavattāya taṇhāya padaṭṭhānam  upanissaya ādi paccaya bhāvato sa para santānesu ajjhosāna lakkhaṇā taṇhā tam upādānassa
translated: Because of the condition of conascence, etc., the sixfold feeling is the proximate cause for the sixfold craving that is associated with the sixfold feeling.🔽That is the proximate cause for the craving that occurs by means of the sixfold feeling.

original: tāya taṇhāya vasena pavattassa catubbidhassa upādānassa padaṭṭhānaṃ upanissayādipaccayabhāvato.
analyzed: tāya taṇhāya vasena pavattassa catubbidhassa upādānassa padaṭṭhānam upanissaya ādi paccaya bhāvato
translated: Because of the condition of decisive support, etc., craving has the characteristic of cleaving to the continuity of others. That is the proximate cause for the fourfold clinging that occurs by means of that craving.

original: “So vedanāyā”ti ca “sā taṇhāyā”ti ca “sā upādānassā”ti ca pāṭhena bhavitabbaṃ, liṅgavipallāsaniddeso vā siyā.
analyzed: saḥ vedanāya iti ca sā taṇhāya iti ca sā upādānassa ati ca pāṭhena bhavitabbam liṅga vipallāsa niddesaḥ vā siyā
translated: Because of the condition of decisive support, etc. “That feeling” and “that craving” and “that clinging” should be read as “that feeling of his” and “that craving of his” and “that clinging of his,” or else this is a description of a reversal of the genders.

original: Yaṃ upādānaṃ opapaccayikaṃ upapattikkhandhanibbattakaṃ, taṃ upādānaṃ duvidhassa bhavassa
analyzed: yam upādānam opa paccayikam upapatti kkhandha nibbattakam tam upādānam duvidhassa bhavassa
translated: The kind of clinging that is a condition for rebirth-linking and the generation of the aggregates of existence is the basis for the two kinds of becoming.

original: padaṭṭhānaṃ. Yo kammabhavo nāmakāyarūpakāyasambhavanalakkhaṇo, so kammabhavo jātiyā
analyzed: padaṭṭhānam yaḥ kamma bhavaḥ nāma kāya rūpa kāya sambhavana lakkhaṇo so kamma bhavaḥ jātiyā
translated: The kamma-process becoming, which has the characteristic of producing the mentality-materiality of the name-and-form of the next becoming, is the basis for birth.🔽Birth, which is the manifestation of the aggregates in the next becoming, is the basis for ageing.

original: padaṭṭhānaṃ. Yā upapattibhūtā jāti khandhapātubhāvalakkhaṇā, taṃ sā jāti jarāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Yā jiṇṇajarā upadhikkhandhaparipākalakkhaṇā, taṃ sā jiṇṇajarā maraṇassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Yampi yassa sammutimaraṇaṃ jīvitindriyupacchedalakkhaṇaṃ, tampi tassa sammutimaraṇaṃ
analyzed: padaṭṭhānam yā upapatti bhūtā jāti khandha pātubhāva lakkhaṇā tam sā jāti jarāya padaṭṭhānam  yā jiṇṇa jarā upadhi khandha paripāka lakkhaṇā tam sā jiṇṇa jarā maraṇassa padaṭṭhānam  yam pi yassa sammuti maraṇam jīvitindriya upaccheda lakkhaṇam tam pi tassa sammuti maraṇam
translated: Ageing, which has the characteristic of maturing the aggregates of clinging, is the basis for death.🔽Death, which has the characteristic of cutting off the life faculty, is the basis for sorrow. Sorrow, which is the state of one who is anxious because he thinks of the death of a loved one, is the basis for lamentation.

original: sokassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Piyassa maraṇaṃ cintentassa yebhuyyena sokuppajjanato yo soko🔽ñātiādipiyesu ussukkakārako, taṃ so soko paridevassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Yo paridevo lālappakārako,
analyzed: sokassa padaṭṭhānam piyassa maraṇam cintentassa yebhuyyena soka uppajjanataḥ yo soko 🔽ñāti ādi piyesu ussukka kārako tam so soko paridevassa padaṭṭhānam yo paridevaḥ lālappa kārako
translated: Lamentation, which is the state of one who laments, is the basis for pain. Pain, which is the state of one who is afflicted in body, is the basis for grief. Grief, which is the state of one who is afflicted in mind, is the basis for despair. Despair, which is the state of one who is desperate, is the basis for the fever of mental derangement.

original: taṃ so paridevo kāyikadukkhassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Yaṃ kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ kāyasampīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: tam so paridevaḥ kāyika dukkhassa padaṭṭhānam yat kāyikam dukkham kāya sampīḍana lakkhaṇam
translated: The grief is the footing for the bodily pain. The bodily pain, which has the characteristic of oppression of the body,🔽is the footing for the mental pain. The mental pain, which has the characteristic of oppression of cognizance,

original: taṃ kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Yaṃ domanassaṃ cittasampīḷanalakkhaṇaṃ,🔽taṃ domanassaṃ upāyāsassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Yo upāyāso odahanakārako avadahanakārako,🔽taṃ so upāyāso bhavassa upāyāsassa nissayasantānabhavassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Bhavassāti vuttabhavaṃ dassetuṃ “imānī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha bhavaṅgāni kileso bhavassa🔽aṅgaṃ kāraṇaṃ kammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭāni bhavasaṅkhātāni aṅgāni avayavāni. Yadā paccuppannādikāle🔽samaggāni nibbattāni bhavanti, tadā so kilesavaṭṭakammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭasaṅkhāto dhammasamūho
analyzed: tam kāyikam dukkham domanassassa padaṭṭhānam yam domanassam citta sampīḍana lakkhaṇam  tam domanassam upāyāsassa padaṭṭhānam yaḥ upāyāsaḥ odahana kārako avadahana kārako  tam so upāyāsaḥ bhavassa upāyāsassa nissaya santāna bhavassa padaṭṭhānam  bhavassa iti vutta bhavam dassetum imāni itiādi vuttam tattha bhavaṅgāni kilesaḥ bhavassa  aṅgam kāraṇam kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭāni bhava saṅkhātāni aṅgāni avayavāni yadā paccuppanna ādi kāle  samaggāni nibbattāni bhavanti tadā saḥ kilesa vaṭṭa kamma vaṭṭa vipāka vaṭṭa saṅkhātaḥ dhamma samūhaḥ
translated: is the footing for the grief. The grief, which is a burning, a burning up,

original: “bhavassā”ti ettha bhavoti daṭṭhabbo. Taṃ bhavasaṅkhātaṃ kilesavaṭṭakammavaṭṭavipākavaṭṭattayaṃ

original: saṃsārassa padaṭṭhānaṃ purimaṃ purimaṃ jātinipphannakilesādivaṭṭena saṃsārassa abbocchinnuppajjanato,
analyzed: saṃsārassa padaṭṭhānam purimam purimam jāti nipphanna kilesa ādi vaṭṭena saṃsārassa abbocchinna uppajjanato
translated: It is the footing for the round of rebirths because the round of rebirths occurs uninterruptedly in the previous birth, etc., with the defilements produced there.

original: yo ariyamaggo niyyānikalakkhaṇo, taṃ so ariyamaggo nirodhassa nibbānassa padaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ ariya maggo niyyānika lakkhaṇo tam saḥ ariya maggo nirodhassa nibbānassa padaṭṭhānam
translated: The Noble Path, which has the characteristic of leading out, is the footing for cessation, that is, for extinction,

original: sampāpakahetubhāvato.
analyzed: sampāpaka hetu bhāvataḥ
translated: because it is the cause that accomplishes it.

original: Bahussuto sabbasissādīnaṃ patiṭṭhānattā titthaṃ viyāti titthaṃ, jānātīti ñū, titthaṃ🔽ñūti titthaññū, titthaññuno bhāvo titthaññutā, sammāpayirupāsanā, sā pītaññutāya🔽padaṭṭhānaṃ. Bahussutassa hi sammāpayirupāsanāya dhammūpasañhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ jāyati,
analyzed: bahussutaḥ sabba sissa ādīnam patiṭṭhāna ttā tittham viyāti tittham jānāti iti ñū tittham  ñū ti titthaññū titthaññunaḥ bhāvaḥ titthaññu tā sā pītaññu tāya  padaṭṭhānam bahu ssutassa hi dhamma upasañhitam pāmojjam jāyati
translated: The learned one is a “knower of the ford” because he is a “ford” , like a ford for people who need to cross, since he is the support for all disciples and so on. He “knows” , thus he is a “knower” ;🔽a “ford-knower” is a titthaññū; the state of a ford-knower is titthaññutā. Right practice is the footing for that. For when the learned one practices rightly, gladness due to the True Idea arises in him;

original: pāmojjena ca kammaṭṭhānabrūhanā jāyatīti sappāyadhammassavanena pītiṃ jānātīti pītaññū,
analyzed: pāmojjena ca kammaṭṭhāna brūhanā jāyati iti sappāya dhamma ssavanena pītim jānāti iti pītaññū
translated: and when he is glad, the meditation subject is extended. So he is a “knower of gladness” because he knows gladness due to hearing the True Idea that is fit for hearing.

original: pītaññuno bhāvo pītaññutā, kammaṭṭhānassa brūhanā, sā pattaññutāya padaṭṭhānaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānabrūhanāya
analyzed: pītaññunaḥ bhāvaḥ pītaññu tā kammaṭṭhānassa brūhanā sā pattaññu tāya padaṭṭhānam kammaṭṭhāna brūhanāya
translated: The state of a knower of gladness is pītaññutā. Extension of the meditation subject is the footing for that.

original: hi bhāvanāpattajānanatā jāyatīti pattaññutā. Bhāvanāpattajānanatā attaññutāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: hi bhāvanā patta jānana tā jāyati iti pattaññu tā bhāvanā patta jānana tā attaññu tāya padaṭṭhānam
translated: for the knowledge that one has attained what is to be developed comes about, thus it is knowledge of what has been attained. Knowledge of what has been attained is the proximate cause for knowledge of oneself.

original: Bhāvanāpattajānanatāya hi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgatassa attano jānanatā jāyatīti
analyzed: bhāvanā patta jānana tāya hi pañcahi padhāniyaṅgehi samannāgatassa attanaḥ jānana tā jāyati iti
translated: For when one possesses the five factors of striving, the knowledge that one has attained what is to be developed comes about, thus

original: attaññutā pubbekatapuññatāya padaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Padhāniyaṅgesu samannāgatattajānanatāya hi pubbe puññakaraṇaṃ jātaṃ, pubbekatapuññatā
analyzed: attaññu tā pubbekata puñña tāya padaṭṭhānam  padhāniyaṅgesu samannāgata tta jānana tāya hi pubbe puñña karaṇam jātam pubbekata puñña tā
translated: knowledge of oneself is the proximate cause for former practice of merit.

original: patirūpadesavāsassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Pubbe hi katena puññena patirūpadesavāso laddho,🔽patirūpadesavāso sappurisūpanissayassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Patirūpadesavāsena hi sappurisūpanissayo🔽laddho, sappurisūpanissayo attasammāpaṇidhānassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Sappurisūpanissayena
analyzed: pati rūpa desavāsassa padaṭṭhānam pubbe hi katena puññena pati rūpa desavāsaḥ laddho  patirūpa desavāso sappurisa upanissayassa padaṭṭhānam patirūpa desavāsena hi sappurisa upanissayo  laddhaḥ sappurisa upanissayaḥ atta sammāpaṇidhānassa padaṭṭhānam sappurisa upanissayena
translated: For when one possesses the factors of striving, former practice of merit comes about. Former practice of merit is the proximate cause for living in befitting places. For by former practice of merit one obtains living in befitting places.

original: hi attasammāpaṇidhānaṃ jātaṃ, attasammāpaṇidhānaṃ sīlānaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ. Attasammāpaṇidhānena
analyzed: hi atta sammāpaṇidhānam jātam atta sammāpaṇidhānam sīlānam padaṭṭhānam atta sammāpaṇidhānena
translated: Living in befitting places is the proximate cause for association with good people. For by living in befitting places one obtains association with good people. Association with good people is the proximate cause for right disposition of oneself. For by association with good people right disposition of oneself comes about. Right disposition of oneself is the proximate cause for virtue. For by right disposition of oneself virtue comes about.

original: hi sīlāni sampatiṭṭhitāni, sīlāni avippaṭisārassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Attani hi sampatiṭṭhitaṃ🔽sīlaṃ paccavekkhantassa vippaṭisāro natthevāti, avippaṭisārena pāmojjaṃ jāyati, tasmā🔽avippaṭisāro pāmojjassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Pāmojjena pīti jāyati, tasmā pāmojjaṃ pītiyā🔽padaṭṭhānaṃ. Pītiyā passaddhi jāyati, tasmā pīti passaddhiyā padaṭṭhānaṃ. Passaddhiyā🔽sukhaṃ jāyati, tasmā passaddhi sukhassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Sukhena samādhi jāyati, tasmā🔽sukhaṃ samādhissa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Samādhinā yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ jāyati, tasmā samādhi
analyzed: hi sīlāni sampatiṭṭhitāni sīlāni a vippaṭisārassa padaṭṭhānam attani hi sampatiṭṭhitam  sīlam paccavekkhantassa vippaṭisāro nattha eva ati a vippaṭisārena pāmojjam jāyati tasmā  a vippaṭisāro pāmojjassa padaṭṭhānam pāmojjena pīti jāyati tasmā pāmojjam pītiyā  padaṭṭhānam pītiyā passaddhi jāyati tasmā pīti passaddhiyā padaṭṭhānam passaddhiyā  sukham jāyati tasmā passaddhi sukhassa padaṭṭhānam sukhena samādhi jāyati tasmā  sukham samādhissa padaṭṭhānam samādhinā yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanam jāyati tasmā samādhi
translated: for his virtue is well established. Virtue is the footing for non-remorse. For when he reviews his virtue as well established in himself,

original: yathābhūtañāṇassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Yathābhūtañāṇadassanena nibbidāñāṇaṃ jāyati, tasmā🔽yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ nibbidāya padaṭṭhānaṃ. Nibbidāya virāgo jāyati, tasmā nibbidā
analyzed: yathābhūta ñāṇassa padaṭṭhānam yathābhūta ñāṇa dassanena nibbidā ñāṇam jāyati tasmā 🔽yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanam nibbidāya padaṭṭhānam nibbidāya virāgaḥ jāyati tasmai nibbidā
translated: he has no remorse. So non-remorse is the footing for gladness. Gladness is born with joy, so gladness is the footing for joy. Joy is born with tranquillity, so joy is the footing for tranquillity. Tranquillity is born with pleasure, so tranquillity is the footing for pleasure. Pleasure is born with concentration, so pleasure is the footing for concentration. Concentration is born with knowledge and vision of things as they really are, so concentration is the footing for knowledge and vision of things as they really are. Knowledge and vision of things as they really are is born with the knowledge of disenchantment, so knowledge and vision of things as they really are is the footing for the knowledge of disenchantment. Disenchantment is born with fading of lust, so disenchantment is the footing for fading of lust.

original: virāgassa padaṭṭhānaṃ. Virāgena vimutti jāyati, tasmā virāgo vimuttiyā padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: virāgassa padaṭṭhānam virāgena vimutti jāyati tasmā virāgaḥ vimuttiyā padaṭṭhānam
translated: and the basis for dispassion is the Noble Eightfold Path.🔽Liberation arises with dispassion, thus dispassion is the basis for liberation.

original: Vimuttiyā vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ jāyati, tasmā vimutti vimuttiñāṇadassanassa padaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: vimuttiyāḥ vimutti ñāṇa dassanam jāyati tasmā vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassanassa padaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: Knowledge and vision of liberation arises with liberation, thus liberation is the basis for knowledge and vision of liberation.

original: Evaṃ yathāvuttanayena yo koci dhammo upanissayo hoti, yo koci dhammo paccayo hoti,
analyzed: evam yathā vutta nayena yaḥ koci dhammo upanissayaḥ hoti yaḥ koci dhammo paccayaḥ hoti
translated: So any state that is a decisive-support condition and any state that is a condition in any way whatever

original: sabbo so dhammo attano paccayuppannassa dhammassa padaṭṭhānanti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: sabbaḥ saḥ dhammaḥ attanaḥ paccaya uppannassa dhammassa padaṭṭhānan ti daṭṭhabbo
translated: should be regarded as the basis for the state conditionally arisen from it.

original: “Upanissayadhammassa, paccayadhammassa vā paccayuppannadhammassa padaṭṭhānabhāvo
analyzed: upanissaya dhammassa paccaya dhammassa vā paccayuppanna dhammassa padaṭṭhāna bhāvaḥ
translated: “By what is the fact that a state that is a decisive-support condition or a condition in any way whatever🔽is the basis for the state conditionally arisen from it to be believed?”

original: kena saddahitabbo”ti vattabbattā “tenāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tenāti yassa kassaci
analyzed: kena saddahitabbaḥ iti vattabbattā tena āha atiādi vuttam tattha tena ati yassa kassaci
translated: Because this question arises, the following passage beginning with the words “Therefore the venerable Mahā Kaccāna said” is stated. Herein, therefore is because of the fact that any state that is a decisive-support condition or a condition in any way whatever

original: upanissayadhammassa, paccayadhammassa ca paccayuppannadhammassa padaṭṭhānabhāvena
analyzed: upanissaya dhammassa paccaya dhammassa ca paccayuppanna dhammassa padaṭṭhāna bhāvena
translated: is the basis for the state conditionally arisen from it.

original: āyasmā mahākaccāno “dhammaṃ deseti jino”tiādikaṃ yaṃ vacanaṃ āha, tena vacanena tesaṃ
analyzed: āyasmā mahākaccānaḥ dhammam deseti jinoti ādikam yam vacanam āha tena vacanena tesam
translated: The venerable Mahā Kaccāna said the words beginning with “The Jina teaches the Dhamma” in order to show that fact.

original: upanissayadhammapaccayadhammānaṃ padaṭṭhānabhāvo saddahitabboti. “Yathāvutto padaṭṭhāno
analyzed: upanissaya dhamma paccaya dhammānam padaṭṭhāna bhāvo saddahitabbaḥ iti yathā vuttaḥ padaṭṭhānaḥ
translated: “The mode of Conveying a Proximate Cause is fulfilled in the way stated.

original: hāro paripuṇṇo kiṃ, udāhu añño niddhāretvā yojetabbo atthi ki”nti vattabbattā “niyutto🔽padaṭṭhāno hāro”ti vuttaṃ. Idha pāḷiyaṃ avibhattampi yathālābhavasena padaṭṭhāno
analyzed: hāraḥ paripuṇṇaḥ kim udāhu aññaḥ niddhāretvā yojetabbaḥ atthi kinti vattabbattā niyuttaḥ  padaṭṭhānaḥ hāro ti vuttam idha pāḷiyam avibhattam pi yathā lābha vasena padaṭṭhānaḥ
translated: But is there any other mode of Conveying a Proximate Cause to be extracted and applied? ”🔽“The mode of Conveying a Proximate Cause is applied” is said.

original: hāro nīharitvā yutto yujjitabbo, vibhajitabbanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: hāraḥ nīharitvā yuttaḥ yujjitabbaḥ vibhajitabbanti vuttam hoti
translated: Although not divided in the text here, the mode of Conveying a Proximate Cause should be extracted and applied according to the occasion, which is to say that it should be divided.

original: Iti padaṭṭhānahāravibhaṅge sattibalānurūpā racitā
analyzed: iti padaṭṭhāna hāra vibhaṅge satti bala anurūpā racitā
translated: So the mode of Conveying a Proximate Cause is composed in accordance with the measure of the knife.

original: Vibhāvanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vibhāvanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition is ended.

original: Paṇḍitehi pana aṭṭhakathāṭīkānusārena gambhīrattho vitthārato vibhajitvā gahetabboti.
analyzed: paṇḍitehi pana aṭṭhakathā ṭīkā anusārena gambhīra atthaḥ vitthārataḥ vibhajitvā gahetabbaḥ ti
translated: But it should be taken in detail by the wise in accordance with the meaning of the deep Suttas, following the commentaries and subcommentaries.

original: 5. Lakkhaṇahāravibhaṅgavibhāvanā
analyzed: lakkhaṇa hāra vibhaṅga vibhāvanā
translated: The exposition of the mode of Conveying Characteristics

original: 23. Yena yena saṃvaṇṇanāvisesabhūtena padaṭṭhānavibhaṅgena avijjādīnaṃ padaṭṭhānāni
analyzed: yena yena saṃvaṇṇanā visesa bhūtena padaṭṭhāna vibhaṅgena avijjā ādīnam padaṭṭhānāni
translated: By means of which particular kind of exposition of a proximate cause the proximate causes of ignorance, etc.,

original: vibhattāni, so saṃvaṇṇanāvisesabhūto padaṭṭhānahāravibhaṅgo paripuṇṇo, “katamo lakkhaṇahāravibhaṅgo”ti
analyzed: vibhattāni so saṃvaṇṇanā visesa bhūto padaṭṭhāna hāra vibhaṅgo paripuṇṇo katamo lakkhaṇa hāra vibhaṅgo ti
translated: are divided, that particular kind of exposition of a proximate cause is fulfilled. “What is the exposition of the mode of Conveying Characteristics? ”

original: pucchitabbattā “tattha katamo lakkhaṇo hāro”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tattha-saddassa
analyzed: pucchitabba ttā tattha katamaḥ lakkhaṇaḥ hāraḥ tiādi vuttam tattha tattha saddassa
translated: “What is the Mode of Conveying Characteristics there?” etc. is said because it has to be asked.🔽Herein,

original: attho vuttova. Katamo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso lakkhaṇo hāro lakkhaṇahāravibhaṅgoti pucchati.🔽“Vuttamhi ekadhamme”tiādiniddesassa idāni mayā vuccamāno “ye dhammā”tiādiko vitthārasaṃvaṇṇanāviseso🔽lakkhaṇo hāro lakkhaṇahāravibhaṅgo nāmāti viññeyyoti. Tena vuttaṃ –“tattha katamo🔽lakkhaṇo hārotiādi lakkhaṇahāravibhaṅgo nāmā”ti. Ayaṃ idāni vuccamāno vitthārabhūto
analyzed: atthaḥ vuttaḥ iva katamo saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ lakkhaṇaḥ hāraḥ lakkhaṇa hāra vibhaṅgo ti pucchati  vuttamhi eka dhamma iti ādi niddesassa idāni mayā vuccamānaḥ ye dhammā ti ādikaḥ vitthāra saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ  lakkhaṇaḥ hāraḥ lakkhaṇa hāra vibhaṅgaḥ nāma ati viññeyyaḥ ti tena vuttam tattha katamo  lakkhaṇaḥ hāraḥ tiādi lakkhaṇa hāra vibhaṅgaḥ nāma ati ayam idāni vuccamānaḥ vitthāra bhūto
translated: “What is the Mode Conveying Characteristics?” is said because it has to be asked about. The meaning of the word “there” is stated. He asks, “What is the Mode Conveying Characteristics, which is a particular kind of explanation? ”

original: lakkhaṇo hāro piṭakattaye desitesu dhammesu kiṃ nāma lakkhitabbaṃ dhammaṃ lakkhīyatīti🔽pucchitvā pucchite lakkhaṇahāravicaye dhamme saṅkhepena dassetuṃ “ye dhammā”tiādi
analyzed: lakkhaṇaḥ hāraḥ piṭaka ttaye desitesu dhammesu kim nāma lakkhitabbam dhammam lakkhīyati iti  pucchitvā pucchite lakkhaṇa hāra vicaye dhamme saṅkhepena dassetuṃ ye dhamma atiādi
translated: The detailed explanation beginning with the words “When one thing is stated” is now being spoken by me. This is the Mode Conveying Characteristics, which is a particular kind of explanation. It should be understood as being called “The Mode Conveying Characteristics, which is a particular kind of explanation.” Therefore it is said: “What is the Mode Conveying Characteristics? ” and so on. This detailed Mode Conveying Characteristics, which is now being spoken, is called “The Mode Conveying Characteristics, which is a particular kind of explanation.” In the Dhamma taught in the three Baskets, what is the Dhamma that is characterized by what?

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha ye dhammāti ye samūhā dhammā. Ekalakkhaṇāti samānalakkhaṇā. Tesaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tattha ye dhammā ti ye samūhāḥ dhammāḥ eka lakkhaṇā ti samāna lakkhaṇā tesam
translated: Having asked this question, in order to show in brief the Dhamma that is to be asked about, the Mode Conveying Characteristics, he said “Ye dhamma” and so on. Herein, ye dhamma means the groups of dhammas. Ekalakkhaṇa means having the same characteristic. Tesaṃ

original: dhammānanti samānalakkhaṇānaṃ tesaṃ samūhadhammānaṃ, niddhāraṇe cetaṃ. Ekasmiṃ dhammeti🔽samānalakkhaṇe ekasmiṃ dhamme, pāḷiyaṃ bhagavatā vutte sati vuttadhammato avasiṭṭhasamānalakkhaṇā
analyzed: dhammānam ti samāna lakkhaṇānam tesam samūha dhammānam niddhāraṇe ca itaṃ ekasmin dhamma iti  samāna lakkhaṇe ekasmin dhamme pāḷiyam bhagavatā vutte sati vutta dhammataḥ avasiṭṭha samāna lakkhaṇā
translated: ‘In the ideas’: in those ideas that are a collection of ideas of the same characteristic. In the locative case. ‘In one idea’:

original: dhammā samānalakkhaṇena vuttā bhavantīti attho.🔽Lakkhaṇahāravisaye dhamme vitthārato imasmiṃ dhamme vutte ime samānalakkhaṇā dhammāpi🔽vuttā bhavantīti niyametvā dassetuṃ “yathā kiṃ bhave”tiādimāha. Tassattho – yathā🔽yena pakārena vuttā bhavanti, so pakāro kiṃ bhaveti pucchati. Yathā yena pakārena
analyzed: dhammā samāna lakkhaṇena vuttāḥ bhavanti iti attho  lakkhaṇa hāra visaye dhamme vitthārataḥ imasmin dhamme vutte ime samāna lakkhaṇāḥ dhammā api  vuttāḥ bhavanti iti niyametvā dassetum yathā kim bhava iti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ yathā  yena pakārena vuttāḥ bhavanti saḥ pakāraḥ kim pucchati yathā yena pakārena
translated: in one idea of the same characteristic. When the Blessed One has stated in the text, then the ideas of the same characteristic that remain over from the stated idea are stated by the same characteristic. This is the meaning.🔽In the province of the bearer of the characteristic, when these ideas have been stated in detail in this Thread, then these ideas of the same characteristic are stated too. Having defined that, he said “How, then, in what way?” in order to show it. The meaning is this:

original: vuttā bhavanti, so pakāro samānalakkhaṇāti bhāvo bhaveti attho. Kinti bhagavā āha?
analyzed: vuttāḥ bhavanti saḥ pakāraḥ samāna lakkhaṇā ati bhāvaḥ bhaveti atthaḥ kim ti bhagavā āha
translated: he asks “How, then, in what way?” in what way they are stated. The meaning is this: the way in which they are stated is the same characteristic. What did the Blessed One say?

original: “Cakkhuṃ bhikkhave”tiādiṃ bhagavā āha. “Cakkhuṃ, bhikkhave, anavaṭṭhita”ntiādimhi
analyzed: cakkhum bhikkhave itiādim bhagavā āha cakkhum bhikkhave anavaṭṭhita ntiādimhi
translated: The Blessed One said “Bhikkhus, the eye” , etc. In the passage beginning “Bhikkhus, the eye is unincluded” ,

original: vutte “sotaṃ, bhikkhave, anavaṭṭhita”ntiādivacanampi vuttameva bhavati.
analyzed: vutte sotam bhikkhave anavaṭṭhita nti ādi vacanam pi vuttam eva bhavati
translated: and the words “The ear, bhikkhus, is not-self” and so on are also said.🔽“Or else, because of the sameness of characteristic in the sense of the sameness of characteristic as not-inconstant, and so on,

original: “Anavaṭṭhitādilakkhaṇena samānalakkhaṇattā vā ajjhattikāyatanabhāvena samānalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: anavaṭṭhita ādi lakkhaṇena samāna lakkhaṇa ttā vā ajjhattika āyatana bhāvena samāna lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: or in the sense of the sameness of characteristic as internal sense-bases,

original: vāti āyatanavaseneva ekalakkhaṇaṃ vattabba”nti vattabbattā khandhavasenapi ekalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: vā ti āyatana vasena iva eka lakkhaṇam vattabbanti vattabbattā khandha vasena api eka lakkhaṇam
translated: it should be said that the characteristic is single in the sense of the sense bases. ”🔽In order to show that it should also be said that the characteristic is single in the sense of the aggregates, the text says: “And as in the case of the past, so too in the case of the future, and in the case of the present” .

original: dassetuṃ “yathā cāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Atīte, rādha, rūpe anapekkho hoti, anāgataṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: dassetum yathā ca āha atiādi vuttam atīte rūpe anapekkhaḥ hoti anāgatam rūpam
translated: “Rādha, one should not expect of past form,

original: mā abhinandi, paccuppannassa rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya cāgāya paṭinissaggāya🔽paṭipajjā”ti vutte “atītāya, rādha, vedanāya anapekkho hoti, anāgataṃ vedanaṃ mā🔽abhinandi, paccuppannāya vedanāya nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya cāgāya paṭinissaggāya
analyzed: mā abhinandi paccuppannassa rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya cāgāya paṭinissaggāya  paṭipajja ati vutte atītāya rādha vedanāya anapekkhaḥ hoti anāgatam vedanam mā  abhinandi paccuppannāya vedanāya nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya cāgāya paṭinissaggāya
translated: one should not welcome future form, one should practise for the revulsion, fading away, and cessation of present form” ,

original: paṭipajjā”tiādi vuttaṃ bhave.
analyzed: paṭipad jāti ādi vuttam bhave
translated: and so on.

original: “Anapekkhanīyalakkhaṇena samānalakkhaṇattā vā khandhalakkhaṇena samānalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: anapekkhanīya lakkhaṇena samāna lakkhaṇa ttā vā khandha lakkhaṇena samāna lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: “Or else, because of the sameness of characteristic in the sense of the sameness of characteristic as not to be expected, and so on,🔽or in the sense of the sameness of characteristic as the characteristic of the aggregates,

original: vāti khandhāyatanavaseneva ekalakkhaṇadhammā vattabbā”ti vattabbattā satipaṭṭhānavasenāpi🔽vattabbāti dassetuṃ “yathāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā yena ekalakkhaṇattena ca
analyzed: vā ti khandha āyatana vasena iva eka lakkhaṇa dhammā vattabbā ati vattabba ttā sati paṭṭhāna vasena api  vattabbā ti dassetum yathā āha atiādi vuttam tattha yathā yena eka lakkhaṇa ttena ca
translated: and that they should be spoken of as dhammas with a single characteristic only in terms of the aggregates and bases.🔽“As he said” is said in order to show that they should also be spoken of in terms of the foundations of mindfulness.

original: bhagavā āha, tathā ca tena ekalakkhaṇattena ca avuttāpi dhammā vuttā bhavantīti attho.
analyzed: bhagavā āha tathā ca tena eka lakkhaṇa ttena ca avuttā api dhammā vuttāḥ bhavanti iti attho
translated: Herein, the meaning is this: just as the Blessed One said that dhammas are of a single characteristic by a certain characteristic, so too dhammas that are not said to be of a single characteristic by that characteristic are said to be so.

original: Ye vipassakā puggalā pañcasu khandhesu niccaṃ susamāraddhā niccaṃ kāyagatāsatiṃ bhāventi,
analyzed: ye vipassakā puggalā pañcasu khandhesu niccam su samāraddhā niccam kāyagata asatim bhāventi
translated: The Blessed One said that those who are meditators, who are always well engaged in the five aggregates, who always develop mindfulness occupied with the body,

original: te vipassakā akiccaṃ subhasukhādikaṃ, kasivāṇijjādikammaṃ vā na sevanti, kicce asubhāsukhādike,
analyzed: te vipassakāḥ akiccam subha sukha ādikam kasi vāṇijja ādi kammam vā na sevanti kicce asubha asukha ādike
translated: do not pursue what should not be pursued, namely, the idea of beauty, the idea of pleasure, and so on, or the work of agriculture, trade, and so on, but they pursue what should be pursued, namely, the idea of foulness, the idea of pain, and so on,

original: kāyādike vā sātaccakārino hontīti bhagavā āhāti yojanā.
analyzed: kāya ādike vā sātacca kārinaḥ honti iti bhagavān āha ati yojanā
translated: or they are occupied with the body, and so on, in a way that is conducive to pain.🔽Here the word iti has a missing syllable.

original: Itisaddassa cettha ekassa lopo. Iti evaṃ “yesañcā”tiādigāthāya kesādike kāye gatāya
analyzed: iti saddassa ca ittha ekassa lopaḥ iti evam kesa ādike kāye gatāya
translated: So, when the mindfulness occupied with the body, which occurs in the verse beginning, “And those who have mindfulness occupied with the body” ,

original: pavattāya satiyā bhagavatā sarūpena vuttāya vijjamānāya tadavasesā vedanāgatā sati
analyzed: pavattāya satiyā bhagavatā sarūpena vuttāya vijjamānāya tad avasesā vedanā gatā sati
translated: is stated by the Blessed One in its individual essence, the mindfulness that remains in addition to that, namely, the mindfulness of feelings,

original: ca cittagatā sati ca dhammagatā sati ca satipaṭṭhānabhāvena ekalakkhaṇattena vuttā🔽bhavantīti saṅkhepato niccaṃ susamāraddhā niccaṃ vedanāgatā sati ca…pe… niccaṃ cittagatā
analyzed: ca citta gatā sati ca dhamma gatā sati ca sati paṭṭhāna bhāvena eka lakkhaṇa ttena vuttā  bhavanti iti saṅkhepataḥ niccam su samāraddhā niccam vedanā gatā sati cape niccam citta gatā
translated: And mindfulness of feeling, of cognizance, and of mental objects, are stated as one characteristic in the sense of being foundations of mindfulness.

original: sati ca…pe… niccaṃ dhammagatā satīti vattabbāti.
analyzed: sati cape niccam dhamma gatā satī iti vattabbā ati
translated: So it can be said that mindfulness of feeling is always well begun, and mindfulness of cognizance and of mental objects is always well begun.🔽“The ideas stated as one characteristic should be stated as foundations of mindfulness” .

original: “Satipaṭṭhānavaseneva ekalakkhaṇā dhammā vattabbā”ti vattabbattā “tathā yaṃ kiñcī”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha yaṃ kiñci rūpāyatanaṃ cakkhuviññāṇena diṭṭhaṃ, yaṃ kiñci saddāyatanaṃ
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna vasena iva eka lakkhaṇāḥ dhammāḥ vattabbā ati vattabba ttā tathā yam kiñci itiādi  vuttam tattha yam kiñci rūpa āyatanam cakkhu viññāṇena diṭṭham yam kiñci sadda āyatanam
translated: So in order to show that, “So too, any kind of” is said.

original: sotaviññāṇena sutaṃ, yaṃ kiñci gandharasaphoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ ghānaviññāṇādittayena🔽viññāṇena mutaṃ, iti evaṃ diṭṭhādittaye bhagavatā sarūpena vutte sati tadavasesaṃ
analyzed: sota viññāṇena sutam yam kiñci gandha rasa phoṭṭhabba āyatanam ghāna viññāṇa ādittayena  viññāṇena mutam iti evam diṭṭhāt ittaye bhagavatā sarūpena vutte sati tad avasesam
translated: Herein, any kind of visible-form base that has been seen with eye-consciousness, any kind of sound base that has been heard with ear-consciousness, any kind of odour, flavour or tangible-data base that has been sensed with nose-, tongue- or body-consciousness,🔽so that the Blessed One has stated the three, that is to say, the seen, the heard, and the sensed, in their individual essence, and the rest,

original: yaṃ kiñci viññātaṃ dhammārammaṇapariyāpannaṃ rūpaṃ bhagavatā ālambitabbabhāvena ekalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: yam kiñci viññātam dhamma ārammaṇa pariyāpannam rūpam bhagavatā ālambitabba bhāvena eka lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: any kind of idea that has been cognized, which is included in the cognizance-object, is stated by the Blessed One as one characteristic in the sense of being the object of apprehension.

original: vuttaṃ bhavatīti attho. Atha vā yaṃ kiñci rūpāyatanaṃ diṭṭhaṃ bhagavatā vuttaṃ, tasmiṃ
analyzed: vuttam bhavati iti atthaḥ atha vā yat kiñci rūpa āyatanam diṭṭham bhagavatā vuttam tasmin
translated: The meaning is: what has been said. Or else, whatever visible-form base has been said by the Blessed One,

original: vutte sati tadavasesaṃ sutādikampi vuttaṃ hotīti ādiattho visuṃ visuṃ yojetabbo.
analyzed: vutte sati tad avasesam suta ādikam pi vuttam hoti iti ādi atthaḥ visum visum yojetabbaḥ
translated: when that has been said, the rest of it, namely, what has been heard, etc., has also been said. The meaning of “etc.” should be construed separately.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “diṭṭhaṃ vā sutaṃ vā mutaṃ vā”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam diṭṭham vā sutam vā mutam vā iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “seen, heard, sensed, or cognized.”

original: “Kāyagatāya satiyā vuttāya tadavasesā vedanāgatāsatiādayoyeva vattabbā”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: kāya gatāya satiyā vuttāya tad avasesāḥ vedanā gata asati ādayaḥ yā iva vattabbā ati pucchitabba ttā
translated: When mindfulness occupied with the body has been said, the rest of the mindfulnesses, namely, those occupied with feeling, etc., have also been said.

original: sattatiṃsabodhipakkhiyadhammāpi vuttā bhavantīti dassetuṃ “yathā cāha bhagavā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā yena niyyānikalakkhaṇena ekalakkhaṇattena ca bhagavā āha, tathā
analyzed: sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhammā api vuttāḥ bhavanti iti dassetum yathā ca āha bhagavā itiādi  vuttam tattha yathā yena niyyānika lakkhaṇena eka lakkhaṇa ttena ca bhagavā āha tathā
translated: In order to show that the seventy-two factors of enlightenment are also said, it is said: “And as the Blessed One said,” etc.🔽Herein, the meaning is: just as the Blessed One said by way of the characteristic of being a way out and by way of the single characteristic,

original: tena ekalakkhaṇattena ca bhagavā āha, tathā tena ekalakkhaṇattena ca vuttā bhavantīti
analyzed: tena eka lakkhaṇa ttena ca bhagavā āha tathā tena eka lakkhaṇa ttena ca vuttāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: so by way of that single characteristic they are said.

original: attho. “Tasmā abhijjhādomanassena abhibhūtattā iha mama sāsane, bhikkhu, tvaṃ ātāpī
analyzed: attho tasmai abhijjhā domanassena abhibhūta ttā iha mama sāsane bhikkhu tvaṃ ātāpī
translated: Because of being overcome by covetousness and grief, in my Dispensation, monk, you are not ardent

original: sampajāno satimā hutvā loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ tadaṅgappahānena vā vikkhambhanappahānena
analyzed: sampajānaḥ satimā hutvā loke abhijjhā domanassam tad aṅga ppahānena vā vikkhambhana ppahānena
translated: either by abandoning them through the factor of complete understanding or by abandoning them through the factor of suppression.🔽He should abide contemplating the body as a body,

original: vā vineyya vinayitvā kāye kesādirūpakāye kāyānupassī kesādirūpakāyānupassī hutvā🔽viharāhī”ti bhagavatā vutte sati “tasmātiha, tvaṃ bhikkhu, vedanāsu vedanānupassī🔽viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ, tasmātiha, tvaṃ🔽bhikkhu, citte cittānupassī viharāhi…pe… domanassaṃ, tasmātiha, tvaṃ bhikkhu, dhammesu
analyzed: vā vineyya vinayitvā kāye kesa ādi rūpa kāye kāya anupassī kesa ādi rūpa kāya anupassī hutvā  viharāhi iti bhagavatā vutte sati tasmāt iha tvam bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanā anupassī  viharāhi ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassam tasmā ati ha tvam  bhikkhu citte citta anupassī vihara āhipe domanassam tasmā ati ha tvam bhikkhu dhammesu
translated: after thus abandoning and removing covetousness and grief, either by abandoning them through the factor of complete understanding or by abandoning them through the factor of suppression.🔽When this was said, mindfulness of feelings, etc., should be understood as stated by the words, “Therefore, bhikkhu, you should abide contemplating feelings as feelings … mind as mind … mind-object as mind-object, ardently, clearly comprehending, fully aware, having mindfulness set up, having overcome desire and grief in the world.”

original: dhammānupassī viharāhi…pe… domanassa”nti vuttaṃ bhavatīti saṅkhepattho veditabbo.
analyzed: dhamma anupassī vihara ahipe domanassanti vuttam bhavati iti saṅkhepa tthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning in brief is this.

original: Vitthārattho pana aṭṭhakathāyaṃ bahudhā vuttoti amhehi na vitthārito.
analyzed: vitthāra atthaḥ pana aṭṭhakathā ayam bahudhā vuttaḥ ti amhehi na vitthārito
translated: But the detailed meaning is given in the Commentary in many places, so we have not done so in detail.

original: “Ekasmiṃ satipaṭṭhāne vutte kasmā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā vuttā bhaveyyu”nti vattabbattā
analyzed: ekasmin satipaṭṭhāne vutte kasmā cattāro satipaṭṭhānāḥ vuttāḥ bhaveyyun ti vattabbattā
translated: Since it might be asked how it is that the four foundations of mindfulness are mentioned when only one is stated,

original: “ātāpīti vīriyindriya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha “ātāpī”ti iminā padena kāyavedanācittadhammesu🔽pavattaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ vuttaṃ. “Sampajāno”ti padena kāyavedanācittadhammesu pavattaṃ
analyzed: ātāpī iti vīriya indriya ntiādi vuttam tattha ātāpī iti iminā padena kāya vedanā citta dhammesu  pavattam vīriya indriyam vuttam sampajānoti padena kāya vedanā citta dhammesu pavattam
translated: Herein, by the word “ardent” the faculty of energy occurring in the body, in feelings, in cognizance, and in mental objects is stated.🔽By the word “clearly comprehending” the faculty of wisdom occurring in the body, in feelings, in cognizance, and in mental objects is stated.

original: paññindriyaṃ vuttaṃ. “Satimā”ti padena kāyavedanācittadhammesu pavattaṃ satindriyaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. “Vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassa”nti padena kāyavedanācittadhammesu pavattaṃ
analyzed: paññindriyam vuttam satimā ti padena kāya vedanā citta dhammesu pavattam satindriyam  vuttam vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassanti padena kāya vedanā citta dhammesu pavattam
translated: By the word “mindful” the faculty of mindfulness occurring in the body, in feelings, in cognizance, and in mental objects is stated.

original: samādhindriyaṃ vuttaṃ, na kāyeyeva pavattaṃ. Evaṃ pakārena kāye kāyānupassino yogāvacarassa
analyzed: samādhi indriyam vuttam na kāyeya iva pavattam evam pakārena kāye kāya anupassinaḥ yogāvacarassa
translated: By the word “having put away greed and sorrow in the world” the faculty of concentration occurring in the body, in feelings, in cognizance, and in mental objects is stated, not only that occurring in the body.

original: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchantīti ce vadeyya, evaṃ sati catunnaṃ
analyzed: cattāraḥ satipaṭṭhānāḥ bhāvanā pāripūrim gacchanti iti ce vadeyya evam sati
translated: If it be said that in this way the four foundations of mindfulness come to fulfilment in the meditator who is contemplating the body in the body,

original: vīriyapaññāsatisamādhīnaṃ indriyānaṃ catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ sādhakabhāvena ekalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: vīriya paññā sati samādhīnam indriyānam catunnam sati paṭṭhānānam sādhaka bhāvena eka lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: then, since the four faculties of energy, of wisdom, of mindfulness, and of concentration have the same characteristic in that they are the accomplishes of the four foundations of mindfulness,

original: samānalakkhaṇattā pāripūriṃ gacchantīti yojanā. Tena vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ – “catusatipaṭṭhānasādhane
analyzed: samāna lakkhaṇa ttā pāripūrim gacchanti iti yojanā tena vuttam aṭṭhakathā ayam catusati paṭṭhāna sādhane
translated: The construction is: “They reach fulfilment through the state of having the same characteristic as the four foundations of mindfulness.”

original: imesaṃ indriyānaṃ sabhāvabhedābhāvato samānalakkhaṇattā”ti.
analyzed: imesam indriyānam sabhāva bheda abhāvato samāna lakkhaṇa ttā ti
translated: Hence it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “Because there is no difference in individual essence between these faculties, they have the same characteristic” .

original: 24. “Evaṃ vuttepi cattāro satipaṭṭhānāyeva vattabbā bhaveyyuṃ, kathaṃ sattatiṃsabodhipakkhiyadhammā
analyzed: evam vutte pi cattāro sati paṭṭhānāya iva vattabbāḥ bhaveyyum katham sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhammā
translated: “But even so, they would still have to be called the four foundations of mindfulness. How then can they be called the thirty-seven states partaking of enlightenment? ”

original: vattabbā”ti vattabbattā “catūsu satipaṭṭhānesū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu
analyzed: vattabbā ati vattabba ttā catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu itiādi vuttam tattha catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu
translated: Because of this question, the answer is given: “In the four foundations of mindfulness” and so on. Herein, in the four foundations of mindfulness,

original: yena yogāvacarena bhāviyamānesu tassa yogāvacarassa cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvanāpāripūriṃ
analyzed: yena yogāvacarena bhāviyamānesu tassa yogāvacarassa cattāro sammappadhānāḥ bhāvanā pāripūriṃ
translated: the four right endeavours of the meditator who is developing them reach fulfilment.🔽The same method of explanation applies to the rest.

original: gacchanti. Evaṃ sesesupi yojanā kātabbā. Catunnaṃ saccānaṃ bujjhanaṃ bodhaṃ, ariyamaggañāṇaṃ,
analyzed: gacchanti evam sesesu pi yojanā kātabbā catunnam saccānam bujjhanam bodham ariya magga ñāṇam
translated: Enlightenment is the knowledge of the noble path that is the discovery of the four truths.

original: bodhaṃ gacchantīti bodhaṅgamā. Bodhassa ariyamaggañāṇassa pakkhe bhavāti bodhipakkhiyā.
analyzed: bodham gacchanti iti bodhaṅgamā bodhassa ariya magga ñāṇassa pakkhe bhavāti bodhi pakkhiyā
translated: They go to enlightenment, thus they are enlightenment factors . They are in the enlightenment, thus they are enlightenment factors .

original: “Kusalāyeva dhammā ekalakkhaṇabhāvena nīharitā kiṃ, udāhu akusalāpi dhammā”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: kusalāya iva dhammāḥ eka lakkhaṇa bhāvena nīharitā kim udāhu akusalā api dhammā ati pucchitabba ttā
translated: “Are only profitable ideas to be defined by their single characteristic, or are unprofitable ideas also to be defined by their single characteristic?”

original: “evaṃ akusalāpī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha kusalā dhammā ekalakkhaṇattena niddhāritā yathā,
analyzed: evam akusalā api itiādi vuttam tattha kusalāḥ dhammāḥ eka lakkhaṇa ttena niddhāritāḥ yathā
translated: “So too unprofitable ideas” is said in order to answer that question. Herein, just as profitable ideas are defined by their single characteristic,

original: evaṃ akusalāpi dhammā ekalakkhaṇattena niddhāritabbāyevāti attho. “Kathaṃ niddhāretabbā”ti🔽pucchitabbattā pahānekaṭṭhabhāvena niddhāretabbāti dassento “ekalakkhaṇattā pahānaṃ
analyzed: evam akusalāḥ api dhammāḥ eka lakkhaṇa ttena niddhāritabbāya eva ati atthaḥ katham niddhāretabbā ati  pucchitabba ttā pahāna ikaṭṭha bhāvena niddhāretabbā ti dassento eka lakkhaṇa ttā pahānam
translated: so too unprofitable ideas are to be defined by their single characteristic too. That is the meaning. “How are they to be defined?”

original: abbhatthaṃ gacchantī”ti āha. Tattha ekalakkhaṇattāti pahānekaṭṭhabhāvena samānalakkhaṇattā.
analyzed: abbhattham gacchanti iti āha tattha eka lakkhaṇa ttā ati pahā an ekaṭṭha bhāvena samāna lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: is asked. Showing how they are to be defined, he said “By defining in terms of abandoning they come to have the meaning of ‘far’” . Herein, by their single characteristic means by their single characteristic consisting in abandoning.🔽“What is it that comes to have the meaning of ‘far’ by abandoning?” is asked.

original: “Katamaṃ pahānaṃ abbhatthaṃ gacchantī”ti pucchitabbattā “catūsu satipaṭṭhānesū”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: katamam pahānam abbhattham gacchanti iti pucchitabba ttā catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu utiādi vuttam
translated: “In the four foundations of mindfulness” is said in order to answer that question.

original: Tattha catūsu…pe… pariññaṃ gacchantīti kāyāgatāsatipaṭṭhāne yogāvacarena bhāviyamāne
analyzed: tattha catūsupe pariññam gacchanti iti kāya āgata asati paṭṭhāne yogāvacarena bhāviyamāne
translated: Herein, in the four foundations of mindfulness … come to have the meaning of ‘far’ by abandoning is said because when mindfulness occupied with the body is being developed by a meditator,

original: sati tena yogāvacarena asubhe kesādike rūpakāye “subha”nti vipallāso pahīyati, assa
analyzed: sati tena yogāvacarena asubhe kesa ādike rūpa kāye vipallāso pahīyati assa
translated: Then, by that means, the meditator abandons the perversion of perceiving as beautiful the foul body consisting of head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, faeces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, oil that lubricates the joints, and urine.

original: yogāvacarassa kabaḷīkārāhāro pariññaṃ gacchati, “āhārasamudayā rūpasamudayo”ti vuttattā
analyzed: yogāvacarassa kabaḷīkāra āhāro pariññam gacchati āhāra samudayā rūpa samudayā iti vutta ttā
translated: And the meditator’s material food is fully understood, because it is said, “With the arising of nutriment there is the arising of form” .

original: rūpakāye chandarāgaṃ pajahantassa tassa samudaye kabaḷīkārāhārepi chandarāgo pahīyatīti
analyzed: rūpa kāye chanda rāgam pajahantassa tassa samudaye kabaḷīkāra āhāre pi chanda rāgo pahīyati iti
translated: So the meaning is that when he abandons desire and greed for the material body, then his desire and greed for the material food that is its origin is abandoned too.

original: attho. Vedanāgatāsatipaṭṭhāne bhāviyamāne sati dukkhe “sukha”nti vipallāso pahīyati,
analyzed: atthaḥ vedanā gata asati paṭṭhāne bhāviyamāne sati dukkhe sukhanti vipallāso pahīyati
translated: When the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of feelings is being developed, the perversion of perceiving as pleasant what is painful is abandoned,

original: assa yogāvacarassa phassāhāro pariññaṃ gacchati, “phassapaccayā vedanā”ti vuttattā
analyzed: assa yogāvacarassa phassa āhāro pariññam gacchati phassa paccayā vedanā ti vutta ttā
translated: and the meditator’s contact as nutriment is fully understood, because it is said, “With contact as condition there is feeling” .

original: vedanāya chandarāgaṃ pajahantassa tassa paccaye phassāhāre chandarāgo pahīyati. Cittagatāsatipaṭṭhāne
analyzed: vedanāya chanda rāgam pajahantassa tassa paccaye phassa āhāre chanda rāgo pahīyati citta gata asati paṭṭhāne
translated: So the meaning is that when he abandons desire and greed for feeling, then his desire and greed for the contact as nutriment that is its condition is abandoned too. When the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of consciousness is being developed,

original: bhāviyamāne anicce “nicca”nti vipallāso pahīyati, assa yogāvacarassa viññāṇāhāro🔽pariññaṃ gacchati. Dhammagatāsatipaṭṭhāne bhāviyamāne anattani “attā”ti vipallāso
analyzed: bhāviyamāne anicce vipallāso pahīyati assa yogāvacarassa viññāṇa āhāro 🔽pariññam gacchati dhamma gata asati paṭṭhāne bhāviyamāne anattani attā ati vipallāsaḥ
translated: the perversion of perceiving as permanent what is impermanent is abandoned, and the meditator’s consciousness as nutriment is fully understood,🔽and when the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of mental objects is being developed, the perversion of perceiving as self what is not self is abandoned,

original: pahīyati, assa yogāvacarassa manosañcetanāhāro pariññaṃ gacchatīti visuṃ visuṃ yojetvā
analyzed: pahīyati assa yogāvacarassa manaḥ sañcetanā āhāro pariññam gacchati iti visum visum yojetvā
translated: and the nutriment of mental volition is fully understood.

original: ekekasmiṃ pahātabbe vutte tadavasesā pahātabbā vuttā bhavanti pahātabbabhāvena ekalakkhaṇattāti attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: eka ekasmin pahātabbe vutte tad avasesā pahātabbā vuttā bhavanti pahātabba bhāvena eka lakkhaṇa ttā ati atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ
translated: When it is said that each of the three kinds of feeling is to be abandoned, then the rest of the kinds of feeling are included as well, since they are of the same nature as to being abandonable.

original: “Āhārā cassa pariññaṃ gacchantī”ti vacane āhāresu pavattā kāmarāgadosamohā byantīkatā🔽hontīti attho gahito. Kabaḷīkārāhārañhi ārabbha pavatte kāmarāge vijjamāne kabaḷīkārāhārassa
analyzed: āhārā ca ssa pariññam gacchanti iti vacane āhāresu pavattā kāma rāga dosa mohā byantīkatā  honti iti atthaḥ gahitaḥ kabaḷīkāra āhāram hi ārabbha pavatte kāma rāge vijjamāne kabaḷīkāra āhārassa
translated: When it is said that the nutriments are fully understood, then the lust, hatred and delusion that occur with regard to the nutriments are brought to an end.

original: vijānanā nattheva, tasmiṃ kāmarāge pana pahīne parijānanā bhavatīti. Sesāhārajānanampi
analyzed: vijānanā nattha iva tasmin kāma rāge pana pahīne parijānanā bhavati iti sesa āhāra jānanam pi
translated: For when lust for nutriment occurs, there is no understanding of nutriment; but when that lust is abandoned, there is understanding.🔽The same method applies to the other kinds of nutriment.

original: eseva nayo. Yassa yogāvacarassa satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā, vipallāsā pahīnā, āhāraparijānanā
analyzed: esā iva nayaḥ yassa yogāvacarassa sati paṭṭhānā bhāvitā vipallāsā pahīnā āhāra parijānanā
translated: When a meditator has developed the foundations of mindfulness, abandoned the perversions, and aroused the understanding of the nutriments, he becomes one who has no more clinging to the kinds of clinging.

original: uppannā, so yogāvacaro upādānehi anupādāno bhavati. Subhasaññite hi kāye kāmupādānaṃ
analyzed: uppannā saḥ yogāvacaraḥ upādānehi anupādānaḥ bhavati subha saññite hi kāye kāma upādānam
translated: For in the case of the material form aggregate, which is the object of the perception of beauty, there is clinging through lust.

original: visesena bhavatīti subhasaññito kāyo kāmupādānassa vatthu, kāyagatāya satiyā anusaritabbo
analyzed: visesena bhavati iti subha saññitaḥ kāyaḥ kāma upādānassa vatthu kāya gatāya satiyā anusaritabbo
translated: The body, which is the basis for the perception of beauty, is the object of sensual-desire clinging. It should be reviewed with mindfulness of the body.

original: asubhasaññito kesādi kāmupādānassa vatthu na hotveva. Sukhavedanāya assādavasena
analyzed: asubha saññitaḥ kesa ādi kāma upādānassa vatthu na hotvā iva sukha vedanāya assāda vasena
translated: The body, which is the basis for the perception of foulness, is not the object of sensual-desire clinging.🔽The pleasant feeling, which is the basis for clinging to sensual pleasure, is the object of clinging to sensual pleasure. It should be reviewed with mindfulness of feeling.

original: diṭṭhupādānaṃ bhavatīti sukhasaññitā vedanā diṭṭhupādānassa vatthu, vedanāgatāya🔽pana satiyā anupassitabbā vedanā diṭṭhupādānassa vatthu na hotveva. “Cittaṃ nicca”nti🔽diṭṭhigahaṇavasena tassa tassa attano sīlavatavasena parisuddhīti parāmasanaṃ hotīti
analyzed: diṭṭhupādānam bhavati iti sukha saññitā vedanā diṭṭhupādānassa vatthu vedanā gatāya  pana satiyā anupassitabbā vedanā diṭṭhupādānassa vatthu na hotvā iva cittam niccanti  diṭṭhi gahaṇa vasena tassa tassa attano sīlavata vasena parisuddhi iti parāmasanam hoti iti
translated: The pleasant feeling, which is the basis for the delight in sensual pleasure, is the object of clinging to sensual pleasure.
