original: puggalo “gacchatī”ti iminā desitoti. Evaṃ desitesu dhammesu akusalā samudayasaccaṃ,🔽“vasaṃ mārassa gacchatī”ti iminā padena ye pañcupādānakkhandhe upādāya paññatto puggalo
analyzed: puggalaḥ gacchati iti iminā desito ti evam desitesu dhammesu akusalā samudaya saccam  vasam mārassa gacchati iti iminā padena ye pañca upādāna khandhe upādāya paññattaḥ puggalo
translated: The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.

original: vutto, te pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhasaccanti dve saccāni desitāni. “Kimatthāya dve🔽saccāni desitānī”ti pucchitabbattā “tesaṃ bhagavā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tesaṃ dvinnaṃ saccānaṃ
analyzed: vuttaḥ te pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkha saccanti dve saccāni desitāni kim atthāya dve  saccāni desitāni iti pucchitabba ttā tesam bhagavā atiādi vuttam tesam dvinnam saccānam
translated: The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.

original: pariññāya ca pahānāya ca “arakkhitenā”tiādi dhammaṃ bhagavā deseti, tāni dve saccāni🔽“arakkhitenā”tiādikena ñāpetīti attho.
analyzed: pariññāya ca pahānāya ca arakkhitena atiādi dhammam bhagavā deseti tāni dve saccāni 🔽arakkhitena ati ādikena ñāpeti iti attho
translated: The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to in the verse are the truth of suffering and the truth of origination.🔽The two truths referred to

original: “Tesu dvīsu saccesu kassa saccassa pariññāya, kassa saccassa pahānāya desetī”ti pucchitabbattā🔽“dukkhassa pariññāya, samudayassa pahānāyā”ti vuttaṃ. “Pariññāpahānehi katamāni saccāni
analyzed: tesu dvīsu saccesu kassa saccassa pariññāya kassa saccassa pahānāya deseti iti pucchitabbattā  dukkhassa pariññāya samudayassa pahānāya ati vuttam pariññā pahānehi katamāni saccāni
translated: “In regard to the two truths, for the full understanding of which truth, and for the abandoning of which truth, does he teach?”🔽“For the full understanding of suffering, and for the abandoning of the origin of suffering.” “By means of the full understanding and the abandoning of which truths

original: desitānī”ti vattabbattā “yena cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yena arahattamaggena parijānāti, yena🔽arahattamaggena pajahati ca, ayaṃ arahattamaggo maggasaccaṃ nāma. Yaṃ nibbānadhammaṃ
analyzed: desitāni iti vattabbattā yena ca atiādi vuttam yena arahatta maggena parijānāti yena  arahatta maggena pajahati ca ayam arahatta maggaḥ maggasaccam nāma yam nibbāna dhammam
translated: are the truths taught?” “By means of which he fully understands,🔽and by means of which he abandons, this is the truth of the path. The state of Nibbāna,

original: ārabbha taṇhāya, avijjāya ca pahānaṃ jātaṃ, ayaṃ nibbānadhammo nirodho nirodhasaccaṃ
analyzed: ārabbha taṇhāya avijjāya ca pahānam jātam ayam nibbāna dhammaḥ nirodhaḥ nirodha saccam
translated: which is the object of the path, and the abandoning of craving and ignorance that occurs in regard to it, is the truth of cessation.”

original: nāmāti. Evaṃ cattāri saccāni bhagavatā desitāni.
analyzed: nāma ati evam cattāri saccāni bhagavatā desitāni
translated: Thus the four truths are taught by the Blessed One.

original: “Catunnaṃ saccānaṃ desitabhāvo kena viññātabbo”ti vattabbattā “tenāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: catunnam saccānam desita bhāvo kena viññātabbaḥ ti vattabbattā tena āha atiādi vuttam
translated: “By whom is the teaching of the four truths to be known?” “Therefore he said.”

original: Tesu catūsu saccesu samudayasaccena assādo gahito, dukkhasaccena ādīnavo gahito,
analyzed: tesu catūsu saccesu samudaya saccena assādaḥ gahito dukkha saccena ādīnavaḥ gahito
translated: In regard to the four truths, the pleasant feeling is included in the truth of suffering, the unpleasant feeling is included in the truth of suffering, and the neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling is included in the truth of suffering.

original: maggasaccanirodhasaccehi nissaraṇaṃ gahitaṃ, samudayappahānavasena sabbagatipajahanaṃ
analyzed: magga sacca nirodha saccehi nissaraṇam gahitam samudaya pahāna vasena sabba gati pajahanam
translated: The escape is stated by the truths of path and of cessation, the abandoning of all destinations by way of abandoning of origin.

original: jātaṃ, sabbagatipajahanaṃ phalanti gahitaṃ. Yena rakkhitacittatādikena sabbagatipajahanaṃ
analyzed: jātam sabba gati pajahanam phalanti gahitam yena rakkhita citta tā ādikena sabba gati pajahanam
translated: The fruit is stated by the abandoning of all destinations. The one who has abandoned all destinations by means of the guarded mind, etc.,

original: jātaṃ, so rakkhitacittatādiko upāyoti gahito, arakkhitacittatādikassa paṭisedhanamukhena
analyzed: jātam saḥ rakkhita citta tā ādikaḥ upāyaḥ ti gahitaḥ arakkhita citta tā ādikassa paṭisedhana mukhena
translated: is stated by the word “follower.” The prohibition of the unguarded mind, etc.,

original: rakkhitacittatādikassa niyojanaṃ bhagavato āṇattīti gahitanti desanāhārena nānāsuttesu
analyzed: rakkhita citta tā ādikassa niyojanam bhagavataḥ āṇatti iti gahitam ti desanā āhārena nānā suttesu
translated: and the direction to the guarded mind, etc., are stated by the word “instruction” of the Blessed One. Thus the benefits of teaching are stated in various suttas,

original: dassitā assādādayo “arakkhitenā”tiādike ekasmiṃyeva sutte nīharitvā dassitā.
analyzed: dassitāḥ assāda ādayaḥ arakkhitena ati ādike ekasmiṃ yeva sutte nīharitvā dassitā
translated: and the advantages, etc., are brought out in one sutta only, namely, the “Unguarded Mind” sutta.

original: “Assādādīnaṃ nīharitvā dassitabhāvo kena viññātabbo saddahitabbo”ti vattabbattā “tenāhā”tiādi
analyzed: assāda ādīnam nīharitvā dassita bhāvaḥ kena viññātabbaḥ saddahitabbaḥ iti vattabbattā tena āha atiādi
translated: Since it must be said: “By what is it to be known and believed that the advantages, etc., are brought out in one sutta only?” the words “Therefore the Exalted One said” are stated.

original: vuttaṃ. Ettha ca yena saṃvaṇṇanāvisesena nānāsuttesu assādādayo nīharitvā dassitā,
analyzed: vuttam ettha ca yena saṃvaṇṇanā visesena nānā suttesu assāda ādayaḥ nīharitvā dassitā
translated: And here, by what special commentary the advantages, etc., are brought out in various suttas,

original: so saṃvaṇṇanāviseso desanāhāravibhaṅgo nāma. Yena saṃvaṇṇanāvisesena ekasmiṃyeva
analyzed: so saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ desanā āhāra vibhaṅgaḥ nāma yena saṃvaṇṇanā visesena ekasmin yeva
translated: that special commentary is called the analysis of the benefits of teaching. By what special commentary the advantages, etc., are brought out in one sutta only,

original: sutte assādādayo nīharitvā dassitā, so saṃvaṇṇanāviseso desanāhārasampāto nāmāti viseso daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: sutte assāda ādayaḥ nīharitvā dassitā saḥ saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ desanā āhāra sampātaḥ nāma ati visesaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The advantages, etc., are pointed out by extracting them from the sutta. The difference should be understood as follows: the difference in the teacher’s skill in expounding the sutta.

original: “Ettakova desanāhārasampāto paripuṇṇo”ti vattabbattā “niyutto desanāhārasampāto”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Ekekasmiṃyeva sutte assādādayo yena yena saṃvaṇṇanāvisesabhūtena desanāhārasampātena
analyzed: ettakaḥ iva desanā āhāra sampāto paripuṇṇo ti vattabbattā niyuttaḥ desanā āhāra sampāto ti  vuttam eka ekasmin yeva sutte assāda ādayaḥ yena yena saṃvaṇṇanā visesa bhūtena desanā āhāra sampātena
translated: “The teacher’s skill in expounding the sutta is fulfilled by this alone” should be said.🔽The advantages, etc., in each sutta are pointed out as appropriate by extracting them by means of the teacher’s skill in expounding the sutta, which is a special kind of skill in expounding.

original: nīharitvā yathārahaṃ dassitā, so so saṃvaṇṇanāvisesabhūto desanāhārasampāto niyutto
analyzed: nīharitvā yathāraham dassitā saḥ saḥ saṃvaṇṇanā visesa bhūtaḥ desanā āhāra sampātaḥ niyuttaḥ
translated: That special kind of skill in expounding the sutta, which is a special kind of skill in expounding, is applied

original: yathārahaṃ niddhāretvā yujjitabboti attho gahito.
analyzed: yathāraham niddhāretvā yujjitabbaḥ ti atthaḥ gahito
translated: by extracting it as appropriate. This is the meaning taken.

original: Iti desanāhārasampāte sattibalānurūpā racitā
analyzed: iti desanā āhāra sampāte satti bala anurūpā racitā
translated: Thus the skill in expounding the sutta is composed in accordance with the strength of the knife.

original: Vibhāvanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vibhāvanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The analysis is finished.

original: Paṇḍitehi pana…pe… gahetabboti.
analyzed: paṇḍitehi panape gahetabbo ti
translated: But the wise should take it …

original: 2. Vicayahārasampātavibhāvanā
translated: The analysis of the skill in expounding the analysis

original: 53. Yena desanāhārasampātena assādādayo ācariyena vibhattā, amhehi ca ñātā, so desanāhārasampāto
analyzed: yena desanā āhāra sampātena assāda ādayaḥ ācariyena vibhattā amhehi ca ñātā saḥ desanā āhāra sampātaḥ
translated: The skill in expounding the sutta by means of which the advantages, etc., have been analysed by the teacher and are known by us,

original: paripuṇṇo, “katamo vicayahārasampāto”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha katamo vicayo hārasampāto”tiādi
analyzed: paripuṇṇaḥ katamaḥ vicaya hāra sampāto ti pucchitabba ttā tattha katamaḥ vicayaḥ hāra sampāto tiādi
translated: “Herein, what is the fulfilment of the analysis-search?”

original: vuttaṃ. Tatthāti tesu desanāhārasampātādīsu soḷasasu hārasampātesu katamo saṃvaṇṇanāviseso🔽vicayahārasampāto nāmāti pucchati. Imesu dhammesu ayaṃ dhammo yena saṃvaṇṇanāvisesena
analyzed: vuttam tattha ati tesu desanā hāra sampāta ādīsu soḷasasu hāra sampātesu katamaḥ saṃvaṇṇanā viseso  vicaya hāra sampātaḥ nāma ati pucchati imesu dhammesu ayam dhammaḥ yena saṃvaṇṇanā visesena
translated: is said in order to ask about it. Herein, among the sixteen fulfilments of the search, beginning with the fulfilment of the search for teaching, what is the difference in the exposition?

original: vicayitabbo, so saṃvaṇṇanāviseso vicayahārasampāto nāmāti niyametvā vibhajituṃ “tattha
analyzed: vicayitabbo so saṃvaṇṇanā visesaḥ vicaya hāra sampātaḥ nāma ati niyametvā vibhajitum tattha
translated: He asks, “What is called the fulfilment of the analysis-search?” In these ideas this idea should be analysed by means of what difference in the exposition. That difference in the exposition is called the fulfilment of the analysis-search. Having defined it thus, in order to expound it, “Herein, craving” is said.

original: taṇhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana –🔽“Evaṃ desanāhārasampātaṃ dassetvā idāni vicayahārasampātaṃ dassento yasmā desanāhārapadatthavicayo🔽vicayahāro, tasmā desanāhāre vipallāsahetubhāvena niddhāritāya taṇhāya kusalādivibhāgapavicayamukhena
analyzed: taṇhā tiādi vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam pana  evam desanā hāra sampātam dassetvā idāni vicaya hāra sampātam dassentaḥ yasmā desanā hāra padattha vicayo  tasmai desanā āhāre vipallāsa hetu bhāvena niddhāritāya taṇhāya kusala ādi vibhāga pavicaya mukhena
translated: But in the Commentary it is said:

original: vicayahārasampātaṃ dassetuṃ ‘tattha taṇhā duvidhā’tiādi āraddha”nti –
analyzed: vicaya hāra sampātam dassetum tattha taṇhā duvidhā iti ādi āraddhanti
translated: “Having thus shown the fulfilment of the search for teaching, he now shows the fulfilment of the analysis-search. Since the analysis of the meaning of the terms in the fulfilment of the search for teaching is the analysis-search, therefore, in order to show the fulfilment of the analysis-search by means of the analysis of the profitable, etc., of craving, which is defined as the cause of perversion in the fulfilment of the search for teaching, he began the passage with ‘Herein, craving is twofold’ ” .

original: Vuttaṃ. Tattha tatthāti tasmiṃ “arakkhitena cittenā”tiādisuttatthe desanāhārasampātena
analyzed: vuttam tattha tattha ati tasmin arakkhitena cittena ati ādi sutta atthe desanā āhāra sampātena
translated: This has been said. Therein, in the various places, in the Thread beginning, “With mind unguarded” , the craving that is demonstrated as “craving” is all craving demonstrated in the unprofitable ideas that are commended in the demonstration of the nutriment of food.

original: saṃvaṇṇite akusaladhamme “taṇhā”ti niddhāritā sabbataṇhā. Kusalāpīti catubhūmake🔽kusale uddissa pavattā taṇhāpi. Akusalāpīti akusaladhamme uddissa pavattā taṇhāpīti🔽duvidhā hotīti vicayitabbā. Tena vuttaṃ ṭīkāyaṃ – “kusaladhammārammaṇāti kusaladhamme🔽uddissa pavattamattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na tesaṃ ārammaṇapaccayataṃ, idha ‘kusalā
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇite akusala dhamme taṇhā ati niddhāritā sabba taṇhā kusalā api iti catu bhūmake  kusale uddissa pavattā taṇhā api akusalā api iti akusala dhamme uddissa pavattā taṇhā api iti  duvidhā hoti iti tena vuttam ṭīkā ayam kusala dhamma ārammaṇā ti kusala dhamme  uddissa pavatta mattam sandhāya vuttam na tesam ārammaṇa paccaya tat idha kusalā
translated: As to profitable : this is the craving that occurs in the four-jhāna profitable. As to unprofitable : this is the craving that occurs in unprofitable ideas.

original: dhammā’ti lokuttaradhammānampi adhippetattā”ti.🔽“Kusalā taṇhā kiṃgāminī, akusalā taṇhā kiṃ gāminī”ti pucchitabbattā “akusalā saṃsāragāminī”tiādi
analyzed: dhammā ti lokuttara dhammānam pi adhippeta ttā ti  kusalā taṇhā kiṃgāminī akusalā taṇhā kim gāminī iti pucchitabbattā akusalā saṃsāra gāminī itiādi
translated: It should be investigated thus as twofold. Hence it is said in the Commentary : “ As to profitable ideas as object : this is said with reference to mere occurrence in profitable ideas as object, not with reference to their being object condition for them, since here ‘ profitable ideas ‘ are intended to include supramundane ideas too” .

original: vuttaṃ. Atha vā “katamo kusalākusalataṇhānaṃ viseso”ti pucchitabbattā “akusalā saṃsāragāminī”tiādi
analyzed: vuttam atha vā katamaḥ kusala akusala taṇhānam visesaḥ ti pucchitabba ttā akusalā saṃsāra gāminī itiādi
translated: “ What is the profitable kind of craving’s destination? What is the unprofitable kind of craving’s destination?” Because this question has to be asked, it is said “ The unprofitable kind of craving’s destination is in the round of rebirths” . Or alternatively, because the question “ What is the difference between profitable and unprofitable craving?” has to be asked, it is said “ The unprofitable kind of craving’s destination is in the round of rebirths” .

original: vuttaṃ. “Taṇhā nāma saṃsāragāminī hotu, kathaṃ apacayagāminī”ti vattabbattā “pahānataṇhā”ti🔽vuttaṃ, pahānassa hetubhūtā taṇhā pahānataṇhāti attho, pahātabbataṇhaṃ āgamma yaṃ
analyzed: vuttam taṇhā nāma saṃsāra gāminī hotu katham apacaya gāminī iti vattabbattā pahāna taṇhā ti  vuttam pahānassa hetu bhūtā taṇhā pahāna taṇhā ti atthaḥ pahātabba taṇham āgamma yam
translated: “Craving” is what leads to the round of rebirths. How does it lead to decrease? To show this, “craving for destruction” is said. The meaning is: craving that is a cause for destruction.🔽“Craving for destruction” is said because of the craving that is to be destroyed.

original: pahānaṃ pavattetabbaṃ, tena pavattetabbena pahānena apacayaṃ gacchatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pahānam pavattetabbam tena pavattetabbena pahānena apacayam gacchati iti vuttam hoti
translated: “Craving” is what leads to the round of rebirths. How does it lead to decrease? “Craving for destruction” is said. The meaning is: craving that is a cause for destruction. It is said that it leads to decrease by the decrease of what is to be destroyed by means of the destruction that is to be brought about.

original: “Kiṃ pana taṇhāyeva kusalākusalāti dubbidhā, udāhu aññopi kusalākusalāti dubbidho”ti
analyzed: kim pana taṇhāya iva kusala akusalā ati dubbidhāḥ udāhu aññaḥ pi kusala akusalā ati dubbidhaḥ ti
translated: “But is craving alone twofold as profitable and unprofitable, or are other states also twofold in this way?”

original: vattabbattā “mānopī”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Katamo māno kusalo, katamo māno akusalo”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: vattabba ttā mānaḥ api itiādi vuttam katamaḥ mānaḥ kusalaḥ katamaḥ mānaḥ akusalaḥ ti pucchitabba ttā
translated: “Conceit also” is said. “What kind of conceit is profitable, and what kind unprofitable?”

original: “yaṃ mānaṃ nissāya mānaṃ pajahati, ayaṃ māno kusalo. Yo pana māno dukkhaṃ nibbattayati,
analyzed: yam mānam nissāya mānam pajahati ayam mānaḥ kusalaḥ yaḥ pana mānaḥ dukkham nibbattayati
translated: “Conceit that, depending on conceit, abandons conceit is profitable. But conceit that generates suffering

original: ayaṃ māno akusalo”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha yaṃ mānaṃ…pe… kusaloti yaṃ mānaṃ nissāya upanissāya
analyzed: ayam māno akusalo ti vuttam tattha yam mānam pe kusalo ti yam mānam nissāya upanissāya
translated: is unprofitable.” Herein, “Conceit that, depending on conceit, abandons conceit is profitable” means that, depending on and relying on this kind of conceit, one abandons conceit.

original: pahānaṃ pavattitaṃ, tena pahānena santāne uppajjanārahaṃ mānaṃ pajahati, ayaṃ upanissayapaccayabhūto
analyzed: pahānam pavattitam tena pahānena santāne uppajjana araham mānam pajahati ayam upanissaya paccaya bhūtaḥ
translated: The abandoning is set up. By means of that abandoning he abandons the conceit that is fit to arise in his continuity. This is the condition by way of decisive support.

original: māno phalūpacārena kusalo. Yo pana…pe… akusaloti yo pana māno parahiṃsanādivasena🔽pavattamāno hutvā attano ca parassa ca dukkhaṃ nibbattayati, ayaṃ māno akusaloti
analyzed: māno phala upacārena kusalaḥ yaḥ akusalaḥ iti yaḥ pana māno para hiṃsana ādi vasena  pavattamānaḥ hutvā attanaḥ ca parassa ca dukkham nibbattayati ayam mānaḥ akusalaḥ ti
translated: Conceit is profitable by way of the fruit of the past. But that which … is unprofitable. But that conceit which, occurring by way of the harming of others, etc.,

original: vicayitvā veditabbo.
analyzed: vicayitvā veditabbaḥ
translated: produces suffering for oneself and for others, this conceit should be understood as unprofitable.

original: “Saṃsārāpacayagāminīsu tāsu taṇhāsu katamā apacayagāminī taṇhā kusalā”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: saṃsāra apacaya gāminīsu tāsu taṇhāsu katamā apacaya gāminī taṇhā kusalā ati pucchitabba ttā
translated: “In those craving that leads to the decrease of the round of rebirths, which craving that leads to the decrease of the round of rebirths is profitable?” Because it is necessary to ask this,

original: “kusalā”ti vuttāya taṇhāya sarūpaṃ dassetuṃ “tattha yaṃ nekkhammasita”ntiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Tatthāti tāsu saṃsārāpacayagāminīsu taṇhābhūtāsu kusalākusalāsu. Ayaṃ taṇhā kusalāti
analyzed: kusalā iti vuttāya taṇhāya sarūpam dassetum tattha yam nekkhamma sita ntiādi vuttaṃ  tattha ati tāsu saṃsāra apacaya gāminīsu taṇhā bhūtāsu kusala akusalāsu ayam taṇhā kusalā ati
translated: “profitable” is said. In order to show the individual essence of the craving that is said to be profitable, “Herein, that which is accompanied by renunciation” is said.🔽Herein means in those craving that leads to the decrease of the round of rebirths, in those that are craving that is profitable and unprofitable. This craving is profitable.🔽This is the connection. The noble persons, having realized the noble fruit-state, which is a peaceful sense-base,

original: sambandho. “Ariyā puggalā santaṃ āyatanaṃ yaṃ ariyaphaladhammaṃ sacchikatvā upasampajja
analyzed: sambandhaḥ ariyā puggalā santam āyatanam yam ariya phala dhammam sacchikatvā upasampajja
translated: and having entered upon it,

original: viharanti, taṃ āyatanaṃ ariyaphaladhammaṃ ahaṃ kudāssu sacchikatvā viharissa”nti
analyzed: viharanti tam āyatanam ariya phala dhammam aham kudāssu sacchikatvā viharissanti
translated: “When shall I live, having realized that state of the noble fruit of Stream-Entry?”

original: patthayantassa tassa kulaputtassa tasmiṃ ariyaphale pihā uppajjati, pihāpaccayā yaṃ🔽domanassaṃ uppajjati, idaṃ domanassaṃ “nekkhammasita”nti vuccati. Ayaṃ ariyaphale
analyzed: patthayantassa tassa kula puttassa tasmim ariya phale pihā uppajjati pihā paccayā yaṃ  domanassam uppajjati idam domanassam nekkhamma sitanti vuccati ayam ariya phale
translated: Then, in that noble fruit, there arises longing in that clansman who is aspiring, and because of longing

original: pihāsaṅkhātā taṇhā kusalā anavajjā anavajjaariyaphaladhammaṃ uddissa pavattattāti vicayitabbaṃ.
analyzed: pihā saṅkhātā taṇhā kusalā anavajjā anavajja ariya phala dhammam uddissa pavatta ttā ati
translated: there arises sorrow. This sorrow is called “longing for renunciation.” This is the wholesome, blameless craving that should be investigated as to whether it is the craving that occurs with reference to the blameless noble fruit.

original: “Kathaṃ pavattā”ti vattabbattā “rāgavirāgā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yā rāgavirāgā cetovimutti🔽pattabbā. Tadārammaṇā taṃ cetovimuttiṃ āgamma pavattā taṇhā kusalā anavajjā, yā avijjāvirāgā
analyzed: katham pavattā ati vattabbattā rāga virāga atiādi vuttam yā rāga virāgā cetaḥ vimutti  pattabbā tad ārammaṇā tam cetaḥ vimuttim āgamma pavattā taṇhā kusalā anavajjā yā avijjā virāgā
translated: “How does it occur?” should be asked. “With fading of lust” is said. The fading of lust is the freedom of mind🔽that is to be attained. The craving that occurs with that as its object, having come to that freedom of mind, is wholesome and blameless. The fading of ignorance is the freedom by understanding

original: paññāvimutti pattabbā, tadārammaṇā taṃ paññāvimuttiṃ āgamma pavattā taṇhā kusalā
analyzed: paññā vimutti pattabbā tad ārammaṇā tam paññā vimuttim āgamma pavattā taṇhā kusalā
translated: that is to be attained. The craving that occurs with that as its object, having come to that freedom by understanding, is wholesome and

original: anavajjāti vicayitabbā. Tāya paññāvimuttiyā vasena bhagavatā –
analyzed: anavajjā ati tāya paññā vimuttiyā vasena bhagavatā
translated: blameless. This should be investigated. By means of that freedom by understanding the Blessed One said:

original: “Tasmā rakkhitacittassa, sammāsaṅkappagocaro;
analyzed: tasmā rakkhita cittassa sammā saṅkappa gocaraḥ
translated: “Therefore, with guarded mind, whose range is right thinking,

original: Sammādiṭṭhipurekkhāro, ñatvāna udayabbayaṃ;
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi purekkhāraḥ ñatvānaḥ udaya bbayam
translated: With right view as his guide, who knows the rise and fall of things,

original: Thinamiddhābhibhū bhikkhu, sabbā duggatiyo jahe”ti. –
analyzed: thinamiddha abhibhū bhikkhu sabbāḥ duggatiyaḥ jaheti
translated: The bhikkhu who has overcome sloth and torpor abandons all unhappy destinations.”

original: Gāthāyaṃ “sabbā duggatiyo jahe”ti padaṃ vuttaṃ, “tassā paññāvimuttiyā yo pavicayo
analyzed: gāthāyam sabbāḥ duggatiyaḥ jaheti padam vuttam tassā paññā vimuttiyā yo pavicayo
translated: The words “abandons all unhappy destinations” are stated in the verse. The inquiry that should be made into that deliverance by wisdom

original: kātabbo, katamo so pavicayo”ti pucchitabbattā “tassā ko pavicayo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tassā
analyzed: kātabbaḥ katamo so pavicayo ti pucchitabba ttā tassā kaḥ pavicayaḥ tiādi vuttam tassā
translated: is this: “What is the inquiry into that?”

original: paññāvimuttiyā ko pavicayoti ce puccheyya “aṭṭha maggaṅgāni – sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo
analyzed: paññā vimuttiyāḥ ko pavicayaḥ ti ce puccheyya aṭṭha maggaṅgāni sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo
translated: If one should ask, “What is the inquiry into that deliverance by wisdom?” the answer is: “The eight path factors: right view, right thinking,

original: sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhī”ti pavicayo
analyzed: sammā vācā sammā kammantaḥ sammā ājīvo sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā sati sammā samādhi iti pavicayo
translated: right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.”

original: veditabbo. “So pavicayo kattha daṭṭhabbo”ti pucchitabbattā “so katthā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ so pavicayaḥ kattha daṭṭhabbaḥ iti pucchitabba ttā saḥ kattha atiādi vuttam
translated: If one should ask, “Where should that inquiry be seen?” the answer is:

original: So paññāvimuttiyā pavicayo kattha kasmiṃ dhamme daṭṭhabboti pucchati. Catutthe jhāne
analyzed: so paññā vimuttiyā pavicayo kattha kasmin dhamme daṭṭhabbo ti pucchati catutthe jhāne
translated: “That” inquiry into the deliverance by wisdom should be seen in what, in which state? He asks this. In the fourth jhāna,

original: pāramitāya ukkaṃsagatāya catutthajjhānabhāvanāya so pavicayo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: pāramitāya ukkaṃsa gatāya catuttha jjhāna bhāvanāya so pavicayaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The development of the fourth jhāna, which is the perfection of the jhāna, is the investigation.

original: “Catutthe jhāne pāramitāyā”ti vuttamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “catutthe hi jhāne”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Yo so catutthajjhānalābhī puggalo catutthe jhāne parisuddhaṃ pariyodātaṃ anaṅgaṇaṃ
analyzed: catutthe jhāne pāramitāya iti vuttam attham vivaritum catutthe hi jhāna itiādi vuttam  yaḥ saḥ catuttha jhāna lābhī puggalo catutthe jhāne parisuddham pariyodātam an aṅgaṇam
translated: The meaning of the words “in the fourth jhāna, the perfection” is explained in the passage beginning, “For in the fourth jhāna” .🔽The person who has attained the fourth jhāna develops the mind that possesses eight factors,

original: vigatūpakkilesaṃ mudu kammaniyaṃ ṭhitaṃ āneñjappattaṃ, iti aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ cittaṃ🔽bhāvayati, so catutthajjhānalābhī puggalo tattha catutthe jhāne aṭṭhavidhaṃ vijjācaraṇaṃ
analyzed: vigata upakkilesam mudu kammaniyam ṭhitam āneñja ppattam iti aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam cittam  bhāvayati so catuttha jhāna lābhī puggalo tattha catutthe jhāne aṭṭhavidham vijjā ācaraṇam
translated: which is purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilements, pliable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability.

original: adhigacchati. Katamaṃ aṭṭhavidhaṃ? Cha abhiññā, dve ca visese vā adhigacchatīti yojanā.
analyzed: adhigacchati katamam aṭṭhavidham cha abhiññāḥ dve ca visese vā adhigacchati iti yojanā
translated: The person who has attained the fourth jhāna acquires the eight kinds of knowledge and conduct in the fourth jhāna. What are the eight? He acquires the six kinds of direct knowledge and the two kinds of distinction.

original: Iddhividhādayo pañca, lokiyābhiññā ceva arahattamaggapaññā cāti cha abhiññā. Manomayiddhi
analyzed: iddhividha ādayaḥ pañca lokiya abhiññā ca iva arahatta magga paññā ca ati cha abhiññāḥ manaḥ maya iddhi
translated: The five beginning with the supernormal power, which are mundane direct knowledge, and the knowledge of the path of arahatship are the six kinds of direct knowledge. The supernormal power of the mind-made body

original: ceva vipassanāñāṇañcāti dve ca visesā honti.
analyzed: ca iva vipassanā ñāṇam ca ati dve ca visesāḥ honti
translated: and the knowledge of insight are the two kinds of distinction.

original: “Taṃ catutthajjhānacittaṃ kuto parisuddhaṃ…pe… kuto āneñjappatta”nti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: tam catuttha jjhāna cittam kutas parisuddham pe kutas āneñja ppattanti pucchitabba ttā
translated: “From what is that fourth-jhana consciousness purified? … From what is it attained to imperturbability?”

original: “taṃ cittaṃ yato parisuddha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Taṃ cittaṃ yato upekkhāsatipārisuddhibhāvato🔽parisuddhaṃ, tato upekkhāsatipārisuddhibhāvato pariyodātaṃ hoti. Sukhādīnaṃ paccayaghātena🔽yato vītarāgādianaṅgaṇabhāvato anaṅgaṇaṃ, tato vītarāgādianaṅgaṇabhāvato vigatūpakkilesaṃ.
analyzed: tam cittam yatas parisuddha ntiādi vuttam tam cittam yatas upekkhā sati pārisuddhi bhāvato  parisuddham tatas upekkhā sati pārisuddhi bhāvataḥ pariyodātam hoti sukha ādīnam paccaya ghātena  yatas vīta rāga ādi anaṅgaṇa bhāvataḥ anaṅgaṇam tatas vīta rāga ādi anaṅgaṇa bhāvataḥ vigata upakkilesam
translated: “From what is that consciousness purified?” etc. is said because he has to be asked this. From the time when it is purified by the surmounting of happiness,🔽it is bright. From the time when it is without pain, it is unblemished. From the time when it is well developed, it is malleable. From the time when it is purified, etc.,

original: Yato subhāvitabhāvato mudu, tato subhāvitabhāvato kammaniyaṃ. Yato parisuddhādīsu
analyzed: yatas su bhāvita bhāvataḥ tatas su bhāvita bhāvataḥ kammaniyam yatas parisuddha ādīsu
translated: it is steady. From the time when it is attained to imperturbability, it is wieldy.

original: ṭhitabhāvato ṭhitaṃ, tato parisuddhādīsu ṭhitabhāvato āneñjappattaṃ hotītipi yojanā
analyzed: ṭhita bhāvataḥ ṭhitam tatas parisuddha ādīsu ṭhita bhāvataḥ āneñja ppattam hoti iti pi yojanā
translated: This interpretation is appropriate because it is given in the texts in pairs.

original: yuttā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ yugaḷato āgatattā. Saddhāvīriyasatisamādhipaññāobhāsehi pariggahitabhāvato
analyzed: yuttā aṭṭhakathāyam yugaḷataḥ āgata ttā saddhā vīriya sati samādhi paññā obhāsehi pariggahita bhāvato
translated: It is attained to imperturbability because it is embraced by the light of faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding.

original: āneñjappattaṃ. Saddhāya hi pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ paṭipakkhe assaddhiye na iñjati na
analyzed: āneñja ppattam saddhāya hi pariggahitam cittam paṭipakkhe assaddhiye na iñjati na
translated: For the mind embraced by faith does not waver through lack of faith.

original: calati, vīriyena pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ paṭipakkhe kosajje na iñjati, satiyā pariggahitaṃ
analyzed: calati vīriyena pariggahitam cittam paṭipakkhe kosajje na iñjati satiyā pariggahitam
translated: When the mind is supported by energy, it does not waver in its opposite, idleness.🔽When it is supported by mindfulness, it does not waver in its opposite, negligence.

original: cittaṃ paṭipakkhe pamāde na iñjati, samādhinā pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ paṭipakkhe uddhacce
analyzed: cittam paṭipakkhe pamāde na iñjati samādhinā pariggahitam cittam paṭipakkhe uddhacce
translated: When it is supported by concentration, it does not waver in its opposite, agitation.

original: na iñjati, paññāya pariggahitaṃ cittaṃ paṭipakkhāya avijjāya na iñjati, obhāsagataṃ
analyzed: na iñjati paññāya pariggahitam cittam paṭipakkhāya avijjāya na iñjati obhāsa gatam
translated: When it is supported by understanding, it does not waver in its opposite, ignorance. When the mind has reached illumination, it does not waver in the darkness of defilement.

original: cittaṃ kilesandhakāre na iñjati. Iti imehi chahi dhammehi pariggahitaṃ catutthajjhānacittaṃ🔽āneñjappattaṃ hoti. Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatattā catutthajjhānacittaṃ channaṃ abhiññāñāṇānañca🔽manomayiddhivipassanāñāṇānañca adhigamūpāyo hoti, tasmā so paññāvimuttiparicayo catutthajjhāne
analyzed: cittam kilesa andhakāre na iñjati iti imehi chahi dhammehi pariggahitam catuttha jjhāna cittam  āneñja ppattam hoti evam aṭṭhaṅga samannāgata ttā catuttha jhāna cittam channam  manaḥ maya iddhi vipassanā ñāṇānaṃ ca adhigama upāyaḥ hoti tasmā so paññā vimutti paricayo catuttha jhāne
translated: So the mind in the fourth jhāna supported by these six things🔽is “reached imperturbability.” And because it possesses these eight factors the mind in the fourth jhāna is the proximate cause for the obtaining of the six kinds of direct knowledge and the supernormal powers and the knowledge of the kinds of psychic power, and so on,🔽So it should be regarded as the development of the liberation by understanding in the fourth jhāna.

original: daṭṭhabboyevāti saṅkhepattho. Vitthārato pana aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “tattha upekkhāsatipārisuddhibhāvenā”tiādinā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ yeva āti saṅkhepa atthaḥ vitthārato pana aṭṭhakathāyam tattha upekkhā sati pārisuddhi bhāvena āti ādinā
translated: This is the meaning in brief. But the meaning in detail is given in the commentary in the passage beginning, “Herein, by means of the fourth jhāna, which is purified in the sense of being cleansed of the defilements of the five hindrances, and bright in the sense of being radiant with the light of the jhāna factors, and so on” ,

original: vā “aparo nayo”tiādinā vā vuttoyevāti amhehi na vutto.
analyzed: vā aparaḥ vā aparaḥ naya uti ādinā vā amhehi na vuttaḥ
translated: and in the passage beginning, “Another method of interpretation” . So it is not given here for fear of making the book too long.

original: “Yesaṃ rāgādiaṅgaṇānaṃ abhāvena anaṅgaṇaṃ, yesaṃ abhijjhādiupakkilesānaṃ abhāvena🔽vigatūpakkilesaṃ, yāya cittassa ṭhitiyā abhāvena ṭhitaṃ, iñjanāya abhāvena āneñjappattaṃ,🔽te rāgādiaṅgaṇādayo katamāya pakkhā”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha aṅgaṇā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yesam rāga ādi aṅgaṇānam abhāvena anaṅgaṇam yesam abhijjhā ādi upakkilesānam abhāvena  vigata upakkilesam yāya cittassa ṭhitiyāḥ abhāvena ṭhitam iñjanāya abhāvena āneñja ppattam  te rāga ādi aṅgaṇa ādayo katamāya pakkhā ti pucchitabbattā tattha aṅgaṇa atiādi vuttaṃ
translated: “In what sense are they without blemish, without stain,🔽and attained to imperturbability? ”🔽“Therein, what are the blemishes? ” etc., is said in order to ask the question: “In what sense are they without blemish, etc., by reason of the absence of the blemishes of greed, etc.,🔽and by reason of the absence of the stains of covetousness, etc.,🔽and by reason of the absence of the state of being steadied, and by reason of the absence of agitation, and by reason of the attainment of imperturbability? ”

original: Tatthāti tesu rāgādiaṅgaṇādīsu aṅgaṇā ca rāgādiaṅgaṇā ca upakkilesā abhijjhādiupakkilesā🔽ca santi, tadubhayaṃ rāgādiaṅgaṇaabhijjhādiupakkilesadvayaṃ taṇhāpakkho rāgādiaṅgaṇānaṃ🔽taṇhāsabhāvattā, abhijjhādiupakkilesānañca taṇhāya anulomattā. Yā iñjanā phandanā🔽yā ca cittassa aṭṭhiti anavaṭṭhānaṃ atthi, ayaṃ iñjanā aṭṭhiti diṭṭhipakkho iñjanāya🔽ca aṭṭhitiyā ca micchābhinivesahetubhāvatoti pavicayo kātabbo.
analyzed: tattha ati tesu rāga ādi aṅgaṇa ādīsu aṅgaṇā ca rāga ādi aṅgaṇā ca upakkilesāḥ abhijjhā ādi upakkilesā 🔽ca santi tat ubhayam rāga ādi aṅgaṇa abhijjhā ādi upakkilesa dvayam taṇhā pakkhaḥ 🔽taṇhā sabhāva ttā taṇhāya anuloma ttā yā iñjanā phandanā 🔽yā ca cittassa aṭṭhiti anavaṭṭhānam atthi ayam iñjanā aṭṭhiti diṭṭhi pakkhaḥ iñjanāya 🔽ca aṭṭhitiyā ca micchā abhinivesa hetu bhāvato ti pavicayo kātabbo

original: “Kiṃ pana catutthajjhānacittaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatattāyeva channaṃ abhiññāñāṇānañca
analyzed: kim pana catuttha jhāna cittam aṭṭhaṅga samannāgata ttāya iva channam
translated: “But is it not because the fourth-jhāna consciousness possesses eight factors that it is a condition for the six kinds of direct-knowledge consciousness and for the four discriminations?

original: manomayiddhivipassanāñāṇānañca adhigamūpāyo hotī”ti pucchitabbattā “cattāri indriyānī”ti
analyzed: manaḥ maya iddhi vipassanā ñāṇānam ca adhigama upāyaḥ hoti iti pucchitabbattā cattāri indriyāni iti
translated: “But is it only because the fourth-jhana consciousness possesses eight factors that it is the means to the attainment of the six kinds of direct knowledge and the four discriminations? ”—in order to answer this question, he said “four faculties” .

original: vuttaṃ. “Tassa catutthajjhānalābhino, dukkhindriyaṃ domanassindriyaṃ sukhindriyaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tassa catuttha jjhāna lābhino dukkha indriyam domanassa indriyam sukha indriyam
translated: When he has attained the fourth jhana, the faculty of pain, the faculty of grief, the faculty of pleasure,

original: somanassindriyaṃ iti cattārindriyāni catutthajjhāne nirujjhanti, tassa catutthajjhānalābhino🔽upekkhindriyaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ bhavati, tasmāpi catutthajjhānacittaṃ vuttappakārānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: somanassindriyam iti cattāri indriyāni catuttha jhāne nirujjhanti tassa catuttha jhāna lābhinaḥ  upekkhindriyam avasiṭṭham bhavati tasmā api catuttha jhāna cittam vutta ppakārānam aṭṭhannam
translated: and the faculty of joy cease in him. When he has attained the fourth jhana,

original: ñāṇānaṃ adhigamūpāyo hoti, so ca adhigamūpāyabhāvo ciṇṇavasībhāvasseva bhaveyya,
analyzed: adhigama upāyaḥ hoti saḥ ca adhigama upāya bhāvaḥ ciṇṇavasībhāvassa iva bhaveyya
translated: the faculty of equanimity remains. That is why the fourth-jhana consciousness is the means to the attainment of the eight kinds of knowledge stated. And that means to attainment would be for one who has reached mastery in the fourth jhana.

original: kathaṃ catutthajjhānamattalābhino ciṇṇavasībhāvo siyā”ti vattabbattā so catutthajjhānalābhī
analyzed: katham catuttha jhāna matta lābhinaḥ siyā ti vattabbattā saḥ catuttha jhāna lābhī
translated: How can one who has merely attained the fourth jhana have reached mastery? ”—in order to answer this question, he said “He who has attained the fourth jhana” .

original: catutthajjhāneyeva aṭṭhatvā arūpasamāpattiyopi evaṃ katvā nibbatteti bhāveti, tasmā
analyzed: catuttha jhāne iya iva evam katvā nibbattā iti bhāveti tasmā
translated: He does not remain only in the fourth jhana but also produces and develops the immaterial states in the same way. Therefore

original: ciṇṇavasībhāvo hotīti dassetuṃ “so uparimaṃ samāpatti”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tassattho aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: ciṇṇavasībhāvaḥ hoti iti dassetum saḥ uparimam samāpatti ntiādi vuttam tassa atthaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: To show that he has attained mastery he is said to “direct his mind to the surmounting of the base consisting of boundless space” . The meaning of this is given in detail in the commentary,

original: vitthārato vutto, tasmā yojanamattaṃ karissāma.🔽So rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānalābhī yogāvacaro rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānasamāpattito uparimaṃ
analyzed: vitthārataḥ vuttaḥ tasmai yojana mattam karissāma  saḥ rūpāvacara catuttha jhāna lābhī yogāvacaraḥ rūpāvacara catuttha jhāna samāpattitaḥ uparimam
translated: so we shall give only the thread of it.🔽A meditator who has attained jhāna in the fine-material sphere directs his mind to the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space, which is more peaceful than the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere, in the way already described.🔽As he directs his mind to the attainment, which is more peaceful than the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere,

original: ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ santato santatarato manasi karoti. Yathāvuttaṃ uparimaṃ🔽samāpattiṃ santato manasi karoto tassa catutthajjhānalābhino yogāvacarassa catutthajjhāne
analyzed: ākāsa anañca āyatana samāpattim santataḥ santatarataḥ manasi karoti yathāvuttam uparimam  samāpattim santataḥ manasi karoto tassa catuttha jhāna lābhinaḥ yogāvacarassa catuttha jhāne
translated: the perception of the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere becomes evident to him as gross, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.🔽And the perception of resistance becomes evident to him as gross, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.🔽As he continues to exercise his mind in this way, the perception of the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere becomes evident to him as a thorn, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.🔽As he continues to exercise his mind in this way, the perception of the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere becomes evident to him as a burden, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.

original: saññā saññāpadhānā samāpatti oḷārikā viya hutvā saṇṭhahati, paṭighasaññā ca ukkaṇṭhā🔽anabhirati hutvā saṇṭhahati, so yathāvuttena vidhinā manasi karonto yogāvacaro sabbaso
analyzed: saññā saññā apadhānā samāpatti oḷārikā viya hutvā saṇṭhahati paṭigha saññā ca ukkaṇṭhā  an abhirati hutvā saṇṭhahati saḥ yathā vuttena vidhinā manasi karontaḥ yoga avacaraḥ sabbaso
translated: As he continues to exercise his mind in this way, the perception of the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere becomes evident to him as a tumour, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.🔽As he continues to exercise his mind in this way, the perception of the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere becomes evident to him as a calamity, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.🔽As he continues to exercise his mind in this way, the perception of the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere becomes evident to him as a disaster, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.🔽As he continues to exercise his mind in this way, the perception of the fourth jhāna in the fine-material sphere becomes evident to him as a terror, and the perception of the base consisting of boundless space becomes evident as peaceful.

original: niravasesato rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ
analyzed: niravasesataḥ rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam
translated: As he continues to exercise his mind in this way, the perception of the fourth jhāna in the

original: amanasikārā “ākāsaṃ ananta”nti manasi katvā pavattamānaṃ ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: a manasikārāḥ ākāsam manasi katvā pavattamānam ākāsa anañca āyatana samāpattim
translated: and by non-attention to that he resolves upon the base consisting of boundless space, and he enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless space.

original: sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati. Rūpasaññā rūpāvacarasaññā pañcavidhaabhiññābhinīhāro
analyzed: sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati rūpa saññā rūpāvacara saññā pañcavidha abhiññā abhinīhāro
translated: The perception of form, the perception of the fine-material sphere, the five kinds of direct-knowledge, and the kinds of conversion,

original: hoti. Nānattasaññā nānārammaṇesu vokāro akusalo pavattati. Evaṃ rūpāvacarajjhāne🔽ādīnavadassī hutvā tā rūpasaññānānattasaññāyo ārammaṇe samatikkamati, assa yogāvacarassa🔽paṭighasaññā ca abbhatthaṃ gacchati. Evaṃ iminā vuttanayena samatikkamena samāhitassa,
analyzed: hoti nānatta saññā nānā ārammaṇesu vokāro akusalo pavattati evam rūpāvacara jhāne  ādīnava dassī hutvā tāḥ rūpa saññā nānatta saññāyo ārammaṇe samatikkamati assa yogāvacarassa  paṭigha saññā ca abbhattham gacchati evam iminā vutta nayena samatikkamena samāhitassa
translated: are unprofitable in the sense that they are a diversity of perception in regard to different objects.🔽So when he has seen danger in the fine-material sphere jhāna in this way, he surmounts the perception of form, the perception of the fine-material sphere, and the perception of diversity.🔽The perception of resistance disappears from him.

original: santavuttinā arūpāvacarasamādhinā samāhitassa yogāvacarassa obhāso rūpāvacarajjhānobhāso
analyzed: santa vuttinā arūpāvacara samādhinā samāhitassa yogāvacarassa obhāsaḥ rūpāvacara jhāna ubhāsaḥ
translated: So when he has thus surmounted the perception of resistance and the perception of diversity, and has emerged from that jhāna,🔽the light and the vision disappear from him.

original: antaradhāyati. Rūpānaṃ kasiṇarūpānaṃ jhānacakkhunā dassanañca antaradhāyatīti yojanā.
analyzed: antaradhāyati rūpānam kasiṇa rūpānam jhāna cakkhunā dassanam ca antaradhāyati iti yojanā
translated: The meaning is that the light of the fine-material-sphere jhāna and the seeing of material forms with the divine eye disappear from him.

original: “Yena samādhinā samāhitassa, samāhitassa obhāso ca rūpānaṃ dassanañca antaradhāyati,
analyzed: yena samādhinā samāhitassa samāhitassa obhāsaḥ ca rūpānam dassanam ca antaradhāyati
translated: “When he has entered upon and is dwelling in that attainment, his bodily formation and his verbal formation have ceased, and his bodily and verbal conduct have been tranquilized.

original: so samādhi kittakehi aṅgehi samannāgato, kathaṃ paccavekkhitabbo”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: so samādhi kittakehi aṅgehi samannāgataḥ katham paccavekkhitabbaḥ ti pucchitabba ttā
translated: “How many factors should that concentration possess? How should it be reviewed?”

original: “so samādhī”tiādi vuttaṃ. So samādhīti yena rūpārūpāvacarasamādhinā samāhito, so🔽duvidhopi samādhi anabhijjhābyāpādavīriyārambhehi tīhi upakārakaṅgehi ca passaddhisatīhi🔽dvīhi parikkhāraṅgehi ca avikkhittena ekena sabhāvaṅgena ca chahi aṅgehi samannāgatoti
analyzed: saḥ samādhi itiādi vuttam saḥ samādhi iti yena rūpa arūpa avacara samādhinā samāhito saḥ  duvidhaḥ api samādhi anabhijjhā byāpāda vīriya ārambhehi tīhi upakāraka aṅgehi ca passaddhi satīhi  dvīhi parikkhāraṅgehi ca avikkhittena ekena sabhāvaṅgena ca chahi aṅgehi samannāgataḥ ti
translated: “That concentration” is stated in reply to the question. “That concentration” is the concentration of the fine-material and immaterial spheres by means of which one is concentrated.🔽That concentration is of two kinds. It should be reviewed, i.e., it should be thought over again and again, it should be considered, as possessing six factors: three factors that are helpful, namely, non-greed, non-ill-will, and the undertaking of energy; two factors that are requisites, namely, tranquillity and mindfulness; and one factor that is the nature of the concentration itself, namely, non-distraction.

original: paccavekkhitabbo punappunaṃ cintetabbo sallakkhetabbo. “Kathaṃ kattha paccavekkhitabbo”ti🔽pucchitabbattā “anabhijjhāsahagataṃ me mānasaṃ sabbaloke”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Tesu chasu
analyzed: paccavekkhitabbaḥ punappunam cintetabbaḥ sallakkhetabbaḥ katham kattha paccavekkhitabbaḥ ti  pucchitabba ttā anabhijjhā sahagatam me mānasam sabba loka iti ādi vuttam tesu chasu
translated: “How and where should it be reviewed?”🔽“My mind accompanied by non-greed” is stated in reply to the question. “Among those six factors, how much is serenity and how much is insight?”

original: aṅgesu kittako samatho, kittakā vipassanā”ti pucchitabbattā ettako samatho, ettakā
analyzed: aṅgesu kittakaḥ samathaḥ kittakā vipassanā ati ettakaḥ samathaḥ ettakā
translated: “This much is serenity, this much is insight” is stated in reply to the question.

original: vipassanāti vibhajituṃ “tattha yañcā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vipassanā iti vibhajitum tattha yat ca itiādi vuttam
translated: “Therein, that which is” is stated in order to analyze this.

original: 54. “Paññāvimuttī”ti vuttassa arahattaphalassa samādhissa samathavipassanāsaṅkhātā
analyzed: paññā vimutti iti vuttassa arahatta phalassa samādhissa samatha vipassanā saṅkhātā
translated: The concentration of the Arahant fruit called “liberation by wisdom” has been explained by the teacher under the heading of concentration as the way of preparation called serenity and insight.

original: pubbabhāgapaṭipadā samādhimukhena ācariyena vibhattā, “tāya paṭipadāya labhitabbo
analyzed: pubbabhāga paṭipadā samādhi mukhena ācariyena vibhattā tāya paṭipadāya labhitabbo
translated: The question arises, “How long does it take to reach the concentration of the Arahant fruit by that way of preparation?”

original: arahattaphalasamādhi kittakena veditabbo”ti pucchitabbattā “so samādhi pañcavidhena
analyzed: arahatta phala samādhi kittakena veditabbaḥ ti pucchitabba ttā so samādhi pañcavidhena
translated: So it is said, “That concentration should be known by five ways.”

original: veditabbo”ti vuttaṃ. Yo arahattaphalasamādhi samathavipassanāpaṭipadāya labhitabbo,
analyzed: veditabbaḥ iti vuttam yaḥ arahatta phala samādhi samatha vipassanā paṭipadāya labhitabbaḥ
translated: The concentration of the Arahant fruit that can be reached by the way of preparation of serenity and insight

original: so arahattaphalasamādhi pañcavidhena ñāṇadassanena veditabbo.
analyzed: so arahatta phala samādhi pañcavidhena ñāṇa dassanena veditabbo
translated: should be known by the five kinds of knowledge and vision.

original: “Kathaṃ pañcavidhañāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ bhavatī”ti vattabbattā “ayaṃ samādhī”tiādi
analyzed: katham pañcavidha ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitam bhavati iti vattabbattā ayam samādhi itiādi
translated: The question, “How is the fivefold knowledge and vision present?” is answered by “This concentration” and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ arahattaphalasamādhi appitappitakkhaṇe phalasamāpattisukhattā paccuppannasukho
analyzed: vuttam ayam arahatta phala samādhi appita ppita khaṇe phala samāpatti sukhattā paccuppanna sukhaḥ
translated: This concentration of the Arahant fruit is pleasant in the present moment because of the pleasure of fruition attainment,

original: hoti, iti paccavekkhantassa assa arahato paccattameva ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti paccavekkhantassa assa arahataḥ paccattam eva ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitam
translated: so when the Arahant reflects thus, his knowledge and vision is present to himself.

original: bhavati. Ayaṃ arahattaphalasamādhi āyatiṃ samāpajjitabbassa arahattaphalasamādhissa🔽upanissayapaccayattā āyatiṃ sukhavipāko hoti, iti paccavekkhantassa…pe… bhavati.🔽Ayaṃ arahattaphalasamādhi kilesaarīhi ārakattā ariyo, kāmāmisavaṭṭāmisalokāmisānaṃ
analyzed: bhavati ayam arahatta phala samādhi āyatim samāpajjitabbassa arahatta phala samādhissa  upanissaya paccaya ttā āyatim sukha vipākaḥ hoti iti bhavati  ayam arahatta phala samādhi ārakattā ariyaḥ kāma āmisa vaṭṭa āmisa loka āmisānam
translated: This concentration of the Arahant path is a condition for the future concentration of the Arahant path that is to be entered upon,🔽and so it is a condition for the future pleasant fruition of that path.

original: abhāvato nirāmiso ca hoti, iti paccavekkhantassa…pe… bhavati. Ayaṃ arahattaphalasamādhi
analyzed: abhāvataḥ nirāmisaḥ ca hoti iti bhavati ayam arahatta phala samādhi
translated: This concentration of the Arahant path is noble because it is far from defilements, and it is without lust because it is without the lust of sense desires, the lust of becoming, and the lust of ignorance.

original: akāpurisehi sammāsambuddhapaccekabuddhasāvakabuddhehi sevitabbattā akāpurisasevito🔽hoti, iti paccavekkhantassa…pe… bhavati. Ayaṃ arahattaphalasamādhi aṅgasantakilesadarathasantattā🔽santo ceva divasampi samāpajjantassa atittikaraṇato paṇīto ca paṭippassaddhakilesena
analyzed: a kāpurisehi sammāsambuddha paccekabuddha sāvakabuddhehi sevitabba ttā a kāpurisa sevitaḥ  hoti iti bhavati ayam arahatta phala samādhi  santaḥ ca iva divasam pi samāpajjantassa a tittikaraṇato paṇītaḥ ca paṭippassaddha kilesena
translated: This concentration of the Arahant path is to be cultivated by the noble persons, the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples, and so it is to be cultivated by the noble persons.

original: arahatā puggalena laddhattā paṭippassaddhiladdho ca arahattamaggasamādhisaṅkhātena
analyzed: arahatā puggalena paṭippassaddhi laddhaḥ ca arahatta magga samādhi saṅkhātena
translated: This concentration of the Arahant path is peaceful because it is free from the defilements that are its opposite, and it is sublime because it is beyond the range of the ordinary man, and it is to be obtained by the tranquillized person, that is, by the Arahant, because it is entered upon all day long without causing satiety.🔽This concentration of the Arahant path is called “obtained by tranquillization” because it is obtained by the Arahant, who is tranquillized by the tranquillization of defilements.

original: ekodibhāvena adhigatattā ekodibhāvādhigato ca sasaṅkhārena sapayogena adhigatattā,
analyzed: ekodi bhāvena adhigata ttā ekodi bhāva adhigataḥ ca sa saṅkhārena sa payogena adhigata ttā
translated: Because it is attained with unification, and because it is attained with applied thought and sustained thought,

original: nīvaraṇādipaccanīkadhamme niggayha anadhigatattā, aññe kilese vāretvā anadhigatattā,
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ādi paccanīka dhamme niggayha anadhigata ttā aññe kilese vāretvā anadhigata ttā
translated: because it is attained without defining away the states that are opponents to the jhāna such as the hindrances, etc., and without defining away other defilements,

original: arahattamaggaphalabhāveneva pavattattā nasasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato hoti, iti paccavekkhantassa
analyzed: arahatta magga phala bhāvena iva pavatta ttā nasa saṅkhāra niggayha vārita gataḥ hoti iti paccavekkhantassa
translated: because it occurs only as the path and fruition of Arahantship, it is not attained with applied thought and sustained thought, and without defining away .🔽So when he reviews the Arahant path and fruition in this way,

original: assa arahato paccattameva ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ bhavatīti pañcavidhena ñāṇadassanena
analyzed: assa arahataḥ paccattam eva ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitam bhavati iti pañcavidhena ñāṇa dassanena
translated: his knowledge and vision of the Arahant path and fruition becomes evident to him in five ways.

original: so arahattaphalasamādhi vicayitvā veditabboti.
analyzed: saḥ arahatta phala samādhi vicayitvā veditabbā uti
translated: The Arahant path and fruition should be understood as concentration by reviewing.

original: “Paccuppannasukhādīsu samādhīsu kittako samatho, kittakā vipassanā”ti pucchitabbattā
analyzed: paccuppanna sukha ādīsu samādhīsu kittakaḥ samathaḥ kittakā vipassanā ti pucchitabbattā
translated: “How much of the concentration that is pleasant here and now, etc., is serenity, and how much is insight?”

original: “tattha yo ca samādhi paccuppannasukho”tiādi vuttaṃ. Samatho, vipassanāti ca arahattaphalasamathavipassanāva
analyzed: tattha yaḥ ca samādhi paccuppanna sukha itiādi vuttam samathaḥ vipassanā ti ca arahatta phala samatha vipassanā va
translated: “Herein, the concentration that is pleasant here and now” is said in order to answer that question. And it is the serenity and insight of the Arahant path and fruition

original: adhippetā, na pubbabhāgasamathavipassanāti. Arahattaphalasamādhi pañcavidhena veditabboti
analyzed: adhippetā na pubba bhāga samatha vipassanā ati arahatta phala samādhi pañcavidhena veditabbaḥ ti
translated: that are intended here, not that of the earlier stage. The Arahant path and fruition should be understood as concentration by reviewing in five ways.

original: ācariyena vutto, “tassa arahattaphalasamādhissa pubbabhāgapaṭipadāyaṃ vutto samādhi
analyzed: ācariyena vutto tassa arahatta phala samādhissa pubba bhāga paṭipadā ayam vutto samādhi
translated: The teacher said: “The concentration spoken of in the preliminary work for the attainment of the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere is the concentration that is spoken of as the preliminary work for the attainment of the fruit of arahantship.

original: kittakena veditabbo”ti pucchitabbattā “so samādhi pañcavidhena veditabbo”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kittakena veditabbaḥ iti pucchitabba ttā so samādhi pañcavidhena veditabbaḥ iti vuttam
translated: How is it to be known?” “That concentration is to be known in five ways.”

original: Yo rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānasamādhi pubbabhāgapaṭipadāyaṃ vutto, so rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānasamādhi
analyzed: yaḥ rūpāvacara catuttha jhāna samādhi pubbabhāga paṭipadā ayam vuttaḥ saḥ rūpāvacara catuttha jhāna samādhi
translated: The concentration of the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere spoken of in the preliminary work is the concentration of the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere.

original: pañcavidhena pakārena veditabbo. “Katamenā”ti pucchitabbattā “pītipharaṇatā”tiādi
analyzed: pañcavidhena pakārena veditabbaḥ katamena ati pucchitabba ttā pīti pharaṇa tā atiādi
translated: It is to be known in five ways. “In what five ways?” “By the pervasion of happiness, and so on.”🔽In the first and second jhānas understanding is the pervasion of happiness.

original: vuttaṃ. Paṭhamadutiyajjhānesu paññā pītipharaṇatā hoti. Paṭhamadutiyatatiyajjhānesu
analyzed: vuttam paṭhama dutiya jhānesu paññā pīti pharaṇa tā hoti paṭhama dutiya tatiya jhānesu
translated: In the first, second and third jhānas🔽understanding is the pervasion of pleasure. In the fourth jhāna understanding is the pervasion of cognizance.

original: paññā sukhapharaṇatā hoti. Catutthajjhāne cetopariyapaññā cetopharaṇatā hoti. Dibbacakkhupaññā
analyzed: paññā sukha pharaṇa tā hoti catuttha jhāne cetaḥ pariya paññā cetaḥ pharaṇa tā hoti dibba cakkhu paññā
translated: In the divine eye understanding is the pervasion of light.

original: ālokapharaṇatā hoti. Jhānaṃ paccavekkhitvā pavattamānapaññā paccavekkhaṇānimittaṃ
analyzed: āloka pharaṇa tā hoti jhānam paccavekkhitvā pavattamāna paññā paccavekkhaṇā nimittam
translated: In the understanding that occurs when reviewing after emerging from jhāna the sign of reviewing is present.🔽So it is to be known by investigating with the fivefold investigation of understanding.

original: hoti. Iti pañcavidhena paññāpakārena vicayitvā veditabboti. “Tesu pañcavidhesu pakāresu
analyzed: hoti iti pañcavidhena paññā pakārena vicayitvā veditabbaḥ ti tesu pañcavidhesu pakāresu
translated: “In the fivefold investigation of understanding

original: kittako samatho, kittakā vipassanā”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha yo ca pītipharaṇo”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kittakaḥ samathaḥ kittakā vipassanā ti pucchitabbattā tattha yaḥ ca pīti pharaṇaḥ tiādi vuttam
translated: “Therein, the pervasion of rapture” is said in order to answer that.

original: 55. Sampayogavasena samādhi ācariyena vibhatto, amhehi ca ñāto, “kathaṃ ārammaṇavasena🔽vibhatto”ti pucchitabbattā “dasa kasiṇāyatanānī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Imehi dasahi ārammaṇehi
analyzed: sampayoga vasena samādhi ācariyena vibhattaḥ amhehi ca ñāto katham ārammaṇa vasena  vibhattaḥ ti pucchitabbattā dasa kasiṇāyatanāni itiādi vuttam imehi dasahi ārammaṇehi
translated: Concentration has been analyzed by the teacher according to its concomitants, and we have understood it thus. “How is it analyzed according to its object?”🔽“The ten kasina bases” is said in order to answer that. Concentration should be understood as analyzed by the kasiṇas, which are the ten objects.

original: kasiṇehipi samādhi vicinitvā veditabboti. “Tesu dasasu kittako samatho, kittakā vipassanā”ti🔽pucchitabbattā “tattha yañcā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Kasiṇanti ca kasiṇamaṇḍalampi parikammampi
analyzed: kasiṇehi pi samādhi vicinitvā veditabbo ti tesu dasasu kittako samathaḥ kittakā vipassanā ati  pucchitabba ttā tattha yat ca atiādi vuttam kasiṇam ti ca kasiṇa maṇḍalam pi parikammam pi
translated: “How much is serenity, how much is insight?” is said in order to answer that.

original: paṭibhāganimittampi tasmiṃ paṭibhāganimitte uppannajjhānampi vuccati, idha pana sasampayuttajjhānameva adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimittam pi tasmim paṭibhāga nimitte uppanna jjhānam pi vuccati idha pana sa sampayutta jhānam eva adhippetam
translated: “Therein, the kasiṇa” is said. And the kasiṇa disk, the preliminary work, the counterpart sign, and the jhāna arisen in the counterpart sign are called “kasiṇa.” But here only the jhāna together with its associated states is intended.

original: “Kiṃ pana vuttappakāro samādhiyeva samathavipassanāya yojetabbo, udāhu aññopi yojetabbo”ti
analyzed: kim pana vutta ppakāraḥ samādhiyā iva samatha vipassanāya yojetabbaḥ udāhu aññaḥ api yojetabbaḥ ti
translated: “But is concentration of the kind described to be yoked only to serenity and insight, or is it to be yoked to others as well?”

original: vattabbattā satipaṭṭhānādipubbabhāgapaṭipadābhedena anekabhedabhinno niravaseso ariyamaggopi
analyzed: vattabba ttā sati paṭṭhāna ādi pubbabhāga paṭipadā bhedena aneka bheda bhinnaḥ niravasesaḥ ariya maggaḥ api
translated: The Noble Path, which is of many kinds, being classified according to the different kinds of foundations of mindfulness, etc., and the different kinds of progress in the earlier stage,

original: vicayitvā yojetabboti dassetuṃ “evaṃ sabbo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha evanti mayā vuttanayena
analyzed: vicayitvā yojetabbā iti dassetum evam sabba uti ādi vuttam tattha evam ti mayā vutta nayena
translated: should be brought into relation by discerning it in the way stated. To show this, it is said: “Thus all the Noble Path should be brought into relation.” Herein, thus = in the way stated by me.🔽In the way stated by me, in the way stated by the method, all the Noble Path should be brought into relation,

original: vuttanayānusārena sabbo niravaseso satipaṭṭhānādipubbabhāgapaṭipadābhedena anekabhedabhinno
analyzed: vutta naya anusārena sabbaḥ niravasesaḥ sati paṭṭhāna ādi pubbabhāga paṭipadā bhedena aneka bheda bhinno
translated: without exception, being of many kinds, being classified according to the different kinds of foundations of mindfulness, etc., and the different kinds of progress in the earlier stage.

original: ariyo maggo yojetabbo. Kathaṃ? Yena yena anabhijjhādiākārena paccuppannasukhatādiākārena
analyzed: ariyaḥ maggaḥ yojetabbaḥ katham yena yena anabhijjhā ādi ākārena paccuppanna sukha tā ādi ākārena
translated: How? By whatever kind of non-greed, etc., and by whatever kind of present happiness, etc.,

original: samādhi mayā vutto, tena tena anabhijjhādiākārena paccuppannasukhatādiākārena yo🔽yo ariyamaggo samathena yojetuṃ sambhavati, so so ariyamaggo samathena vicayitvā🔽yojayitabbo. Yo yo ariyamaggo vipassanāya yojetuṃ sambhavati, so so ariyamaggo vipassanāya
analyzed: samādhi mayā vuttaḥ tena tena anabhijjhā ādi ākārena paccuppanna sukha tā ādi ākārena yaḥ  yaḥ ariya maggaḥ samathena yojetum sambhavati saḥ saḥ ariya maggaḥ samathena  yojayitabbaḥ yaḥ yaḥ ariya maggaḥ vipassanāya yojetum sambhavati saḥ saḥ ariya maggaḥ vipassanāya
translated: concentration has been stated by me, by that kind of non-greed, etc., and by that kind of present happiness, etc.,🔽whatever Noble Path is possible to bring into relation by serenity, that Noble Path should be brought into relation by serenity after discerning it.

original: yojayitvā yojayitabboti attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: yojayitvā yojayitabbaḥ iti atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: Whatever Noble Path is possible to bring into relation by insight, that Noble Path should be brought into relation by insight after discerning it. This is the meaning to be understood.

original: “Yehi samathādhiṭṭhānehi vipassanādhammehi yojayitabbo, te samathādhiṭṭhānā vipassanādhammā
analyzed: yehi samatha adhiṭṭhānehi vipassanā dhammehi yojayitabbo te samatha adhiṭṭhānāḥ vipassanā dhammāḥ
translated: “By what means of concentration and what states of insight is he to be brought to unification?🔽By what states are they comprised?”

original: katamehi dhammehi saṅgahitā”ti pucchitabbattā “te tīhi dhammehi saṅgahitā aniccatāya🔽dukkhatāya anattatāyā”ti vuttaṃ, te samathādhiṭṭhānā vipassanādhammā “aniccatāya
analyzed: katamehi dhammehi saṅgahitā ati pucchitabba ttā te tīhi dhammehi saṅgahitāḥ anicca tāya  dukkha tāya anatta tāya iti vuttam te samatha adhiṭṭhānāḥ vipassanā dhammāḥ anicca tāya
translated: The answer is: “They are comprised by three states: impermanence,🔽suffering, and not-self.”🔽The means of concentration and the states of insight are comprised by the three kinds of contemplation, namely,

original: paññāya dukkhatāya paññāya anattatāya paññāyā”ti tīhi anupassanādhammehi saṅgahitā
analyzed: paññāya dukkha tāya paññāya anatta tāya paññāya ati tīhi anupassanā dhammehi saṅgahitā
translated: contemplation of impermanence, contemplation of suffering, and contemplation of not-self.

original: gaṇhitāti attho. Aniccatādinā sahacaraṇato anupassanāpaññāpi “aniccatā dukkhatā anattatā”ti vuccati.
analyzed: gaṇhitā ti atthaḥ anicca tā ādinā sahacaraṇataḥ anupassanā paññā api anicca tā dukkha tā anatta tā ti vuccati
translated: The meaning is that they are grasped by them. And the insight that accompanies impermanence, etc., is also called “impermanence,” “suffering,” and “not-self.”

original: “Yo yogī puggalo samathādhiṭṭhānaṃ vipassanaṃ bhāvayamāno hoti, so yogī puggalo kiṃ bhāvayatī”ti pucchitabbattā “so samathavipassanaṃ bhāvayamāno”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ yogī puggalo samatha adhiṭṭhānam vipassanam bhāvayamāno hoti saḥ yogī puggalo kim bhāvayati iti pucchitabba ttā so samatha vipassanam bhāvayamānaḥ tiādi vuttam
translated: “What does the meditator who is developing insight based on concentration develop?”

original: Samathavipassanādīni bhāvayamāno puggalo rāgacarito dosacarito mohacaritoti tividho,
analyzed: samatha vipassanā ādīni bhāvayamānaḥ puggalo rāga caritaḥ dosa caritaḥ moha caritaḥ iti tividhaḥ
translated: The meditator who is developing serenity and insight is of three kinds: one of lust temperament, one of hate temperament, and one of delusion temperament.

original: “tattha katamo puggalo katamena katamena vimokkhamukhena niyyāti, katamāyaṃ katamāyaṃ🔽sikkhanto, katamaṃ katamaṃ pajahanto, katamaṃ katamaṃ anupagacchanto, katamaṃ katamaṃ🔽parijānanto, katamaṃ katamaṃ pavāhento, katamaṃ katamaṃ niddhunanto, katamaṃ katamaṃ
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ puggalo katamena katamena vimokkha mukhena niyyāti katamā ayam katamā ayam  sikkhantaḥ katamam katamam pajahantaḥ katamam katamam anupagacchantaḥ katamam katamam  parijānantaḥ katamam katamam pavāhentaḥ katamam katamam niddhunantaḥ katamam katamam
translated: “Herein, by what kind of outlet does a person go forth by what kind of …🔽training, what kind of … abandoning, what kind of … not taking up, what kind of …🔽understanding, what kind of … purifying, what kind of … shaking off, what kind of …🔽

original: vamento, katamaṃ katamaṃ nibbāpento, katamaṃ katamaṃ uppāṭento, katamaṃ katamaṃ vijaṭento🔽niyyātī”ti pucchitabbattā “rāgacarito puggalo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “idāni🔽yesaṃ puggalānaṃ yattha sikkhantānaṃ visesato niyyānamukhāni, yesañca kilesānaṃ paṭipakkhabhūtāni
analyzed: vamento katamam katamam nibbāpento katamam katamam uppāṭento katamam katamam vijaṭento  niyyāti iti pucchitabbattā rāga carito puggalo tiādi vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam pana idāni  yesam puggalānam yattha sikkhantānam visesataḥ niyyāna mukhāni yesam ca kilesānam paṭipakkha bhūtāni
translated: “Herein, what kind of person goes forth by what kind of outlet from what kind of defilement, what kind of training does he train in, what kind of abandoning does he practise, what kind of non-comprehending does he not comprehend, what kind of comprehending does he comprehend, what kind of surmounting does he surmount, what kind of casting out does he cast out, what kind of entering does he enter, what kind of surmounting of perception does he surmount, what kind of disentanglement does he disentangle, going forth?”—

original: tīṇi vimokkhamukhāni, tehi saddhiṃ tāni dassetuṃ ‘rāgacarito’tiādi vutta”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tīṇi vimokkha mukhāni tehi saddhim tāni dassetum rāga caritā tiādi vuttanti vuttam
translated: It is because of the need to ask this question that the passage beginning “One of greedy temperament” is stated. But in the commentary it is said: “Now, in order to show the three outlets that are pre-eminent for those of the various kinds of persons who train in them, and the three doors to deliverance that are opposed to the defilements of the various kinds of persons, the passage beginning ‘One of greedy temperament’ is stated.”

original: Tassatthopi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttoyeva.
analyzed: tad atthaḥ api aṭṭhakathāyam vuttaḥ yeva
translated: And the meaning of this is also given in the commentary.

original: “Kasmā tīṇi vimokkhamukhāni bhāvayanto tayo khandhe bhāvayatī”ti vattabbattā “tattha🔽suññatavimokkhamukha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tatthāti tesu tīsu vimokkhamukhesu. Suññatavimokkhamukhaṃ
analyzed: kasmā tīṇi vimokkha mukhāni bhāvayantaḥ tayo khandhe bhāvayati iti vattabbattā tattha  suññata vimokkha mukha ntiādi vuttam tattha ati tesu tīsu vimokkha mukhesu suññata vimokkha mukham
translated: “Why, when he develops the three doors to liberation, does he develop three aggregates?” In order to answer this question, the following is said:🔽“Herein, the door to liberation by nothingness is the aggregate of wisdom” .

original: paññākkhandho anattānupassanāya paññāpadhānattā. Animittavimokkhamukhaṃ samādhikkhandho
analyzed: paññā kkhandhaḥ anatta anupassanāya paññā apadhāna ttā animitta vimokkha mukham samādhi kkhandho
translated: The door to liberation by the signless is the aggregate of concentration,🔽because concentration is the principal factor in contemplation of impermanence.🔽The door to liberation by emptiness is the aggregate of virtue,

original: aniccānupassanāya samādhipadhānattā. Appaṇihitavimokkhamukhaṃ sīlakkhandho dukkhānupassanāya
analyzed: anicca anupassanāya samādhi padhāna ttā appaṇihita vimokkha mukham sīla kkhandho dukkha anupassanāya
translated: because virtue is the principal factor in contemplation of suffering.

original: sīlapadhānattā. Iti tīhi vimokkhamukhehi tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ saṅgahitattā tīṇi vimokkhamukhāni
analyzed: sīla padhāna ttā iti tīhi vimokkha mukhehi tiṇṇam khandhānam saṅgahita ttā tīṇi vimokkha mukhāni
translated: Thus, since the three aggregates are included in the three doors to liberation,

original: bhāvayanto so yogī puggalo tayo khandhe bhāvayatiyevāti paññāpadhānādibhāvo aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: bhāvayanto so yogī puggalo tayo khandhe paññā apadhāna ādi bhāvaḥ aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: the meditator who develops the three doors to liberation develops the three aggregates. The meaning of “principal factor in wisdom,” etc., is stated in the commentary.

original: vutto. Tayo khandhe bhāvayanto ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvayati. “Kasmā bhāvayatī”ti
analyzed: vuttaḥ tayo khandhe bhāvayantaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam bhāvayati kasmai bhāvayati iti
translated: “One who develops the three aggregates develops the noble eightfold path.” “Why does he develop it?”

original: vattabbattā kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “tattha yā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vattabba ttā kāraṇam dassetum tattha yā tiādi vuttam
translated: In order to show the reason, the following is said:

original: Tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ ariyaaṭṭhaṅgikamaggabhāvo vibhatto, amhehi ca jānito, “kathaṃ samathavipassanābhāvo🔽jānitabbo”ti vattabbattā tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ samathavipassanābhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “tattha🔽sīlakkhandho cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. “Yo yogī puggalo samathavipassanaṃ bhāveti, tassa yogino🔽puggalassa bhavaṅgāni katamaṃ bhāvanaṃ gacchantī”ti pucchitabbattā “yo samathavipassanaṃ🔽bhāveti, tassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Kāyo ca cittañca dve bhavaṅgāni upapattibhavassa aṅgāni
analyzed: tiṇṇam khandhānam ariya aṭṭhaṅgika magga bhāvaḥ vibhattaḥ amhehi ca jānitaḥ katham samatha vipassanā bhāvaḥ  jānitabbaḥ iti vattabba ttā tiṇṇam khandhānam samatha vipassanā bhāvam dassetum tattha  sīlakkhandho ca atiādi vuttam yaḥ yogī puggalo samatha vipassanam bhāveti tassa yogino  puggalassa bhavaṅgāni katamam bhāvanam gacchanti iti pucchitabba ttā yaḥ samatha vipassanaṃ  bhāveti tassa atiādi vuttam kāyo ca cittam ca dve bhavaṅgāni upapatti bhavassa aṅgāni
translated: The three aggregates’ state of being the Noble Eightfold Path has been analysed and is known to us. Now it is asked, “How should the state of being serenity and insight be known?”🔽In order to show the state of being serenity and insight of the three aggregates, “Herein, the virtue aggregate” is said. “The yogi who develops serenity and insight, which of his states of consciousness go to development?”🔽Since it is asked, “The yogi who develops serenity and insight, which of his states of consciousness go to development?” “The yogi who develops serenity and insight” is said. The two states of consciousness, body and mind, are the factors of the rebirth-process.

original: bhāvanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ gacchanti. Sīlañca samādhi ca dve padāni dve pādā bhavanirodhagāminī🔽paṭipadā bhāvanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: bhāvanam vaḍḍhanam gacchanti sīlam ca samādhi ca dve padāni dve pādā bhava nirodha gāminī  paṭipadā bhāvanam vaḍḍhanam gacchanti
translated: The state of the three aggregates as the Noble Eightfold Path has been explained and is known to us. Now it should be said how the state of serenity and insight is to be known. In order to show the state of serenity and insight of the three aggregates, “Herein, the virtue aggregate” and so on is said. “The yogi who develops serenity and insight, whose life-continua go to which development?” In order to ask this, “The yogi who develops serenity and insight” and so on is said. The two life-continua of body and mind go to the development of the rebirth-existence. The two factors of virtue and concentration go to the development of the way leading to the cessation of existence.

original: “Kathaṃ gacchantī”ti vattabbattā “so hoti bhikkhū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Bhāvitakāyoti bhāvito
analyzed: katham gacchanti iti vattabbattā so hoti bhikkhu itiādi vuttam bhāvita kāyaḥ ti bhāvitaḥ
translated: “How do they go?” In order to say this, “The bhikkhu” and so on is said. The developed ones are the developed.

original: kāyo kāyaābhisamācāriko, kāyasaṃvaro vā yena bhikkhunāti bhāvitakāyo. Sesesupi esa
analyzed: kāyaḥ kāya ābhisamācāriko kāya saṃvaro vā yena bhikkhunā ati bhāvita kāyaḥ sesesu pi esa
translated: “The body” is bodily conduct or bodily restraint. “One who has developed the body” is a bhikkhu. The same method applies in the other cases.

original: nayo. Kāye kāyaābhisamācārike, kāyasaṃvare vā bhāviyamāne sati sammākammanto, sammāvāyāmo🔽ca dve dhammā bhāvanaṃ gacchanti kāyasamācārasīlattā. Sīle vācāsaṃvaraājīvasaṃvaravasena
analyzed: kāye kāya ābhisamācārike kāya saṃvare vā bhāviyamāne sati sammā kammantaḥ sammā vāyāmaḥ  ca dve dhammā bhāvanam gacchanti kāya samācāra sīlattā sīle vācā saṃvara ājīva saṃvara vasena
translated: When the body is being developed in the sense of bodily conduct or bodily restraint, right action and right effort are being developed.🔽These two things are being developed because of the virtue consisting in bodily conduct and restraint.🔽When virtue is being developed in the sense of restraint of speech, restraint of bodily action, and the right livelihood, right speech and right livelihood are being developed.

original: pavatte sīle bhāviyamāne sati sammāvācā ca sammāājīvo ca dve dhammā bhāvanaṃ gacchanti
analyzed: pavatte sīle bhāviyamāne sati sammā vācā ca sammā ājīvo ca dve dhammā bhāvanam gacchanti
translated: These two things are being developed because of the virtue consisting in restraint of speech, etc.

original: vācādisaṃvarasīlattā. Citte cittasaṃvaravasena pavatte citte bhāviyamāne sati sammāsati
analyzed: vācā ādi saṃvara sīla ttā citte citta saṃvara vasena pavatte citte bhāviyamāne sati sammā asati
translated: When the mind is being developed in the sense of restraint of mind, right mindfulness and right concentration are being developed.🔽These two things are being developed because of the virtue consisting in restraint of mind.

original: ca sammāsamādhi ca dve dhammā bhāvanaṃ gacchanti cittasaṃvarasīlattā. Paññāya bhāviyamānāya
analyzed: ca sammāsamādhi ca dve dhammā bhāvanam gacchanti citta saṃvara sīla ttā paññāya bhāviyamānāya
translated: When understanding is being developed, right view and right thought are being developed.

original: sati sammādiṭṭhi ca sammāsaṅkappo ca dve dhammā bhāvanaṃ gacchanti samānattā, upakārakattā
analyzed: sati sammādiṭṭhi ca sammāsaṅkappo ca dve dhammā bhāvanam gacchanti samāna ttā upakāraka ttā
translated: These two things are being developed because of their sameness and because of their helpfulness.

original: ca. Sammāsaṅkappena hi punappunaṃ saṅkappantassa paññā vaḍḍhatīti.
analyzed: ca sammāsaṅkappena hi punappunam saṅkappantassa paññā vaḍḍhati iti
translated: For understanding increases when one thinks again and again by means of right thought.

original: “Sammākammanto ca sammāvāyāmo ca dve dhammā kāyavaseneva vibhattā vicetabbā kiṃ,🔽udāhu cittavasena vibhattā vicetabbā ki”nti pucchitabbattā “tattha yo ca sammākammanto”tiādi
analyzed: sammākammanto ca sammāvāyāmo ca dve dhammā kāya vasena iva vibhattā vicetabbā kiṃ  udāhu citta vasena vibhattā vicetabbā kinti pucchitabba ttā tattha yaḥ ca sammākammanto tiādi
translated: “Right action and right effort are two things that should be analyzed as to whether they are to be classed as body or as mind.

original: vuttaṃ. Kāyasucaritacetanābhūto yo ca sammākammanto, taṃsahito yo ca sammāvāyāmo
analyzed: vuttam kāya su carita cetanā bhūto yaḥ ca sammā kammanto tad sahitaḥ yaḥ ca sammā vāyāmo
translated: “Herein, right action that is a volition of bodily good conduct, and right effort associated with that,

original: siyā kāyiko, viratibhūto yo ca sammākammanto, taṃsahito yo ca sammāvāyāmo siyā cetasiko,
analyzed: siyā kāyikaḥ virati bhūto yaḥ ca sammā kammanto tad sahitaḥ yaḥ ca sammā vāyāmo siyā cetasiko
translated: may be bodily. Right action that is abstinence, and right effort associated with that, may be mental.

original: tattha tesu kāyikacetasikabhūtesu sammākammantasammāvāyāmesu yo sammākammantasammāvāyāmo
analyzed: tattha tesu kāyika cetasika bhūtesu sammā kammanta sammāvāyāmesu yaḥ sammā kammanta sammāvāyāmo
translated: Herein, as regards these two, right action and right effort, which are classed as bodily and mental,

original: kāyasaṅgaho, so sammākammantasammāvāyāmo kāye kāyaābhisamācārike, kāyasaṃvare vā🔽bhāvite sati bhāvanaṃ gacchati. Yo sammākammantasammāvāyāmo cittasaṅgaho, so sammākammantasammāvāyāmo
analyzed: kāya saṅgaho so sammā kammanta sammā vāyāmo kāye kāya ābhisamācārike kāya saṃvare vā  bhāvite sati bhāvanam gacchati yaḥ sammā kammanta sammāvāyāmo citta saṅgaho so sammā kammanta sammāvāyāmo
translated: that right action and right effort which are classed as bodily are developed when the development of the body, that is, of bodily good conduct, or of the restraint of the body,

original: citte cittasaṃvare bhāvite sati bhāvanaṃ gacchatīti yojanā.
analyzed: citte citta saṃvare bhāvite sati bhāvanam gacchati iti yojanā
translated: is developed. That right action and right effort which are classed as mental are developed when the development of the mind, that is, of mental good conduct, or of the restraint of the mind,🔽is developed.” This is how the exposition should be known here as to development.

original: “Samathavipassanaṃ bhāvayanto so yogī puggalo kittakaṃ adhigamaṃ gacchatī”ti vicayitabbattā
analyzed: samatha vipassanam bhāvayantaḥ saḥ yogī puggalo kittakam adhigamam gacchati iti
translated: “How far does the yogi go in his attainment when he develops serenity and insight?”🔽“When he develops serenity and insight” is said in order to show this.🔽“And he is a quick worker” is said in order to show the fivefold attainment of the noble path.

original: “so samathavipassanaṃ bhāvayanto”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pañcavidhaṃ ariyamaggādhigamaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: so samatha vipassanam bhāvayantaḥ tiādi vuttam pañcavidham ariya magga adhigamam dassetuṃ
translated: Its meaning is analysed in the commentary.

original: “khippādhigamo cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tassattho aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vibhatto. “Kena katamo adhigamo
analyzed: khippa adhigamo ca atiādi vuttam tassa atthaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam vibhatto kena katamaḥ adhigamo
translated: “By what means and what kind of attainment does he go?”

original: hotī”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha samathenā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti pucchitabbattā tattha samathena atiādi vuttam
translated: “Therein, by serenity” is said in order to show this.

original: 56. “Arakkhitena cittenā”tiādisuttattho veneyyānaṃ arahattaphalavimuttimukhena ācariyena🔽vicayito vibhatto, amhehi ca ñāto, “desakassa dasabalasamannāgatassa dasa balāni🔽kathaṃ vicayitabbānī”ti pucchitabbattā “tattha yo desayati, so dasabalasamannāgato”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana –
